Given that this is a computationally known iodine-rich oxyhalide with just one oxygen per formula unit, how much of the apparent bond valence failure is an artifact of applying oxide-calibrated BVS parameters to a structure where I- dominates the anion sublattice?

Pr3OsO8 is the only material in this batch with a perfect space group match (SG 63, Cmcm, matching 100% of experimental entries), charge neutrality, zero Pauling violations across 16 bonds, and zero Shannon radii violations -- yet it is classified as novel. Its Pr sites show BVS of 2.1-2.7 against expected +3, with a systematic ~30% underbonding on the two equivalent sites. The isostructural family member Nd3OsO8 (same SG 63, same batch) shows nearly identical Nd BVS deviations (2.096 vs 2.106). Hypothesis: the Ln3OsO8 structure type is a genuinely synthesizable family awaiting experimental confirmation, with the lanthanide underbonding reflecting a real structural feature of large rare-earth sites rather than a prediction error.

Sr13Si14O has a massive +10.0 charge neutrality residual -- the largest positive residual in this batch -- with 100% Pauling violation (but only 1 bond checked) and Sr BVS of 0.657 v.u. vs expected +2 (67.2% underbonded). The formula itself is extraordinary: 13 Sr and 14 Si atoms sharing a single oxygen, with formation energy of only -0.628 eV/atom (very low). This looks more like a Zintl-phase intermetallic (Sr-Si) with a trace oxygen impurity than a genuine oxide. Is GNoME misclassifying a metallic silicide with adventitious oxygen as a ternary oxide compound?

La5Bi3O14 is computationally known but predicted in triclinic P1 (SG 1) while experiments show 100% tetragonal I4/mmm (SG 139) -- the maximum possible symmetry mismatch. The Bi sites show wildly inconsistent BVS: one at 2.483, another at 5.403, and a third at 5.327 v.u., all against an expected +4. This spread of nearly 3 v.u. across nominally equivalent Bi sites is among the largest intra-element BVS variance in the dataset. The triclinic distortion appears to create chemically distinct Bi environments that the tetragonal parent structure would not have -- is the P1 prediction a genuine low-temperature distortion or a DFT convergence artifact?

Eu2SbO has both oxi methods disagreeing and charge neutrality failing by -2.0, with Sb assigned as -3 (antimonide). The BVS for Sb shows -1.969 v.u. against expected -3 (34.4% underbonded), while the family member EuSb11O26 has a strikingly high GII of 1.01 -- well above the 0.2 v.u. ICSD baseline. Eu-Sb-O compounds straddle the boundary between oxides and pnictides; with only 8 sites and a formula suggesting an anti-perovskite or inverse structure, would reclassifying this as a pnictide rather than an oxide fundamentally change which validators are appropriate to apply?

Hg11(IO)4 contains 11 mercury atoms per formula unit in a triclinic P-1 cell with only 19 sites, suggesting significant positional disorder or partial occupancy. As an oxyhalide with mixed valence, both Hg1+ and Hg2+ are likely present -- consistent with mercury's well-known tendency to form Hg2^2+ dumbbells. The oxygen BVS of -1.1 v.u. (45% underbonded) and iodine BVS of -0.396 v.u. (60% underbonded) together suggest the anion sublattice is barely held together. Could this structure actually represent a calomel-type Hg2^2+ framework with I- and O2- partially occupying the same sites?

Nd3OsO8 and Pr3OsO8 (both in this batch) are isostructural in SG 63 (Cmcm) with nearly identical metrics: GII 0.577 vs 0.579, Pauling 0/16 vs 0/16, and lanthanide BVS deviations within 0.01 of each other (Nd 2.096 vs Pr 2.106). Pr3OsO8 matches the experimental space group perfectly while Nd3OsO8 scores 0.333 -- yet both are novel. The family members also mirror: Ln3Os2O9 (GII ~0.60) and Ln(OsO3)3 (GII ~0.32) exist for both. Hypothesis: the entire Ln3OsO8 series from La to Gd likely adopts Cmcm with smoothly varying lattice parameters, representing a robust structure type that GNoME has independently rediscovered for multiple lanthanides.

The Na-Rh-O family in this batch is remarkably large (8 members) and every single one fails charge neutrality (residuals of -1.0 or -2.0), while GII values cluster tightly between 0.538 and 0.623. Na9Rh7O16 itself has mixed valence with both oxi methods agreeing -- but agreeing on what? With Rh sites showing BVS of 2.035-2.039 against expected +3 (32% under), the systematic underbonding suggests Rh may actually be in a +2 state across this entire family. A universal Rh oxidation state error would simultaneously explain the charge neutrality failures and the compressed GII range.

Rh4OF11 is a fluorine-dominated oxyhalide (11 F vs 1 O) where the Pauling check could only evaluate 2 bonds (both violated, 100% score) with a warning flag. All Rh sites show BVS ~1.97-1.99 against expected +3 (34% under), nearly identical to the pure-oxide Na9Rh7O16 in this same batch. The entire Rh-O-F family (5 members, all novel) shows consistent charge residuals of -1 to -3 and GII of 0.53-0.56. Since BVS parameters were calibrated on oxide structures, how reliable are they for a compound that is essentially a rhodium fluoride with a single oxygen substitution?

Li5Rh3O8 in trigonal R-3m (SG 166) is computationally known and matches 50% of experimental space groups. All oxygen sites show identical BVS of -1.302 v.u. against expected -2.0, a uniform 35% underbonding. The isostructural analog Li9Rh7O16 (also SG 166, computationally known) has virtually the same GII (0.622 vs 0.573), and both carry a -2.0 charge residual. Hypothesis: these are layered Li-Rh-O compounds analogous to the well-known NaxCoO2 battery materials, where the charge residual reflects mobile Li+ ions whose occupancy is fractional, making the formal stoichiometry misleading for bond valence purposes.

Cd9Bi7O24 has Bi sites with a striking BVS split: two sites at 5.041 v.u. and one at 3.026 v.u., all against expected Bi4+. Bi4+ is extremely rare -- bismuth strongly prefers +3 or +5. If the two high-BVS sites are actually Bi5+ (deviation drops to 0.8%) and the low-BVS site is Bi3+ (deviation becomes 0.9%), the structure would contain mixed-valence Bi3+/Bi5+ with near-perfect local bonding. This would make Cd9Bi7O24 a charge-disproportionated bismuthate, similar to BaBiO3 -- a class of materials with potential superconducting properties. Does reclassifying Bi as mixed +3/+5 resolve all validation anomalies simultaneously?

Ti8C4O is classified as a pure oxide but has only 1 oxygen vs 4 carbons, with carbon assigned C4- (carbide) showing BVS of -4.707 v.u. (17.7% overbonded). Both oxi methods disagree and the material has mixed valence. The Ti-C-O family is well-represented (5 members, mostly computationally known) and includes the known MXene-precursor Ti2CO (GII 0.468). Ti8C4O's 100% Pauling violation (1 bond checked) is meaningless statistically. Should titanium carbide-oxides be validated using carbide BVS parameters rather than oxide ones, and does the single-oxygen formula make this effectively a binary carbide that was misclassified as a ternary oxide?

Ta3Sb5O16 contains an Sb site with BVS of 5.621 against expected +3 -- an 87.4% deviation, the largest single-site BVS error in this entire batch. Yet two other Sb sites show a reasonable 2.557 v.u. (14.8% under). This extreme split suggests one crystallographic Sb site has coordination appropriate for Sb5+ while others suit Sb3+, pointing to mixed Sb3+/Sb5+ valence that the single-method oxi assignment missed. The family member TaSb7O16 has GII of 0.962 (near the instability threshold), while Ta9SbO25 achieves 0.118. Is the Sb-rich end of the Ta-Sb-O system fundamentally unstable due to unresolvable Sb3+/Sb5+ disproportionation?

SrMn2O4 is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations, yet BVS shows every Mn site at 2.21 v.u. against an expected +3 -- a systematic 26% underbonding. Across the Sr-Mn-O family, the two charge-neutral members (SrMn2O4 and Sr4Mn2O7) both have elevated GII (0.57 and 0.61), while the Mn-rich SrMn8O16 achieves a much lower GII of 0.41 but carries a -6 charge imbalance. Is GNoME systematically trading geometric strain for stoichiometric simplicity in these low-Mn compositions, or does Mn3+ in the specific orthorhombic Pmmn setting genuinely prefer this compressed coordination environment?

The Na-Rh-O family presents a striking pattern: every single composition -- eight in total -- fails charge neutrality by -1 or -2, and all are novel predictions. The consistent Rh BVS of ~2.07 v.u. vs. expected +3 across multiple space groups (P-1, R-3, P2/m) suggests GNoME is systematically predicting Rh coordination environments that underbond rhodium by ~31%. Are these compositions converging on a metastable Rh2+ bonding motif that DFT stabilizes but classical Rh3+ BVS parameters cannot capture, or does this family represent a systematic failure mode of the GNoME network for late transition metal oxides?

Ta(BiO2)7 shows a dramatic internal inconsistency in its Bi bonding: one Bi site has a BVS of 5.38 v.u. (79% overbonded relative to Bi3+) while the remaining Bi sites sit at 2.49 v.u. (17% underbonded). With 71% Pauling Rule 2 violations and a -2 charge imbalance, this structure appears severely strained. Yet its family member Ta3BiO9 achieves a GII of only 0.24 with perfect charge neutrality. Does the high Bi:Ta ratio in Ta(BiO2)7 force Bi into coordination environments incompatible with its lone pair stereochemistry, explaining why the simpler Ta3BiO9 stoichiometry is so much more plausible?

Rb7Sc3O8 passes every Tier 1 check perfectly -- charge neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations -- yet its BVS reveals oxygen sites at only -1.23 to -1.29 v.u. against expected -2, a 36-38% underbonding. Within the Rb-Sc-O family, GII scales inversely with Sc content: Sc-rich RbSc3O5 has GII 0.47, while Rb-rich Rb8Sc2O7 reaches 0.64. This suggests the large Rb+ cations create cavities that leave oxygen severely undercoordinated. Could the Rb:Sc ratio serve as a tunable parameter for oxide ion conductivity in this family, given that underbonded oxygen is a known predictor of oxide mobility?

Rb5VO5 achieves charge neutrality and zero Shannon violations, but has 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations across all 10 checked polyhedra, and its oxygen sites show BVS of only -1.07 v.u. (46% underbonded vs. expected -2). This is one of the most extreme cases of a Tier-1-passing, Tier-2-failing material. The family member RbV6O12 has vastly better GII (0.33) but a catastrophic -10 charge imbalance. Is the high alkali:vanadium ratio forcing V5+ into such an unusual tetrahedral or trigonal bipyramidal environment that Pauling electrostatic rules completely break down, or is V5+ misassigned?

Na4Rh3O7 is assigned oxi states by only oxi_state_guesses (single method), and like its family member Na7Rh5O12, it shows Rh BVS of 2.08 v.u. against expected Rh3+ with a -2 charge imbalance. Notably, this material adopts trigonal R-3 symmetry (SG 148), while the known experimental Na-Rh-O structures prefer Pnma (SG 62) and R-3m (SG 166). Given that every Na-Rh-O composition in this batch carries the same Rh underbonding signature, should the assigned Rh3+ be reconsidered in favor of a mixed Rh2+/Rh3+ or even Rh2+ assignment, which would simultaneously resolve the charge imbalance and the BVS discrepancy?

Rb4N2O5 is an oxynitride that achieves charge neutrality despite its non-oxide anion mix, yet shows a Shannon radii violation fraction of 0.071 -- unusual because pure oxides almost universally score 0.0 on this check. The BVS worst offenders are oxygen at -1.14 v.u. (43% underbonded) and nitrogen at 2.30 v.u. (23% underbonded vs. N3-). Given that the BVS parameters were calibrated assuming O2- environments, how much of this strain is real geometric distortion versus an artifact of applying oxide-calibrated BVS parameters to a mixed anion system where N3- competes for coordination?

K8Fe2O7 and its family member K6Fe2O7 both adopt P2_1/c (SG 14) and are computationally known, but they assign Fe to different oxidation states: K8Fe2O7 has Fe BVS of 2.20 (expected Fe3+, both_agree) while K6Fe2O7 has Fe BVS of 3.04 (expected Fe4+, bv_analyzer only). With K:Fe ratios of 4:1 and 3:1 respectively, the higher-potassium compound paradoxically has lower Fe oxidation despite more electropositive cation content. Does DFT preferentially stabilize Fe3+ in K-rich environments through expanded lattice parameters, and could the novel family member K7Fe3O8 (GII 0.525, charge neutral) represent an intermediate Fe3+/Fe4+ mixed-valence ground state?

Ba4Mn2O7 is computationally known and passes all Tier 1 checks cleanly, with Mn BVS of 2.18 v.u. against expected Mn3+ (27% underbonded). Its family member Ba6Mn5O15 in the unusual R32 space group carries a -3 charge imbalance but similar GII (0.53). Given that Ba2+ is significantly larger than Sr2+ (1.42 vs. 1.26 angstrom for CN=8), and the Sr analog SrMn2O4 in this same batch shows nearly identical Mn underbonding (BVS 2.21), is this ~27% Mn3+ underbonding a universal feature of alkaline-earth manganites in GNoME predictions, potentially indicating that DFT systematically elongates Mn-O bonds in these structures?

Pr2Se3O10 is an oxychalcogenide where two Se sites show BVS of 5.84 v.u. (46% overbonded vs. expected Se4+) while a third Se sits at 3.51 v.u. (12% underbonded). The charge imbalance is -4, yet the family members with proper selenate stoichiometry -- Pr2(SeO4)3 and Pr2Se5O13 -- achieve GII of 0.10 and 0.31 respectively with perfect charge neutrality. The progression from GII 0.10 in the well-known Pr2(SeO4)3 to 0.57 in this novel Pr2Se3O10 suggests the Se3O10 stoichiometry forces Se into two crystallographically distinct environments that cannot both satisfy Se4+ bonding requirements simultaneously.

Nd2Se3O10 is nearly identical to Pr2Se3O10 (batch-mate 0aabdc3f05) -- same space group C2/c (SG 15), same 30 sites, same -4 charge, virtually identical Se BVS (5.85 vs. 5.84 overbonded, 3.52 vs. 3.51 underbonded), same 20% Pauling violations, and formation energies within 0.001 eV/atom. Yet Nd2Se3O10 is computationally known while Pr2Se3O10 is novel. Since Pr3+ and Nd3+ differ by only ~0.01 angstrom in ionic radius, the near-identical validation signatures confirm that this is a genuine lanthanide-series structural analog. Why does the Materials Project contain the Nd version but not the Pr version -- is this a gap in computational screening coverage rather than a stability difference?

Cs2Pb4O7 is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations, but Pb shows BVS of 1.84 v.u. against expected Pb3+ -- a 39% underbonding that is among the most severe for any main-group cation in this batch. Pb3+ is itself an unusual oxidation state (Pb typically prefers +2 or +4), and the oxi assignment comes from only oxi_state_guesses. Meanwhile, family member Cs6Pb2O5 achieves much better GII (0.37) with charge neutrality. Could the Pb3+ assignment be incorrect, with the true oxidation state being a Pb2+/Pb4+ mixture? If half the Pb sites are +2 and half +4, the formula Cs2(Pb2+)2(Pb4+)2O7 would yield charge -2, matching the stoichiometric tension.

Sr2(OsO3)3 adopts cubic I23 (SG 197), but experimental Sr-Os-O compounds are known only in SG 62 and 88. Across the Sr-Os-O family, GII varies dramatically with Os oxidation environment: Sr(OsO3)3 achieves a remarkably low GII of 0.16 while SrOs5O13 reaches 0.70. The charge imbalance of -4 for Sr2(OsO3)3 combined with Sr BVS of 1.44 (28% underbonded) suggests the cubic structure leaves Sr severely undercoordinated. Given that the family member Sr4Os6O19 shares the same I23 space group with much better GII (0.40) and charge neutrality, is the cubic framework specifically favorable for Os-rich compositions where the rigid OsO6 octahedral network can dictate the topology?

Rb4Ga2O5 is computationally known and passes all Tier 1 checks, yet oxygen sites are consistently underbonded at -1.31 v.u. (35% deviation from -2). Its sole family member RbGa9O14 has a much lower GII of 0.37 with perfect charge neutrality. The Rb:Ga ratio drops from 2:1 to 1:9 between these compounds, and GII improves dramatically. Since Ga3+ is a strong Lewis acid that typically achieves near-ideal BVS in tetrahedral coordination, the oxygen underbonding in Rb4Ga2O5 likely reflects insufficient cation-oxygen contacts in the Ga-poor, Rb-dominated structure. Could Rb4Ga2O5 be a candidate for high-temperature oxide ion conduction, given that its severely underbonded oxygens indicate weak lattice binding?

Bi3(Ru2O7)2 is a novel mixed-valence compound with a -3 charge imbalance, yet it adopts the high-symmetry R-3m (SG 166) trigonal structure. Across the Bi-Ru-O family, GII values are unusually high: Bi2RuO6 at 0.92, Bi8RuO18 at 0.89, Bi3RuO7 at 0.71 -- well above the ICSD baseline of ~0.2 v.u. The only well-behaved member is Bi14RuO24 (GII 0.54, charge neutral). The Ru BVS of 3.10-3.14 against expected Ru4+ (22% underbonded) in the title compound is mild compared to the family's extreme Bi-driven strain. Is the Bi3+ lone pair stereochemical activity systematically distorting these structures beyond what bond valence models can capture, making the entire Bi-Ru-O family appear artificially strained?

VNi5O8 is the only material in this batch where oxi methods fully disagree (both_disagree), and it is flagged as mixed-valence with a -2 charge imbalance. The BVS worst offenders are all oxygen sites at -1.25 to -1.28 v.u., severely underbonded at 36-37% deviation. With a V:Ni ratio of 1:5 in a monoclinic C2/m structure, and the family member V2NiO5 (opposite V:Ni ratio, GII 0.50, charge neutral), the oxidation state ambiguity may stem from the difficulty of partitioning charge between V and Ni when both have multiple accessible oxidation states. Does GNoME's predicted Ni-rich composition represent a genuine metastable phase, or is the oxi disagreement a signal that the DFT ground state mixes V3+/V5+ and Ni2+/Ni3+ in a way that defies simple integer assignment?

Cs5U18O54 has the most extreme charge imbalance in this batch at -13, despite passing Shannon radii and Pauling checks perfectly. With 77 sites and U BVS of 6.16 v.u. against expected U5+ (23% overbonded), the data strongly suggests the oxidation state assignment is wrong -- U6+ would yield BVS deviation of only ~3%, and the formula Cs5U18(6+)O54 gives a charge of +5+108-108 = +5, still imbalanced but less so. The family members CsU6O18 and CsU3O9 also carry large negative charges (-5, -4). Is this entire Cs-U-O family a case where oxi_state_guesses systematically underestimates uranium oxidation, and would reassigning to U6+ simultaneously improve charge neutrality and BVS across the family?

Rb4BiO4 is flagged as mixed-valence with oxi assigned by bv_analyzer only (single method), carries a -2 charge imbalance, and has a near-zero bandgap of 0.047 eV despite being an alkali-bismuth oxide that should be insulating. Its family member Rb3BiO4 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality and a much lower GII of 0.35. The stoichiometric difference is exactly one Rb per formula unit, and the extra Rb apparently destabilizes the structure. Given that the bv_analyzer assigns mixed valence while oxi_state_guesses presumably could not find a solution, is the Rb4BiO4 composition itself electronically unstable -- essentially an electron-doped version of the stable Rb3BiO4 that would spontaneously reduce to metallic Bi?

Rh3OF8 is an oxyhalide where both oxi methods disagree, mixed valence is flagged, and 100% of the (only 2) checked Pauling polyhedra are violated. All three Rh sites show BVS of 2.01-2.21 v.u. against expected Rh3+, with the two most underbonded Rh atoms at 33% deviation. Across the Rh-O-F family, every member is novel and every member fails charge neutrality. The extremely high fluorine content (F:O ratio of 8:1) means the bonding environment is dominated by Rh-F interactions, yet BVS parameters are calibrated primarily for oxide environments. Are the Rh BVS deviations an artifact of applying oxide-calibrated parameters to a fluoride-dominated structure, and would fluoride-specific BVS parameters yield a dramatically different picture?

Mn4Br6O has the most extreme oxygen underbonding in this batch: BVS of -0.83 v.u. against expected -2, a 58% deviation. With only a single oxygen atom in a halide-dominated structure (Br:O = 6:1), this oxygen is essentially isolated in a sea of bromide, receiving far less cation bonding than expected. Despite this, the material passes charge neutrality and Shannon radii perfectly. The Mn sites also show significant underbonding at BVS 1.31 vs. expected Mn2+. Is this an example of a halide structure where the lone oxygen atom serves as an interstitial defect-like site rather than a structural oxide, and does GNoME's prediction of this unusual stoichiometry reflect a genuine energy minimum or an artifact of the training data including similar oxyhalide entries?

Nd4Co2O9 is novel and passes all Tier 1 checks with 60 sites and zero Pauling violations across 36 checked polyhedra -- an unusually thorough validation. Co BVS is 2.19 v.u. against expected Co3+ (27% underbonded). Intriguingly, the Co-rich family member Nd(CoO2)3 achieves a much lower GII of 0.29 with charge neutrality, while the intermediate Nd4Co6O19 could not even be validated (null GII). The space group P2_1/c (SG 14) matches one of the three experimentally known space groups for this chemistry. Given the clean Tier 1 results and matching space group, could Nd4Co2O9 be a strong candidate for experimental synthesis, with the systematic Co3+ underbonding reflecting a genuine Jahn-Teller distortion of octahedral Co3+ (d6 low-spin)?

Sn7Pb5O16 shows Sn BVS of 1.62 v.u. against expected Sn3+ -- a 46% underbonding that is extreme even by this batch's standards. However, Sn3+ is not a common oxidation state; Sn typically adopts +2 or +4. The oxi_state_guesses assignment (single method) and -1 charge imbalance suggest the oxidation state is likely wrong. Remarkably, all five Sn-Pb-O family members adopt the same Pm space group yet span GII from 0.41 to 0.72 and charge imbalances from 0 to -8. The entire family appears to be exploring Sn/Pb substitution within a single structural framework. Is this a case where Sn2+/Sn4+ mixed valence should be assigned instead of uniform Sn3+, which would explain both the BVS deviation and the variable charge across the family?

Sr4Pt6O19 is charge-neutral with near-zero Pauling violations (5.3%), adopting cubic I23 (SG 197) -- the same unusual space group as Sr2(OsO3)3 in this batch. Both show identical Sr underbonding (BVS ~1.44, 28% deviation), suggesting this cubic framework generically undercoordinates the A-site alkaline earth. The Pt BVS data is not among the worst offenders, implying the PtO6 network is well-formed while Sr rattles in oversized cavities. With family member Sr2Pt2O7 achieving GII of only 0.22 in the orthorhombic Imma setting, does the cubic polymorph represent a high-temperature phase stabilized by Sr disorder, analogous to the disordered A-site in many cubic perovskites?

K6Fe2O7 is a computationally known compound where bv_analyzer (single method) assigns Fe4+, yielding BVS of 3.04 v.u. (24% underbonded). Its K-richer family member K8Fe2O7 (also in this batch) has both methods agreeing on Fe3+, with BVS of 2.20 v.u. (27% underbonded). Both are charge-neutral in P2_1/c, but K6Fe2O7 has a much lower bandgap (0.35 vs. 1.85 eV), consistent with Fe4+ being closer to metallic behavior. The disagreement between methods on Fe oxidation state across the K-Fe-O family raises a critical calibration question: are the BVS parameters for Fe4+ in alkali-rich oxides reliable, or does the anomalously low Fe4+ BVS indicate that Fe3+ with an extra electron delocalized into the K sublattice is the more physical description?

Rb5(AuO2)2 shows the most extreme cation underbonding in this batch: Rb BVS of 0.37-0.41 v.u. against expected Rb+ -- a 59-63% deviation that implies Rb is barely bonded to the lattice at all. It also has the highest Shannon radii violation fraction in the batch at 0.17, carries a -2 charge imbalance, and its sole family member Rb6Au4O has an extreme GII of 0.91. The near-zero bandgap (0.003 eV) for an alkali-gold oxide is highly suspicious. With Au typically in +1 or +3 oxidation states, is GNoME predicting a structure where Rb atoms are essentially free ions trapped in voids of an Au-O framework, making this less a crystal and more a clathrate-like arrangement that would likely decompose to RbAuO2 or Rb2O + Au under real conditions?

In the Sr-V-O family, Sr5V3O11 (GII 0.554) sits between the lower-strain Sr4V6O19 (GII 0.406) and higher-strain Sr10V6O25 (GII 0.596), all novel and charge-neutral. The BVS shows vanadium consistently underbonded at ~3.2 v.u. versus expected V4+. Could these structures actually stabilize V3+ in an unusual coordination environment, and does the monotonic GII increase with Sr:V ratio suggest a compositional stability window centered near the 2:3 ratio of Sr4V6O19?

Dy5(RuO6)2 is computationally known yet shows a striking space group mismatch: GNoME predicts monoclinic C2/m (SG 12) while 100% of experimental Dy-Ru-O compounds adopt cubic Fd-3m (SG 227). Both oxi state methods disagree and the Ru BVS is only 2.91 v.u. against an expected 4+, suggesting the assigned oxidation state may be wrong. Its family member Dy6RuO12 has an even worse GII of 0.789 -- is GNoME systematically misrepresenting the Ru coordination geometry in rare-earth ruthenates?

Sr16(Tc5O16)3 is a remarkably large unit cell (79 sites) with a charge imbalance of -4.0 and 37.5% Pauling Rule 2 violations, yet its family member Sr(TcO4)2 achieves a near-ideal GII of 0.272 and perfect charge neutrality. Within the Sr-Tc-O family, GII spans from 0.104 (SrTc5O8, but charge -16!) to 0.537 (Sr6Tc2O11), and the charge-neutral members cluster around GII 0.27-0.54. Why does GNoME predict this specific high-nuclearity stoichiometry when simpler charge-neutral compositions like Sr(TcO4)2 already exist computationally?

Na14Zn2O9 passes charge neutrality and Pauling Rule 2 perfectly, yet Zn shows a BVS of only 1.07 v.u. against expected 2+, a 46.5% deviation that is among the most extreme underbonding signals in the dataset. With a 7:1 Na:Zn ratio, this is an extraordinarily sodium-rich composition. Its only family member Na6Zn16O has the inverse ratio and could not even be evaluated (null GII/charge). Is the predicted structure placing Zn in an anomalously large coordination cage where it cannot achieve adequate bond valence?

Ho5(RuO6)2 and Dy5(RuO6)2 are isostructural (both monoclinic C2/m, 19 sites, computationally known) with nearly identical validation profiles: both show Ru BVS of ~2.91 v.u. vs expected 4+, both have methods_disagree oxi confidence, and both have GII ~0.553. Yet experimental Ln-Ru-O compounds exclusively adopt SG 227 (cubic pyrochlore). Given that the lanthanide contraction from Dy3+ to Ho3+ is only ~0.02 A, should we expect ANY structural difference between these two, and does the identical BVS deviation suggest a systematic bias in how BVS parameters handle Ru in this coordination?

Ba6Zr5O16 achieves charge neutrality and a space group (I4/mmm, SG 139) that matches 33% of known Ba-Zr-O compounds, the best space group score in this batch. However, 62.5% of its bonds violate Pauling Rule 2, and Ba is consistently underbonded (BVS 1.26 v.u. vs expected 2+). Its family member Ba5Zr3O11 shows a similar GII (0.586 vs 0.553). Could these Ba-rich zirconates represent a Ruddlesden-Popper-like homologous series where Ba underbonding is structurally accommodated by the layered architecture?

Bi2RhO6 is novel with a trigonal structure (SG 150) that has no overlap with the known monoclinic/orthorhombic Bi-Rh-O phases. All three Rh sites show BVS of ~2.8-2.9 v.u. against expected Rh4+, a consistent 28-30% underbonding. Its family member Bi3(Rh2O7)2 has a charge imbalance of -4.0 and GII of 0.474. With a near-zero bandgap of 0.007 eV and oxi confidence from only a single method, is the Rh oxidation state actually Rh3+ rather than Rh4+, which would simultaneously explain the BVS deviation and the charge neutrality?

The Na-Rh-O system has 8 family members in this dataset, all novel except Na5Rh3O8, and every single one that could be evaluated shows a charge imbalance of -1 or -2. This is not a one-off failure but a systematic pattern: Na3Rh2O5 (charge -2), Na5(RhO2)6 (-1), Na6(RhO2)7 (-1), Na4Rh3O7 (-2), Na5Rh3O8 (-2), Na7Rh5O12 (-2), Na9Rh7O16 (-2), Na8(RhO2)9 (-1). Are the oxi state assignment methods systematically failing for Rh in sodium-rich environments, or is GNoME predicting an entire family of electron-doped rhodates?

Rh2OF5 is an oxyhalide with 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation, but this was evaluated on only 1 bond with a compound-class warning flag. The BVS assumes O2- for the oxygen, yielding only -1.26 v.u. (37% underbonded), while Rh shows 2.2 v.u. vs expected 3+. Across the Rh-O-F family (5 members), every evaluable member shows charge imbalances of -1 to -3. Given that fluorine's high electronegativity competes with oxygen for electron density, are the BVS reference parameters (calibrated on pure oxides) fundamentally inappropriate for oxyhalides, and should this entire family be flagged as outside the validators' domain of applicability?

Cs2Cr2O7 (cesium dichromate) is computationally known and passes charge neutrality perfectly, yet all Cr sites show BVS of 4.97 v.u. against expected Cr6+ -- a 17% underbonding that is remarkably uniform across all three measured Cr sites. Its family member Cs4CrO4 (the orthochromate) is novel with a higher GII of 0.601. Since Cs2Cr2O7 has the highest bandgap in this batch (2.81 eV) consistent with a d0 Cr6+ configuration, could the systematic Cr underbonding reflect the known tendency of BVS to underestimate valence for highly charged tetrahedral oxyanions like CrO4/Cr2O7?

Rb5U18O54 has the largest charge imbalance in this batch at -13.0, yet achieves zero Pauling Rule 2 violations across all 50 checked bonds. The BVS reveals U at 6.08 v.u. against expected U5+, suggesting the uranium is actually U6+ (where 6.08 would be a reasonable BVS). If the true oxidation state is U6+, the formula Rb5U18O54 would give charge +5 +108 -108 = +5, still not neutral. This compound appears in the family of RbU3O9, which shows the same U BVS pattern. Is GNoME predicting a uranium oxide with mixed U5+/U6+ valence that the single-method oxi guesser cannot resolve?

Ti5Si3O is a highly unusual oxygen-poor intermetallic-like compound with only 1 oxygen per 8 metal atoms and a massive charge imbalance of -8.0. The BVS finds Ti at 3.03 v.u. versus expected Ti2+, a 51.7% overbonding -- the largest deviation in this batch. With 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations (2/2 bonds) and 25% Shannon radii violations, this material fails nearly every check. Given the formula suggests a Nowotny phase (Ti5Si3-type with interstitial O), are the classical ionic validators simply inapplicable to what is essentially a metallic compound with partial ionic character?

SrMn5O11 is novel with high oxi confidence (both_agree) and near-perfect Pauling (9.1% violation) and Shannon scores, yet all three worst Mn sites show BVS of 3.11 v.u. against expected Mn4+, a consistent 22.3% underbonding. The Sr-Mn-O family spans 5 members with GII from 0.414 (SrMn8O16, hollandite-like?) to 0.606 (Sr4Mn2O7). Given that SrMn8O16 is computationally known with the lowest GII despite a -6 charge imbalance, could the Mn-rich end of this family represent tunnel structures where large charge imbalances are accommodated by the framework topology?

Pr5(CoO6)2 is novel with mixed-valence Co and shows Co BVS values split between 2.81 and 3.01 v.u. against expected Co4+, while its family member Pr(CoO2)3 achieves a much lower GII of 0.305 with perfect charge neutrality. The CoO2 stoichiometry in Pr(CoO2)3 suggests edge-sharing CoO6 octahedral layers (like NaxCoO2 thermoelectrics). Could the Pr-Co-O system support a compositional gradient from layered Pr(CoO2)3 to the more three-dimensional Pr5(CoO6)2, analogous to the Na-Co-O misfit layered cobaltates?

Ca3Se3O10 is an oxychalcogenide where two Se sites show BVS of 5.97 v.u. against expected Se4+, a 49.4% overbonding -- the second largest deviation in this batch. This strongly suggests those Se atoms are actually Se6+ (selenate) rather than Se4+ (selenite), where BVS ~6.0 would be nearly perfect. With a charge imbalance of -4.0 and 40% Pauling violations (flagged with compound-class warning), the single-method oxi guesser appears to have assigned the wrong Se oxidation state. Does this material contain both selenite (SeO3)2- and selenate (SeO4)2- groups, making it a mixed-anion selenite-selenate?

Mg(Pt3O4)4 is novel with cubic symmetry (SG 202, Fm-3m) and a charge imbalance of -6.0, yet shows only a single site in its BVS worst list (Mg at 1.45 v.u., 27% underbonded) -- unusually few problem sites for a material with such a large charge imbalance. Its family member Mg(PtO3)2 is charge-neutral with GII 0.488. The Pt3O4 stoichiometry implies Pt in a sub-2+ average oxidation state, which is rare for platinum oxides. Is GNoME predicting a platinum-bronze-like metallic oxide with delocalized electrons that cannot be captured by integer oxidation states?

LiTa4O8 is computationally known with high oxi confidence (both_agree for mixed-valence Ta), yet shows an enormous charge imbalance of -9.0. The BVS reveals Ta at 4.24 v.u. against expected Ta3+, a 41.6% overbonding. If the tantalum were actually Ta5+ (BVS 4.24 would then be 15% underbonded, much more reasonable), the formula Li1+Ta4(5+)O8(2-) gives charge 1+20-16 = +5, also not neutral. This suggests neither Ta3+ nor Ta5+ produces charge balance. Is this a genuinely metallic compound where Ta exists in a non-integer average oxidation state around +4?

Ba16Tc6O37 is charge-neutral and passes Shannon radii, but one Ba site shows BVS of 3.81 v.u. against expected Ba2+, a 90.4% overbonding that is the single largest site deviation in this entire batch. This is physically implausible for Ba2+ in any reasonable coordination environment. Across the Ba-Tc-O family, the charge-neutral members span GII from 0.285 (Ba2TcO5) to 0.660 (Ba(TcO4)2), with this compound's GII (0.544) in the middle. Is the extreme Ba overbonding at one specific site evidence of a structural error in the GNoME prediction, perhaps a misplaced Ba atom too close to its oxygen neighbors?

Ag5(BiO3)2 shows Ag BVS of only 0.345 v.u. against expected Ag1+, a 65.5% underbonding that is the most extreme metal underbonding in this batch. The Ag atoms are receiving barely a third of their expected bond valence, suggesting they sit in vastly oversized cavities. Its family member Ag6BiO8 has an even more extreme GII of 0.987 and charge of -5.0. Known AgBiO3 is a promising photocatalyst with Bi5+ -- if Bi is actually Bi5+ here (not the guessed Bi3+), the formula Ag5(1+)Bi2(5+)O6(2-) would give +5+10-12 = +3, still not neutral. What oxidation state combination could produce stability in this silver bismuthate?

TbCo2O5 is novel, charge-neutral, and passes Pauling Rule 2 perfectly (0/20 violations), but Tb shows BVS of 2.78 v.u. against expected Tb4+, a 30.5% underbonding. Since Tb is one of the few lanthanides that can adopt both 3+ and 4+ states, a BVS of 2.78 actually falls closer to Tb3+. If the true state is Tb3+(Co3+)(Co4+)O5, this would be a charge-ordered double perovskite analog (like YBaCo2O5). Does the orthorhombic SG 55 (Pbam) symmetry, which differs from the experimental Pnma (SG 62) for related RE-Co-O phases, reflect a specific Co3+/Co4+ charge ordering pattern?

Nd2Cr3O12 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality, zero Pauling violations across 24 bonds, and high oxi confidence (both_agree), making it one of the cleanest validation profiles in this batch. Yet all Cr sites show BVS of ~5.0 v.u. against expected Cr6+, the same systematic ~17% underbonding seen in Cs2Cr2O7. With a bandgap of 2.10 eV consistent with a charge-transfer insulator, this material validates the hypothesis that BVS systematically underestimates the valence of Cr6+ in tetrahedral coordination. Should a Cr6+-specific correction factor be applied to the BVS reference parameters?

RbU3O9 appears both as an independent entry and as a family member of Rb5U18O54 (which is simply 5x the formula unit). Both show identical U BVS patterns (~6.0 v.u. vs expected U5+) and charge imbalances (-4.0 and -13.0 respectively, where -13 is approximately -4 times the scaling factor minus 1 from the Rb). The space groups differ (P6mm vs P6/mmm), suggesting these may be closely related superstructures. Are these truly independent GNoME predictions, or did the model predict essentially the same structure at two different supercell sizes, and should they be deduplicated?

RbV3O5 is novel with perfect charge neutrality, high oxi confidence, and a moderate 20% Pauling violation rate, but all three V sites show identical BVS of 2.28 v.u. against expected V3+, a uniform 24.1% underbonding. The perfectly symmetric underbonding across all V sites in an orthorhombic Pnma structure is unusual -- it suggests a systematic offset rather than local distortion. With a bandgap of 1.39 eV (semiconducting), could this be a Mott insulator candidate where the V3+ d2 electrons are localized, and the underbonding reflects V-O bond lengths optimized for electronic correlation rather than ionic packing?

Ba13Si14O has the most extreme charge imbalance in this batch at +10.0 (positive, unlike most others which are negative), a total Pauling Rule 2 violation (1/1 bond), and Ba sites with BVS as low as 0.573 v.u. (71.3% underbonded). With only 1 oxygen atom per 27 non-oxygen atoms and a formation energy of only -0.58 eV/atom (the weakest in this batch), this is essentially a Ba-Si intermetallic with trace oxygen. The positive charge imbalance suggests the oxi guesser assigned unreasonably high cation charges to a metallic compound. Should materials with fewer than ~10% anion sites be excluded from ionic validators entirely?

Nd5(PtO6)2 is computationally known but shows Nd BVS of 2.20-2.45 v.u. against expected Nd3+, a moderate underbonding. Its family member Nd2Pt7O18 has an alarming GII of 1.176 -- nearly 4x the ICSD baseline of 0.2 v.u. and among the highest in the entire dataset. The Pt:Nd ratio jumps from 0.4 in Nd5(PtO6)2 to 3.5 in Nd2Pt7O18, with the GII more than doubling. Does the extreme structural strain in Pt-rich compositions suggest a fundamental limit on how much Pt can be incorporated into rare-earth platinum oxides before the structure becomes geometrically untenable?

The entire Na-Rh-O family predicted by GNoME (8 novel members plus this computationally known Na5Rh3O8) systematically fails charge neutrality, with residual charges of -1.0 or -2.0 across every composition. The BVS analysis consistently shows Rh underbonded at ~2.15 v.u. versus the expected 3+. Given that both oxi-state methods disagree and the material is flagged as mixed-valence, is GNoME generating a family of structures that require Rh in a non-integer or reduced oxidation state (e.g., Rh2.33+) that our validators cannot represent, or are these genuinely electrostatically unstable?

Dy2Cr3O12 and its family member Dy2Cr3O8 share the same Dy:Cr ratio but with different oxygen content; the O8 variant is novel with a notably lower GII (0.378 vs. 0.538) and adopts a higher-symmetry C2/m space group versus triclinic P-1. This suggests the Cr3O8 framework may be more geometrically relaxed than Cr3O12. Could the Cr3O12 stoichiometry represent a metastable over-oxidized chromate (Cr6+ confirmed by both methods, BVS ~5.0 vs. expected 6), while the O8 variant accommodates a more natural Cr coordination?

La2Se3O10, classified as an oxychalcogenide, shows a striking discrepancy: two of the three Se sites have BVS of 5.82 (46% above expected Se4+), while the third is at 3.49 (13% below). Yet the charge-neutral family members La2(SeO4)3 and La2(Se2O7)3 achieve remarkably low GII values of 0.143 and 0.152 respectively. The parent compound's -4.0 charge residual and the Se overbonding suggest that GNoME may have placed Se into Se6+-like selenate coordination environments while the oxi-state guesser assigned Se4+. Is this a misassigned selenate masquerading as a selenite?

Rh4(OF3)3 is a novel rhodium oxyfluoride where every validator raises flags simultaneously: 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation, -3.0 charge residual, methods disagree on oxi states, and oxygen sites are severely underbonded (BVS -1.22 vs. expected -2.0, 39% deviation). Across the entire Rh-O-F family (5 novel members), not a single compound achieves charge neutrality, with residuals ranging from -1.0 to -3.0. This systematic pattern suggests GNoME's neural network may have poor training coverage for mixed-anion Rh-O-F chemistry, producing an entire family of electrostatically implausible structures.

Gd2Cr3O12 is essentially isostructural and isoelectronic to Dy2Cr3O12 (both triclinic P-1, 34 sites, charge neutral, zero Pauling violations), yet their GII values are nearly identical (0.538 vs. 0.538) and the Cr BVS deviations are within 0.003 of each other (~17% below expected Cr6+). With lanthanide contraction moving from Gd3+ (1.053 A) to Dy3+ (1.027 A), the invariance of the GII across this substitution suggests the Cr-O framework dominates the strain, not the rare-earth site. Could this Ln2Cr3O12 series tolerate even smaller rare earths (Er, Yb) without structural penalty?

Sr6Tc2O11 is novel and nominally charge-neutral, yet it adopts P1 (the lowest-symmetry space group) with 38 sites and a near-zero bandgap (0.0003 eV), suggesting metallic character unusual for a Sr-Tc oxide. The Sr sites are severely underbonded (BVS 1.26 vs. expected 2.0, 37% deviation). Within the family, Sr(TcO4)2 stands out with a remarkably low GII of 0.272, while the anomalous SrTc5O8 has a GII of only 0.104 but a catastrophic -16.0 charge residual. This Tc-rich end member appears to be a computational artifact with no physically meaningful oxidation state assignment.

Tb2(SeO3)3 is computationally known but both oxi-state methods disagree, and the BVS assigns Tb4+ (BVS 2.84, 29% below expected 4+). However, Tb4+ is exceptionally rare outside of fluorides like TbF4; in oxide selenites, Tb3+ is the standard state. The family member Tb2(SeO4)3 achieves a GII of only 0.161 with zero charge residual, suggesting Tb3+/Se6+ is the correct assignment. Should the oxi-state disagreement for the selenite be resolved in favor of Tb3+/Se4+, and if so, how does recalculating with Tb3+ change the BVS picture?

K8Sc2O7 shows a peculiar bonding pattern: all three worst-BVS sites are oxygen with identical deviations (BVS -1.261, 37% below expected -2.0), indicating the oxygen atoms are uniformly and severely underbonded. This is consistent with a structure where the K:O ratio is too high (8 large K+ ions competing for only 7 oxygens), creating an electrostatically dilute environment. The family members K7Sc3O8 and K17Sc5O16 maintain similar alkali-rich stoichiometries. Is GNoME systematically generating over-potassiated scandates that would be thermodynamically unstable against K2O decomposition?

Pr2Cr3O12 is novel, yet it passes every Tier 1 check perfectly (charge neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across all 24 bonds checked) with both oxi methods agreeing. The Cr BVS of ~5.01 shows only 16.5% deviation from expected Cr6+, the best among the Ln2Cr3O12 series in this batch (Gd: 17.0%, Dy: 17.2%, Sm: 17.1%). Given that Pr3+ is the largest trivalent lanthanide in the series, does its larger ionic radius provide the best geometric match for the chromate framework, and should this material be prioritized for experimental synthesis?

Nd(PtO3)2 is novel with a trigonal structure (SG 162), but the known space group for Nd-Pt oxides is Fd-3m (SG 227, cubic pyrochlore), a completely different structure type. The family member Nd2Pt7O18 has a catastrophically high GII of 1.176, more than double the ICSD baseline of 0.2 v.u., with a -2.0 charge residual. If GNoME is predicting platinum in octahedral PtO3 units (expected Pt4+ in PtO6), the mismatch between the trigonal layered structure and the expected pyrochlore framework raises serious questions about whether this prediction represents a real metastable polymorph or a geometric hallucination.

K6Cr2O7 is computationally known with charge neutrality (K+6 Cr4+2 O2-7 = 0), but the BVS reveals Cr is dramatically underbonded at 3.17 v.u. versus the expected 4+, a 21% deviation. In the same K-Cr-O family, K5Cr2O7 (novel) achieves a lower GII of 0.346 despite a -2.0 charge residual, while K3Cr4O8 has GII 0.463 with the same charge issue. The better-bonded structures are the ones that fail charge neutrality. Could the assigned Cr4+ oxidation state be incorrect, with Cr6+ (as in dichromate K2Cr2O7) being the actual chemistry, which would require rewriting the stoichiometry entirely?

Bi14RuO24 is novel and charge-neutral but its Ru site is catastrophically underbonded (BVS 3.62 vs. expected Ru6+ = 6.0, a 40% deviation), and oxygen sites are similarly distressed (BVS -1.07, 46% below expected). The entire Bi-Ru-O family shows escalating GII: Bi3RuO7 at 0.708, Bi4Ru2O11 at 0.743, Bi8RuO18 at 0.888, and Bi2RuO6 at 0.919 -- all well above the ICSD baseline of 0.2 v.u. With the Bi:Ru ratio climbing to 14:1, GNoME appears to be generating increasingly bismuth-diluted ruthenates where the Ru coordination environment becomes progressively more distorted. Is there a physical limit to Bi dilution in this system?

K5ErO4 is novel with perfect Tier 1 scores (charge neutral, zero Shannon and Pauling violations) and both oxi methods agree, yet has no family members in the dataset to compare against. The oxygen BVS shows all four O sites identically underbonded at -1.334 (33% deviation), the same pattern seen in the isostructural K5LaO4 (O BVS -1.342, same SG 59). The Er3+ and La3+ compounds adopt identical structures despite a 17% difference in ionic radius (Er3+ = 0.89 A vs. La3+ = 1.03 A). Does this K5MO4 structure type represent an unusually flexible framework that could accommodate the entire lanthanide series?

NaOs5O13 is novel with all Tier 1 checks passing, yet Na is catastrophically underbonded (BVS 0.464 vs. expected 1.0, a 54% deviation -- the worst in this batch). The Na-Os-O family tells a remarkable story: as the Na:Os ratio increases from 1:5 toward Na-rich compositions, GII plummets -- Na4OsO5 achieves 0.093, Na(OsO4)2 reaches an extraordinary 0.011, and Na4OsO6 sits at 0.240. The NaOs5O13 structure appears to have far too little Na to satisfy the bonding requirements of its cavity. Is the Na site in this Os-rich structure essentially a rattler with minimal bonding contribution?

Sm2Cr3O12 is one of four Ln2Cr3O12 compounds in this batch (Pr, Gd, Dy, Sm), all novel or computationally known, all in triclinic P-1 with 34 sites, all charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations. The Cr BVS values form a tight cluster: Pr (5.009), Sm (4.975), Gd (4.980), Dy (4.968) -- a monotonic decrease with decreasing Ln3+ radius. This 0.8% spread across four lanthanides suggests the Cr-O bond network is extraordinarily rigid. Could this Ln2Cr3O12 structure represent a genuine isostructural series amenable to combinatorial synthesis screening?

K5LaO4 is novel and isostructural with K5ErO4 (both SG 59, orthorhombic, 20 sites), with nearly identical oxygen underbonding (BVS -1.342 vs. -1.334). Despite La3+ being 16% larger than Er3+, the GII values are essentially the same (0.532 vs. 0.536). With no K5LaO4 family members in the dataset (unlike the K-Sc-O system which shows two members), this isolated prediction raises a question: is the K5MO4 framework so dominated by the K-O sublattice that the central M3+ ion is largely a spectator, and if so, could this tolerance be exploited for rare-earth-agnostic synthesis?

CeAs2O7 is novel with Ce in the 4+ state (both methods agree), yet the Ce BVS of 4.89 is 22% above the expected 4+, indicating Ce is overbonded. This is unusual because most sites in the dataset are underbonded relative to their expected oxidation state. The sole family member, Ce4As3O4 (also novel), has a +1.0 charge residual -- one of the rare positively charged predictions in the dataset. With Ce4+ being a strong oxidizer and As existing in both As3+ and As5+ states, could GNoME be struggling with the redox interplay between Ce4+/Ce3+ and As3+/As5+, producing stoichiometries that sit on an unstable redox boundary?

K5CrO5 is computationally known but shows 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (all 10 checked bonds fail), while its family member K6Cr2O7 in this same batch has only 28.6% violation. Both are charge-neutral with Cr in the 5+ and 4+ states respectively. The K5CrO5 BVS shows Cr at 4.02 vs. expected 5+ (20% deviation), suggesting the Cr may actually prefer Cr4+ in this coordination. If K5CrO5 and K6Cr2O7 represent two points on the K-Cr-O phase diagram with the same K:Cr oxidation mismatch pattern, are both structures adopting geometries more appropriate for a lower Cr oxidation state than assigned?

Ba16Fe8O31 is novel with an enormous unit cell (55 sites, the largest in this batch) and a severe -6.0 charge residual, the worst among all pure oxides here. Strikingly, the majority of its 7 Ba-Fe-O family members (Ba6Fe4O13, Ba12Fe4O19, Ba10Fe5O19, Ba21Fe14O43, Ba7Fe6O19) have null GII and null charge values, meaning oxi states could not even be assigned. Only Ba3Fe4O9 and Ba4Fe2O7 yielded valid results. This pattern of systematic oxi-state assignment failure across an entire family, combined with the mixed-valence flag (Fe2+/Fe3+), suggests GNoME is exploring a complex iron redox landscape that classical validators cannot parse.

Ba6Mn5O15 has the single worst site-level BVS deviation in this batch: a Mn site at BVS 1.158 vs. expected Mn3+ (3.0), a 61% deviation. This means the Mn is receiving barely a third of the bond valence it needs, suggesting it occupies an enormously oversized cavity. Combined with 60% Pauling Rule 2 violations and a -3.0 charge residual, this novel trigonal structure (SG 155, unusual for Ba-Mn oxides where SG 194 and 70 dominate) appears to be a geometric outlier. Is GNoME placing Mn into Ba-sized sites in this structure, creating an inherently unstrained but electrostatically implausible prediction?

Rb5AlO4 is novel with charge neutrality and both oxi methods agreeing, but 50% Pauling Rule 2 violation and uniform oxygen underbonding (all O at BVS -1.315, 34% deviation). The two family members Rb8Al2O7 (GII 0.508) and Rb4Al2O5 (GII 0.401) show that Al-richer compositions achieve better bond valence sums. The Rb5AlO4 stoichiometry implies isolated AlO4 tetrahedra embedded in a sea of Rb+ -- essentially a clathrate-like arrangement. Given that the analogous K5AlO4 is not experimentally known and Rb+ is even larger, what is the maximum alkali:Al ratio that can sustain a connected Al-O network rather than isolated tetrahedra?

Rh3(OF3)2 shares an identical family with Rh4(OF3)3 (material 9019d19919 in this batch), and both show the same pathology: methods disagree on oxi states, mixed valence is flagged, and charge neutrality fails (-2.0 and -3.0 respectively). Comparing the two, Rh3(OF3)2 has a slightly lower GII (0.530 vs. 0.538) and a slightly less negative charge residual. The entire Rh-O-F family of 5+ members, all novel, all fail charge neutrality. This is not an isolated prediction error but a systematic bias: GNoME appears unable to produce a single viable rhodium oxyfluoride in this composition space.

EuSeO is computationally known, charge-neutral, and both oxi methods agree on Eu3+/Se2-/O2-, yet it shows 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (all 4 checked bonds) with a warning flag for the oxychalcogenide class. The BVS shows all Eu sites identically underbonded at 2.274 (24% below expected 3+). The family reveals an intriguing contrast: Eu2(SeO3)3 (novel selenite) achieves GII 0.176 with charge neutrality, far better than EuSeO's 0.530. Does the simple EuSeO rocksalt-type structure force Eu into an unfavorable coordination that the more complex selenite framework resolves, and could EuSeO decompose into Eu2(SeO3)3 phases at ambient conditions?

Na2Co3O7 is novel with perfect Tier 1 scores and both oxi methods agreeing on Co4+, yet all three worst-BVS Co sites show ~22-23% deviation below the expected 4+ (BVS ~3.1). Co4+ is a strong oxidizer that is relatively rare in stable oxides outside of electrochemical contexts (e.g., NaxCoO2 battery cathodes). With the family member Na(CoO2)6 showing a catastrophic -10.0 charge residual, the Na-Co-O system appears particularly challenging for oxi-state assignment. Could Na2Co3O7 actually contain Co3+ in a different stoichiometric interpretation, and if confirmed as Co4+, would this make it a candidate high-voltage cathode material?

Y7FeO12 is computationally known with an unusually high formation energy magnitude (-3.69 eV/atom, the most negative in this entire batch), suggesting exceptional thermodynamic stability. Yet the Fe site is significantly underbonded (BVS 2.04 vs. expected Fe3+ = 3.0, 32% deviation), the worst Fe-site deviation in the batch. With a Y:Fe ratio of 7:1, the iron is extremely dilute in the yttrium oxide matrix. The sole family member Y5(FeO6)2 has null GII and charge values, suggesting computational intractability. Does the extreme Y dilution create an unusually large Fe site that DFT stabilizes energetically but that real synthesis would struggle to maintain against Fe clustering?

Mg3Rh3O8 has a charge imbalance of -1.0 and all three Rh sites show identical BVS of 2.227 vs. expected 3+ (deviation 0.258), yet Shannon radii and Pauling checks pass cleanly across all 8 bonds. Could this systematic Rh under-bonding indicate that Rh is actually adopting a mixed +2/+3 state rather than uniform +3, and if so, does the fact that its Mg-Rh-O family members (MgRh5O12, MgRh3O8) are all novel with no computable GII suggest GNoME is exploring an entire uncharted Rh oxidation landscape?

TlV3O9 is charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing, yet the Tl sites show BVS of 4.642 against an expected +3 (deviation 0.547) -- the highest cation over-bonding in this batch. Thallium is known for Tl+/Tl3+ ambiguity; could GNoME's predicted monoclinic structure (SG 9) be forcing Tl into an anomalously high effective valence, and does the family member TlV4O8 having a much lower GII of 0.365 suggest that increasing the V:Tl ratio relieves this Tl coordination strain?

Li3(Pt3O4)4 carries a massive charge imbalance of -5.0 and Li sites show BVS of only 0.466-0.477 vs. expected +1 (deviation 0.523-0.534), yet it is computationally known. Strikingly, the Li-Pt-O family splits into two classes: members with balanced charge (Li4PtO5, Li6PtO6, LiPt3O8) have GII values of 0.138-0.171, while those with charge deficits (Li(Pt3O4)4 at -7.0, Li3Pt3O8 at -2.0) have GII 0.251-0.414. Does this pattern reveal that the oxi_state_guesses method systematically misassigns Pt oxidation states in Pt-rich compositions, and should Pt4+ rather than Pt2+ be considered?

KTa10O18 shows the largest charge imbalance in this batch at -10.0 with all Ta sites registering BVS of ~4.53 vs. expected +3 (deviation 0.51), yet Pauling Rule 2 passes perfectly across all 36 bonds and Shannon radii show zero violations. If the oxi_state_guesses method is assigning Ta3+ when the BVS strongly suggests Ta5+ (which would yield charge neutrality for K+Ta10(5+)O18(2-) = +1+50-36 = +15, still wrong), what oxidation state assignment would simultaneously satisfy both charge neutrality and BVS for this unusual 1:10:18 stoichiometry?

Cu3P2O7 is the only material in this batch where both oxi methods disagree AND mixed valence is flagged, and it shows the only non-zero Shannon radii violation (0.2) alongside P sites with BVS of 6.19 vs. expected +5 (deviation 0.238). Given that copper commonly adopts Cu+/Cu2+ mixed valence in phosphates, could the Shannon radii violation be a direct consequence of the oxi method assigning the wrong Cu oxidation state to 20% of sites, and would resolving the Cu+/Cu2+ ambiguity simultaneously fix both the charge imbalance (-2.0) and the P over-bonding?

Pr2OsO5 is computationally known, charge-neutral, passes all Tier 1 checks, and has moderate BVS deviations (Pr at 2.381 vs. expected 3+, deviation 0.206), yet its family reveals a striking GII gradient: Pr(OsO3)3 at 0.318, Pr2OsO5 at 0.526, Pr3OsO8 at 0.579, and Pr3Os2O9 at 0.599. This monotonic increase of GII with decreasing Os:Pr ratio suggests that osmium coordination is the stabilizing factor. Could Pr2OsO5 represent a boundary composition where Os coordination geometry transitions from optimal to strained as the rare-earth fraction increases?

Sr9(CoO3)7 has the largest unit cell in this batch (74 sites) with mixed valence, methods-disagree oxi confidence, and a charge imbalance of -6.0, yet its extensive Sr-Co-O family of 7 members reveals a systematic pattern: every single composition with Co shows charge imbalances ranging from 0 to -10.0, and GII values cluster around 0.29-0.49 except Sr6Co5O16 (GII 0.64, charge 0.0). Why does the only charge-neutral family member have the worst GII, and does this inverse correlation between charge balance and structural strain suggest that GNoME's DFT training is optimizing geometry at the expense of correct electron counting for Co mixed-valence systems?

K7Fe3O8 is novel, charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing, passes Pauling and Shannon checks perfectly, yet Fe sites show BVS of 2.176-2.210 vs. expected +3 (deviation 0.263-0.275). The K:Fe ratio of 7:3 is unusually alkali-rich; family members K8Fe2O7 and K6Fe2O7 are both computationally known with even higher GII values (0.567 and 0.555). Could this alkali-rich ferrate family represent a case where GNoME has discovered a novel K7Fe3O8 composition that is actually more structurally plausible (lower GII at 0.525) than its computationally known relatives, suggesting the intermediate K:Fe ratio optimizes the alkali coordination environment?

Ba3Fe4O9 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality, both oxi methods agreeing, and a 2.2 eV bandgap suggesting a genuine insulator, yet its extensive Ba-Fe-O family of 7 members is almost entirely novel and 4 out of 7 family members have null GII and null charge (Ba6Fe4O13, Ba12Fe4O19, Ba10Fe5O19, Ba21Fe14O43). What systematic property of these compositions causes the oxi state assignment to fail entirely, and does the fact that Ba3Fe4O9 is the only family member with successful validation suggest it occupies a unique compositional sweet spot where Fe oxidation states are unambiguous?

KV3O5 is charge-neutral with both methods agreeing on V3+ assignment, but shows a 20% Pauling Rule 2 violation rate (4 of 20 bonds) alongside BVS deviations of 0.242 for all V sites (BVS 2.273 vs. expected 3+). Its sole family member KV6O12 has a staggering charge imbalance of -10.0. Given that vanadium commonly spans V2+ through V5+, could KV3O5 contain V in a true +3 state stabilized by the K+ counter-ion, while doubling the V:K ratio in KV6O12 makes the +3 assignment geometrically impossible, suggesting a maximum V-loading threshold for this oxidation state in potassium vanadates?

Sr3PtO6 passes every Tier 1 check (charge-neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across 12 bonds) but has Sr sites with BVS of only 1.362 vs. expected +2 (deviation 0.319), indicating significant Sr under-bonding. Its family shows enormous GII variation: Sr2Pt2O7 at 0.220, Sr3PtO6 at 0.524, Sr3(PtO3)2 at 0.641, and Sr2Pt7O18 at 0.704. Why does the predicted monoclinic SG 14 structure deviate so strongly from the expected SG 167 (R-3c, the known space group for the A3BO6 structure type), and could the wrong space group be the root cause of the Sr under-bonding?

Ag5(P2O7)2 is computationally known with both oxi methods agreeing and mixed valence flagged, yet carries a charge imbalance of -3.0. All three worst-deviating sites are P with BVS of 6.106-6.173 vs. expected +5 (deviation 0.221-0.235), systematically over-bonded. The Ag-P-O family shows escalating GII with increasing P:Ag ratio (Ag2PO4 at 0.451, Ag5(P2O7)2 at 0.524, Ag5(PO3)6 at 0.602, AgP4O11 at 0.822). Does this monotonic GII increase with phosphorus enrichment indicate that the P-O tetrahedral network becomes increasingly strained as it must accommodate fewer Ag+ ions, and is there a critical P:Ag ratio beyond which these structures become physically implausible?

Eu2NO is classified as an oxynitride -- one of the 18% non-pure-oxide compounds where the O2- assumption may not hold -- and its BVS worst sites include N at -2.219 vs. expected -3 (deviation 0.260) and O at -1.370 vs. expected -2 (deviation 0.315). With only 2 Pauling bonds checked (flagged with a warning) and a charge imbalance of -2.0 from single-method oxi assignment, could the BVS deviations reflect that the N-Eu bond valence parameters (calibrated for nitrides) are being applied in an oxynitride environment where the mixed anion field fundamentally alters bond lengths, making the BVS reference values inappropriate?

Tb2Cr3O12 is novel, charge-neutral with both methods agreeing on Cr6+ assignment, and has a bandgap of 1.96 eV, yet Cr sites show BVS of 4.979-5.014 vs. expected +6 (deviation 0.164-0.170) -- a consistent ~17% under-bonding. The sole family member Tb5Cr2O12 (computationally known) has a charge imbalance of -1.0 and GII of 0.389, lower than Tb2Cr3O12's 0.522. Given that Cr6+ is a strong oxidizer, could the systematic Cr under-bonding signal that the DFT-optimized Cr-O distances are slightly too long, and would this predict that Tb2Cr3O12 is thermodynamically metastable with respect to reduction to a Cr5+ or Cr3+ phase?

Nd7RhO12 is novel, perfectly charge-neutral with both methods agreeing, and passes all Tier 1 checks, but Rh shows BVS of only 1.811 vs. expected +3 (deviation 0.396) -- the most severely under-bonded transition metal site in this batch after Co in Sr9(CoO3)7. Oxygen sites are also under-bonded at -1.445 vs. -2 (deviation 0.277). The family member Nd2Rh2O7 (pyrochlore structure, Fd-3m) has an even higher GII of 0.869. Is GNoME predicting that the Nd7RhO12 trigonal structure (R-3) provides better Rh coordination than the pyrochlore arrangement, and does the formation energy of -3.47 eV/atom (the second deepest in this batch) support this as a genuinely stable phase despite the BVS concerns?

Cu3(BiO3)4 is novel with a charge imbalance of -2.0, and Cu sites show the most extreme cation under-bonding in this entire batch: BVS of 1.066-1.070 vs. expected +2 (deviation 0.465-0.467), meaning Cu is receiving barely half its expected bond valence. With cubic symmetry (SG 204, Im-3) -- a space group not seen in any of the experimental references (SG 108, 130) -- and no family members for comparison, could this represent a case where GNoME has placed Cu in a coordination environment so under-saturated that Cu+ rather than Cu2+ would better describe the actual bonding, and would reassigning Cu+ resolve the charge imbalance?

Ba5(PtO5)2 is novel, charge-neutral, and passes Shannon and most Pauling checks (only 10% violation), but Ba sites show BVS of only 1.039 vs. expected +2 (deviation 0.481) -- Ba is receiving barely half its expected bond valence. Its sole family member Ba2(PtO3)3 (computationally known) has a remarkably low GII of 0.014, essentially a perfect crystal by BVS standards. Given that Ba5(PtO5)2 and Ba2(PtO3)3 have very different Ba:Pt ratios (5:2 vs. 2:3), does the dramatic GII difference (0.520 vs. 0.014) indicate that barium platinates only achieve structural ideality when Pt-rich, and is the Ba-rich composition inherently frustrated due to insufficient Pt-O polyhedra to saturate all Ba coordination sites?

Pr6MoO12 is novel, charge-neutral, and passes all Tier 1 checks perfectly across 12 bonds, but Mo shows BVS of 4.726 vs. expected +6 (deviation 0.212) and oxygen sites are under-bonded at -1.418 vs. -2 (deviation 0.291). Its sole family member Pr2Mo2O7 has a lower GII (0.449 vs. 0.520) despite having the same Pr and Mo oxidation states. With the very high formation energy of -3.43 eV/atom, could Pr6MoO12 represent a fluorite-derivative structure (R-3, common for Ln6MO12 compositions) where the single Mo atom must satisfy oxygen bonding demands that would normally be shared across multiple transition metal sites, explaining the systematic Mo and O under-bonding?

Tm5(RuO6)2 has methods-disagree oxi confidence with mixed valence flagged, and Ru shows BVS of 2.953 vs. expected +4 (deviation 0.262). Its family members Tm3RuO7 (GII 0.711) and Tm6RuO12 (GII 0.764) both have much higher GII values and are charge-neutral, while Tm5(RuO6)2 itself has a charge imbalance of -1.0. Given that Ru commonly adopts +3, +4, and +5 states and the BVS of 2.953 falls between Ru3+ and Ru4+, could the disagreement between oxi methods indicate genuine ambiguity about Ru's oxidation state in this structure, and would the family-wide high GII values (all above 0.5) suggest that the entire Tm-Ru-O system is poorly described by the available BVS reference parameters?

Ca13Si14O stands out as the most anomalous material in this batch: it has a charge excess of +10.0 (the only positive imbalance), 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (1 of 1 bond checked), and Ca BVS of only 0.880 vs. expected +2 (deviation 0.560). With a stoichiometry of 13:14:1 where oxygen is the minority species, this appears to be a silicide with trace oxygen rather than an oxide. Is this material fundamentally misclassified as a 'pure_oxide', and does its extremely low formation energy of -0.678 eV/atom (the shallowest in this batch) combined with total validator failure suggest that GNoME's prediction is chemically implausible as an oxygen-containing compound?

Cd4Bi2O9 is computationally known, perfectly charge-neutral with both methods agreeing, yet Cd shows BVS of only 1.124-1.140 vs. expected +2 (deviation 0.430-0.438), indicating severe Cd under-bonding. Its family members show escalating dysfunction: Cd9Bi7O24 (charge -2.0, GII 0.572), Cd(BiO2)7 (charge -5.0, GII 0.817), while Cd5BiO8 has null GII entirely. Does the consistent Cd under-bonding across this family suggest that the BVS reference parameters for Cd2+-O bonds are poorly calibrated for bismuth-containing environments where Bi3+'s lone pair distorts the local coordination geometry and elongates Cd-O bonds beyond the BVS model's assumptions?

Sr7Tc4O19 is computationally known and charge-neutral but has the highest Pauling Rule 2 violation rate among charge-balanced materials in this batch at 31.6% (6 of 19 bonds), alongside Sr under-bonding (BVS 1.332 vs. expected +2, deviation 0.334). Its family reveals a remarkable outlier: SrTc5O8 has a GII of just 0.104 but a charge imbalance of -16.0. How can a structure have near-perfect bond valence geometry (GII 0.104) yet be 16 electrons away from charge neutrality -- does this expose a fundamental limitation where BVS validation and charge neutrality can be completely orthogonal, and should compound-level scoring weight these checks differently for technetium compounds?

Pb4W4O13 shows W with BVS of 5.584 vs. expected +4 (deviation 0.396), but W4+ is an unusual oxidation state -- tungsten far more commonly adopts W6+. If W is actually W6+ in this structure, the BVS of 5.584 would give a deviation of only 0.069 (excellent), but the charge balance would shift from -2.0 to +6.0. Meanwhile, Pb at BVS 1.311-1.379 vs. expected +2 suggests Pb under-bonding. Could the oxi_state_guesses method have assigned W4+/Pb2+ when the true state is W6+/Pb2+ with a Pb lone-pair-driven structural distortion explaining both the Pb under-bonding and the anomalous trigonal space group (SG 160 vs. expected SG 14)?

CsU3O9 is novel with a charge imbalance of -4.0, and all three U sites show BVS of 5.98-6.042 vs. expected +5 (deviation 0.196-0.208), systematically over-bonded. Uranium commonly adopts U4+, U5+, and U6+ states; a BVS near 6.0 strongly suggests U6+ rather than the assigned U5+. The family members Cs5U18O54 (charge -13.0) and CsU6O18 (charge -5.0) both show massive charge imbalances. If U6+ is the correct assignment throughout this Cs-U-O family, does the fact that CsU3O9 adopts the hexagonal SG 194 (P6_3/mmc) suggest a uranyl-type layered structure where Cs+ occupies interlayer sites, and would U6+ assignment bring the charge closer to neutrality (+1+18-18 = +1, still off)?

Lu5(RuO6)2 is computationally known yet has a charge imbalance of -1.0 and Ru BVS of 2.980 vs. expected +4 (deviation 0.255), nearly identical to its structural analogue Tm5(RuO6)2 (Ru BVS 2.953, deviation 0.262, also monoclinic SG 12). Both adopt the same space group, same formula type Ln5(RuO6)2, and show the same Ru under-bonding pattern. Does this lanthanide-independent consistency in Ru BVS deviation (0.255 vs. 0.262) across the Ln5(RuO6)2 series indicate a systematic error in the Ru4+-O BVS reference parameters rather than a structural deficiency, and could recalibrating the Ru4+ R0 parameter by ~0.03 Angstroms resolve both simultaneously?

LiTl3O5 is a novel pure oxide in space group Pbam (55) while experimental Li-Tl-O compounds exclusively adopt tetragonal space groups (I4_1/amd 141 and P4_2/nmc 137) -- all three Tl sites show identical BVS of 3.731 v.u. against expected Tl3+ (deviation 0.244), suggesting a uniformly overbonded thallium sublattice. Could this orthorhombic distortion represent a metastable polymorph where Tl3+ coordination is systematically compressed, or does the 24% BVS excess on every Tl site indicate the DFT relaxation converged to a geometry incompatible with Tl3+ ionic radii?

Across the Dy-Cr-O family, GII values follow a clear trend with stoichiometry: Dy2Cr3O8 (0.378) < Dy2CrO6 (0.511) < Dy2Cr3O12 (0.538), yet Dy2CrO6 and Dy2Cr3O8 both show charge imbalances of -1.0 while Dy2Cr3O12 achieves neutrality. Given that Cr in Dy2CrO6 is systematically underbonded (BVS 5.171 vs expected Cr6+ = 6, deviation 14%), could the Cr-deficient stoichiometry force an unfavorable coordination geometry for hexavalent chromium, and would this family converge on better BVS if Cr adopted a lower oxidation state?

Mn4I7O is a novel mixed-valence oxyhalide with a striking 7:1 iodine-to-oxygen ratio, yet it fails charge neutrality (residual charge -1.0) and shows severely underbonded oxygen (BVS -1.241 vs expected -2, a 38% deviation) alongside underbonded Mn2+ (BVS 1.344, deviation 32.8%). Its family member Mn7I12O achieves charge neutrality but with even worse GII (0.588). With only 1 Pauling bond checked and a warning flag, does the extreme halide dominance in this structure mean the single oxide ion is so isolated that it cannot achieve proper coordination, fundamentally undermining the stability of any Mn-I-O phase with sub-stoichiometric oxygen?

In the Eu-Bi-O family, Eu3BiO7 (GII 0.511) is computationally known while its relatives EuBiO4 (GII 0.317, novel) and Eu(BiO2)7 (GII 0.824, novel, charge -4.0) span a wide quality range. Eu3BiO7 shows a dramatic split: Eu is severely underbonded at BVS 1.838 vs expected 3+ (38.7% deviation) while Bi is moderately overbonded at 5.659 vs expected 5+ (13.2%). Given the nearly zero bandgap (0.0005 eV), could the Eu underbonding reflect incipient Eu2+ character that would make this a mixed-valence conductor rather than the insulator implied by the formal Eu3+/Bi5+ assignment?

Ba11Mo4O23 is a novel 76-atom triclinic (P1) structure where all three worst BVS sites are Mo with systematically low valence sums (4.768, 4.866, 4.911 vs expected Mo6+), representing 18-21% underbonding. Oxidation states were assigned by only a single method (oxi_state_guesses). Its family member Ba5Mo3O11 in the high-symmetry P4/mmm has a lower GII of 0.466. Could the P1 symmetry with 76 atoms indicate a DFT relaxation artifact where the optimizer settled into a low-symmetry local minimum, and would the true ground state adopt the tetragonal symmetry seen in the related Ba5Mo3O11 stoichiometry?

K17Sc5O16 is a novel compound with an unusually alkali-rich stoichiometry (K:Sc ratio of 3.4:1) where all three worst BVS deviations occur on oxygen sites, each showing BVS around -1.31 vs expected -2 (34% underbonding). Its family members K8Sc2O7 (GII 0.537, computationally known) and K7Sc3O8 (GII 0.483, novel) show a trend: as the K:Sc ratio increases from 2.3 to 3.4, GII worsens from 0.483 to 0.510. With a 37.5% Pauling Rule 2 violation rate across 16 bonds, is there a fundamental limit to how alkali-rich a K-Sc-O phase can be before the oxygen coordination becomes too potassium-dominated to sustain proper bond valence?

Rb8Al2O7 is novel with an extreme alkali:metal ratio (4:1) and shows 57.1% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 14 bonds -- the highest violation rate in this batch -- while all three worst BVS sites are oxygens underbonded at -1.274 v.u. (36.3% deviation from -2). Its family members Rb5AlO4 (GII 0.531) and Rb4Al2O5 (GII 0.401) show that increasing the Al fraction dramatically improves structural quality. Should Pauling Rule 2 thresholds be recalibrated for heavily alkali-dominated structures where large Rb+ ions crowd the anion coordination sphere, or does the 57% violation rate genuinely indicate that this stoichiometry cannot form a stable crystal?

Sm2CrO6 and Dy2CrO6 (batch material 408c1aff84) are isostructural in C2/c (SG 15) with nearly identical BVS patterns: Cr underbonded at 5.128/5.171 vs expected 6+, and the rare earth underbonded at 2.368/2.336 vs expected 3+. Yet Sm2CrO6 has zero Pauling violations (0/12) while Dy2CrO6 shows 33% violations (4/12), despite both being computationally known. Given Sm3+ (1.079 A) is larger than Dy3+ (1.027 A), does the lanthanide contraction push Dy2CrO6 toward coordination geometries that violate Pauling's electrostatic valence rule even though the BVS distortion magnitudes remain comparable?

Sr5Ti3O11 is a novel Ruddlesden-Popper-like layered titanate with zero Pauling violations (0/11) and perfect charge neutrality, yet its worst BVS sites are oxygen at -1.278 v.u. (36.1% underbonding). Its family members show a striking pattern: Sr2Ti13O22 has excellent GII (0.276) but charge -2.0, while Sr7Ti7O20 has moderate GII (0.436) but charge -5.0. Could the consistent oxygen underbonding across the Sr-Ti-O family indicate that GNoME systematically predicts Sr-Ti-O structures with expanded oxygen polyhedra, possibly because the DFT training data overestimates the Sr-O bond length?

TiSe2O7 is a novel oxychalcogenide where Se sites show contradictory BVS behavior: two Se atoms are severely underbonded (BVS 3.775 vs expected Se5+, deviation 24.5%) while a third Se is overbonded (BVS 5.970 vs expected 5+, deviation 19.4%). Its family members TiSeO5 (GII 0.102) and Ti(SeO4)2 (GII 0.161) both achieve excellent structural quality with charge neutrality. With oxi states assigned by only a single method and a Pauling warning flag, could the Se5+ assignment be incorrect for the two underbonded sites -- perhaps they are Se4+ with a lone pair -- which would explain both the BVS mismatch and the oxyhalide-class warning?

Y3BiO7 is computationally known with a large 6-member Y-Bi-O family spanning GII from 0.505 to 0.872, where every Bi-rich composition (Y(BiO2)7 at 0.809, Y3Bi5O14 at 0.872, YBi3O7 at 0.842) shows both high GII and large charge imbalances (-4.0 or -2.0). Y itself shows severe underbonding (BVS 2.029 vs expected 3+, deviation 32.4%) while Bi is overbonded (5.857 vs 5+, 17.1%). Is the systematic degradation of structural quality with increasing Bi content evidence that BVS reference parameters for Bi5+-O are poorly calibrated for these fluorite-derived structures, or does it genuinely reflect increasing structural strain?

Pr5Mn2O12 is computationally known yet fails charge neutrality (residual -1.0) with single-method oxi assignment, and shows Mn underbonded at BVS 3.125 vs expected Mn4+ (21.9% deviation). Its family member Pr4Mn6O19 also fails neutrality (charge -2.0) despite being computationally known. With space group C2/m matching one of the experimental references (25% match), and a near-zero bandgap (0.0015 eV), could the charge imbalance indicate that Mn should be assigned Mn3+ rather than Mn4+, which would give Pr5Mn2O12 a total charge of +1 instead of -1 -- suggesting neither oxidation state assignment achieves neutrality and the true ground state may require mixed Mn3+/Mn4+?

Ba4PuO7 belongs to a 5-member Ba-Pu-O family where GII scales inversely with the Ba:Pu ratio -- BaPu3O10 (0.283), Ba2Pu2O7 (0.406), BaPu2O7 (0.584), Ba16Pu6O37 (0.684) -- yet Ba4PuO7 itself (GII 0.504) breaks this trend with Ba underbonded at 1.378 vs expected 2+ (31.1% deviation). With 42.9% Pauling violations and single-method oxi assignment, does the structural quality degradation at high Ba:Pu ratios reflect a genuine thermodynamic instability in barium-rich plutonium oxides, or could the Pu oxidation state (assumed 4+ for charge neutrality) be incorrect given that Pu commonly adopts 3+, 5+, or 6+?

K8Ga2O7 is computationally known with zero Pauling violations (0/14) and perfect charge neutrality, yet all three worst BVS sites are oxygens at -1.302 v.u. (34.9% underbonded). This material is structurally analogous to Rb8Al2O7 (also in this batch, SG 14 monoclinic), which shows a dramatically worse 57.1% Pauling violation rate despite the same A8B2O7 stoichiometry. Given that K+ (1.38 A) is smaller than Rb+ (1.52 A) while Ga3+ (0.62 A) is larger than Al3+ (0.535 A), does the better size matching in K8Ga2O7 explain why it achieves zero Pauling violations while its structural twin Rb8Al2O7 fails spectacularly?

Sr10Mn5O19 is computationally known with mixed valence and a severe charge imbalance of -3.0, while its oxygen sites show the largest BVS deviations in this batch (BVS -1.236, deviation 38.2%). Across its 5-member Sr-Mn-O family, charge neutrality failures are pervasive: Sr16Mn8O31 (-6.0), SrMn8O16 (-6.0), and Sr10Mn5O19 (-3.0), while only SrMn5O11 and Sr4Mn2O7 achieve neutrality. With both oxi methods agreeing, why does a computationally established compound show such extreme charge imbalance -- could the mixed Mn valence (Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+) be misassigned, and would allowing Mn to access all three common oxidation states simultaneously resolve the -3.0 residual?

Cs4Rb2O3 belongs to a remarkable 5-member all-novel Cs-Rb-O family spanning diverse stoichiometries (CsRb2O, Cs2Rb4O3, Cs4Rb2O3, Cs5RbO2, Cs5RbO3), yet three members (CsRb2O, Cs5RbO2, CsRb5O2) have null GII and null charge -- meaning BVS could not even be computed. Among the computable members, GII ranges from 0.473 (Cs5RbO3) to 0.587 (Cs2Rb4O3). Given that binary Cs-O and Rb-O compounds are already rare experimentally, does the prediction of five novel ternary Cs-Rb-O phases represent a genuine chemical space that GNoME has discovered, or an artifact of the training data having insufficient examples of heavy alkali oxides to constrain predictions?

Y7VO12 is a novel trigonal (R-3, SG 148) compound with zero Pauling violations, perfect charge neutrality, and a deeply negative formation energy (-3.800 eV/atom), yet vanadium is dramatically underbonded (BVS 2.235 vs expected V3+, deviation 25.5%) and yttrium likewise (BVS 2.382 vs expected Y3+, deviation 20.6%). The most common experimental space group for Y-V-O is Fd-3m (227, 33%), a fluorite-related cubic phase.
