Could Y7VO12 represent a rhombohedral distortion of the fluorite structure where the V3+ ion, being unusually large for vanadium, creates local strain that lowers symmetry from cubic to trigonal while maintaining topological connectivity?

Ca3C3O is a novel mixed-valence compound with a highly unusual 3:1 carbon-to-oxygen ratio and a positive charge imbalance (+1.0) -- one of the few materials in the dataset with excess positive charge. The BVS results are extraordinary: Ca is underbonded at 1.139 vs expected 2+ (43.1% deviation), and carbon shows BVS of -1.484 vs expected C1- (48.4% deviation). With a formation energy of only -1.007 eV/atom and only 7 atoms in the unit cell, does this compound represent a calcium carbide-oxide hybrid where the carbon atoms form C-C bonded units (like C2^2- acetylide ions) that the BVS formalism fundamentally cannot evaluate because it assumes purely ionic bonding?

Rb2I4O11 is a computationally known oxyhalide with 72.7% Pauling Rule 2 violations (16/22 bonds) and a Pauling warning flag, yet it achieves perfect charge neutrality and has a substantial bandgap of 2.856 eV. Its iodine sites show uniform BVS of 4.267 vs expected I5+ (14.7% deviation). The family shows a dramatic compositional swing: Rb6I4O has only 1 oxygen with GII 0.580, while Rb2I4O11 has 11 oxygens. Should the high Pauling violation rate be interpreted differently for iodate-containing structures where I5+ forms IO3- pyramidal units with inherently asymmetric bond distributions, rather than the symmetric coordination assumed by the electrostatic valence rule?

PrNb10O18 is a novel 58-atom structure where both oxi methods disagree (the lowest confidence tier), resulting in catastrophic charge neutrality failure (residual -6.0) and the most severe Pr underbonding in the batch (BVS 1.547 vs expected 3+, deviation 48.4%). Meanwhile, Nb shows contradictory behavior: one Nb site has BVS 4.203 vs expected Nb3+ (overbonded by 40.1%), suggesting it should actually be Nb5+. With zero Pauling violations across 36 bonds and a small but nonzero Shannon violation (0.035), is this a case where the oxidation state assignment is so fundamentally wrong that all downstream validators become unreliable, and could reassigning Nb as Nb5+ with Pr3+ yield a charge-balanced formula?

V2NiO5 is a novel pure oxide with zero Pauling violations (0/10), perfect charge neutrality, and all vanadium sites showing nearly identical BVS (3.329-3.330 vs expected V4+, deviation 16.7-16.8%). Its sole family member VNi5O8 is also novel but has charge -2.0 and worse GII (0.564). Given the remarkably uniform V4+ underbonding and the moderate GII of 0.501, could V2NiO5 represent a genuinely synthesizable new vanadate where the systematic 17% V underbonding reflects an expanded V-O bond length characteristic of V4+ in unusual coordination, perhaps analogous to the V4+ environments seen in vanadium bronze structures?

Y5Cr2O12 is computationally known but fails charge neutrality (residual -1.0) with single-method oxi assignment, and Cr shows BVS 3.297 vs expected Cr4+ (deviation 17.6%). Its family members Y3Cr7O24 (charge -4.0, GII 0.468) and Y2Cr3O8 (charge -1.0, GII 0.449) also fail neutrality. Notably, this is structurally parallel to Dy5Cr2O12 in the Dy-Cr-O family (material 408c1aff84), which also shows charge -1.0 and GII 0.414. Does the persistent -1.0 charge across both RE5Cr2O12 compositions (RE = Y, Dy) indicate a systematic oxidation state misassignment for Cr in this structure type, where Cr should be assigned 3.5+ (mixed Cr3+/Cr4+) rather than a single integer value?

Nd6MoO12 is computationally known in R-3 (SG 148) with zero Pauling violations and perfect charge neutrality, yet Mo is severely underbonded (BVS 4.772 vs expected Mo6+, deviation 20.5%). Strikingly, its family member Nd2Mo5O18 achieves a GII of only 0.181 -- among the best in the entire dataset -- with charge neutrality in Pbcn symmetry. The 5:1 Mo ratio difference between these compounds (Nd6MoO12 has Mo:Nd = 1:6 vs Nd2Mo5O18 at 5:2) suggests that dilute Mo in a rare earth oxide matrix is inherently strained. Is the 20% Mo underbonding in Nd6MoO12 evidence that isolated MoO6 octahedra in a Nd-rich matrix cannot achieve optimal Mo-O distances because the lattice parameters are dictated by the dominant Nd-O framework?

Pu(BrO4)2 is a novel oxyhalide perbromate with 75% Pauling Rule 2 violations (12/16 bonds) and a Pauling warning, yet achieves charge neutrality and passes Shannon radii checks. The oxygen BVS is uniformly -1.501 vs expected -2 (24.9% underbonding), and the near-zero bandgap (0.128 eV) is anomalous for a compound containing nominally Br7+ perbromate groups, which should be strongly oxidizing insulators. Given that perbromate (BrO4-) is one of the most powerful oxidizing agents known and is extremely rare even in aqueous chemistry, is the prediction of a solid-state plutonium perbromate physically plausible, or does the combination of actinide and perbromate represent a chemical space where GNoME has extrapolated far beyond its training data?

KU3O9 is a novel uranium oxide in hexagonal P6mm (SG 183) that fails charge neutrality (residual -2.0) with single-method oxi assignment, while all three worst BVS sites are uranium showing an unusual pattern: U is overbonded at 6.022, 5.972, and 5.963 vs expected U5+ (19-20% excess). Its family members K3UO4 (GII 0.314, charge neutral) and K6UO6 (GII 0.319, charge neutral) both achieve good structural quality. Given that U commonly adopts U6+ in uranyl (UO2)2+ environments, could reassigning uranium as U6+ simultaneously resolve the charge imbalance (3 x U6+ + K+ = +19, vs 18 from 9 x O2-) and reduce the BVS overbonding, suggesting the true composition is closer to a potassium uranate?

Sm3Os2O9 carries a residual charge of -2.0 despite both Sm-Os-O family members (Sm2OsO5 with GII 0.436, Sm(OsO3)3 with GII 0.309) achieving perfect charge neutrality -- why does this specific Sm:Os 3:2 stoichiometry uniquely fail charge balance when the oxi state assignment relies on only a single method (oxi_state_guesses), and could an alternative Os oxidation state (e.g., Os6+ instead of Os8+) resolve both the charge deficit and the systematic ~19% BVS undervaluation of Sm (BVS 2.42 vs expected 3)?

The Sr-Os-O family reveals a striking pattern: novel compounds with correct stoichiometry (SrOsO5, GII 0.299; Sr3(OsO5)2, GII 0.435) achieve charge neutrality, while computationally known phases Sr2(OsO3)3 and Sr(OsO3)3 carry large charge deficits of -4.0 and -2.0 respectively -- does this suggest GNoME preferentially discovers charge-balanced Sr-Os-O stoichiometries that DFT databases miss, and does the Sr BVS of 0.728 (64% deviation from expected 2+) in Sr5(OsO6)2 indicate a severely underbonded A-site that would destabilize this tetragonal structure?

Bi5Sb3O14 is flagged as mixed-valence with both methods agreeing on the oxi states, yet it still fails charge neutrality (residual -1.0) -- critically, the Sb BVS values split dramatically between 2.41 and 5.21, suggesting the assigned Sb4+ oxidation state is physically unrealistic and the structure actually contains Sb3+/Sb5+ disproportionation, which would explain both the anomalous BVS deviations (40% and 30%) and why 6 of 8 Bi-Sb-O family members also fail charge neutrality with deficits ranging from -1 to -7?

Sc2Cr3O12 passes every Tier 1 check perfectly (charge neutrality 0.0, Shannon 0.0, Pauling 0.0 across all 24 bonds) yet is novel and adopts triclinic P-1 (SG 2) rather than the experimentally expected orthorhombic Pnma (SG 62, 100% prevalence) -- given this near-flawless classical chemistry profile with a 2.28 eV bandgap, could this represent a metastable polymorph of a Cr6+ chromate where the triclinic distortion lowers symmetry to accommodate the 16.9% Cr BVS deficit (4.99 vs expected 6)?

V2PbO5 achieves perfect charge neutrality and Shannon compliance yet exhibits 40% Pauling Rule 2 violations (4 of 10 bonds) -- the worst case among all novel vanadates in this batch -- while every V site shows a consistent ~17% BVS deficit (3.33 vs expected 4+), suggesting systematically elongated V-O bonds; does the Pb2+ lone pair stereoactivity in orthorhombic Pmmn (SG 59) distort the vanadate polyhedra enough to drive these coordinated Pauling violations that are absent in the structurally simpler Pr2VO5 (0% Pauling violations)?

Pr7LuO12 passes all Tier 1 checks flawlessly (charge 0.0, Shannon 0.0, Pauling 0.0/12) in trigonal R-3 (SG 148) despite having no experimental precedent for this symmetry (100% of known RE sesquioxides adopt Pnma, SG 62) -- with an exceptionally high formation energy of -3.79 eV/atom and its sole family member Pr3LuO6 (R-3, GII 0.477) sharing the same space group, does the 7:1 Pr:Lu ratio create a fluorite-derivative superstructure where the 22% Pr BVS deficit (2.34 vs 3+) reflects the large coordination numbers typical of fluorite-type RE oxide ordering?

ThAs2O7 achieves a remarkably clean validation profile (charge 0.0, Pauling 0.0/14, Shannon 0.0) with both oxi methods agreeing, yet the As BVS of 5.85 exceeds the expected 5+ by 17% across all three symmetry-equivalent sites -- given that the computationally known family member Th2As2O9 in Cmce achieves a much lower GII of 0.245, does the orthorhombic Pnnm (SG 58) structure compress the AsO4 tetrahedra, and would this overbonding make ThAs2O7 a candidate high-pressure arsenate phase?

Sr12V8O27 simultaneously fails on three fronts: -6.0 charge residual, methods_disagree oxi confidence, and oxygen BVS of -1.23 (39% underbonded vs expected -2) -- yet the entire Sr-V-O family (Sr5V3O11, Sr4V6O19, Sr10V6O25) achieves perfect charge neutrality with GII values of 0.554, 0.406, and 0.596; does the unusual 12:8:27 stoichiometry (non-integer Sr:V:O ratios suggest a superstructure) indicate this is actually a defect structure or intergrowth that GNoME's graph neural network generated by interpolating between the charge-neutral family end-members?

Y5Mn2O12 is computationally known yet fails charge neutrality (residual -1.0) with only single-method oxi assignment (oxi_state_guesses), and the Y BVS deficit of 25.6% (2.23 vs 3+) is the largest among all rare-earth sites in this batch -- given that the assigned Mn4+ gives BVS of 3.37 (16% deficit), would reassigning manganese as Mn3+ (high-spin d4) resolve the charge imbalance while also explaining the near-zero bandgap (0.003 eV) through Jahn-Teller-driven metallic behavior?

CaNb10O18 has the largest charge deficit in this batch (-8.0) despite both oxi methods agreeing on the state assignment -- the Ca BVS of 0.78 represents a 61% deviation from the expected 2+, one of the most extreme underbonding values observed, while Nb shows BVS of 4.22 against expected 3+ (41% overbonded); with 58 sites, 36 bonds checked, and mixed valence flagged, could this massive 8-electron surplus indicate that the true Nb oxidation states span Nb3+ through Nb5+ in an ordered fashion that the simple oxi_state_guesses method cannot capture?

The Sn-Pb-O family presents a systematic pattern failure: all 5 family members are novel and 4 of 5 fail charge neutrality (deficits from -1 to -8), yet every member adopts the same Pm space group -- the parent Sn3Pb3O8 shows a dramatic Sn BVS split (1.63 vs 3.60 against expected 3+, a 46% vs 20% deviation) consistent with Sn2+/Sn4+ mixed valence rather than uniform Sn3+; does this entire Sn-Pb-O family represent GNoME discovering a series of structurally related but electrochemically unstable tin-lead oxides?

La3Ta8O24 is computationally known yet shows a -7.0 charge residual with methods_disagree oxi confidence and mixed valence flagged -- the Ta BVS of 4.89 against expected 4+ (22% overbonded) suggests tantalum is closer to Ta5+ than the assigned Ta4+, and reassigning to Ta5+ would give La3Ta8O24 -> La3(3+)Ta8(5+)O24(2-) = +9+40-48 = +1, still imbalanced; does this persistent charge mismatch across multiple oxi state assignments indicate a fundamental stoichiometry error in the GNoME prediction rather than an oxidation state problem?

Cr3In2O12 is a novel trigonal R-3 (SG 148) garnet-type oxide that passes every Tier 1 check perfectly (charge 0.0, Shannon 0.0, Pauling 0.0/24) with both oxi methods in agreement -- the systematic Cr BVS of 5.06 vs expected 6+ (15.7% deficit identical across all three Cr sites) mirrors the Sc2Cr3O12 pattern (Cr BVS 4.99, same 16.9% deficit, same SG 148); does this consistent Cr6+ underbonding across multiple novel chromates in R-3 reflect a systematic bias in the BVS reference parameters for Cr6+-O rather than a structural deficiency?

Sr8(CoO3)7 carries the most extreme charge deficit in this batch (-10.0) with Co BVS of 1.79 (40% deficit from expected 3+) and a massive 72-site unit cell -- yet the Sr-Co-O family shows a clear bifurcation where Co-rich phases (Sr(CoO2)2 GII 0.316, Sr(CoO2)3 GII 0.289) achieve reasonable GII despite their own charge failures, while Sr-rich phases (Sr6Co5O16 GII 0.640, Sr9(CoO3)7 GII 0.525) show structural strain; does this 10-electron surplus indicate the single-method oxi assignment is forcing Co3+ when the true ground state requires mixed Co2+/Co3+ or even Co4+ to approach charge balance?

Mg(PtO3)2 passes all Tier 1 checks (charge 0.0, Shannon 0.0, Pauling 0.0/12) with Mg slightly overbonded at BVS 2.49 vs expected 2+ (24% deviation) in tetragonal P4_2/mnm (SG 136), while its sole family member Mg(Pt3O4)4 has a drastically different structure (Fm-3, GII 0.547, charge -6.0) -- given that Pt4+ in octahedral coordination is well-established in PtO2 rutile, does the tetragonal rutile-type symmetry suggest Mg(PtO3)2 could be an experimentally synthesizable Mg-doped platinum oxide with photocatalytic applications, and would the Mg overbonding stabilize or destabilize this phase?

Ba5(TcO5)2 passes charge neutrality perfectly yet shows 40% Pauling Rule 2 violations (8 of 20 bonds) -- the highest among charge-neutral materials in this batch -- while Ba BVS of 1.14 (43% underbonded from expected 2+) is among the worst alkaline earth deviations observed; the Ba-Tc-O family reveals a striking GII gradient from 0.272 (Sr(TcO4)2, computationally known) to 0.660 (Ba(TcO4)2, computationally known), suggesting Ba2+ is simply too large for the technetate cage; does this extreme Ba underbonding predict that Ba5(TcO5)2 would decompose to the more stable Ba4Tc2O9 (GII 0.365)?

Cs3MoO4 achieves charge neutrality and passes Shannon checks yet shows the most extreme Pauling Rule 2 violation in this entire batch at 75% (12 of 16 bonds violated) -- given that the Mo BVS of 4.39 vs expected Mo5+ (12% deficit) and the formation energy of -1.94 eV/atom are both moderate, does this unprecedented Pauling violation rate indicate that the Cs+ ions (the largest common monovalent cation) force a coordination environment around Mo where electrostatic bond strength sums fundamentally cannot satisfy Pauling's second rule, making this a genuine structural novelty rather than a prediction error?

Sr2PuO5 is computationally known and achieves perfect charge neutrality with all Sr sites showing identical BVS of 1.44 (28% underbonded from expected 2+), while the Sr-Pu-O family spans 5 novel phases with GII values ranging from 0.307 (Sr5Pu5O19) to 0.957 (SrPu2O7) -- given the monoclinic P2_1/c (SG 14) structure versus the experimentally expected R-3m (SG 166), and the near-zero bandgap (0.004 eV), could this Sr2PuO5 polymorph be a metallic actinide oxide relevant to nuclear fuel behavior, where the consistent Sr underbonding reflects the large plutonium cation expanding the lattice?

CeSb2O7 is computationally known with both oxi methods agreeing on Ce4+, yet the Ce BVS of 5.07 (27% overbonded vs expected 4+) paired with O BVS of -2.71 (35% overbonded vs expected -2) suggests the structure is under compressive strain -- if Ce is actually in the Ce3+ state (reducing expected from 4 to 3, making BVS deviation 69%), the charge balance would shift from 0.0 to +1.0; does this BVS overbonding pattern specifically indicate that the orthorhombic Imma (SG 74) structure forces shorter Ce-O bonds than the experimentally preferred tetragonal phases (SG 85, 139), and should BVS deviations exceeding 25% trigger an automatic recheck of the assumed oxidation state?

K7Sc3O8 achieves perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across all 16 bonds with both oxi methods agreeing, yet shows oxygen BVS of -1.36 (32% underbonded from expected -2) and the highest bandgap in this batch at 2.79 eV -- the K-Sc-O family member K8Sc2O7 (computationally known, GII 0.537) shares this wide-bandgap insulating character; does the K:O ratio of 7:8 (nearly 1:1) suggest an anti-perovskite-like framework where the extreme oxygen underbonding reflects K+ ions partially substituting into oxide sites, creating a novel potassium scandate with potential solid-state electrolyte applications?

Sr4Tc2O9 is charge-neutral in hexagonal P6_3/m (SG 176) with Sr BVS of 1.34 (33% underbonded) and 33% Pauling violations, while its family member SrTc5O8 achieves a remarkably low GII of 0.104 -- the lowest in the entire Sr-Tc-O family by 2.6x -- despite a catastrophic charge deficit of -16.0; does this inverse correlation between structural quality (GII) and electrochemical validity (charge neutrality) across the Sr-Tc-O series indicate that GNoME optimizes for geometric relaxation at the expense of electronic consistency, and could Sr4Tc2O9 be a 6H-type hexagonal perovskite given its Ba:B:O = 2:1:4.5 ratio?

Nd4Zr3O12 achieves a flawless Tier 1 profile (charge 0.0, Shannon 0.0, Pauling 0.0/12) with the highest bandgap in this batch (3.96 eV) and the most negative formation energy (-3.84 eV/atom), yet adopts triclinic P-1 (SG 2) instead of the experimentally universal Fd-3m (SG 227, 100% prevalence for Nd-Zr-O) -- given that Nd4Zr3O12 has the Nd:Zr ratio of a pyrochlore-fluorite boundary composition (4:3 vs canonical 2:2), does this symmetry-breaking from cubic to triclinic represent an ordering transition at intermediate RE:Zr ratios that could affect oxide-ion conductivity in solid oxide fuel cell electrolytes?

Pr2VO5 is novel yet achieves the cleanest validation among all vanadates in this batch: perfect charge neutrality, zero Pauling violations across 20 bonds, Shannon compliance, space group match at 25% (Pnma SG 62), and a consistent V BVS of 3.23 across all sites (19% deficit from expected 4+) -- with a formation energy of -3.36 eV/atom and bandgap of 1.76 eV placing it in the visible-light absorption range, could Pr2VO5 in orthorhombic Pnma be a synthesizable photocatalyst analogous to BiVO4, where the moderate V4+ underbonding indicates slightly expanded VO4 tetrahedra favorable for polaron-mediated charge transport?

Sr16Mn8O31 has 55 sites, methods_disagree oxi confidence, mixed valence, and a -6.0 charge deficit, yet achieves zero Pauling violations across all 31 bonds -- this decoupling between perfect local bond-strength allocation and global charge failure is rare; the Sr-Mn-O family shows that every member has GII > 0.50 (range 0.414-0.606), suggesting systematic structural strain across the entire compositional space; does the non-stoichiometric oxygen content (31 vs 32 for charge balance) indicate an oxygen-vacancy-ordered superstructure where the 37% oxygen underbonding (BVS -1.26 vs -2) marks the vacancy-adjacent sites?

Ba2(OsO4)3 is computationally known yet fails charge neutrality (residual -2.0) with single-method oxi assignment and 50% Pauling violations (6 of 12 bonds) -- however, its Ba-Os-O family contains members with extraordinarily low GII values: Ba2(OsO3)3 at 0.045 and Ba4Os6O19 at 0.113, which are among the lowest GII values observed across the entire 3,262-material dataset; does the coexistence of near-perfect structures and highly strained ones (Ba3OsO7, GII 0.745) within a single chemical family suggest that osmium's flexible oxidation states (Os4+ through Os8+) create a rugged energy landscape where GNoME finds both deep minima and shallow local traps?

Y3MoO6 is charge-neutral and passes all Tier 1 checks, yet its BVS analysis reveals Mo achieving only a BVS of 2.32 against an expected +3, a 22.6% deviation, while GNoME places it in trigonal SG 148 (R-3) despite experimental Y-Mo-O phases favoring SGs 12, 14, and 15 (all monoclinic). Could the large Mo under-bonding indicate that the predicted trigonal structure forces Mo into an unfavorable coordination geometry that would destabilize the material under synthesis conditions?

Ba10V6O25 shows a Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 0.64 (16 of 25 bonds violating electrostatic valence balance) alongside systematic V under-bonding (BVS 4.33 vs expected +5, dev 13.4%), yet the related family member BaV6O12 in C2/m achieves a much lower GII of 0.376 with the same elements. Given that Ba10V6O25 has a 10:6 Ba:V ratio versus BaV6O12's 1:6, could the excess barium be creating over-coordinated oxygen sites that simultaneously explain the high Pauling violations and the V under-bonding?

Pr4Mn6O19 carries a residual charge of -2.0 despite being a computationally known phase, and its worst BVS deviation occurs on oxygen (BVS -1.25 vs expected -2, dev 37.6%), suggesting extreme oxygen under-bonding. Meanwhile, its family member Pr5Mn2O12 also fails charge neutrality (charge -1.0) with a higher GII of 0.504. Given that oxi states were assigned by only a single method (oxi_state_guesses), is the charge failure driven by Mn being assigned +4 when a mixed Mn3+/Mn4+ assignment would better satisfy both charge balance and the observed oxygen BVS deficiency?

LaNb10O18 presents a severe identity crisis: oxi state methods disagree (both_disagree), it has mixed valence, residual charge is -6.0, and La shows a BVS of only 1.74 against an expected +3 (42.1% deviation), while one Nb site achieves a BVS of 4.19 against an expected +3 (39.8% over-bonded). With 58 sites and 36 Pauling bonds all passing Rule 2, could the disagreement stem from Nb genuinely occupying multiple oxidation states (+3/+5) in a way that the automated assignment methods cannot resolve, and does the extreme La under-bonding suggest La sits in an oversized cavity created by the Nb-O framework?

Pr3LuO6 passes every Tier 1 check perfectly (charge neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across 12 bonds) yet shows systematic Pr under-bonding at BVS 2.38 vs expected +3 (dev 20.7%) uniformly across all three Pr sites, while its family member Pr7LuO12 in the same SG R-3 has a slightly higher GII of 0.496. Given that GNoME predicts SG 148 but 100% of experimental Pr-Lu-O phases adopt SG 62 (Pnma), could the trigonal structure artificially expand the Pr-O distances relative to the orthorhombic ground state, and would a Pnma polymorph reduce the uniform Pr under-bonding?

Rb8Tl2O7 passes charge neutrality and all Pauling checks (0 of 14 bonds violating), yet Rb shows catastrophic under-bonding with a BVS of only 0.40 against expected +1 (60.3% deviation) uniformly across multiple Rb sites. This is among the most extreme alkali under-bonding in the dataset. For a novel material with both oxi methods agreeing, how can the electrostatic valence sums (Pauling Rule 2) be perfectly satisfied while the actual bond lengths produce Rb-O bonds delivering barely 40% of the expected valence contribution — does this indicate the predicted structure has unrealistically large Rb-O distances?

K6Be2O5 achieves charge neutrality and zero Shannon violations, but 100% of its 10 Pauling bonds violate electrostatic valence balance, and all three worst BVS deviations are oxygen sites with BVS -1.39 vs expected -2 (30.5% deviation). Known K-Be-O phases adopt monoclinic SGs 14 and 15 (50% each), yet GNoME predicts tetragonal SG 136 (P42/mnm). Could the high-symmetry tetragonal structure be forcing oxygen into coordination environments that are fundamentally incompatible with the Be tetrahedral bonding requirement, explaining both the total Pauling failure and the systematic oxygen under-bonding?

Y3WO7 shows a striking split in Y-site bonding: two symmetry-equivalent Y sites have BVS 1.94 (dev 35.3% from expected +3) while a third Y site achieves BVS 2.53 (dev 15.8%), despite both oxi methods agreeing on the oxidation states. With a formation energy of -3.46 eV/atom and a 2.43 eV bandgap suggesting an insulating ground state, could the two severely under-bonded Y sites indicate a structural instability where Y would prefer to migrate to the better-bonded position, potentially driving a phase transformation to a denser polymorph with more uniform Y coordination?

YSO is classified as an oxychalcogenide, and its Pauling Rule 2 check shows 100% violation (4 of 4 bonds failing) with a warning flag, while BVS reports Y at 2.33 vs expected +3 (22.4% deviation). Its Y-S-O family contains Y(S8O)3 with a GII of 1.241 and charge -3.0, one of the highest GII values in the family set. Since the BVS parameters and Pauling bond strength calculations assume O2- for all anions, how much of the apparent validation failure is an artifact of applying pure-oxide reference parameters to a structure where S2- occupies distinct anion sites with different bond-valence parameters than oxygen?

Gd2Mn2O7 adopts the pyrochlore structure (cubic SG 227, Fd-3m) yet experimental Gd-Mn-O phases are only found in SGs 55 and 62 (50% each, both lower symmetry). The BVS analysis reveals oxygen sites with BVS -2.85 (dev 42.5% over-bonded) while Mn achieves only BVS 3.34 vs expected +4 (dev 16.6%). In pyrochlore A2B2O7, the 8b oxygen (O') is linearly coordinated by two A-site cations. Could the anomalously over-bonded oxygen sites correspond to the O' position receiving excessive Gd3+ valence, and would this structural strain favor decomposition into the experimentally preferred lower-symmetry polymorphs?

Bi3(Rh2O7)2 fails charge neutrality with a residual of -4.0, assigned by only a single oxi method, and its BVS shows all three worst deviations on oxygen (BVS -1.34 vs expected -2, dev 32.9%). Its family member Bi2RhO6 achieves charge neutrality with GII 0.552. Bi commonly exhibits the 6s2 lone pair effect, adopting asymmetric coordination environments. Could the charge imbalance indicate that the automated assignment is forcing Bi3+ when a Bi5+ state on some sites would resolve the -4 charge residual, and would the resulting shorter Bi5+-O bonds also correct the severe oxygen under-bonding?

Cs5RbO3 belongs to an extensive Cs-Rb-O family of 5 novel compounds spanning Cs:Rb ratios from 5:1 (Cs5RbO2) to 1:5 (CsRb5O2), all novel, with GII values increasing from null (Cs5RbO2) through 0.473 (this material) to 0.587 (Cs2Rb4O3). The BVS reveals oxygen under-bonding at BVS -1.32 to -1.34 (dev 33%), typical of heavy-alkali suboxides. Does the systematic GII increase with Rb enrichment across this family reflect a fundamental size-mismatch penalty where the smaller Rb+ (1.52 A) creates progressively more strained Rb-O bonds compared to Cs+ (1.67 A), suggesting a compositional stability limit in this suboxide family?

Sm5(IrO6)2 is computationally known but has methods_disagree oxi confidence, mixed valence, and a -1.0 charge residual. Ir achieves a BVS of 4.98 against an assigned +4 (24.4% over-bonded), strongly suggesting Ir is actually closer to +5. Its family member Sm2Ir2O7 (pyrochlore, Fd-3m) is charge-neutral with a much lower GII of 0.259, while the Ir-rich member SmIr5O13 has GII 0.728 and charge -6.0. Given that Ir BVS overshoots +4 by nearly a full valence unit, is the true oxidation state assignment Ir4.5+ (mixed Ir4+/Ir5+), which would resolve the charge imbalance and explain why the oxi state methods cannot agree?

RbSc3O5 is computationally known, charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing, yet its worst BVS deviations are all on oxygen (BVS -1.275 vs expected -2, dev 36.2-36.3%), and its Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction is 0.20 (4 of 20 bonds). Within its Rb-Sc-O family, GII systematically increases with Rb content: RbSc3O5 at 0.472, Rb7Sc3O8 at 0.569, Rb8Sc2O7 at 0.640, and Rb17Sc5O16 at 0.623. Does this monotonic GII-composition trend validate bond valence analysis as a tool for mapping thermodynamic stability across a compositional series, and does it predict that only the Sc-rich end of this family is experimentally accessible?

Nd5Mn2O12 is computationally known and has a near-zero bandgap (0.0001 eV), yet its charge neutrality fails at -1.0 and oxi states come from only a single method. BVS shows Mn at 3.19 vs expected +4 (dev 20.4%) and Nd at 2.31 vs expected +3 (dev 23.1%), with both cation species significantly under-bonded. Experimental Nd-Mn-O phases adopt SGs 14, 55, and 62 (33% each), but GNoME predicts SG 12 (C2/m). Could the metallic-like near-zero bandgap indicate that this material should exhibit Mn3+/Mn4+ charge ordering, and does the uniform Mn under-bonding suggest the predicted structure lacks the Jahn-Teller distortions expected for Mn3+ octahedra?

Nd2VO5 is one of the rare cases where GNoME's predicted space group (62, Pnma) matches an experimental space group (33% of known Nd-V-O phases), giving a space group score of 0.333. It is charge-neutral, passes all Shannon and Pauling checks (0 of 20 bonds violating), yet V shows a uniform BVS of 3.26 against expected +4 (dev 18.4%) across all V sites. Could the 18.4% V under-bonding, despite the correct space group assignment, indicate that the predicted V-O bond lengths are systematically ~0.05 A too long, and would DFT relaxation at a higher level of theory (e.g., hybrid functionals) contract these bonds to match expected bond-valence parameters?

Y3Cr7O24 fails charge neutrality at -4.0, has oxi states from only a single method, and its worst BVS deviation shows Cr at 2.65 vs expected +5 (46.9% deviation) — nearly half the expected valence. Meanwhile its family members Y5Cr2O12 and Y2Cr3O8 also fail charge neutrality (both -1.0) but have much lower GII values (0.499 and 0.449). Is the extreme 46.9% Cr under-bonding evidence that the assigned Cr5+ state is incorrect, and that Cr actually adopts +3 (yielding BVS 2.65 close to 3, dev 11.7%), which would simultaneously require revising the stoichiometry interpretation and could explain the large charge residual?

Cr3(BiO6)2 passes all Tier 1 checks perfectly (charge neutral, zero Shannon and Pauling violations across 24 bonds) with both oxi methods agreeing, yet Cr shows a uniform BVS of 5.00 against expected +6 (dev 16.6%). Its family member Cr3(BiO4)2 is computationally known with a lower GII of 0.404 but carries charge -1.0. Given that Cr6+ in tetrahedral CrO4 coordination is well-established in chromates, could the BVS shortfall of exactly 1.0 valence unit on Cr indicate that one of the six Cr-O bonds in the octahedral coordination is anomalously long, and might the structure benefit from a distortion that creates tetrahedral Cr6+ sites?

Eu2Cl3O is an oxyhalide that fails charge neutrality at -4.0 (single-method oxi assignment) and shows 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation on only 4 checked bonds with a warning flag, while oxygen BVS is -1.40 vs expected -2 (dev 30.2%). Its family member Eu2ClO2 achieves a much lower GII of 0.248 despite also carrying charge -1.0. Since the BVS calculation only evaluates Eu-O bonds and ignores Eu-Cl bonds, and Pauling Rule 2 checks only 4 of the material's bonds, to what extent are these apparent failures artifacts of applying oxide-only validation to a structure where Cl- contributes significantly to cation coordination and charge balance?

KNb4O6 presents a paradox: Nb has a BVS of 3.01 against an assigned +2 (50.6% over-bonded), while being computationally known with charge residual -3.0. Across its 5-member K-Nb-O family, the charge-neutral members K5NbO5 (GII 0.422), K8Nb6O19 (GII 0.379), and KNb5O8 (GII 0.242) all show substantially lower GII than this material (0.468). The BVS of 3.01 is almost exactly +3, not +2. Is the oxidation state assignment of Nb2+ fundamentally incorrect for this structure, and would reassigning Nb to +3 or mixed +3/+5 resolve the charge residual and bring the BVS analysis into agreement with the 50.6% apparent deviation?

Ti2CO is a MXene-adjacent oxycarbide (computationally known) with an extensive 5-member Ti-C-O family spanning compositions from carbon-rich Ti10C8O (GII 0.371) to oxygen-rich Ti8CO12 (GII 0.356). Ti2CO itself shows BVS deviations of C at -4.79 vs expected -4 (dev 19.8%) and O at -1.58 vs expected -2 (dev 21.1%), while the carbon-rich extreme Ti6C4O achieves the lowest family GII of 0.186. Does the U-shaped GII trend across the Ti-C-O composition space (lowest at intermediate C:O ratios) suggest an optimal carbon-to-oxygen ratio for structural stability, and could Ti6C4O's remarkably low GII of 0.186 indicate it is the most synthesizable member of this MXene oxide family?

Cd2SeO5 is an oxychalcogenide that is charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing, yet Cd shows BVS of 1.23 and 1.33 against expected +2 (38.7% and 33.6% deviation), among the worst Cd under-bonding in the dataset. Its Pauling Rule 2 violation is 0.20 with a warning flag noting the non-oxide anion. Its family member CdSe2O7 achieves a much lower GII of 0.216 with charge neutrality. Given that Se6+ in selenate (SeO4)2- tetrahedra creates shorter Se-O bonds than typical metal-oxide bonds, could the Cd under-bonding reflect a structure where Cd2+ is competing with Se6+ for oxygen coordination, and would explicit inclusion of Cd-Se bond-valence parameters improve the BVS accuracy for this oxychalcogenide?

Nd5(IrO6)2 is isostructural with Sm5(IrO6)2 (both SG 12, C2/m, 19 sites) and shows nearly identical validation signatures: both have methods_disagree oxi confidence, mixed valence, charge -1.0, and Ir over-bonding (Nd variant: Ir BVS 4.85 vs +4, dev 21.3%; Sm variant: Ir BVS 4.98 vs +4, dev 24.4%). Both share a family member pattern with Ln_Ir5O13 (GII ~0.73, charge -6.0). Does the systematic Ir over-bonding increase from Nd (4.85) to Sm (4.98), tracking the lanthanide contraction, indicate that as the Ln3+ ionic radius decreases across the series, the IrO6 octahedra compress and progressively destabilize the Ln5(IrO6)2 structure type?

Ba5Mo3O11 is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations (0 of 11 bonds) and both oxi methods agreeing, yet its worst BVS deviations reveal oxygen under-bonding (BVS -1.37, dev 31.6%) and Mo under-bonding (BVS 3.38 vs +4, dev 15.4%). GNoME predicts tetragonal SG 123 (P4/mmm), but experimental Ba-Mo-O phases favor SGs 4, 62, and 88 (none tetragonal). Its family member Ba11Mo4O23 in SG P1 (triclinic) has a higher GII of 0.510. Could the predicted high-symmetry tetragonal structure represent a metastable high-temperature phase, and would lowering the symmetry to a monoclinic or orthorhombic cell allow the Mo-O and Ba-O bond lengths to relax independently, reducing the GII?

Mn3V3O11 is novel with mixed valence and a charge residual of -2.0, yet both oxi methods agree on the assignment. V shows systematic under-bonding at BVS 4.22-4.25 vs expected +5 (dev 15.0-15.5%), and the Pauling violation fraction is 0.182 (4 of 22 bonds failing). Its space group score of 0.30 (SG 2, P-1, matching 30% of experimental Mn-V-O phases) is among the higher matches in this batch. With its family member Mn2V4O13 achieving charge neutrality and a lower GII of 0.358, does the -2 charge residual in Mn3V3O11 indicate that the Mn2+/Mn3+ mixed-valence ratio is incorrectly partitioned, and would shifting one Mn from +2 to +3 simultaneously resolve the charge imbalance and explain the moderate V under-bonding through adjusted oxygen sharing?

Mn5SbO8 is charge-neutral-failing (residual -2.0) yet passes Shannon radii with a perfect 0.0 violation fraction. Both oxi-state methods agree, but the BVS reveals Sb sites at 4.295 v.u. versus an expected 5 (14.1% underbonded) and one Mn site at 1.369 v.u. versus expected 2 (31.6% underbonded). Its family member Mn4Sb2O9 achieves charge neutrality and a lower GII of 0.333. Could the stoichiometric shift from Mn4Sb2 to Mn5Sb1 be introducing a non-trivial mixed-valence Mn arrangement that destabilizes the Sb coordination environment, and does the monoclinic C2/c setting (SG 15) represent a distortion pathway from the trigonal P-3c1 parent?

Ti3C2O belongs to a five-member Ti-C-O family where all other members are computationally known, yet this novel compound is the only one where both oxi-state methods disagree. Its Pauling Rule 2 violation is 100% (1/1 checked), oxygen BVS is -1.497 versus expected -2 (25.2% deviation), and the charge residual is -1.0. Strikingly, its family spans GII from 0.186 (Ti6C4O) to 0.572 (Ti8C4O) with charge residuals from 0 to -8.0. Is GNoME interpolating into a Ti-C-O stoichiometry that physically corresponds to an MXene-like layered carbide rather than a conventional oxide, making the BVS O^2- reference state fundamentally inappropriate?

Ba3Eu4O9 is charge-neutral, passes Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 (0/9 violations), yet Ba sites show BVS of only 1.198 v.u. versus expected 2 (40.1% underbonded) and Eu sites at 2.316-2.330 versus expected 3 (22-23% underbonded). With both methods agreeing on Eu^3+ and no mixed valence, this systematic underbonding suggests the trigonal R32 (SG 155) structure places both cations in oversized coordination polyhedra. Could this material be a candidate for pressure-induced densification that would simultaneously improve both Ba and Eu bond valence sums toward their formal values?

Er(TcO4)3 passes charge neutrality, Shannon radii, and Pauling Rule 2 (0/24 violations) with only single-method oxi confidence. Its Er sites show BVS of 2.537 versus expected 3 (15.4% underbonded), while its family member Er6Tc16O has a dramatically different chemistry with GII of 1.643 — nearly 4x worse. Given that technetium pertechnetates (TcO4^-) are among the few well-characterized Tc compounds, does the relatively clean validation profile of Er(TcO4)3 (GII 0.463) suggest GNoME is successfully leveraging the known stability of the pertechnetate anion subunit even when predicting novel hexagonal (SG 176) arrangements?

Eu5Mn2O12 has a charge residual of -1.0 from single-method oxi assignment, with Eu BVS at 2.195 (26.8% underbonded vs expected 3) and Mn at 3.326 (16.8% underbonded vs expected 4). All 12 Pauling Rule 2 bonds pass, and Shannon radii show zero violations. The expected space groups for this family split evenly between SG 55 (Pbam) and SG 62 (Pnma), but GNoME predicts monoclinic C2/m (SG 12). Is the charge imbalance an artifact of assigning Mn^4+ when the structure actually accommodates Mn^3+ at some sites, and would a Mn^3+/Mn^4+ mixed-valence model restore neutrality while explaining the monoclinic distortion via Jahn-Teller active Mn^3+?

SrNb10O18 has the largest charge residual in this batch at -8.0, despite both oxi-state methods agreeing and confirming mixed valence. The BVS for Nb sites shows 4.187 versus expected 3 (39.6% overbonded), which is paradoxical: the structure is formally electron-rich (negative charge residual) yet Nb appears overbonded. With 58 sites and 0/36 Pauling Rule 2 violations, the local coordination geometry is well-formed. Could the oxi-state assignment be misidentifying Nb^3+ when the true state is Nb^5+ (which would give +52 cation charge vs -36 anion charge = +16, also unbalanced), suggesting SrNb10O18 occupies a stoichiometry that simply cannot achieve charge balance with any integer Nb oxidation state?

K3Cr4O8 is computationally known but has a charge residual of -2.0, with all four Cr sites showing identical BVS of 2.355 versus expected 3 (21.5% underbonded). Its K-Cr-O family spans four members with GII ranging from 0.346 (K5Cr2O7) to 0.536 (K6Cr2O7), and two of the four are novel. The oxi assignment uses only a single method (oxi_state_guesses). Given that chromium commonly adopts +3 and +6 oxidation states, could a mixed Cr^3+/Cr^6+ assignment — rather than uniform Cr^3+ — simultaneously resolve the charge imbalance and explain why the BVS is systematically low across all Cr sites?

Mn4Br7O is an oxyhalide with mixed valence where the lone oxygen shows BVS of -1.31 versus expected -2 (34.5% underbonded), the most severe O deviation in this batch. Its Pauling Rule 2 score of 1.0 (1/1 bond violated) carries a compound-class warning since the O^2- assumption may not hold for oxyhalides. The family member Mn4Br6O achieves charge neutrality with one fewer Br, suggesting the extra bromide in Mn4Br7O creates an impossible-to-balance stoichiometry. Does the extreme oxygen underbonding indicate that O is not in a traditional oxide role but rather occupies an interstitial site within a predominantly bromide framework, making BVS parameterized for oxide bonds structurally inappropriate?

La2Cr3O12 achieves the best space group match in this batch (score 0.2, matching SG 15 to expected SG 15 at 20% prevalence) while also passing charge neutrality, Shannon radii, and Pauling Rule 2. All three Cr sites show BVS of 5.07-5.085 versus expected 6 (15.2-15.5% underbonded), suggesting Cr^6+ in tetrahedral chromate coordination. With a formation energy of -2.441 eV/atom and 34 sites, this novel monoclinic structure has an unusually clean validation profile. Could La2Cr3O12 represent a La-chromate with the La2(CrO4)3 stoichiometry in an unreported C2/c polymorph, and does the systematic ~15% Cr underbonding reflect the known tendency of DFT to slightly over-expand Cr-O bonds in chromates?

Pr5(IrO6)2 is computationally known but has disagreeing oxi-state methods, mixed valence, and a charge residual of -1.0. The Ir BVS is 4.786 versus expected 4 (19.6% overbonded), while Pr shows 2.137 versus expected 3 (28.8% underbonded). Across its three-member Pr-Ir-O family, charge residuals are persistently -1.0 for two compounds, and GII values cluster tightly at 0.364-0.388. Does the systematic Pr underbonding across the family suggest that GNoME consistently underestimates Pr-O bond lengths in these iridates, or is the -1.0 charge residual indicating Ir^5+ rather than Ir^4+ at some sites — which would make the Ir overbonding even more pronounced?

Rb(OsO3)3 shows the most severe single-element BVS deviation in this batch: Rb at 0.54 v.u. versus expected 1 (46% underbonded). Despite being computationally known, it has a charge residual of -4.0 and single-method oxi confidence. Its five-member Rb-Os-O family shows a pattern: compounds with balanced Rb:Os ratios (Rb4Os2O9, Rb4OsO4, Rb3OsO5) achieve charge neutrality and lower GII (0.352-0.382), while Os-rich compositions (this compound, Rb(OsO4)2) fail. Is the extreme Rb underbonding evidence that GNoME's hexagonal SG 191 structure places Rb+ in a cavity far too large for its ionic radius, and does the family trend suggest that high Os:Rb ratios systematically produce structures where Rb cannot find adequate coordination?

Pr3WO7 passes charge neutrality, Shannon radii, and has only 14.3% Pauling Rule 2 violations, with both oxi-state methods in agreement. However, two of three Pr sites show 31.2% underbonding (BVS 2.065 vs expected 3), while the third Pr site is much closer at 15.5% deviation. Its family members PrWO4 (GII 0.300) and Pr2W2O7 (GII 0.425) both achieve charge neutrality. Given the known Ln3WO7 (Ln = lanthanide) fluorite-derivative family in experimental literature, does the orthorhombic Cmcm (SG 63) prediction represent a novel polymorph distinct from the reported C2221 structure, and could the severely underbonded Pr sites correspond to the large 8-coordinate cavities characteristic of defect-fluorite arrangements?

CsNb10O18 has the most extreme charge residual in this entire batch at -10.0, yet achieves the highest space group score (0.5) by matching its predicted SG 14 to the 50% expected P2_1/c. The Nb BVS of 4.116 versus expected 3 (37.2% overbonded) mirrors the pattern in its isostructural analog SrNb10O18 (Nb BVS 4.187, charge -8.0). Its family member CsNb3O8 achieves charge neutrality with GII of only 0.271, while the Nb-richer CsNb8O14 has charge residual of -12.0. Is the ANb10O18 stoichiometry (A = Cs, Sr) fundamentally incompatible with integer Nb oxidation states, and does the consistent Nb overbonding across both A-site variants indicate a metallic Nb-Nb bonding network that the ionic BVS model cannot capture?

Ti10Si6O has Shannon radii violations (score 0.4), the only material in this batch with a nonzero Shannon score besides itself. Both oxi methods disagree, it has mixed valence, charge residual of -6.0, and its single Pauling Rule 2 bond is violated (100%). Ti BVS reaches 3.007 versus expected 2 (50.3% overbonded) — the most severe overbonding in the batch. With only one oxygen atom among 17 sites, this is essentially a Ti-Si intermetallic with trace oxygen. Does the extreme Ti overbonding and Shannon radii failure indicate that the assigned Ti^2+ oxidation state is incorrect, and that this compound should be understood as a Nowotny silicide (Ti5Si3-type) with interstitial oxygen rather than a conventional oxide?

Pr3IO8 is an oxyhalide with disagreeing oxi methods, charge residual of -2.0, and a Pauling Rule 2 warning flag. The iodine BVS of 6.413 versus expected 5 (28.3% overbonded) suggests the I site is more highly coordinated than I^5+ typically demands, while one O site shows BVS of -2.464 (23.2% overbonded). Its family member PrIO4 (computationally known, charge neutral, GII 0.411) provides a reference point with balanced stoichiometry. Given that iodate chemistry (IO3^-) is well-established but IO4^- (periodate) less common in rare-earth compounds, is the oxi-state assignment treating I as +5 when the actual bonding environment supports I^7+ (periodate), which would shift the charge balance from -2.0 to 0.0 and explain the apparent I overbonding?

TcPb2O5 is charge-neutral, passes Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 (0/10 violations), with all three Pb sites showing BVS of 1.411-1.500 versus expected 2 (25-29.5% underbonded). Its family member Tc6Pb4O19 has a much higher GII of 0.624, while Tc4Pb4O13 is closer at 0.404. Given that Pb^2+ is a known lone-pair active cation whose asymmetric coordination often produces artificially low BVS values in symmetric models, could the systematic Pb underbonding be a signature of stereochemically active 6s^2 lone pairs creating asymmetric Pb-O environments that GNoME's DFT-relaxed structure partially captures but the BVS spherical-shell model underestimates?

Nd2TcO5 is computationally known, charge-neutral, and passes all Tier 1 checks with both oxi methods agreeing. Its GII of 0.456 is moderate, with all three Nd sites showing identical BVS of 2.464 (17.9% underbonded vs expected 3). Its family spans an enormous GII range: Nd6Tc16O at 1.621 (extreme) versus Nd(TcO4)3 at 0.389 and Nd2TcO6 at 0.366. The Nd6Tc16O outlier is also computationally known despite its extreme GII. Does the tetragonal I4/a (SG 87) structure of Nd2TcO5 represent an intermediate in Tc reduction from pertechnetate (TcO4^-, Tc^7+) down toward metallic Tc, and could the uniform Nd underbonding reflect a structural compromise needed to accommodate the unusual Tc^4+ oxidation state?

UMn3O6 is novel, charge-neutral, and passes Shannon radii with 0/12 Pauling violations, while both oxi methods agree. Yet all three symmetry-distinct Mn sites show severe, nearly identical underbonding: BVS of 1.278-1.288 versus expected 2 (35.6-36.1% underbonded). Its family member U2MnO6 achieves a much lower GII of 0.243 with balanced stoichiometry. The trigonal R3 (SG 146) structure with 20 sites suggests a polar space group. Could the systematic Mn underbonding indicate that U is absorbing excess bonding capacity (possibly U^5+ or U^6+ rather than U^4+), effectively starving the Mn sites of oxygen coordination, and does the polar R3 symmetry suggest ferroelectric potential in this actinide manganite?

Ce(MoO2)6 crystallizes in the lowest-symmetry space group in the batch (P1, SG 1, triclinic) and exhibits a striking internal contradiction: both oxi methods agree on the assignment with mixed valence, yet the charge residual is -3.0. The Ce BVS is 4.204 versus expected 3 (40.1% overbonded), suggesting Ce is actually closer to Ce^4+ than Ce^3+, while Mo sites show 2.357-2.440 versus expected 3 (18.7-21.4% underbonded). With no family members for comparison and 16.7% Pauling violations, does the Ce overbonding reveal that the true oxidation state is Ce^4+Mo^3+, and would reassigning Ce^4+ reduce the charge residual from -3.0 to -2.0 while explaining why the structure adopts the unusual P1 symmetry — the lowest possible — to accommodate the size mismatch between large Ce^4+ and underbonded Mo^3+?

Cs8(RuO3)3 is a novel 80-site structure where both oxi methods disagree, yet all three worst-BVS entries are oxygen at -1.397 versus expected -2 (30.2% underbonded), while the Ru and Cs BVS values are not even among the three worst. Its Cs-Ru-O family shows alarming GII values: Cs3RuO4 at 0.927 and Cs3RuO5 at 0.714, far above the ICSD baseline of ~0.2. The Cs3(RuO4)2 family member has null GII and charge, suggesting it could not even be computed. Is the systematic oxygen underbonding across all three reported O sites evidence that the Cs8(RuO3)3 structure has severely under-coordinated anions trapped in the large Cs-dominated voids, and does the family-wide pattern of extreme GII values suggest the entire Cs-Ru-O system is poorly described by the ionic bonding model?

Eu4Zr3O12 passes all Tier 1 checks (charge neutrality 0.0, Shannon 0.0, Pauling 0/12 violations) with both oxi methods agreeing, making it one of the cleanest-validating materials in this batch. Its GII of 0.454 is driven by Zr underbonding at 3.249-3.297 versus expected 4 (17.6-18.8%). Both family members (Eu4Zr4O15, Eu6ZrO12) have null GII and charge values, meaning they could not be validated at all. With a formation energy of -3.544 eV/atom — the most negative in this batch — and triclinic P-1 symmetry, could Eu4Zr3O12 be a promising candidate for thermal barrier coating applications given that Eu2Zr2O7 pyrochlore is already used in this role, and does the Zr underbonding suggest potential for oxygen vacancy ordering that would further reduce thermal conductivity?

Eu2VO5 has a reported bandgap of Infinity — a unique computational artifact in this batch — alongside a charge residual of -4.0, disagreeing oxi methods, and the highest Pauling Rule 2 violation rate (40%, 8/20 bonds) among pure oxides here. All V sites show BVS of 4.020 versus expected 5 (19.6% underbonded). Its family member EuV3O9 achieves charge neutrality with GII 0.324, suggesting the 2:1 Eu:V ratio is problematic. Given that Eu can adopt both +2 and +3 oxidation states, could the -4.0 charge residual and infinite bandgap artifact both stem from an incorrect Eu^2+ assignment when Eu^3+ would reduce the residual, and does the 40% Pauling violation rate indicate that V^5+ tetrahedral coordination is being disrupted by the large orthorhombic Pnma unit cell (32 sites)?

Ag2PO4 has a charge residual of -4.0 despite both oxi methods agreeing, with all three P sites showing BVS of 6.070-6.083 versus expected 5 (21.4-21.7% overbonded). The mixed-valence flag is set, suggesting Ag^1+/Ag^3+ coexistence. Its family spans GII values from 0.524 (Ag5(P2O7)2) to 0.822 (AgP4O11), all higher than this compound's 0.451. Since P^5+ in tetrahedral PO4 coordination typically gives BVS very close to 5.0 in well-determined structures, does the systematic ~21% P overbonding indicate that the GNoME-predicted P-O distances are ~4% too short, and could this be a systematic DFT-GGA error in predicting phosphate bond lengths that would affect all phosphorus-containing GNoME predictions?

Pr2Mo2O7 passes all Tier 1 checks (charge 0.0, Shannon 0.0, Pauling 0/14) with both oxi methods agreeing and no mixed valence, yielding one of the cleanest profiles in this batch. The GII of 0.449 is driven entirely by Mo at 3.418 versus expected 4 (14.5% underbonded). The tetragonal I4_1/a (SG 88) structure is notable because the expected space groups for RE2Mo2O7 pyrochlores include SG 87 (I4/a) at 25% — very close but subtly different in screw axis. With its family member Pr6MoO12 showing higher GII (0.520), does the 2:2:7 stoichiometry represent the sweet spot for the Pr-Mo-O system, and is GNoME predicting a tetragonal distortion of the cubic pyrochlore (SG 227) that would be consistent with radiation-damage-induced transformations observed experimentally in related RE2Mo2O7 compounds?

Y2Cr3O8 has disagreeing oxi methods, mixed valence, and a charge residual of -1.0, yet passes Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 (0/8 violations). The worst BVS entries include both Cr at 2.396 (20.1% underbonded vs expected 3) and O at -1.485 (25.8% underbonded vs expected -2), suggesting simultaneous cation and anion bond-valence distress. Its family member Y3Cr7O24 has a -4.0 charge residual, while Y5Cr2O12 has -1.0 — the same persistent -1.0 offset. Given that Cr commonly takes +3 and +6 oxidation states, is the recurring -1.0 residual across the Y-Cr-O family evidence of a systematic half-electron-per-formula-unit error in the oxi-state guessing algorithm when applied to mixed-valence chromium compounds, and would explicit Cr^3+/Cr^6+ partitioning resolve the family-wide charge imbalance?

Cs5V3O10 shows all V sites with BVS of 4.32 against an expected +5, yielding a 13.6% deviation -- could this systematic underbonding indicate that GNoME's predicted V-O bond lengths are uniformly too long, and does the family member Cs3V7O16 (GII 0.60, charge residual -1.0) suggest that Cs-V-O compositions generically struggle with V coordination in the GNoME predictions?

Y2OF4 is an oxyhalide where the Pauling Rule 2 check only examined 2 bonds (with a warning flag) and all Y sites show BVS of 2.29 vs. expected +3 (23.6% deviation) -- given that BVS parameters are calibrated for pure oxide environments, how much of this apparent underbonding is an artifact of applying O-based BVS reference values to a mixed O/F anion coordination shell?

Bi4(AuO4)3 is a novel cubic (SG 204) material with a near-zero bandgap of 0.005 eV and oxi states assigned only by a single method (oxi_state_guesses), yet it achieves perfect charge neutrality and zero Shannon violations -- is the nearly metallic character physically plausible for a Bi-Au oxide, or does the single-method oxi assignment (likely Au3+ rather than the more exotic Au5+) mask an incorrect electronic picture?

In13(MoO8)3 has a charge residual of -13.0 (the largest magnitude in this batch) and both oxi state methods disagree, while Mo sites show BVS of ~2.4 against an expected +3 -- with 40 sites in triclinic P1, does this massive charge imbalance indicate that GNoME generated a fundamentally unphysical stoichiometry, or could the disagreeing oxi methods be assigning wrong states to the unusual In:Mo ratio of 13:3?

Ce4As3O4 shows mixed valence with both methods agreeing on oxi states, yet As sites exhibit BVS of -1.72 and -1.59 against expected -1 (59-72% deviation) and charge residual is +1.0 -- given that the family member CeAs2O7 is charge-neutral with GII 0.532, does the anomalous As bonding in Ce4As3O4 suggest GNoME predicted As in an environment intermediate between As3- arsenide and As5+ arsenate character?

Ba2Np2O7 belongs to a Ba-Np-O family of 4 members spanning compositions from BaNp2O7 (GII 0.66) to Ba10Np3O22 (GII null) -- the systematic Ba underbonding (BVS 1.43 vs. expected +2, 28.4% deviation) across the parent compound suggests Ba2+ is consistently undercoordinated; could this family-wide pattern indicate that GNoME systematically underestimates Ba-O bond lengths in neptunium oxide frameworks?

Bi2SbO6 has a charge residual of -3.0 and Bi sites show BVS of 4.23 vs. expected +3 (40.9% overbonding), yet it belongs to a family of 8 Bi-Sb-O compounds where GII values systematically increase as Bi:Sb ratio rises (Bi2Sb4O13 GII 0.324 vs. Bi7SbO16 GII 0.904) -- does this trend reveal that GNoME's structural predictions degrade specifically when Bi3+ lone-pair stereochemistry must dominate the structure?

RbNb10O18 has a charge residual of -10.0 with Nb BVS of 4.17 vs. expected +3 (38.9% overbonding), yet charge-neutral family members RbNb5O8 (GII 0.247) and RbNb3O8 (GII 0.279) exist with excellent structural quality -- why does GNoME produce a well-validated structure at Rb:Nb ratios of 1:5 and 1:3 but fail catastrophically at 1:10, and does the extreme Nb-rich stoichiometry force unphysical coordination environments?

HoNb7O12 is novel trigonal (R3, SG 146) with charge-neutral oxi states agreed by both methods, yet one Nb site has BVS 4.06 (35.4% over expected +3) while two others show 2.38 (20.7% under) -- does this bimodal Nb bonding distribution indicate that GNoME is predicting a structure with two crystallographically distinct Nb environments that may correspond to incipient charge disproportionation (Nb2+/Nb4+)?

Al6Cd4O13 is a novel cubic (SG 217, I-43m) material where the worst BVS deviation is on oxygen itself (BVS -0.98 vs. expected -2, a 50.8% deviation) and Cd shows BVS 1.11 vs. expected +2 (44.5% deviation) -- could such extreme underbonding of both cation and anion sublattices in a high-symmetry cubic structure indicate that GNoME predicted an expanded, porous framework with anomalously long bond lengths throughout?

YNb7O12 and HoNb7O12 (db4d33d409) share the identical formula type LnNb7O12, both adopt trigonal SG 146 (R3), and display strikingly similar BVS patterns -- one Nb at ~4.05 and two at ~2.37 -- suggesting GNoME found the same structural prototype for both; does this reproducibility across rare earths (Y3+ = 0.90 A, Ho3+ = 0.90 A, nearly identical radii) validate the prediction, or merely reflect a single erroneous template propagated through the training data?

NdTi2O5 is computationally known with mixed valence and disagreeing oxi methods, yet achieves perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across 20 bonds -- given that the Ti BVS of 3.10 vs. expected +4 (22.6% deviation) is consistent across all Ti sites, could the methods_disagree flag indicate genuine ambiguity between Ti3+/Ti4+ mixed valence assignments rather than a methodological failure?

Na5Ir3O8 is novel with a charge residual of -2.0, and all Ir sites show BVS 3.92 vs. expected +3 (30.6% overbonding) -- notably, 4 of 6 Na-Ir-O family members have null GII values (suggesting BVS parameters are unavailable), while the two that compute show GII of 0.184 (Na2Ir2O7) and 0.28 (Na6IrO6); does the systematic Ir overbonding suggest that Ir is actually in the +4 state rather than the assigned +3, which would resolve the charge imbalance (Na5Ir3(4+)O8 = +5+12-16 = +1)?

Ba5(SbO5)2 is computationally known in hexagonal SG 194, with all Sb sites showing BVS 3.86 vs. expected +5 (22.8% deviation) and a small 10% Pauling violation rate -- given that experimental Ba-Sb oxides predominantly adopt monoclinic (SG 14, 33%) or triclinic (SG 2, 17%) symmetry, does the hexagonal prediction represent a genuinely distinct high-symmetry polymorph, or an artifact of GNoME favoring higher symmetry?

Tm2Cr3O12 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality, zero Pauling violations across 24 bonds, and Cr BVS of ~5.07 vs. expected +6 (15.5% deviation) -- the family member TmCr9O24 in SG R3 has a significantly worse GII of 0.749; does the 3x increase in Cr content from Tm2Cr3O12 to TmCr9O24 cause geometric frustration in the Cr-O octahedral network that explains the GII degradation?

Rb6Mo2O9 is the only material in this batch with a nonzero space group score (0.2), matching one of its experimental reference space groups (SG 15, C2/c at 20% frequency) -- with Mo BVS of 5.13 vs. expected +6 (14.5% deviation) and an O site at BVS -1.43 vs. expected -2 (28.3% deviation), is the partial space group match a stronger indicator of structural plausibility than the moderate BVS deviations would suggest?

YIO4 is an oxyhalide (computationally known, SG 63 Cmcm) where both I and Y are underbonded -- I at BVS 4.26 vs. expected +5 (14.8% deviation) and Y at 2.55 vs. +3 (14.9% deviation) -- and the Pauling check carries a warning flag for mixed-anion applicability; given that two novel family members Y2IO6 and Y6IO12 both have null GII values, does the I5+/O2- mixed coordination systematically defeat BVS parameterization for the entire Y-I-O chemical space?

Sr7Ti7O20 is novel with mixed valence, disagreeing oxi methods, a charge residual of -5.0, and 45% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 20 bonds -- Sr sites show BVS as low as 1.28 vs. expected +2 (35.9% deviation), yet the family member Sr2Ti13O22 has a relatively low GII of 0.276; does the 1:1 Sr:Ti ratio in Sr7Ti7O20 force Sr into unusually small cavities compared to the Ti-rich Sr2Ti13O22 where Ti-O frameworks can better accommodate the large Sr2+ cation?

Sm2OsO5 is computationally known with Sm BVS of 2.47 vs. expected +3 (17.7% underbonding) and a near-zero bandgap of 0.009 eV -- the family members span GII from 0.163 (Sr(OsO3)3, note: different A-site) to 0.498 (Sm3Os2O9, charge -2.0); could the consistent Sm underbonding and metallic character suggest that Os is partially reduced from the assigned +4, creating a correlated-electron ground state that DFT-based GNoME training data would struggle to capture accurately?

Nd2NO is an oxynitride in high-symmetry tetragonal SG 141 (I41/amd) with disagreeing oxi methods, a charge residual of -2.0, and only 2 Pauling bonds checked (with warning) -- the N site shows BVS -2.39 vs. expected -3 (20.5% deviation) while O shows -1.40 vs. -2 (29.9% deviation); does the inability of both oxi methods to agree on this simple 4-atom formula unit suggest that Nd2NO has an unconventional bonding scheme (e.g., Nd in mixed +2/+3 states) that defies standard oxidation state assignment?

Cs2Zr6O13 is a novel monoclinic material with perfect charge neutrality but 53.8% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 13 bonds, while all Zr sites show BVS ~3.3 vs. expected +4 (17.6% deviation) -- does the combination of high Pauling violations with moderate BVS deviation indicate that the predicted structure has correct Zr-O bond lengths but incorrect coordination polyhedra geometry, suggesting GNoME captured bond distances but not polyhedral connectivity?

Ca5U3O12 belongs to a remarkably large Ca-U-O family of 7 members, where U-rich compositions (CaU5O12 GII 0.142, CaU8O18 GII 0.150, CaU9O20 GII 0.160) consistently outperform Ca-rich ones (Ca5U5O18 GII 0.336, Ca5U5O19 GII 0.393) -- with U BVS of 5.00 and 4.88 vs. expected +4 (22-25% overbonding) in Ca5U3O12 itself, does this family-wide trend indicate that U-O framework topology is inherently more geometrically stable than Ca-O, and that GNoME's predictions are most reliable when U dominates the structure?

Sr3(OsO5)2 is novel with charge neutrality and only 20% Pauling violations, but Sr sites show BVS ranging from 1.50 to 1.71 vs. expected +2 -- this material sits within a 6-member Sr-Os-O family where GII spans from 0.163 (Sr(OsO3)3) to 0.696 (SrOs5O13), and compositions with intermediate Sr:Os ratios (like Sr3Os2) occupy the middle range; does the monotonic relationship between Os content and structural strain suggest a critical Os:Sr threshold beyond which the Os-O octahedral network cannot accommodate the Sr2+ cation size?

Mo(S8O)3 is a novel oxychalcogenide with a formation energy of only -0.59 eV/atom (the shallowest in this batch, suggesting marginal thermodynamic stability), and its family member Mo2(SO4)3 has an extreme GII of 1.574 -- the BVS check only uses 3 bonds (with warning) and treats it as Mo6+/S2-/O2-, but the formula implies S8 chains or rings bonded to Mo and O; could GNoME have predicted a molecular crystal rather than an ionic solid, rendering all ionic bonding validators fundamentally inapplicable?

BaSn3O4 is novel hexagonal (SG 190) with Ba showing the most extreme underbonding in this batch -- BVS 1.15 vs. expected +2 (42.3% deviation) -- despite perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across 8 bonds; with the family member Ba5Sn3O11 having GII 0.421, this material exemplifies the 'tier conflict' pattern where Tier 1 checks pass but Tier 2 (BVS) fails dramatically -- does the hexagonal symmetry force Ba into a coordination environment too large for its actual bonding requirements?

In Ba3Ce2O7, all Ba sites show BVS values of only 1.09-1.36 v.u. against an expected +2, with deviations of 32-45%. Given that both oxi methods agree and charge neutrality is perfect, does this systematic Ba under-bonding indicate that the DFT-relaxed structure has expanded Ba-O distances beyond what classical BVS parameters calibrated on ICSD structures would predict, or could Ba3Ce2O7 adopt a genuinely underbonded layered Ruddlesden-Popper-type arrangement where large Ba2+ cations occupy oversized interlayer sites?

Rb(OsO4)2 is novel with a charge residual of -2.0 despite the oxi_state_guesses method assigning oxidation states, and across the Rb-Os-O family, only stoichiometries with high Rb:Os ratios (Rb4Os2O9, Rb4OsO4, Rb3OsO5) achieve charge neutrality while Os-rich compositions (Rb(OsO4)2, Rb3(OsO4)2, Rb(OsO3)3) all carry negative residuals of -1 to -4. Does this pattern suggest GNoME systematically generates Rb-deficient osmium oxide frameworks where the assigned Os oxidation state (+8 in perosmate) is physically unrealizable in these lower-Rb stoichiometries?

K14Tl4O13 is a novel 62-atom structure where all Tl sites show BVS of 3.80 v.u. versus the expected +3, an overbonding of 26.8%, yet charge neutrality is perfect and both oxi methods agree. Its family member K7Tl3O8 (also novel, GII 0.418) maintains the same K:Tl ratio and charge balance. Could the consistent Tl3+ overbonding across this family indicate that the DFT-optimized Tl-O bonds are systematically shorter than the BVS reference parameters expect, possibly because Tl3+ with its 6s2 lone pair adopts an asymmetric coordination that concentrates bond valence on fewer, shorter bonds?

RbMn2O4 has mixed valence with both oxi methods disagreeing, a charge residual of -4.0, and all Mn sites showing BVS of ~2.35 v.u. against an expected +3 (21-22% deviation). Strikingly, across the Rb-Mn-O family, charge imbalances range from -26.0 (RbMn14O28) to +8.0 (Rb5MnO5), with only Rb6Mn2O7 achieving neutrality but at a much worse GII of 0.581. Does this systematic failure to achieve charge neutrality across nearly all Rb-Mn-O stoichiometries indicate that GNoME's training data lacks reliable Mn mixed-valence references, making this entire compositional family suspect?

Er2Cr3O12 is a novel trigonal (R-3c, SG 167) garnet-like chromate where all Cr sites show a consistent BVS of 5.10 v.u. against expected +6, a 15% under-bonding, yet charge neutrality is perfect, Shannon radii pass, and all 24 Pauling bonds are satisfied. Given that the experimental space groups for this composition family are 62, 88, and 141 (orthorhombic/tetragonal) rather than 167, could the trigonal symmetry represent a high-temperature polymorph of Er2(CrO4)3 that has not yet been experimentally accessed?

In ScNb7O12, one Nb site has a BVS of 4.23 v.u. (40.9% deviation from expected +3) while the other two Nb sites sit at 2.48 v.u. (17.3% deviation), revealing a dramatic 1.75 v.u. spread among crystallographically distinct Nb positions. With both oxi methods agreeing on Nb3+ and charge neutrality achieved, could this bimodal Nb bonding environment indicate that the true oxidation state assignment should be mixed-valence (Nb3+/Nb5+) rather than uniform Nb3+, which would be chemically more plausible for a d-block transition metal oxide?

CsNb8O14 is a massive 92-atom novel structure with mixed valence, a charge residual of -12.0, and three identical Nb sites all showing BVS of 4.22 v.u. against expected +3 (40.6% deviation). Its family member CsNb3O8 (computationally known) achieves perfect charge neutrality with a much better GII of 0.271, while the Nb-rich compositions CsNb8O14 and CsNb10O18 both carry extreme negative charge residuals of -12 and -10 respectively. Is GNoME producing implausible Nb-rich stoichiometries where Nb cannot physically accommodate the assigned +3/+5 mixed-valence states at such high Nb densities?

Nd3WO7 is novel with mixed valence (both methods disagree on oxi states) yet achieves perfect charge neutrality, while BVS reveals Nd sites at 2.14 v.u. (28.7% below expected +3) and W at 4.47 v.u. (10.5% below expected +5). The Pauling violation fraction is 0.143 (2 of 14 bonds). Given that the oxi methods disagree yet the assigned states still produce zero charge residual, could the disagreement reflect genuine ambiguity between W5+/W6+ combined with Nd3+/Nd2+ configurations that happen to be electrostatically equivalent but structurally distinct?

Gd2OsO5 is computationally known with all Gd sites uniformly underbonded at BVS 2.48 v.u. (17.4% below expected +3), yet its family member Gd6OsO12 achieves a much lower GII of 0.233 with charge neutrality. The Gd:Os ratio increases from 2:1 to 6:1 across the family, with GII decreasing from 0.428 to 0.233. Does this trend suggest that Os-rich Gd-Os-O compounds generate structural strain from accommodating high-oxidation-state Os (likely Os6+ or Os7+) that is progressively relieved as the Gd:Os ratio increases and the structure approaches a Gd2O3-like host with dilute Os substitution?

S24IO3 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with a formula suggesting 24 sulfur atoms to only 3 oxygen and 1 iodine, yet it has only 28 sites and a formation energy of just -0.48 eV/atom -- the shallowest in this batch. With a bandgap reported as infinity, charge residual of -1.0, and only 3 Pauling bonds checked (with warning flag), all three O sites show BVS of -1.55 v.u. (22.5% below expected -2). Is this composition physically plausible, or does the extreme S:O ratio suggest a molecular crystal of SO3 units intercalated in an elemental sulfur/iodine matrix rather than a conventional ionic compound, which would render all classical validators fundamentally inapplicable?

Tb(SbO3)3 is computationally known with a space group score of 0.5 (matching SG 63 at 50% prevalence), perfect charge neutrality, and all Sb sites overbonded at BVS 5.89 v.u. (17.9% above expected +5). However, its family members TbSb5O13 and Tb3Sb9O26 show dramatically worse GII values of 0.942 and 0.861 with large charge imbalances (-6 and -7), while Tb6SbO12 with low Sb content has the best GII of 0.213. Does Sb5+ overbonding in the Sb-rich compounds systematically produce unstable structures, suggesting an upper bound on Sb concentration in rare-earth antimonates?

Sr6Sb2O11 sits in triclinic SG 1 (P1, no symmetry) despite the experimental space groups for this composition class being 14, 74, and 162 -- all with substantially higher symmetry. With two distinct Sb environments (BVS 3.55 and 4.43 v.u. against expected +5, deviations of 29.1% and 11.4%), the structure achieves perfect charge neutrality. Could the absence of any symmetry in the GNoME prediction indicate that the DFT relaxation broke higher symmetry, and if so, would re-symmetrizing to P-1 or P2_1/c improve the BVS agreement for the severely underbonded Sb sites?

Eu2(SeO4)3 is a novel oxychalcogenide with charge neutrality, both oxi methods agreeing, but all Eu sites showing BVS of only 1.90 v.u. (36.6% below expected +3) and a Shannon radii violation fraction of 0.042. Its family spans a wide Se:O range from EuSeO (GII 0.530) to Eu2(SeO4)3 (GII 0.428), with the selenite Eu2(SeO3)3 achieving the best GII of 0.176. Does the monotonic worsening of GII from Se4+ selenites to Se6+ selenates suggest that Eu3+ coordination geometries are better accommodated around tetrahedral SeO3 groups than tetrahedral SeO4 groups, possibly due to the lone pair on Se4+ providing structural flexibility?

Tb5(CoO6)2 is computationally known with mixed valence, charge residual of -1.0, and Co sites showing BVS of 3.10 v.u. against expected +4 (22.6% underbonded), while one O site is severely underbonded at -1.44 v.u. (27.8% deviation). Its sole family member TbCo2O5 (novel) has a much higher GII of 0.541 but achieves charge neutrality. Given that Co4+ is relatively rare and unstable in oxide chemistry, could the systematic Co underbonding indicate that the actual oxidation state is Co3+ with compensating Tb3+/Tb4+ mixed valence, which the oxi assignment algorithm failed to resolve?

K4(PtO2)3 is computationally known but has a charge residual of -2.0, with K sites dramatically underbonded at BVS 0.52-0.63 v.u. (37-48% deviation from expected +1). Remarkably, its novel family members K2Pt3O7 and K2Pt3O8 achieve exceptionally low GII values of 0.085 and 0.065 respectively -- among the best in the entire dataset -- yet both carry charge residuals of 0 and -2. Why does the K4(PtO2)3 stoichiometry produce such severe K underbonding when closely related K2Pt3O7 achieves near-perfect BVS, and does this suggest the K-rich stoichiometry creates voids too large for K+ to form adequate bonds?

Pr5(FeO6)2 is novel with a charge residual of -3.0 (oxi from single method only), and two O sites show extreme underbonding at BVS -1.29 v.u. (35.5% below expected -2), while Pr sits at 2.29 v.u. (23.5% below +3). With 19 sites, formation energy of -2.93 eV/atom, and a near-zero bandgap of 0.003 eV, does the combination of significant charge imbalance, severe O underbonding, and essentially metallic character suggest that Pr5(FeO6)2 would be better described with a mixed Pr3+/Pr4+ or Fe3+/Fe4+ assignment rather than the uniform states from oxi_state_guesses, which might resolve both the charge and BVS discrepancies?

Eu6MoO12 is a novel trigonal (R-3, SG 148) structure with perfect charge neutrality, both oxi methods agreeing, and Mo showing BVS of 4.99 v.u. (16.9% below expected +6) while O sites are underbonded at -1.56 v.u. The Eu6MO12 stoichiometry (M = transition metal in a 6:1 ratio with rare earth) mirrors the Gd6OsO12 structure in this batch which also adopts R-3 with GII of 0.233. Could this shared stoichiometry and symmetry represent a stable structural archetype for rare-earth-rich transition metal oxides where the R-3 framework naturally accommodates a single high-valent M6+ cation diluted among six R3+ cations?

Lu2Cr3O12 is a novel trigonal R-3c (SG 167) chromate isostructural with Er2Cr3O12 in this same batch -- both show nearly identical Cr BVS values (5.105 vs 5.100 v.u.), identical GII (~0.426), and identical space groups, yet Er and Lu sit at opposite ends of the lanthanide contraction. With Lu3+ being 14% smaller than Er3+, does the structural invariance of the CrO4 sublattice across the lanthanide series suggest that the chromate framework is rigid and the rare-earth site accommodates the size variation, predicting that the entire Ln2Cr3O12 series (Ln = La-Lu) should be synthetically accessible in R-3c?

Rb4Nb2O7 is novel with perfect charge neutrality but Rb sites are severely underbonded at BVS 0.42 v.u. (58.2% deviation from expected +1) and shows a Pauling violation fraction of 0.286 (2 of 7 bonds). Across the Rb-Nb-O family, Nb-rich compositions with low Rb content (RbNb5O8, RbNb3O8) achieve much better GII values of 0.247-0.279 and charge neutrality, while the Rb-rich Rb4Nb2O7 and Rb8Nb6O19 have higher GII of 0.426 and 0.422. Does this systematic degradation of structural quality with increasing Rb content indicate that Rb+ is simply too large to be accommodated in niobate frameworks at high concentrations?

Pr2W2O7 is a novel tetragonal (I4_1/a, SG 88) structure with perfect charge neutrality where all Pr sites show uniform BVS of 2.43 v.u. (19.2% below expected +3). Its family members Pr3WO7 (GII 0.460) and PrWO4 (GII 0.300) are both novel and charge neutral, with PrWO4 in scheelite-type P2_1/c showing the best structural quality. Given that the Pr:W ratio decreases from 3:1 to 1:1 across the family with improving GII, could PrWO4 represent the thermodynamic ground state while Pr2W2O7 and Pr3WO7 are metastable compositions where excess Pr3+ underbonding accumulates?

Nd9(SbO)5 is computationally known but exhibits extreme pathology: a charge residual of -14.0, 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (10/10 bonds), mixed valence with both oxi methods disagreeing, and Nd BVS of 2.63 v.u. against expected +2 (31.6% overbonded). Across the Nd-Sb-O family, GII values range from 0.374 to 0.691, and most compositions carry charge residuals. With the formula suggesting Sb in an unusual +1 oxidation state (SbO units), is the Nd9(SbO)5 stoichiometry fundamentally misassigned by the oxi algorithm, and should Sb be treated as Sb3- (antimonide) with Nd3+, making this a pnictide-oxide rather than a conventional oxide?

Gd5(OsO6)2 is novel with a charge residual of -1.0, oxi states from single method only, and Gd sites underbonded at 2.45-2.53 v.u. (15-18% below expected +3). Its family member Gd2OsO5 (computationally known, GII 0.428) appears in this same batch, while Gd6OsO12 (also computationally known) achieves the best GII of 0.233. With three Gd-Os-O compounds spanning Gd:Os ratios of 2.5:1, 2:1, and 6:1, and only the single-method oxi assignment available for Gd5(OsO6)2, would applying the both_agree oxi method to resolve the Os oxidation state (Os5+ vs Os6+ vs Os7+) eliminate the charge residual and improve the BVS agreement?

Eu4Se3O2 is a novel oxychalcogenide with mixed valence, charge residual of -4.0, 100% Pauling violation (4/4 bonds), and Se sites dramatically underbonded at BVS -1.26 v.u. (36.8% below expected -2). Despite both oxi methods agreeing, this compound shares a family with Eu2(SeO4)3 and Eu2(SeO3)3 which have Se in positive oxidation states (+6, +4), while Eu4Se3O2 implies Se2-. How can both oxi methods agree on states that produce a -4.0 charge residual and 100% Pauling failure, and does this indicate that the compound sits at a phase boundary between selenide and oxide chemistry where classical validators calibrated for either regime alone will systematically fail?

EuIO4 is a novel oxyhalide with perfect charge neutrality, both oxi methods agreeing on Eu3+/I5+/O2-, and I sites showing BVS of 4.29 v.u. (14.2% below expected +5) while Eu is at 2.55 v.u. (15.1% below +3). Its sole family member Eu6IO12 (also novel) has null GII and charge data, preventing comparison. Given that IO4- (periodate) is a well-established oxyanion and Eu3+ is the most stable Eu oxidation state, does the combination of charge neutrality and moderate BVS deviations make EuIO4 one of the most synthetically promising novel predictions in this batch, warranting experimental validation as a potential new rare-earth periodate?

Pr6BiO12 is novel in trigonal R-3 (SG 148), but its Pr-Bi-O family tells a remarkable story: GII values escalate dramatically with Bi content, from Pr3BiO7 at 0.417 to Pr2Bi2O7 at 0.714 to PrBi3O7 at 0.785 to Pr(BiO2)7 at 0.792, while charge residuals worsen from 0 to -4. Pr6BiO12 itself has Pr BVS of 2.44 v.u. (18.5% below +3) with charge residual of -1.0. With seven family members spanning Pr:Bi ratios from 9:1 to 1:7, does this systematic GII degradation with increasing Bi3+ content indicate that the large, stereochemically active lone pair of Bi3+ generates progressively more structural distortion that the DFT relaxation cannot resolve to crystallographically reasonable bond lengths?

Se(S8O)3 is an oxychalcogenide in space group R3m (160), yet 100% of experimental Se-S-O compounds crystallize in P2_1/c (14) -- a monoclinic group with inversion symmetry that the trigonal prediction entirely lacks.
