The BVS shows Se at 5.27 v.u. vs expected 6+ (12.2% deviation) and O at -1.76 v.u. vs expected -2 (12.1% deviation), suggesting the Se-O bonds are systematically too long. Its family sibling SeSO5 also predicted novel adopts P4/n with a lower GII of 0.375. Could the trigonal symmetry be an artifact of the GNN relaxation underestimating the covalent character of Se-S bonds, which would favor lower-symmetry arrangements with directional bonding?

Rb8Nb6O19 is computationally known with high oxi confidence (both methods agree on Nb5+), yet its Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 0.263 across 19 anion polyhedra is notably higher than the family median. Comparing across the Rb-Nb-O family: charge-neutral members RbNb5O8 (GII=0.247) and RbNb3O8 (GII=0.279) show significantly better bond valence agreement than this compound (GII=0.422), while the Nb-rich compositions RbNb10O18 and Rb3Nb16O23 show massive charge imbalances of -10.0 and -11.0. Hypothesis: the Rb:Nb ratio controls structural stability in this family, with intermediate ratios like 8:6 achieving charge neutrality but at the cost of Pauling electrostatic rule violations due to excessive edge-sharing among NbO6 octahedra.

K5NbO5 achieves perfect Pauling Rule 2 compliance (0/10 violations) and charge neutrality, but its Nb BVS of 4.07 v.u. deviates 18.5% from the expected 5+, which is the largest Nb underbonding in the entire K-Nb-O family. Its family sibling KNb5O8 (novel, GII=0.242) has the best GII of any family member. Given that the K-Nb-O system spans 6 compositions from K5NbO5 to K3Nb16O23 with K:Nb ratios from 5:1 to 3:16, and the two charge-neutral novel predictions (K8Nb6O19 and KNb5O8) bracket this compound's GII, should systematic BVS analysis across the full K-Nb-O compositional space be used to identify the optimal stoichiometry where both charge neutrality and bond valence satisfaction are simultaneously achieved?

Ca6TcO8 is a computationally known cubic Fm-3m (225) structure, but experimental Ca-Tc-O compounds exclusively adopt Pnma (62) -- an orthorhombic group with completely different symmetry operations. The BVS reveals uniform Ca underbonding at 1.57 v.u. vs expected 2+ (21.8% deviation) across all three worst sites, suggesting the Ca-O distances are systematically too large for the cubic framework. Its only family member Ca8Tc7O20 is novel with a charge imbalance of -3.0 and GII of 0.284 (much better than Ca6TcO8's 0.422). Given Tc's radioactivity limiting experimental validation, does the uniform Ca underbonding pattern indicate the cubic structure overestimates the Ca coordination number, and would a Pnma distortion bring the BVS closer to the expected values?

Ba5Sn3O11 is a novel pure oxide predicted in monoclinic C2 (5), yet experimental Ba-Sn-O phases overwhelmingly prefer cubic Pm-3m (221, 67%) or tetragonal I4/mmm (139, 33%) -- both high-symmetry aristotypes. Its BVS shows severe O underbonding at -1.40 v.u. (29.8% deviation from -2) and Ba underbonding at 1.43 v.u. (28.7% deviation from 2+), with the two worst oxygen sites exhibiting identical deviations suggesting a systematic structural issue. Its sole family sibling BaSn3O4 (novel, P-62c, GII=0.433) has an even higher GII. Hypothesis: the Ba5Sn3O11 stoichiometry forces an unusually Ba-rich environment that cannot be accommodated in the high-symmetry frameworks preferred by barium stannates, leading to the low-symmetry monoclinic distortion and the observed underbonding pattern.

Re2O3F4 is a novel oxyhalide predicted in orthorhombic Cmc2_1 (36) with near-zero bandgap (0.003 eV), yet its BVS shows O overbonded at -2.58 v.u. (29% deviation from -2) -- the opposite direction from most compounds in this dataset where O is typically underbonded. All three worst-BVS oxygen sites show identical 0.29 deviation. Meanwhile, its Re-O-F family sibling ReOF5 (computationally known, Pnma) achieves an excellent GII of 0.245 with charge neutrality, while Re2O5F (computationally known) has the worst GII at 0.668 with charge imbalance. The O overbonding pattern suggests Re-O bonds are anomalously short -- is the GNN compressing Re-O distances to compensate for the mixed anion (O/F) coordination environment, where the larger F- ions push oxygens closer to Re?

W(S8O)3 is structurally almost identical to Se(S8O)3 (same space group R3m #160, same 28 sites, same oxychalcogenide class, same single_method oxi confidence), yet they contain different transition metals. Both show nearly identical BVS patterns: W at 5.27 v.u. vs expected 6+ (12.1% dev) mirrors Se at 5.27 v.u. vs expected 6+ (12.2% dev), and both have O at -1.76 v.u. vs expected -2 (~12% dev). The formation energies differ only slightly (-0.581 vs -0.531 eV/atom). Given that W6+ (0.60 A) and Se6+ (0.42 A) have substantially different ionic radii, is GNoME predicting an isostructural pair where the M(S8O)3 framework is so rigid that it imposes the same bond length distortions regardless of the central cation size?

Ba4WO7 is a novel pure oxide in monoclinic P2_1 (4) showing W underbonding at 5.27 v.u. vs expected 6+ (12.2% dev) and Ba underbonding at 1.52 v.u. vs expected 2+ (24.1% dev), with a Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 0.143 (2/14 polyhedra). Its family sibling Ba7W4O19 (also novel, C2/m) has a substantially lower GII of 0.337 with charge neutrality. Hypothesis: the 4:1 Ba:W ratio in Ba4WO7 creates an excess of large Ba2+ cations that cannot be efficiently coordinated in the available oxygen framework, explaining why the more W-rich Ba7W4O19 (7:4 = 1.75:1 ratio) achieves better bond valence agreement -- the additional WO6 octahedra provide more shared oxygen vertices to satisfy Ba coordination demands.

K7Tl3O8 is a novel triclinic P-1 (2) compound with extreme K underbonding: the worst K site has BVS of only 0.37 v.u. vs expected 1+ (63.4% deviation), and the third-worst K site at 0.39 v.u. (60.6% dev). These are among the most severe underbonding values in the entire dataset. Despite this, charge neutrality is perfectly satisfied and all 16 Pauling polyhedra pass. Its family sibling K14Tl4O13 (novel, P2_1/c, GII=0.432) maintains the same ~3.5:1 K:Tl ratio. The catastrophic K underbonding suggests some K+ ions sit in cavities far too large for their ionic radius -- are these loosely-bound potassium sites indicative of potential ionic conductivity, analogous to superionic conductors where mobile alkali ions occupy oversized channels?

K7CrO6 has the highest Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction in this batch at 0.667 (16/24 polyhedra violating electrostatic valence balance), combined with a Cr BVS of 4.06 v.u. vs expected 5+ (18.7% deviation). The Cr underbonding is systematic across all three worst sites. Across the K-Cr-O family, the computationally known members K6Cr2O7 and K5CrO5 both have substantially higher GII values (0.536 and 0.532) than the novel K5Cr2O7 (GII=0.346), suggesting GNoME's novel predictions may be finding compositions where chromium achieves better bonding at the expense of massive Pauling violations. Does the 66.7% electrostatic violation rate indicate the structure requires a different Cr oxidation state (Cr6+ rather than Cr5+) that the oxi state guesser failed to assign?

Co2AsO6 carries a charge imbalance of -2.0 despite single_method oxi assignment, and its BVS reveals As at 4.00 v.u. vs expected 5+ (19.9% dev) while Co registers at 3.48 v.u. vs expected 3+ (16.1% dev in the opposite direction -- overbonded). The As underbonding combined with Co overbonding creates a push-pull pattern unusual for arsenates. Its family member Co3(AsO3)2 (novel, P2_1/c) achieves charge neutrality with a much better GII of 0.255 using As3+ rather than As5+. Could the charge imbalance and opposing BVS deviations indicate GNoME has predicted a structure intermediate between arsenite (As3+) and arsenate (As5+) coordination, where the actual stable phase would partition into distinct As3+ and As5+ environments?

Ru2O2F3 is computationally known but carries a -2.0 charge imbalance with only single_method oxi confidence, and BVS shows all Ru sites uniformly underbonded at 2.52 v.u. vs expected 3+ (15.9% dev). The oxyhalide warning flag indicates BVS parameters assuming O2- may not fully apply. Across its Ru-O-F family, the novel RuO2F (GII=0.901) has an extraordinarily high GII, while Ru4(OF3)3 (GII=0.377) and Ru2OF5 (GII=0.412) fare better. Given that Ru commonly adopts both 3+ and 4+ oxidation states, and the charge imbalance of -2.0 could be resolved by assigning Ru to a mixed 3+/4+ state, should the oxi state assignment methodology be extended to systematically test mixed-valence Ru configurations in oxyfluoride environments where standard guessing algorithms may default to a single state?

Cs(WO3)6 has the largest charge imbalance in this batch at -5.0, yet it is computationally known. Its BVS shows W at 5.84 v.u. vs expected 5+ (16.9% overbonded), meaning W is actually closer to W6+ than the assigned W5+. Its family sibling Cs(WO3)4 (novel, P-6m2) has an even more extreme charge imbalance of -9.0, while Cs2W3O10 (novel, GII=0.246) and Cs6W2O9 (computationally known, GII=0.388) are both charge-neutral. The pattern is clear: the W-rich hexagonal tungsten bronzes Cs(WO3)n show systematically wrong oxi assignments. Given W overbonding toward 6+ and the hexagonal bronze structure type being well-known for mixed W5+/W6+ states, does this compound represent a classic case where the oxi guesser assigns uniform W5+ when the actual electronic structure requires partial W6+ to achieve charge balance?

Pr3BiO7 is computationally known with high oxi confidence, perfect charge neutrality, and zero Pauling violations across 14 polyhedra, yet all three worst BVS sites are Pr with systematic underbonding (2.13 and 2.35 v.u. vs expected 3+, deviations of 29% and 21.7%). Across its large Pr-Bi-O family (7 members), GII values escalate dramatically with Bi enrichment: Pr6BiO12 (0.422) to Pr2Bi2O7 (0.714) to Pr(BiO2)7 (0.792). Hypothesis: the stereochemically active lone pair on Bi3+ systematically distorts the oxygen sublattice, creating asymmetric coordination environments that underbond the Pr3+ sites. The monotonic GII increase with Bi content directly tracks the growing lone-pair distortion density in the structure.

K3Nb16O23 is novel with the most severe charge imbalance in the K-Nb-O family at -11.0 and the highest Pauling violation fraction at 0.783 (18/23 polyhedra). Yet its BVS reveals Nb at 2.99 v.u. vs expected 2+ (49.7% overbonded) -- meaning BVS assigns Nb a valence near 3+ rather than the guessed 2+. The single_method oxi assignment to Nb2+ is chemically implausible for a niobium oxide; Nb2+ is extremely rare and typically only found in cluster compounds. Meanwhile, its family sibling KNb5O8 achieves charge neutrality with Nb5+ and GII=0.242. Is K3Nb16O23 a case where the oxi state guesser catastrophically fails, assigning the unusual Nb2+ when the structure actually contains mixed Nb4+/Nb5+, which would simultaneously resolve the -11 charge imbalance and explain the 49.7% BVS deviation?

Tl(WO3)4 is structurally analogous to Cs(WO3)6 -- both are hexagonal P6/mmm (191) tungsten bronzes with large monovalent cations, single_method oxi confidence, and massive charge imbalances (-9.0 and -5.0 respectively). Both show W overbonding toward 6+ (BVS 5.81 and 5.84 v.u. vs expected 5+). Yet Tl(WO3)4's family member Tl2W3O10 achieves an excellent GII of 0.178 (the best in either Cs-W-O or Tl-W-O families) with charge neutrality. Hypothesis: the hexagonal tungsten bronze structure preferentially stabilizes Tl+ over Cs+ as the tunnel cation because Tl+ has a stereochemically active 6s2 lone pair that better fits the hexagonal channel geometry, explaining why GNoME predicts Tl(WO3)4 but not Cs(WO3)4 in the same space group.

Pr13(B2O13)2 is the only material in this batch with a non-zero Shannon radii violation (score=0.018), meaning 1.8% of ionic radius lookups fall outside the 25% tolerance -- unusual given that 99% of the full dataset passes this check. It also has the highest space group match score in the batch (0.5, in P2_1/c matching 50% of experimental phases), yet carries a -2.0 charge imbalance and 48% Pauling violations across 50 polyhedra. With 86 sites it is the largest unit cell here. Its family member PrB5O9 (novel, P2_1/c) achieves an outstanding GII of 0.131 with charge neutrality. Why does the B-rich PrB5O9 achieve dramatically better structural metrics than the Pr-rich Pr13(B2O13)2, and does the rare Shannon violation indicate some Pr3+ ions occupy sites with coordination numbers incompatible with their ionic radius?

TmV4O8 is a novel mixed-valence compound (both methods agree on V3+/V4+) with a -4.0 charge imbalance and BVS showing all V3+ sites at 2.40 v.u. (20% underbonded). Despite the charge imbalance, Pauling Rule 2 is perfectly satisfied across all 32 polyhedra -- a rare combination suggesting the local coordination geometry is electrostatically sound even though the global stoichiometry does not balance. Its family member Tm2VO5 (computationally known, Pnma, GII=0.385) achieves charge neutrality with a single V oxidation state. Does the mixed V3+/V4+ assignment represent GNoME correctly capturing a charge-ordering phenomenon in a frustrated vanadate structure, or is the charge imbalance evidence that the V3+:V4+ ratio assigned by the oxi guesser is incorrect?

Gd4Zr3O12 is computationally known with excellent validation metrics (both_agree oxi, charge neutral, zero Pauling violations across 12 polyhedra), yet its predicted triclinic P-1 (2) space group contradicts the 100% experimental preference for cubic Fd-3m (227) in Gd-Zr-O phases -- the pyrochlore structure. The BVS reveals systematic Zr underbonding at 3.24-3.30 v.u. vs expected 4+ (17.6-19.1% dev). Its novel family member Gd2Zr7O16 (R-3, GII=0.334, charge=-5.0) adopts a rhombohedral structure closer to the pyrochlore aristotype. Should the space group validator weight the 100% experimental consensus for Fd-3m more heavily as a red flag, since the triclinic distortion of a known pyrochlore composition may indicate DFT relaxation trapped in a local minimum rather than finding the global cubic ground state?

La2VO5 is a novel pure oxide predicted in Pnma (62) with the highest space group match score (0.167) among novel materials in this batch, meaning its predicted space group partially matches experimental La-V-O phases. Its V BVS is 3.18 v.u. vs expected 4+ (20.5% dev), and all three worst sites are V with identical deviations, suggesting a uniform structural distortion. The formation energy of -3.45 eV/atom is among the most negative in this batch, indicating strong thermodynamic stability. Hypothesis: La2VO5 represents a genuine novel metastable phase in the La-V-O system -- the combination of partial space group match, deep formation energy, high oxi confidence (both agree), and systematic (rather than random) V underbonding is consistent with a real material that adopts slightly expanded VO6 octahedra rather than a computational artifact.

Na2Mn3O6 is a novel mixed-valence Mn compound (both methods agree) with a -3.0 charge imbalance, yet it perfectly satisfies Pauling Rule 2 across all 18 polyhedra. The BVS shows Mn at 2.33 v.u. vs expected 3+ (22.3% dev), with all three worst Mn sites nearly identical (2.332, 2.332, 2.333 v.u.) -- a suspiciously uniform pattern suggesting the oxi guesser assigned Mn3+ uniformly when the structure actually contains a specific Mn2+/Mn3+ or Mn3+/Mn4+ ordering. Its family member NaMn6O12 (novel, C2/m) carries an extreme -10.0 charge imbalance. Given that layered Na-Mn-O phases are heavily studied as battery cathode materials, could the BVS-derived effective valence of 2.33 indicate Mn in a partially reduced state relevant to electrochemical cycling?

Nd3BiO7 is computationally known and nearly identical to its Pr3BiO7 analogue (same P-1 space group, same 22 sites, same formation energy range, both with Bi3+ lone pair cations), and both show the same Nd/Pr underbonding pattern (Nd at 2.14/2.36 v.u. vs Pr at 2.13/2.35 v.u. -- deviations within 0.01 v.u.). Both have large Ln-Bi-O families where GII escalates with Bi enrichment. Nd3BiO7 has three family members with null GII/charge values (Nd9(BiO)5, Nd8Bi3O8, Nd6BiO12), indicating BVS could not be computed. Hypothesis: the Pr/Nd interchangeability with near-identical bond valence signatures confirms that the lanthanide contraction between Pr3+ (1.126 A) and Nd3+ (1.109 A) is too small to meaningfully alter the Bi3+ lone-pair-driven structural distortions, and GNoME has correctly captured this chemical similarity.

Sm5Mn2O12 is computationally known with near-zero bandgap (0.001 eV) and a -1.0 charge imbalance from single_method oxi assignment. Its BVS shows Mn at 3.26 v.u. vs expected 4+ (18.4% dev) and Sm at 2.40 v.u. vs expected 3+ (20.1% dev) -- both cations systematically underbonded. Experimental Sm-Mn-O phases adopt Pbam (55, 50%) or Pnma (62, 50%), but GNoME predicts C2/m (12). The near-zero bandgap combined with Mn4+ suggests potential magnetic ordering or orbital effects not captured by classical validators. Should near-zero bandgap materials like this be flagged for special attention, since the BVS formalism assumes ionic bonding and may systematically underperform for materials at the metal-insulator transition where covalent/metallic contributions to bonding become significant?

Dy5Cr2O12 is the only material in this batch where both oxi state methods disagree (methods_disagree confidence), yet it is computationally known and shows mixed valence. Its BVS gives Cr at 3.31 v.u. vs expected 4+ (17.3% dev) and Dy at 2.40 v.u. vs expected 3+ (20.1% dev) -- a pattern nearly identical to Sm5Mn2O12 in this same batch (Mn at 3.26/4+, Sm at 2.40/3+), despite involving completely different elements. Both are Ln5M2O12 compounds in C2/m (12) with 19 sites, charge imbalance of -1.0, and near-zero bandgaps. Are GNoME's Ln5M2O12 predictions (Ln=rare earth, M=transition metal) a systematic structural family where the oxi state ambiguity and uniform underbonding pattern arise from the same geometric frustration in the shared C2/m framework?

AgSb5O13 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality, zero Pauling violations across 26 polyhedra, and both oxi methods agreeing -- yet all three worst BVS sites are Sb overbonded at 5.82 v.u. vs expected 5+ (16.3% dev). Its sole family member Ag2Sb2O7 (novel, Fd-3m pyrochlore, GII=0.758) has drastically worse structural metrics despite adopting the well-known pyrochlore structure. Hypothesis: the Sb-rich AgSb5O13 stoichiometry with its orthorhombic Ama2 (40) structure represents the genuine thermodynamic ground state for the Ag-Sb-O system, and GNoME's pyrochlore Ag2Sb2O7 prediction with GII=0.758 is chemically implausible -- the Sb5+ overbonding in AgSb5O13 reflects the known tendency of Sb5+ to form short, strong Sb-O bonds rather than structural instability.

SrMn8O16 has a charge imbalance of -6.0 and both oxi-state methods disagree, yet its Sr-Mn-O family shows a striking pattern: stoichiometries with lower Mn:Sr ratios (SrMn2O4, Sr4Mn2O7) achieve charge neutrality while higher-Mn variants (Sr16Mn8O31 at -6.0, Sr10Mn5O19 at -3.0) systematically accumulate negative charge. Does the hollandite-type tunnel structure in Mn8O16 frameworks require a specific Sr occupancy to maintain neutrality, and does the BVS deviation of 0.579 for Sr (observed BVS 0.842 vs expected 2+) indicate the Sr site is too large for the tunnel, making this compound intrinsically unstable?

Li(Pt3O4)4 carries a massive charge imbalance of -7.0 and its Li BVS is only 0.586 vs expected 1+ (deviation 0.414), yet the Li-Pt-O family reveals that simpler stoichiometries like Li4PtO5 (GII 0.171), Li6PtO6 (GII 0.138), and LiPt3O8 (GII 0.149) are all charge-neutral with excellent bond valence sums. Why does GNoME predict a cubic Fm-3m structure (SG 202) when 100% of experimental Pt-oxide relatives crystallize in SG 148 (R-3), and does the 5x worse GII compared to simpler Li-Pt-O compounds suggest this high-Pt stoichiometry creates an over-coordinated framework that cannot properly accommodate Li?

Er2VO5 is charge-neutral with both oxi-state methods agreeing, passes Shannon radii and Pauling checks perfectly, yet shows a systematic under-bonding of oxygen (three O sites at BVS -1.407 vs expected -2, deviation 0.297 each). Its sole family member Er2V3O8 also shows charge imbalance (-2.0). Given that Er2VO5 adopts the experimentally-matched space group Pnma (SG 62, 25% of known Er-V-O phases) and has a high bandgap of 1.91 eV, could the uniform oxygen under-bonding indicate that the DFT-relaxed structure has systematically expanded O-cation distances, and would this compound be a candidate for high-pressure synthesis where compression could bring O-site BVS closer to ideal?

Cs(WO3)4 is a novel hexagonal tungsten bronze (SG 187) with a charge imbalance of -9.0 and W sites at BVS 5.842 vs expected 5+ (deviation 0.168), suggesting the assigned W5+ may actually be closer to W6+. Across its family, Cs2W3O10 achieves neutrality (GII 0.246) while both Cs(WO3)4 and Cs(WO3)6 carry large negative charges (-9.0 and -5.0 respectively). Given that hexagonal tungsten bronzes are well-established for CsxWO3 compositions, is this a case where the oxi-state guesser assigned W5+ when W6+ is correct, and would re-assignment to Cs+(W6+)4(O2-)12 resolve the charge imbalance exactly (charge = 1 + 24 - 24 = +1, still off)?

Ru2OF5 is a novel oxyhalide where the Pauling Rule 2 check flagged a warning and could only assess 1 of its coordination environments, yielding a misleading perfect score of 1.0. The F-site BVS of -0.603 vs expected -1 (deviation 0.397) indicates severe under-bonding of fluorine, while the family member RuO2F shows an alarming GII of 0.901. Given that BVS parameters for Ru-F bonds are less well-calibrated than Ru-O bonds, how reliable is the GII of 0.412 for this compound, and does the systematic under-bonding of F across the Ru-O-F family (Ru2O2F3 at GII 0.418, Ru4(OF3)3 at GII 0.377) reflect genuine structural strain or inadequate BVS reference parameters for ruthenium oxyhalides?

Ba5Ti5O14 is a novel trigonal (SG 164) compound with both oxi-state methods disagreeing, mixed valence, and a charge imbalance of -3.0. The Ba-site BVS of 1.128 vs expected 2+ (deviation 0.436) indicates severe under-bonding, while the Ti sites show BVS of 3.725 vs expected 3+ (deviation 0.242), suggesting Ti may actually be Ti4+ rather than the assigned Ti3+. With a 57.1% Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction -- far above the dataset mean of 0.172 -- and no family members for comparison, does this material represent a case where oxi-state misassignment (Ti3+ instead of Ti4+) cascades into both the charge imbalance and inflated Pauling violations, and would reassignment to Ba2+5Ti4+5O14 require an impossible -18 oxygen charge?

Er3MoO7 is a novel compound where both oxi-state methods agree on Er3+ and Mo5+, charge neutrality is perfect, Shannon radii pass cleanly, and the Pauling violation fraction of 0.143 is below the dataset mean of 0.172. However, Er sites show BVS of 2.094 vs expected 3+ (deviation 0.302), suggesting substantial under-bonding of the rare earth. Given the formation energy of -3.44 eV/atom (quite favorable) and bandgap of 1.39 eV, could this systematic Er under-bonding reflect a genuinely expanded Er-O coordination shell that stabilizes an unusual Mo5+ oxidation state, and does this explain why GNoME predicts orthorhombic C2221 (SG 20) rather than the monoclinic structures (SG 12, 15) seen in 66% of known Er-Mo-O phases?

Na2MoO3 is a novel, charge-neutral, monoclinic (C2/m, SG 12) compound with perfect Shannon radii and zero Pauling violations across all 6 checked environments. The Mo-site BVS of 3.185 vs expected 4+ (deviation 0.204) and moderate bandgap of 1.27 eV suggest a reduced molybdate with Mo in a genuine 4+ state. Given that Na2MoO4 (the common sodium molybdate with Mo6+) is a well-known compound, could Na2MoO3 represent a thermodynamically accessible reduced phase where Mo4+ is stabilized by the lower coordination demands of only 3 oxygens per Mo, and does the 0.204 BVS deviation fall within the typical range for DFT-optimized Mo4+ environments?

Cs4Nb2O7 is charge-neutral with both oxi-state methods agreeing, yet its Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 0.857 (6 of 7 environments violated) is nearly 5x the dataset mean of 0.172. The Cs sites show BVS of only 0.444 vs expected 1+ (deviation 0.556), among the most severely under-bonded alkali sites in the dataset. Across the Cs-Nb-O family, the Nb-rich variants CsNb10O18 and CsNb8O14 carry enormous charge imbalances (-10 and -12), yet the Nb-poor CsNb3O8 achieves neutrality with a much lower GII of 0.271. Does the 4:2 Cs:Nb ratio create an impossibly Cs-rich structure where the large Cs+ ions cannot find adequate coordination, and is the 0.857 Pauling violation a signal that this stoichiometry is fundamentally incompatible with stable crystal packing?

PrIO4 is a computationally known oxyhalide that achieves charge neutrality with both oxi-state methods agreeing (Pr3+, I5+, O2-), passes all Shannon and Pauling checks, and shows remarkably balanced BVS deviations (I at 0.141, Pr at 0.140). Its family member Pr2I4O13 is also charge-neutral with a comparable GII of 0.394. Given that PrIO4 adopts SG 63 (Cmcm) -- an orthorhombic space group not among the experimental preferences (SG 14 and 129 at 50% each) -- and has a wide bandgap of 3.29 eV typical of stable iodates, could this represent a polymorphic variant of praseodymium iodate that is metastable at ambient conditions but synthesizable under moderate pressure or as a thin film?

Sr(CoO2)4 is a novel mixed-valence cobaltate with both oxi-state methods disagreeing, a charge imbalance of -4.0, and Sr BVS of 1.307-1.327 vs expected 2+ (deviation ~0.34). Its family reveals a remarkable pattern: seven Sr-Co-O compositions span GII values from 0.289 to 0.640, and the three computationally known members all carry charge imbalances (-6, -2, 0) while having the lowest GII values (0.349, 0.289, 0.316). Does the systematic charge imbalance across GNoME's high-Co:Sr ratio predictions reflect a fundamental difficulty in assigning oxidation states to mixed-valence Co (Co3+/Co4+), and could these structures actually be metallic -- consistent with the null bandgap -- where integer oxidation states are inappropriate?

AgSe2O7 is a novel oxychalcogenide where both oxi-state methods agree on Ag2+, Se6+, O2-, achieving charge neutrality, yet the Ag BVS values of 0.938 and 0.965 vs expected 2+ (deviations 0.531 and 0.518) represent some of the most extreme under-bonding in the dataset. The Se sites are nearly perfectly bonded (BVS 5.691 vs expected 6+, deviation only 0.051). Its sole family member Ag2SeO5 shows an even worse GII of 0.734. Is Ag2+ the correct assignment here, or could this compound actually contain Ag1+ with Se in a mixed 4+/6+ state, and does the near-zero bandgap of 0.0001 eV support a metallic/semimetallic character inconsistent with the assigned ionic model?

Dy7FeO12 is a novel trigonal (R-3, SG 148) compound that is charge-neutral with both methods agreeing, passes Shannon radii and Pauling checks perfectly, but the Fe site shows BVS of 2.066 vs expected 3+ (deviation 0.311) -- the worst-bonded site in the structure. Its family member Dy2Fe2O7 has a notably high GII of 0.688 in the pyrochlore structure (Fd-3m). Given that Dy7FeO12 has the unusual 7:1 Dy:Fe ratio and a very favorable formation energy of -3.73 eV/atom (among the most negative in this batch), could this represent a fluorite-derivative superstructure where the Fe3+ ion occupies a single crystallographic site that is systematically too large, and would neutron diffraction reveal partial Dy/Fe site mixing that the DFT model does not capture?

AgS2O7 is structurally nearly identical to AgSe2O7 (same SG 2, same n_sites 20, same compound class), yet it achieves a slightly better space group score (0.5 vs 0.0) because P-1 matches 50% of experimental Ag-S-O phases. The Ag BVS values (0.912-0.913 vs expected 2+, deviations 0.543-0.544) are virtually identical to the Se analog. However, S shows overbonding (BVS 6.488 vs expected 6+, deviation 0.081) while Se in AgSe2O7 shows underbonding (BVS 5.691). Does this systematic sign reversal in chalcogen BVS deviation between S6+ and Se6+ reflect a genuine structural difference, or does it expose a calibration offset in the BVS reference parameters between sulfates and selenates?

Ca6PtO8 is a novel rock-salt-derivative cubic structure (Fm-3m, SG 225) where all six Ca sites show identical BVS of 1.580 vs expected 2+ (deviation 0.210), and charge neutrality is perfect. Its family member Ca(PtO2)3 has a remarkably low GII of 0.047 -- one of the best in the entire dataset -- while the Pt-richer Ca(PtO3)2 has GII of 0.400. Given Ca6PtO8's high symmetry, favorable formation energy of -2.90 eV/atom, and wide bandgap of 1.92 eV, could this antifluorite-related structure with isolated PtO4 units be a promising host for luminescent applications, and does the uniform 0.210 Ca BVS deviation suggest a slightly expanded unit cell that could be corrected by partial Sr substitution?

CsMn3O6 is a novel mixed-valence manganate with a severe charge imbalance of -8.0 despite both oxi-state methods agreeing. All Mn sites show identical BVS of 2.375 vs expected 3+ (deviation 0.208), and 100% of known Cs-Mn-O compounds crystallize in SG 62 (Pnma), yet GNoME predicts SG 15 (C2/c). Its family member CsMn8O16 (hollandite structure) has a much lower GII of 0.305 but still carries -7.0 charge imbalance. With 40 sites in the unit cell and Mn in a mixed-valence state, does the uniform Mn under-bonding at exactly 2.375 across all sites indicate that the Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio is misassigned and the actual average Mn oxidation state is closer to +2.67 (requiring Mn2+/Mn3+ mixing)?

GdS2O7 is a novel oxychalcogenide with mixed valence and a positive charge imbalance of +2.0 -- unusual since most charge imbalances in the dataset are negative. The S sites show a dramatic split: two at BVS 4.93 (deviation 0.178 from expected 6+) and one at BVS 6.639 (deviation 0.107), suggesting two distinct S coordination environments. Its family member Gd(S8O)3 has an extreme GII of 1.138 -- among the worst in the dataset. Given that oxi states came from bv_analyzer alone (single method) and the compound shows mixed valence, could the +2.0 charge excess indicate that some S is actually S2- rather than S6+, consistent with a mixed sulfide-sulfate compound rather than a pure oxychalcogenide?

VI2O7 is a novel oxyhalide where both methods agree on V5+, I5+, O2- and charge neutrality is perfect, yet the Pauling Rule 2 check carries a warning flag for the oxyhalide compound class. All three I sites show identical BVS of 4.344 vs expected 5+ (deviation 0.131), while the V-site BVS is not among the three worst deviations, suggesting V5+ is well-bonded. With 100% of experimental V-I-O phases in SG 14 (P21/c) but GNoME predicting SG 36 (Cmc21), is the orthorhombic prediction a genuinely novel polymorph of vanadium iodate, and could the systematic I5+ under-bonding (all three sites identically at 0.131 deviation) indicate that the IO6 octahedra are uniformly expanded compared to known iodates?

NdIO4 is a novel charge-neutral oxyhalide (Nd3+, I5+, O2-) in SG 63 (Cmcm) with both oxi-state methods agreeing and no Pauling violations across 8 checked environments. Its I-site BVS of 4.277 vs expected 5+ (deviation 0.145) is slightly worse than PrIO4's 4.293 (deviation 0.141), consistent with the lanthanide contraction from Pr to Nd slightly compressing the structure. Given that NdIO4's family includes NdIO5 with a much better GII of 0.219 and charge neutrality, could the IO4 stoichiometry represent a metastable dehydration product of NdIO5 (loss of one O), and does the parallel between PrIO4 (SG 63, computationally known) and NdIO4 (SG 63, novel) suggest an entire series of lanthanide iodates Ln(IO4) awaiting experimental confirmation?

NaNb4O8 is a novel mixed-valence niobate with a charge imbalance of -9.0 and Nb sites showing BVS of 3.957 and 3.935 vs expected 3+ (deviations 0.319 and 0.312), where the observed BVS is higher than the expected oxidation state -- suggesting the assigned Nb3+ is incorrect and these Nb atoms are actually closer to Nb4+ or Nb5+. With 39 sites, a near-zero bandgap (0.005 eV), and a Pauling violation fraction of 0.333 (8 of 24 environments), does this compound represent a case where GNoME has predicted a metallic reduced niobium oxide that cannot be described by integer oxidation states, making all classical validators inherently unreliable for this material?

HfSO5 is a novel charge-neutral oxychalcogenide with both methods agreeing on Hf4+, S6+, O2-, a wide bandgap of 4.20 eV, and the best space group score in this batch (0.333, matching SG 62 at 33% of known phases). All three S sites show identical overbonding at BVS 6.931 vs expected 6+ (deviation 0.155), while the 0.200 Pauling violation fraction is close to the dataset mean. Given that hafnium sulfate Hf(SO4)2 is a known compound and HfSO5 has one extra oxygen per sulfur compared to SO4 tetrahedra, could this structure contain SO5 pyramidal units (rare but documented in peroxosulfates), and does the S overbonding at 6.931 support the hypothesis that S is in an unusually tight coordination environment with more than four oxygen neighbors?

Sn5Pb7O16 is a novel Sn-Pb mixed oxide where one Sn site shows BVS of 1.665 vs expected 3+ (deviation 0.445) while two other Sn sites show BVS of 3.601 (deviation 0.200), revealing a massive intra-element BVS spread of nearly 2 valence units. Its entire family of five Sn-Pb-O compounds all crystallize in SG Pm (SG 6) with universally high GII values (0.490-0.715) and most carry charge imbalances. Given that Sn commonly adopts both 2+ and 4+ states, does the 1.665 BVS site actually represent Sn2+ (for which 1.665 is only a 0.168 deviation) rather than Sn3+, and would reassigning this site to Sn2+ while keeping others as Sn4+ resolve the -3.0 charge imbalance?

Sr4V6O19 is a novel triclinic (P-1, SG 2) vanadate with 58 sites -- one of the largest unit cells in this batch -- that achieves perfect charge neutrality and passes Shannon radii, with only 2 of 38 Pauling environments violated (5.3%). The Sr sites show BVS of 1.245 vs expected 2+ (deviation 0.378), while V sites are at 4.398 vs expected 5+ (deviation 0.120). Its family shows a trend: all three Sr-V-O relatives are novel with GII values from 0.494 to 0.596, and those achieving charge neutrality (Sr5V3O11, Sr10V6O25) have higher GII than the charge-imbalanced Sr12V8O27. Could the near-2:3 Sr:V ratio in Sr4V6O19 represent an optimal balance point in this family, and does the low 0.120 V-site deviation confirm that the V5+O4 tetrahedral framework is robust while the Sr2+ sublattice is systematically under-coordinated?

Cd3(SbO3)2 is a novel charge-neutral monoclinic compound (P21/c, SG 14) with both methods agreeing, zero Shannon or Pauling violations across 24 checked environments, and all three worst BVS deviations from identical Cd sites at 1.334 vs expected 2+ (deviation 0.333). With 44 sites and no family members in the dataset for comparison, this compound has unusually clean classical chemistry credentials except for the Cd under-bonding. Given that Cd2Sb2O7 (pyrochlore) is a known compound and Cd3(SbO3)2 has a Cd-richer stoichiometry, could this material adopt a weberite-related superstructure where the extra Cd2+ ions occupy interstitial sites with inherently lower coordination numbers, explaining the systematic 0.333 BVS deviation?

Ba2Pu2O7 is computationally known but has oxi states from only one method (oxi_state_guesses), presumably assigning Pu5+. The Ba sites show a gradient of BVS deviations (0.261, 0.262, 0.118), and charge neutrality is perfect. Its family of five Ba-Pu-O compounds spans GII from 0.283 (BaPu3O10) to 0.684 (Ba16Pu6O37), with Ba2PuO6 lacking GII data entirely. Given that plutonium can adopt 3+ through 7+ oxidation states and only one oxi-state assignment method succeeded, how sensitive are the BVS results to the assumed Pu oxidation state, and would reassignment from Pu5+ to Pu4+ or Pu6+ significantly change the GII -- potentially revealing whether GNoME's Ba-Pu-O predictions are consistently modeling one Pu valence state?

RbSb5O13 shows a BVS deviation of 0.89 v.u. on Rb (computed BVS 1.89 vs expected 1.0), suggesting Rb is significantly overbonded in this structure. Its family member RbSb3O5 achieves a much lower GII of 0.172 v.u. with the same Rb+/Sb5+ chemistry. Does the higher Sb:Rb ratio of 5:1 in RbSb5O13 versus 3:1 in RbSb3O5 force Rb into an over-coordinated cage environment that artificially inflates its apparent valence?

Er5(TcO6)2 fails charge neutrality with a residual of -1.0 and was assigned oxidation states by only a single method (oxi_state_guesses), while its predicted space group (SG 12, monoclinic) completely contradicts the experimentally expected SG 227 (Fd-3m, cubic). Across its Er-Tc-O family, GII values escalate dramatically from 0.463 in Er(TcO4)3 to 1.643 in Er6Tc16O. Is the charge imbalance an artifact of incorrect Tc oxidation state assignment, or does this structure genuinely represent a metastable phase with unusual Tc valence?

Cs5TlO4 is a novel GNoME prediction with perfect charge neutrality and Shannon radii compliance, yet all three Cs sites show BVS values of only 0.46 (expected 1.0), yielding a 54% underbonding deviation. Given that the predicted monoclinic SG 14 contradicts the experimentally dominant SG 166 (R-3m) for this chemistry, could GNoME have predicted a low-density polymorph where the large Cs+ ions sit in oversized cavities, making this structure thermodynamically unstable despite formal charge balance?

Sr3(IO5)2 is classified as an oxyhalide with a Pauling Rule 2 warning flag and 20% violation fraction, while iodine BVS comes in at 6.235 vs the expected 7.0 (10.9% deviation). The oxi states were assigned by bv_analyzer alone (single_method confidence). Given that assuming O2- may be incorrect for oxyhalides where I could adopt I5+ rather than I7+, how sensitive is the BVS score to the choice of iodine oxidation state, and would reassigning I as 5+ bring the BVS deviation closer to zero?

Cs(OsO4)2 fails charge neutrality with a residual of -2.0 and is novel, yet it belongs to a large Cs-Os-O family of 6 members where charge neutrality failures are pervasive: Cs3(OsO4)2 at -1.0, Cs(OsO3)3 at -4.0, and Cs5(OsO3)18 at -13.0. Strikingly, the Os-rich compositions with the worst charge imbalances show the lowest GII values (0.046 and 0.078 v.u.), while charge-neutral Cs3OsO5 has a higher GII of 0.31. Is GNoME systematically generating geometrically plausible but electrostatically impossible Cs-Os-O frameworks due to difficulty assigning Os oxidation states?

Ba3(IO5)2 is an oxyhalide with charge neutrality (0.0 residual), no Pauling violations (0/20 checked), and iodine BVS of 6.105 vs expected 7.0, giving a 12.8% underbonding deviation on all three I sites uniformly. Its structural analog Sr3(IO5)2 (material 942a57d585) shows an almost identical I BVS deviation (10.9%) despite different alkaline earth cations. Does this systematic ~11-12% iodine underbonding across both Ba and Sr analogs indicate a fundamental BVS parameter problem for I7+ in these periodate-like environments rather than a structural deficiency?

Sr4Os6O19 adopts cubic SG 197 (I23) despite all experimentally known Sr-Os-O compositions crystallizing in SG 62 (Pnma, 50%) or SG 88 (I4_1/a, 50%). Within its family, the only other I23 structure is the computationally known Sr2(OsO3)3, which carries a -4.0 charge imbalance, while Sr4Os6O19 is charge neutral but shows uniform Sr underbonding at BVS 1.573 vs expected 2.0 (21.4% deviation). Could GNoME be forcing an incompatible cubic framework onto a chemistry that prefers lower symmetry, explaining the systematic Sr underbonding?

Tc4Pb4O13 fails charge neutrality with a -2.0 residual and adopts cubic SG 216 (F-43m) while the experimentally expected SG for this chemistry is 227 (Fd-3m, 100% of known compounds). All four Pb sites show consistent ~22.7% underbonding (BVS 1.546-1.549 vs expected 2.0). Its family member Tc6Pb4O19 (novel, I23) has worse GII at 0.624 but achieves charge neutrality. Is the charge deficit in Tc4Pb4O13 evidence that the assigned Tc oxidation state is wrong, and would Tc adopting a different valence resolve both the charge imbalance and the Pb underbonding?

UPb2O5 is a novel prediction with high oxi confidence (both_agree), perfect charge neutrality, but a Pauling Rule 2 violation of 40% (8 of 20 bonds violating coordination number expectations) and severe Pb underbonding at BVS 1.286 vs expected 2.0 (35.7% deviation). Its family member U4Pb3O13 (computationally known) achieves a much lower GII of 0.325 with the same U-Pb-O chemistry. Could the high Pauling violation fraction indicate that Pb2+ adopts an asymmetric coordination driven by its 6s2 lone pair, which BVS parameters for symmetric environments systematically underestimate?

Cr3(BiO4)2 is computationally known yet exhibits disagreeing oxidation state methods (both_disagree) with confirmed mixed valence, a charge neutrality residual of -1.0, and Cr underbonding (BVS 2.442 vs expected 3.0). Its family member Cr3(BiO6)2 (novel) achieves charge neutrality but with higher GII of 0.468. Given that Cr commonly adopts both +2 and +3 states and Bi can be +3 or +5, does the methods_disagree flag here signal a genuine mixed-valence Cr2+/Cr3+ compound that the automated oxidation state guessers cannot consistently resolve?

RbMn3O6 shows the largest charge neutrality failure in this batch at -4.0, combined with methods_disagree oxi confidence and mixed valence, yet passes Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 with zero violations. Across its 5-member Rb-Mn-O family, charge failures are endemic: RbMn14O28 at -26.0, RbMn2O4 at -4.0, and RbMn8O16 at -7.0. The one charge-neutral member, Rb6Mn2O7, has the worst GII at 0.581. Is GNoME systematically predicting Rb-Mn-O structures with Mn in an oxidation state that no automated method can correctly assign, given Mn's accessibility of +2, +3, +4, and +7 states?

Gd6MoO12 is a novel trigonal (SG 148, R-3) prediction with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations, but Mo shows BVS of 4.931 vs expected 6.0 (17.8% underbonding) while oxygen sites are also underbonded at -1.529 vs -2.0 (23.6% deviation). With a remarkably high formation energy of -3.5521 eV/atom and bandgap of 1.985 eV, could this represent a stable rare-earth molybdate where Mo6+ sits in an unusually large coordination polyhedron, systematically lengthening Mo-O bonds beyond the BVS reference values calibrated on tetrahedral molybdates?

Te2PbO5 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with Pauling Rule 2 warning and 20% violation fraction, and its Pb sites show severe underbonding at BVS 1.164 vs expected 2.0 (41.8% deviation). Its family member TePb7O13 has an extreme GII of 0.969 with a -6.0 charge residual. Given that Te can adopt -2, +4, or +6 oxidation states and both methods agree on oxi states here, does the oxychalcogenide classification correctly capture the bonding character, or is Te functioning as Te4+/Te6+ (a tellurite/tellurate) rather than Te2- (a chalcogenide), which would fundamentally change how BVS parameters should be applied?

Er7FeO12 is a novel trigonal (SG 148) prediction where Fe shows the strongest underbonding at BVS 2.130 vs expected 3.0 (29% deviation), while the Er sites are more mildly underbonded at 14.7%. Its structural analog Ho7FeO12 (material 82db930f1c, also SG 148) shows a strikingly similar pattern: Fe BVS 2.052 (31.6% deviation) and Ho BVS 2.581 (14% deviation). Both share Er/Ho family members with Fd-3m pyrochlore structures (Er2Fe2O7, Ho2Fe2O7) at GII ~0.64. Does the consistent Fe underbonding across both lanthanide analogs suggest these R-3 structures systematically place Fe3+ in an under-coordinated site that would be more stable in the competing pyrochlore arrangement?

Tb6MoO12 (computationally known, SG 148) and Gd6MoO12 (novel, SG 148) are isostructural rare-earth molybdates with nearly identical Mo BVS deviations: Mo at 4.899 (18.3%) and 4.931 (17.8%) respectively, and matching O underbonding at ~23.5%. Both have high formation energies (-3.617 and -3.552 eV/atom) and significant bandgaps (2.36 and 1.98 eV). Given that Tb6MoO12 is computationally known while Gd6MoO12 is novel, does the lanthanide contraction from Gd3+ (1.053 A) to Tb3+ (1.040 A) sufficiently explain the persistence of the R-3 structure type, and can we predict that other Ln6MoO12 compositions would be equally stable?

GdTi2O5 is computationally known with high oxi confidence (both_agree), yet shows a severe -4.0 charge neutrality residual and confirmed mixed valence. Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 both pass perfectly (0.0 scores), while Gd is underbonded at BVS 2.186 vs expected 3.0 (27.1% deviation). Its predicted SG 55 (Pbam) matches neither the dominant SG 62 (67%) nor SG 227 (33%) for this chemistry. Does the charge imbalance arise from mixed Ti3+/Ti4+ valence that the both_agree assignment fails to fully capture, and is the Gd underbonding a consequence of the incorrect symmetry placing Gd in a site too large for Gd3+?

Ho7FeO12 is computationally known with perfect Tier 1 checks (charge neutral, zero Shannon and Pauling violations), yet Fe shows 31.6% BVS underbonding (2.052 vs 3.0), the largest single-site deviation in this batch. Its family member Ho2Fe2O7 (novel, Fd-3m pyrochlore) has a high GII of 0.633 while Ho5(FeO6)2 (novel, C2/m) has no GII data at all. Could the 7:1 Ho:Fe ratio in Ho7FeO12 create a structure where the single Fe site is surrounded predominantly by Ho-O polyhedra, leading to anomalously long Fe-O bonds and apparent underbonding that would not occur in more Fe-rich compositions?

Rb4Al2O5 is a novel prediction with perfect charge neutrality and Shannon compliance, but Rb shows extreme 57.4% underbonding (BVS 0.426 vs expected 1.0) and Pauling Rule 2 violations reach 40%. Across all three Rb-Al-O family members (Rb5AlO4, Rb8Al2O7, and Rb4Al2O5), GII values are consistently high (0.531, 0.508, 0.401), all are novel, and all adopt P2_1/c or C2/c symmetry. Is the Rb-Al-O system fundamentally hostile to stable crystal structures because the extreme size mismatch between Rb+ (1.72 A) and Al3+ (0.535 A) prevents Rb from achieving adequate coordination in any Al-O framework?

V5CrO10 is computationally known with mixed valence and methods_disagree oxi confidence, a charge residual of -2.0, and Cr BVS of 2.367 vs expected 3.0. Both V and Cr are first-row transition metals with accessible +2/+3/+4/+5 oxidation states, and neither assignment method could converge. Given that V5CrO10 has 16 sites in a triclinic cell (SG 2), does the low symmetry create crystallographically distinct V sites with different effective oxidation states that a single oxi_state_guesses assignment cannot represent, and would site-resolved BVS analysis reveal V in multiple valence states?

TiCrO5 is a novel orthorhombic (SG 62, Pnma) prediction with both_agree oxi confidence, perfect charge neutrality, and zero Shannon violations, yet Cr6+ shows 15.1% BVS underbonding (5.096 vs expected 6.0) and Pauling Rule 2 violations reach 20%. The experimentally expected SG for Ti-Cr-O compositions is 15 (C2/c, 100%), not 62. Could the orthorhombic distortion from the expected monoclinic symmetry indicate a high-pressure polymorph where the Cr6+ tetrahedral environment is compressed, and if so, would the predicted structure become synthesizable under pressure?

Bi(SbO3)3 is a novel prediction with perfect charge neutrality, both_agree oxi confidence, and zero Pauling violations, yet Sb shows BVS of 5.844 vs expected 5.0, indicating 16.9% overbonding -- an unusual case where cations are overbonded rather than underbonded. Among its 8-member Bi-Sb-O family, GII values range widely from 0.324 (Bi2Sb4O13, computationally known) to 0.904 (Bi7SbO16, novel), with charge neutrality failures of up to -7.0. Does the Sb overbonding suggest that Sb5+ in this structure is in a compressed octahedral site, and does the trend of increasing GII with increasing Bi:Sb ratio indicate that Bi3+ with its lone pair destabilizes the Sb-O sublattice?

Ca(PtO3)2 is a novel trigonal (SG 162) prediction with only 9 sites and a single Ca BVS worst case (1.6 vs 2.0, 20% deviation). Its family member Ca(PtO2)3 (computationally known) achieves a remarkably low GII of 0.047 with charge of -1.0, while Ca6PtO8 (novel) jumps to GII 0.409. Given that Pt can adopt +2 or +4 oxidation states and the PtO3 unit implies Pt4+, does the 20% Ca underbonding reflect insufficient Ca-O coordination in the trigonal structure, and would a lower-symmetry polymorph matching SG 63 or 166 (the experimentally observed options) provide better Ca coordination and lower GII?

Sr(IrO3)3 is a novel orthorhombic (SG 63) prediction with mixed valence (Ir in multiple oxidation states), -2.0 charge residual, and Ir overbonded at BVS 5.862 vs expected 5.0 (17.2% deviation on all three Ir sites uniformly). In its 6-member Sr-Ir-O family, two members lack GII data entirely (Sr2IrO6 and Sr3(IrO5)2), while the charge-neutral Sr2Ir2O7 (computationally known, Imma) has an excellent GII of 0.157. Does the uniform Ir overbonding in Sr(IrO3)3 indicate that the assigned Ir5+ is wrong and these sites actually host Ir4+, which would resolve the -2.0 charge discrepancy and bring BVS closer to 4.0?

GdIO4 is a novel oxyhalide with both_agree oxi confidence, perfect charge neutrality, and zero Pauling violations, yet iodine shows BVS 4.219 vs expected 5.0 (15.6% underbonding) with a Pauling warning flag. Its sole family member Gd6IO12 (novel) has no computed GII or charge data. Given that I5+ in iodate (IO3-) environments typically has 3-coordinate geometry while GdIO4 implies a periodate-like 4-coordinate I environment, could the BVS underbonding reflect I5+ being in a coordination environment larger than what the BVS reference parameters were calibrated for?

Rb4(CoO2)3 is computationally known with both_agree oxi confidence and confirmed mixed valence, yet fails charge neutrality at -2.0 while oxygen sites show the worst BVS deviations (O at -1.522 vs -2.0, 23.9% underbonding). Its 8-member Rb-Co-O family is strikingly pathological: 6 of 8 members fail charge neutrality (residuals from -3.0 to -19.0), both charge-neutral members have the worst GII values (0.647 and 0.701), and GII paradoxically improves in the most charge-imbalanced compositions (0.263 for Rb3(CoO2)16 at -13.0 charge). Does this inverse correlation between geometric quality and electrostatic balance suggest GNoME optimizes bond lengths at the expense of correct stoichiometry in the Rb-Co-O system?

Dy4(MoO4)3 is a novel triclinic (SG 2) molybdate, yet experimentally known rare-earth molybdates crystallize in SG 12, 15, or 55 -- none triclinic. All Mo sites show BVS of ~3.22 against an expected +4 (deviation 19.4%), suggesting systematically underbonded Mo. Could the triclinic distortion be an artifact of GNoME relaxing into a local minimum that elongates Mo-O bonds beyond their equilibrium values, and would re-optimization under monoclinic symmetry constraints recover a more chemically reasonable BVS?

K6Br4O is a novel oxyhalide with an unusual K:Br:O ratio of 6:4:1 -- an extremely oxygen-poor composition where oxygen is the minority anion. The single O site shows BVS of -1.40 vs expected -2.0 (30% underbonded), and all Pauling Rule 2 bonds are violated (score 1.0, albeit only 2 checked). Given that the O2- assumption drives BVS calculations while this compound is dominated by Br- coordination, does the extreme underbonding of oxygen indicate it occupies an unusually large cavity better suited to Br-, questioning whether this stoichiometry is thermodynamically viable?

MgU3O10 belongs to a Mg-U-O family where two relatives (MgU8O18, MgU9O20) share the same P-1 space group and nearly identical GII values (0.228, 0.232), but both carry a residual charge of -2.0. Given that MgU3O10 itself is charge-neutral and all three are novel, could the systematic -2.0 charge imbalance in the U-rich relatives indicate that GNoME is generating a series of uranate structures that require U mixed valence (U5+/U6+) to achieve neutrality, and if so, does MgU3O10 represent the only stoichiometry in this family where a single U oxidation state (+6) suffices?

Gd11Nb3O24 is predicted in SG 1 (P1, no symmetry) with 38 sites, yet experimentally Gd-Nb oxides adopt SG 15, 20, or 63 -- all with substantial symmetry. All three Nb sites show BVS of 3.98-4.25 against expected +5 (deviations 15-20%), systematically underbonded. Its family member Gd6NbO12 (R-3) could not even compute GII or charge. With a 38-atom P1 cell where every atom is symmetry-independent, is this prediction an overparameterized GNoME solution that sacrificed physical symmetry to minimize DFT energy, producing artificially distorted Nb coordination polyhedra?

Rb6W2O9 is computationally known and passes charge neutrality and Pauling Rule 2 perfectly (0/18 violations), yet its W sites show BVS of 5.36 vs expected +6 (10.7% deviation) and one O site registers BVS of -1.48 vs -2.0 (26.1% deviation). The space group (C2/c, SG 15) appears among the experimental distribution at 25%. For a computationally validated alkali tungstate with clean Tier 1 results, does the moderate BVS deviation reflect a genuine structural strain in the Rb-W-O framework, or does it fall within the typical DFT-vs-ICSD calibration offset (median GII 0.41 for known materials)?

Tb5C2O3 is a novel rare-earth oxycarbide with mixed valence, assigned by only bv_analyzer (single_method confidence), and it fails charge neutrality with a +1.0 residual. Its family shows escalating problems: Tb2CO (GII 0.766, charge neutral) and Tb4C2O (GII 0.945, charge +2.0). Pauling Rule 2 violations are maximal (score 1.0, only 3 bonds checked), and all Tb sites show BVS ~2.47-2.49 vs expected +3 (17% deviation). With cascading failures across Tier 1 and Tier 2, and oxi state disagreement between methods, does this represent a case where GNoME's training data lacked sufficient rare-earth carbide examples to learn correct C-O bonding environments?

HoIO4 is computationally known and shares SG 63 (Cmcm) and identical n_sites (12) with its isostructural analogues ErIO4 and LuIO4 from this batch, yet experimentally the REIO4 family crystallizes in SG 14 (P2_1/c). All three show I BVS of ~4.2-4.3 vs expected +5 (15% deviation). Its family member HoIO5 (novel, P2_1/c, GII 0.212) has lower strain. Could the SG 63 polymorph of REIO4 compounds represent a high-pressure or high-temperature phase that GNoME finds energetically competitive, and does the consistent I underbonding across the series indicate that the orthorhombic polymorph systematically undercoordinates iodine?

LuIO4 shares the exact same space group (63), site count (12), and oxyhalide classification as HoIO4 and ErIO4 in this batch, forming an isostructural REIO4 series. However, LuIO4 uniquely shows a Pauling Rule 2 violation score of 0.5 (4/8 bonds violated) while HoIO4 and ErIO4 score 0.0. Given that Lu3+ is the smallest lanthanide ion (Shannon radius 0.861 A for CN=6), does the lanthanide contraction push Lu-O bonds below the threshold where Pauling electrostatic valence sums balance, and should the Pauling Rule 2 tolerance be adjusted for end-of-series lanthanides?

Gd2VO5 is novel but adopts SG 62 (Pnma), which matches 50% of experimental Gd-V-O space groups -- the highest space group agreement score (0.5) in this batch. All V sites show identical BVS of 3.354 vs expected +4 (16.1% deviation), and its family members Gd7VO12 (GII 0.384) and GdV3O9 (GII 0.302) are both charge-neutral novels with moderate strain. Could Gd2VO5 represent a genuinely synthesizable novel vanadate given its experimentally matching symmetry, zero Pauling violations (0/20), and a coherent family of charge-neutral relatives, with the V underbonding being within the expected DFT calibration offset?

Sm3BiO7 is computationally known yet adopts triclinic SG 2 instead of the experimentally universal SG 139 (I4/mmm) for this composition. Its Sm sites show BVS of 2.194 vs expected +3 (26.9% deviation) while Bi is overbonded at 5.635 vs +5 (12.7% excess). The Sm-Bi-O family shows a pattern: charge-neutral members (Sm2Bi2O7, Sm5Bi3O14) have high GII (0.724, 0.653), while Bi-rich members (Sm(BiO2)7, Sm3Bi5O14) carry -4.0 charge. Does the opposing Sm underbonding / Bi overbonding indicate a size mismatch driving the triclinic distortion, and could this compound actually be a pyrochlore (Fd-3m) that GNoME misassigned?

Tb7FeO12 is novel in SG 148 (R-3), matching one of three experimental space groups for this family (score 0.333). However, the Fe site shows BVS of only 2.024 vs expected +3 (32.5% deviation) -- among the largest single-site deviations in this batch. Its family member Tb2Fe2O7 (Fd-3m, pyrochlore) has GII 0.677, while Tb5(FeO6)2 (C2/m) shows GII 0.325 but carries -3.0 charge. Is the extreme Fe underbonding evidence that Fe actually occupies a site too large for Fe3+ in the R-3 structure, possibly suggesting Fe2+ mixed valence that the oxi assignment (both_agree on Fe3+) failed to capture?

Sr4Ir6O19 is computationally known in cubic SG 197 (I23) -- a rare chiral space group -- yet no experimental Sr-Ir-O is cubic (closest: SG 15, 62, 139). All Sr sites show identical BVS of 1.304 vs expected +2 (34.8% deviation), the most severe alkaline earth underbonding in this batch. Its family spans 6 compositions with GII ranging from 0.157 (Sr2Ir2O7, Imma) to 0.747 (SrIr5O13), and the bandgap is essentially zero (0.0014 eV). Does the extreme Sr underbonding in a metallic iridate indicate that Sr is acting more as a spacer than a true ionic participant, and could this be a Ruddlesden-Popper relative where standard BVS parameters are inappropriate?

EuGa4O7 is a novel gallate in monoclinic SG 15 (C2/c) while all experimental Eu-Ga-O compounds adopt SG 36 (Cmc2_1). Eu shows BVS of 1.421 vs expected +2 (28.9% deviation), suggesting Eu2+ is significantly underbonded, while Ga shows 2.565 vs +3 (14.5% deviation). With Eu2+ being unusually large for a divalent cation (Shannon radius ~1.25 A for CN=8) and Ga3+ being small and tetrahedral, could the Eu underbonding reflect a mismatch between the large Eu2+ ion and the cavity size in a gallate framework designed for smaller cations, indicating this stoichiometry may require Eu3+ instead?

Sr5Pu5O18 is a novel actinide oxide with only single_method (oxi_state_guesses) confidence and a -1.0 charge residual. Its family of 5 relatives shows a clear pattern: charge-neutral members (Sr2PuO5 GII 0.485, Sr5Pu2O12 GII 0.643, SrPu2O8 GII 0.667) have moderate-to-high strain, while the closely related Sr5Pu5O19 (just one extra oxygen) carries -3.0 charge with lower GII (0.307). Could Sr5Pu5O18 actually be the oxygen-deficient variant of Sr5Pu5O19, where one oxygen vacancy per formula unit would resolve the charge imbalance and the low oxi confidence reflects genuine ambiguity in Pu oxidation state assignment?

Sm(CoO2)8 is computationally known but exhibits the worst charge neutrality failure in this batch (-5.0 residual) combined with methods_disagree oxi confidence and mixed valence. The Sm site shows BVS of only 1.654 vs expected +3 (44.9% deviation) -- the single largest BVS deviation in the entire batch. Despite this, Shannon radii pass (score 0.0) and Pauling Rule 2 shows zero violations (0/16). This is a classic tier conflict: Tier 1 passes, Tier 2 fails catastrophically. Does the -5.0 charge residual indicate that Co cannot be uniformly assigned +2 or +3 but requires a specific Co2+/Co3+ mixed-valence ratio that neither oxi method captured correctly?

Na2Se2O5 is a novel oxychalcogenide (Se4+ with O2-) with the highest space group match score in this batch among novel compounds (0.222, matching SG 14 at 22%). All Se sites show identical BVS of 3.216 vs expected +4 (19.6% deviation). As an oxychalcogenide, the BVS calculation assumes standard O2- parameters, but selenite (SeO3^2-) groups have distinctly asymmetric bonding due to the Se4+ lone pair. Does the systematic Se underbonding reflect a genuine structural issue, or is it an artifact of applying O2--only BVS parameters to a compound where the Se lone pair creates inherently asymmetric coordination that standard BVS tables do not account for?

Pr2I4O13 is a novel oxyhalide with 76 sites -- the largest unit cell in this batch by far -- in SG 19 (P2_12_12_1), a chiral space group. It is the only material in this batch with a non-zero Shannon radii score (0.0455), meaning 4.55% of ions have radii outside the 25% tolerance. All I sites show BVS of 4.185 vs expected +5 (16.3% deviation). Its family member PrIO4 (computationally known, GII 0.411) is in the standard Cmcm structure. With 4 iodine and 13 oxygen per 2 Pr in a 76-atom cell, is this an unusually complex iodate superstructure, and does the Shannon radii violation flag a site where I7+ or Pr3+ coordination geometry is geometrically implausible at this cell size?

Rb3(OsO4)2 is computationally known but shows a -1.0 charge residual with only single_method oxi confidence, and its Rb sites exhibit extreme underbonding: BVS of 0.583-0.619 vs expected +1 (38-42% deviation). Its family of 5 Rb-Os-O compounds shows that charge-neutral members (Rb4Os2O9, Rb4OsO4, Rb3OsO5) all have GII of 0.35-0.38, while Rb3(OsO4)2 itself has GII ~0.39. Given that Rb+ is among the largest alkali cations (Shannon radius ~1.52 A for CN=6), does the severe Rb underbonding indicate that the trigonal R-3m structure provides cavities too large even for Rb+, or does the -1.0 charge residual suggest Os should be in a +7 rather than +8 state?

Tb3IO8 is a novel oxyhalide in trigonal SG 160 (R3m) with methods_disagree oxi confidence and a -2.0 charge residual. Critically, the I site shows BVS of 6.216 vs expected +5 -- it is overbonded by 24.3%, the opposite direction from the systematic I underbonding seen in HoIO4, LuIO4, and ErIO4 (all ~15% underbonded). One O site is also overbonded at -2.409 (20.5% excess). With its family members TbIO4 (GII 0.385) and Tb2IO6 (GII 0.374) both being computationally known, does the anomalous I overbonding combined with the -2.0 charge failure suggest that iodine should actually be I7+ rather than I5+ in this structure, which would resolve the charge imbalance?

Ca5U5O19 is computationally known with methods_disagree oxi confidence, mixed valence, and a -3.0 charge residual. Its 7-member Ca-U-O family is the largest in this batch, and U-rich members (CaU5O12 GII 0.158, CaU8O18 GII 0.150, CaU9O20 GII 0.160, CaU4O10 GII 0.142) all show remarkably low GII despite carrying -2.0 charge. The U BVS values in Ca5U5O19 (5.7-6.0 vs expected +5) suggest U is closer to +6. Could the entire Ca-U-O family be best described with U6+ throughout, where the systematic -2.0 charge in U-rich members and -3.0 in Ca5U5O19 would vanish if the oxi assignment shifted from U5+ to U6+?

Ba2Os7O18 is a novel osmium oxide with a -4.0 charge residual and single_method oxi confidence, yet its 8-member Ba-Os-O family reveals a striking trend: Ba2(OsO3)3 (I23, GII 0.045) has the lowest GII in the entire batch's family data, while Ba3OsO7 (P4/mbm, GII 0.745) has among the highest. The charge-neutral family members cluster at GII 0.11-0.32, while charge-imbalanced members span GII 0.045-0.481. Given that Ba2(OsO3)3 achieves near-perfect BVS despite a -4.0 charge, could the Os oxidation state in this family be genuinely ambiguous between Os6+ and Os8+, with the GII minimum at Ba2(OsO3)3 indicating this is the true ground-state stoichiometry?

Eu4(PO4)3 is computationally known in cubic SG 220 (I-43d) -- an unusual high-symmetry space group for a phosphate -- while experiments place this composition exclusively in monoclinic SG 14 (P2_1/c). Despite methods_disagree oxi confidence and a -2.0 charge residual, the P sites show BVS of 5.951 vs expected +5 (19% overbonded), and Pauling Rule 2 is perfectly satisfied (0/24 violations). The -2.0 charge and P overbonding together suggest P is closer to +6 than +5 in this structure. Since P6+ does not exist in conventional chemistry, does this indicate the GNoME structure has compressed P-O bonds below physical limits to accommodate the cubic symmetry, producing an artifact of DFT over-optimization?

ErIO4 is computationally known and isostructural with HoIO4 and LuIO4 (all SG 63, 12 sites, oxyhalide), forming a systematic REIO4 series across this batch. ErIO4 shows I BVS of 4.255 vs expected +5 (14.9% deviation), falling between HoIO4 (4.227, 15.5%) and LuIO4 (4.248, 15.0%). The O BVS deviations follow the same ordering: Ho 17.5%, Er 17.8%, Lu 19.0%. Does this monotonic trend in O underbonding with decreasing RE3+ radius (Ho > Er > Lu) indicate that lanthanide contraction progressively destabilizes the Cmcm REIO4 polymorph, and could extrapolation predict which smaller lanthanides (Tm, Yb) would show even larger BVS deviations?

Na6Be2O5 is computationally known in tetragonal SG 136 (P4_2/mnm) while experiments place Na-Be-O compounds in triclinic SG 2. All Na sites show BVS of only 0.46 vs expected +1 (54% deviation) -- the most severe alkali underbonding in the entire batch. Despite this extreme Na underbonding, charge neutrality is perfect (0.0) and Shannon radii pass. With Na+ achieving barely half its expected bond valence, the Na-O distances must be dramatically elongated. Could this structure represent a Na-stuffed beryllate framework where Na rattles in oversized cavities, and does the 54% BVS deviation exceed the threshold where the structure should be considered physically implausible regardless of DFT energy?

Eu2AuO5 is a novel gold oxide with only single_method oxi confidence, a -4.0 charge residual, and a near-zero bandgap (0.0016 eV) suggesting metallic behavior. All Eu sites show BVS of 2.402 vs expected +2 (20.1% overbonded), implying Eu may actually be closer to Eu3+. The sole family member Eu6AuO12 (R-3) could not compute GII or charge. If Eu is reassigned from Eu2+ to Eu3+, the formula Eu2^3+Au^3+O5^2- sums to +9 vs -10, still leaving a -1 residual. Could this compound require Au in an unusual oxidation state (Au3+ or Au5+) to achieve neutrality, and does the near-zero bandgap support a mixed-valence Eu2+/Eu3+ scenario with metallic conductivity?

DyIO4 is classified as an oxyhalide, yet BVS analysis treats iodine as I5+ with a computed BVS of 4.253 (deviation 0.149 from expected 5). Its family member Dy3IO8 is novel with a lower GII of 0.337 compared to DyIO4's 0.390 -- does the higher Dy:I ratio in Dy3IO8 allow iodine to achieve a more favorable coordination environment, and could this suggest that GNoME's predicted DyIO4 structure has iodine in a geometry that systematically undervalues its bond valence?

Ho2VO5 shows vanadium with a BVS of 3.434 against an expected V4+ (deviation 0.142), while three Ho-V-O family members span different stoichiometries: HoV3O9 (GII 0.304, novel), Ho5V2O12 (GII 0.336, charge -1.0), and Ho7VO12 (GII 0.338). The monotonic increase in GII as the Ho:V ratio rises suggests that vanadium-poor compositions accumulate geometric strain on the rare-earth sublattice. Could V4+ be the wrong oxidation state assignment, and would V5+ with a compensating oxygen vacancy better explain the 15% BVS deficit?

Nd(TcO4)3 adopts hexagonal SG 176 but its known experimental analogs exclusively use cubic SG 227 (100%). With oxi confidence at only 'single_method' and Nd showing a BVS of 2.611 vs expected 3+ (13% deficit), while the Nd-Tc-O family shows wild GII variation from 0.366 (Nd2TcO6) to 1.621 (Nd6Tc16O), does the hexagonal polymorph represent a genuine metastable phase for rare-earth pertechnetate, or is the 13% Nd underbonding evidence that the predicted structure has Nd in an unrealistically low-coordination site?

Novel Lu3CrO6 has Cr with BVS values of 2.041 and 2.336 against an expected Cr3+ (deviations of 32% and 22%), making it one of the most severely underbonded transition metals in this batch. Yet both oxi state methods agree on the assignment, and the material passes charge neutrality and Shannon radii checks. Its family members Lu2Cr3O8 and Lu2Cr3O12 are also novel with non-trivial charges (-1.0 and 0.0). Is the 22-32% Cr underbonding a signature that GNoME placed chromium in an octahedral site too large for Cr3+ (r = 0.615 A), or could Cr2+ (r = 0.73 A) be the correct oxidation state?

Tb5Cr2O12 is computationally known but carries a -1.0 charge residual, mixed valence flag, and near-zero bandgap (0.0031 eV) -- all pointing to a metallic or semimetallic character unusual for a rare-earth chromate. Cr shows BVS of 3.32 vs expected 4+ (17% deficit) while Tb is at 2.432 vs 3+ (19% deficit). Its family member Tb2Cr3O12 is novel with GII of 0.522, substantially worse. Does the simultaneous underbonding of both cation types suggest the structure is under tensile strain, and could the near-zero bandgap indicate an electron delocalization pathway that classical BVS cannot capture?

CaOsO4 has all three Ca sites showing identical BVS of 1.611 vs expected Ca2+ (19.5% deficit), achieved with only single-method oxi confidence. Its sole family member Ca11(OsO6)4 is novel with a -4.0 charge residual but a substantially lower GII of 0.352 vs 0.389. Given that osmium chemistry commonly features Os6+ and Os8+, could the oxi state guesser have assigned the wrong Os charge, and would recalculating with Os6+ instead of the assumed state resolve both the systematic Ca underbonding and the family member's charge imbalance?

Na7Ga3O8 is unusual in having a nonzero Shannon radii violation score (0.0111), one of the few materials in this batch to trigger that check. Ga shows BVS of 2.478 vs expected 3+ (17.4% deficit), and a specific oxygen site has BVS of -1.499 vs -2 (25% deficit). The related Na3Ga5O9 (computationally known, GII 0.346) has a very different Na:Ga ratio. Does the Na-rich stoichiometry of Na7Ga3O8 create an environment where some oxygen sites are coordinated predominantly by Na+ with weak bonds, producing the observed 25% oxygen underbonding and the rare Shannon radii flag?

Novel K2Mn5O10 exhibits a remarkable convergence of red flags: methods_disagree on oxidation states, mixed valence, -3.0 charge residual, and null bandgap. Its BVS shows Mn at 2.457 vs expected 3+ and oxygen at -1.492 vs -2 (25.4% deficit). The sole family member K7MnO6 has the inverse K:Mn ratio and is also novel with GII 0.346. With oxidation state methods disagreeing, could the assumed Mn3+/Mn4+ mixed valence be incorrect, and would a uniform Mn2+ assignment with a different oxygen framework stoichiometry resolve the -3.0 charge discrepancy?

Novel Pr6IrO12 has methods_disagree on oxidation states, a -1.0 charge residual, and all three worst-BVS sites are oxygen with identical deviations of 0.246 (BVS -1.508 vs -2). Across its family, both Pr5(IrO6)2 and Pr3(IrO5)2 are computationally known but also carry -1.0 charge residuals. The systematic -1.0 charge across three independent Pr-Ir-O compositions suggests the oxidation state assignment consistently underestimates one cation's charge by exactly 1. Is Ir4+ being misassigned instead of Ir5+, given that iridium commonly adopts the 5+ state in oxide perovskite-related structures?

Cs6W2O9 is the only material in this batch with both a nonzero Pauling Rule 2 violation (0.222, 4 of 18 bonds violated) and a significant BVS score. Tungsten shows BVS of 5.313 vs expected W6+ (11.4% deficit) while oxygen is at -1.496 (25.2% deficit). Across the Cs-W-O family, GII ranges from 0.246 (Cs2W3O10) to 0.417 (Cs(WO3)6), and two family members carry extreme charge residuals of -5.0 and -9.0. Could the Pauling violations indicate that W is forced into irregular coordination polyhedra by the large Cs+ cations, producing underbonded oxygen sites at polyhedral edges?

Novel Dy5Mn2O12 has no family members in the dataset, making it an isolated prediction in Dy-Mn-O composition space. It shows -1.0 charge residual, null bandgap, and single-method oxi confidence. Both Mn sites are underbonded at 3.387 vs 4+ (15.3% deficit) and Dy at 2.433 vs 3+ (18.9% deficit). With no related compositions to provide structural context and only oxi_state_guesses available, is this an inherently difficult composition for GNoME's neural network, and should the absence of any Dy-Mn-O family members reduce confidence in this prediction?

Novel Ir4Pb3O14 presents a striking BVS inversion: Pb shows BVS of 2.911 against an expected Pb2+ (45.5% overbonded), while the material carries a -2.0 charge residual with methods_disagree on oxidation states. The family member Ir4Pb3O13 (also novel) is charge-neutral with a much lower GII of 0.230, differing by exactly one oxygen atom. Does the 45.5% Pb overbonding indicate that Pb is actually in the 4+ state rather than 2+, and could the O14 vs O13 stoichiometry difference between the two family members reflect a Pb2+/Pb4+ oxidation state ambiguity that GNoME cannot distinguish?

Novel Nb4Sn3O13 shows all three Sn sites with identical BVS of 1.442 vs expected Sn2+ but also has a 23.1% Pauling Rule 2 violation rate (3 of 13 bonds). Despite both oxi methods agreeing and charge neutrality being satisfied, the 27.9% Sn underbonding is substantial. Given that Sn commonly exists as both Sn2+ and Sn4+ and the material has no family members, could a partial Sn4+ assignment with compensating Nb reduction better fit the predicted structure, or does the consistent 27.9% underbonding across all Sn sites indicate uniformly stretched Sn-O bonds in this trigonal framework?

Novel Ho2Cr3O8 has mixed valence, methods_disagree, and a -1.0 charge residual -- yet zero Pauling violations across 8 checked bonds. Cr shows BVS of 2.403 vs expected 3+ (19.9% deficit). Its Ho-Cr-O family members Ho7CrO12 (GII 0.373) and Ho5Cr2O12 (GII 0.381, charge -1.0) suggest a systematic pattern where Cr-rich compositions carry charge residuals. Comparing with batch-mate Lu3CrO6 (Cr BVS 2.041-2.336), rare-earth chromates in this dataset consistently show 20-32% Cr underbonding. Is this a systematic BVS reference parameter issue for Cr3+ in rare-earth oxide environments?

Tm2VO5 is computationally known and one of the best-performing materials in this batch: space group score 0.333 (SG 62 matches 33% of experimental data), charge neutral, zero Shannon/Pauling violations, and both oxi methods agree. Its worst BVS sites are three equivalent oxygen atoms at -1.420 (29% deficit). Its family member Tm7VO12 has GII of 0.338, nearly identical to analog Ho7VO12 (0.338) and Gd7VO12's family member. Does this RE7VO12 series (RE = Gd, Ho, Tm) with identical GII values across the lanthanide contraction represent a structurally rigid prototype where the R-3 framework accommodates ionic radius changes without strain?

Nd(CoO2)8 has the largest charge residual magnitude in this batch at -5.0, with methods_disagree on oxidation states and mixed valence. Nd shows a dramatic BVS of 1.700 vs expected 3+ (43.3% deficit). Its four family members span a wide range: Nd(CoO2)3 has GII 0.291 (charge-neutral), while Nd4Co2O9 has GII 0.558, and two others have null GII values entirely. With 8 Co atoms per formula unit in P1 symmetry, is this structure physically plausible, or does the 43.3% Nd underbonding combined with the extreme charge imbalance suggest a fundamental error in the predicted atomic positions?

TbIO4, DyIO4, and TmIO4 form an isostructural REIO4 oxyhalide series in this batch, all in SG 63 (Cmcm) with 12 sites. Their BVS scores are nearly identical (0.384-0.390) and all show I at ~4.25 vs expected I5+ (15% deficit). TbIO4 reports an infinite bandgap while DyIO4 has 3.30 eV -- is the infinite bandgap a DFT artifact from the Tb 4f electron configuration, and does the remarkable BVS consistency across the series (I BVS: 4.245, 4.253, 4.252) confirm that the 15% iodine underbonding is a systematic feature of the Cmcm iodate structure rather than a per-material prediction error?

Novel Gd7VO12 shows vanadium with BVS of 2.180 vs expected V3+ (27.3% deficit) and Gd at 2.580 vs 3+ (14.0% deficit). Its family member Gd2VO5 (also novel, GII 0.395) and GdV3O9 (novel, GII 0.302) bracket the V-content spectrum. Notably, GdV3O9 has the lowest GII in the family despite having the most vanadium. Does this inverse correlation between V-content and structural strain suggest that vanadium-rich compositions allow V to select its preferred tetrahedral coordination, while V-poor Gd7VO12 forces V into an oversized site surrounded by Gd, explaining the 27.3% underbonding?

Novel Rb3Nb16O23 has the highest Pauling Rule 2 violation rate in this batch at 78.3% (18 of 23 bonds), the most extreme charge residual at -11.0, and Nb showing BVS of 2.896 vs expected Nb2+ (44.8% overbonded). The Rb-Nb-O family shows well-behaved members like RbNb3O8 (GII 0.279, charge-neutral) and RbNb5O8 (GII 0.247, charge-neutral). With 42 sites and 16 Nb atoms, could the extreme Pauling violations and overbonding indicate that Nb is actually Nb5+ rather than Nb2+, which would require a fundamentally different oxygen stoichiometry to achieve charge neutrality?

Novel V7BiO18 has mixed valence, both methods agree on oxidation states, yet the charge residual is -5.0. The BVS data reveals a striking internal inconsistency: one V site has BVS 2.669 vs expected V4+ (33.3% deficit) while two other V sites show 4.471 and 4.463 (11.8% excess). With no family members and P1 symmetry, the coexistence of severely under- and over-bonded vanadium sites in the same structure raises the question: does this mixed-valence V3+/V5+ assignment mask what should be a uniform V5+ with a different Bi oxidation state?

TmIO4 is the third REIO4 oxyhalide in this batch (alongside DyIO4 and TbIO4), all sharing SG 63 with 12 sites. While its family members Tm2IO6 and Tm6IO12 both have null GII and charge values -- meaning BVS could not be computed for them -- TmIO4 itself has GII 0.384. What structural or chemical feature of Tm2IO6 (P2/c) and Tm6IO12 (R-3) prevents BVS computation when TmIO4 succeeds, and does this suggest that these higher-order Tm-I-O compositions have coordination environments outside the BVS parameterization range?

Nd(SbO3)3 achieves the highest space group score in this batch (0.40), with its predicted SG 63 matching 40% of experimental analogs. Sb shows BVS of 5.817 vs expected 5+ (16.3% overbonded), the only material in this batch with a significantly overbonded worst-site cation. Its family member NdSb5O12 has GII of 0.691 -- nearly double. Does the 16.3% Sb overbonding indicate compressed Sb-O bonds that could make this a high-pressure phase, and does the dramatic GII increase to 0.691 when the Sb:Nd ratio rises to 5:1 suggest a solubility limit for antimony in the Nd-Sb-O system?

Novel BaV7O14 has the largest unit cell in this batch (88 sites) and the most extreme charge residual at -20.0, with mixed valence and both oxi methods agreeing. Ba shows BVS of 1.198 and 1.347 vs expected Ba2+ (40.1% and 32.6% deficits). With 50 Pauling bonds checked and zero violations despite a -20.0 charge imbalance, the structure satisfies local coordination rules but catastrophically fails global electroneutrality.
