Does this indicate that the predicted structure has physically reasonable local bonding but an impossible stoichiometry, suggesting GNoME correctly predicted the topology but not the composition?

Novel Tb2VO5 has the highest space group score in this entire batch (0.50), with SG 62 (Pnma) matching 50% of experimental analogs for this composition type. It is charge-neutral with zero Shannon and Pauling violations, and all three worst V sites show identical BVS of 3.392 vs expected V4+ (15.2% deficit). With no family members to compare, and noting that Ho2VO5 and Tm2VO5 in this batch are both computationally known with nearly identical BVS profiles, is Tb2VO5 a strong synthesis candidate that the RE2VO5 (RE = Tb, Ho, Tm) series predicts should exist but has simply not been computed before?

Gd3BiO7 has the largest family in this batch with six members, and the family reveals a dramatic trend: GII escalates from 0.382 (Gd3BiO7 itself) to 0.660 (Gd5Bi3O14), 0.724 (Gd2Bi2O7), 0.797 (Gd(BiO2)7), 0.809 (GdBi3O7), and 0.825 (Gd3Bi5O14). The GII correlates strongly with Bi content -- every increase in the Bi:Gd ratio worsens structural strain. With Gd showing BVS of 2.229 vs 3+ (25.7% deficit) and Bi at 5.727 vs 5+ (14.5% excess), does the anti-correlated bonding behavior suggest that Bi3+ rather than Bi5+ should be assigned, which would fundamentally alter the charge balance and potentially collapse the GII escalation pattern across the family?

Os4Pb4O13 adopts SG 216 (F-43m) while 100% of experimental Os-Pb oxides crystallize in SG 227 (Fd-3m), both cubic but with different symmetry operations. The BVS analysis shows all Pb sites systematically under-bonded at 1.575 v.u. vs. expected 2+ (deviation 0.213), yet the charge neutrality residual is only -2.0. Could the unusual 4:4:13 stoichiometry require a Pb lone-pair-driven distortion that lowers the symmetry from Fd-3m to F-43m, and if so, why does GNoME's DFT relaxation not recover the higher-symmetry structure?

The Eu-Pt-O family spans three stoichiometries with dramatically different structural quality: Eu6PtO12 (R-3, GII 0.29), Eu3PtO7 (Cmcm, GII 0.38), and Eu(PtO3)2 (P-31m, GII 0.937, charge -1.0). The progressive worsening of GII from 0.29 to 0.94 as the Pt:Eu ratio increases suggests that higher Pt content forces geometrically unfavorable coordination environments for Eu3+. Could the low-Pt end-member Eu6PtO12 represent the thermodynamic ground state of this system, with Eu3PtO7 as a metastable intermediate?

Rb4Os2O9 belongs to a five-member Rb-Os-O family where every composition has been computationally explored, yet only Rb4OsO4 (GII 0.352, charge 0.0) and Rb3OsO5 (GII 0.357, charge 0.0) achieve charge neutrality. The remaining three -- including Rb4Os2O9 itself -- show charge residuals of -1.0, -2.0, and -4.0 despite similar GII values (0.38-0.46). Given that all Rb sites are systematically under-bonded at 0.52 v.u. vs. expected 1+, and all 18 Pauling Rule 2 bonds are violated, is GNoME predicting an oxygen-excess structure that would require partial Rb occupancy to stabilize?

Ho5Cr2O12 is flagged as mixed-valence with disagreeing oxidation state methods and a charge residual of -1.0, yet BVS finds Cr at 3.35 v.u. vs. expected 4+ and Ho at 2.455 v.u. vs. expected 3+. Its family member Ho7CrO12 (R-3, GII 0.373) achieves charge neutrality with a lower GII. Why does the Ho5Cr2O12 stoichiometry -- which should accommodate Cr4+/Cr3+ mixed valence -- appear less stable than the Ho-richer Ho7CrO12 where Cr is presumably all Cr3+, and does this reflect a genuine thermodynamic preference or an artifact of the oxi state assignment disagreement?

Er5Mn2O12 is structurally isomorphic to Ho5Cr2O12 (same SG 12, same 19-site cell, same monoclinic system), yet Er5Mn2O12 shows no mixed valence and has no family members in the dataset. BVS reveals Er at 2.444 v.u. (dev 0.185) and Mn at 3.446 v.u. (dev 0.138) vs. expected Mn4+. Given that Mn4+ is significantly more common than Cr4+ in oxide chemistry, could this structural isomorphism between RE5M2O12 compounds (RE = Ho, Er; M = Cr, Mn) indicate a robust structure type where the lanthanide contraction from Ho to Er compensates for the smaller Mn4+ ionic radius?

Ba4Re2O11 has the strongest oxi confidence (both_agree) and perfect charge neutrality in this batch, yet its Pauling Rule 2 violation rate of 90.9% (10 of 11 bonds) is among the highest. The family member Ba3(ReO5)2 (GII 0.287, charge 0.0) has a markedly better GII than Ba4Re2O11 (0.379). With a bandgap of 1.89 eV -- the largest among the Re-containing compounds here -- could the extreme Pauling violations indicate that Ba4Re2O11 adopts an unusual Ba coordination environment that sacrifices local electrostatic balance to achieve a wider electronic gap?

Pr(SbO3)3 matches experimental SG 63 (Cmcm) at 20% representation and achieves charge neutrality with both oxi methods agreeing, yet all three Sb sites are overbonded at 5.808 v.u. vs. expected 5+ (dev 0.162). Its family member PrSb5O12 (R-3m, GII 0.680, charge -1.0) has a GII nearly double that of PrSbO (GII 0.314, charge 0.0). Given that the BVS R0 parameters for Sb5+-O bonds were calibrated on smaller coordination numbers, could the systematic Sb overbonding in the Sb-rich compositions indicate that BVS reference parameters need recalibration for highly connected Sb-O networks?

K8Nb6O19 is novel with perfect charge neutrality, both oxi methods agree, and a wide bandgap of 3.58 eV, yet it has a specific oxygen site with BVS of only -1.341 v.u. (dev 0.330 from expected -2), suggesting a severely under-coordinated bridging oxygen. Its five-member K-Nb-O family shows that charge-neutral compositions (KNb5O8, GII 0.242; K5NbO5, GII 0.422) bracket the GII range. Could the K8Nb6O19 stoichiometry correspond to the Lindqvist-type [Nb6O19]8- polyoxometalate cluster, and if so, does the under-bonded oxygen at -1.341 v.u. correspond to the terminal oxo ligand characteristic of this cluster geometry?

Er2V3O8 is novel with both oxi methods agreeing on mixed valence (V3+/V5+), yet charge neutrality shows a residual of -2.0 and all three worst BVS deviations are on vanadium sites showing 2.44 v.u. vs. expected 3+ (dev ~0.185). Its sole family member Er2VO5 (Pnma, GII 0.414, charge 0.0) achieves neutrality with a simpler V5+ assignment. If the mixed-valence V3+/V5+ assignment is correct for Er2V3O8, the observed BVS values of ~2.44 on the V3+ sites suggest the V-O bonds are slightly too long -- could this indicate that the DFT-relaxed structure over-expands the V3+ polyhedra, a known issue with GGA functionals for reduced transition metals?

La2I4O13 is an oxyhalide with 76 sites -- the largest unit cell in this batch -- and achieves perfect charge neutrality despite being novel. However, its La-I-O family reveals a striking pattern: La2I2O9 and La6IO12 both have null GII and null charge values (validation could not run), while LaIO4 (GII 0.357, charge 0.0) validates cleanly. With Shannon radii showing a small but nonzero violation fraction of 0.0227 (unusual for this dataset where most score exactly 0.0), could the I5+ oxidation state in this large cell create coordination environments that push the limits of Shannon's tabulated ionic radii?

Cs3(OsO4)2 has a charge residual of -1.0 and all Cs sites are severely under-bonded (0.612-0.628 v.u. vs. expected 1+), yet its family includes Cs(OsO3)3 (GII 0.078) and Cs5(OsO3)18 (GII 0.046) -- both with extraordinarily low GII values but massive charge residuals of -4.0 and -13.0 respectively. This six-member Cs-Os-O family suggests that the best-bonded structures are the least charge-balanced. Could this systematic anticorrelation between GII and charge neutrality indicate that the oxi state assignment for Os in the OsO3 stoichiometry is incorrect, and Os6+ rather than Os8+ would resolve the charge discrepancies?

Dy2Cr3O8 is structurally identical to Lu2Cr3O8 (both SG 12, 13 sites, monoclinic, mixed-valence, methods_disagree) with nearly identical GII (0.378 vs. 0.375) and the same charge residual of -1.0. Both show Cr under-bonded at ~2.42 v.u. vs. expected 3+ and O under-bonded at ~-1.54 v.u. Yet Dy2Cr3O8 has a family member Dy2Cr3O12 (GII 0.538, charge 0.0) that achieves charge neutrality. Does the RE2Cr3O8 structure type (RE = Dy, Lu) represent a systematic oxygen-deficient variant of RE2Cr3O12 where Cr mixed valence is geometrically required, and could the lanthanide contraction from Dy to Lu explain why no charge-neutral O12 variant appears in Lu's family?

Cs3(TcO4)2 is isostructural with Cs3(OsO4)2 -- both monoclinic SG 5, 13 sites, charge residual -1.0, with Cs under-bonded at ~0.61 v.u. Yet experimental Cs-Tc oxides crystallize exclusively in SG 62 (Pnma), while Cs-Os oxides appear in SG 9 (Cc). Its family member Cs3TcO5 (Cmcm, GII 0.299, charge 0.0) achieves neutrality with better GII. Given that Tc and Os are adjacent 4d/5d congeners with similar tetrahedral oxoanion chemistry, does the identical structural distortion in both Cs3(MO4)2 compounds (M = Tc, Os) suggest a systematic DFT artifact in modeling large-cation alkali osmate/pertechnetate structures?

Rb6Se2O9 is an oxychalcogenide in cubic SG 225 (Fm-3m, the highest-symmetry space group in this batch) with perfect charge neutrality and both oxi methods agreeing, yet BVS reveals an oxygen site at only -1.093 v.u. (dev 0.453) -- nearly half the expected -2.0 valence. This is the most extreme oxygen under-bonding in the entire batch. Given the oxychalcogenide classification and the Pauling Rule 2 warning flag, could this anomalous oxygen site actually be a Se2- site misidentified as O2- by the structure parser, which would explain both the extreme BVS deviation and the unusual Se:O stoichiometry?

K17Al5O16 has a highly unusual alkali-rich stoichiometry with a K:Al:O ratio of 17:5:16, yet achieves perfect charge neutrality with both oxi methods agreeing. The BVS worst deviations are all on oxygen sites (~-1.44 v.u., dev ~0.28), suggesting systematic under-bonding of O in an alkali-excess environment. With 62.5% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 16 checked bonds and its sole family member K9AlO4 having null GII/charge data, could this extreme K-excess composition represent an electride-like material where excess K electrons occupy interstitial sites rather than contributing to traditional K-O bonding?

Ru4(OF3)3 is an oxyhalide in triclinic SG 1 (P1, the lowest symmetry possible) with the worst charge residual in this batch at -3.0, disagreeing oxi methods, mixed valence, and 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation across all 3 checked bonds. Its family spans a wide GII range from 0.412 (Ru2OF5) to 0.901 (RuO2F) with none achieving charge neutrality better than -1.0. Given this cascade of validation failures across every check, does Ru4(OF3)3 represent a false positive in GNoME's predictions where the Ru-O-F phase space is poorly sampled in the DFT training data?

BaV6O12 has the most extreme charge residual among pure oxides in this batch at -8.0, with disagreeing oxi methods and mixed valence, yet passes Pauling Rule 2 perfectly (0/24 violations). Its family member BaV7O14 has an astonishing charge residual of -20.0 despite a reasonable GII of 0.384. Meanwhile Ba10V6O25 (GII 0.480, charge 0.0) achieves neutrality but with worse bonding. This pattern -- perfect Pauling compliance coexisting with extreme charge imbalance -- suggests the V oxidation state assignment is fundamentally wrong. Could these V-rich barium vanadates contain V in a lower oxidation state (V3+ instead of V5+) that would simultaneously resolve the charge issue?

Dy3WO7 is novel with perfect charge neutrality, both oxi methods agreeing, zero Shannon violations, and a very high formation energy magnitude of -3.49 eV/atom -- the second most negative in this batch. Yet BVS reveals Dy sites at only 2.10 v.u. vs. expected 3+ (dev 0.300), the largest single-site fractional deviation in this batch. With no family members for comparison, could the isolated nature of this prediction combined with the strong thermodynamic stability but poor local bonding geometry indicate that Dy3WO7 occupies a deep energy minimum on the DFT potential energy surface that does not correspond to a kinetically accessible synthesis pathway?

SeSO5 is a novel oxychalcogenide with charge neutrality, both oxi methods agreeing on Se4+ and S6+, and a wide bandgap of 2.97 eV. All three worst BVS deviations are on Se sites at 3.168 v.u. vs. expected 4+ (dev 0.208), suggesting uniformly under-bonded Se4+. Its sole family member Se(S8O)3 (GII 0.422) has a remarkably sulfur-rich composition. Given that Se4+ is a well-known lone-pair cation that creates asymmetric coordination environments, could the systematic Se under-bonding indicate that the BVS R0 parameters for Se4+-O do not account for the stereochemically active lone pair that elongates certain Se-O bonds?

U(BrO)2 is the only material in this batch with a nonzero space group score (0.5), matching experimental SG 14 (P2_1/c) at 50% representation. It also has the best uranium BVS in the batch at 6.581 v.u. vs. expected 6+ (dev 0.097). Its U-Br-O family shows remarkably low GII values across the board (0.156-0.249), far below the dataset median of 0.43. With four family members all in different space groups but consistently excellent bonding, does the U-Br-O system represent one of GNoME's most reliable prediction domains, and could the consistently low GII across multiple stoichiometries serve as a benchmark for validating the BVS methodology itself?

Lu2Cr3O8 and Dy2Cr3O8 form a matched pair with nearly identical GII (0.375 vs. 0.378), both with disagreeing oxi methods and Cr under-bonded at ~2.42 v.u. Lu2Cr3O8's family includes Lu2Cr3O12 (R-3c, GII 0.426, charge 0.0) and Lu3CrO6 (R-3, GII 0.389, charge 0.0), both achieving charge neutrality. Since Lu3+ is the smallest trivalent lanthanide (0.861 A), could the RE2Cr3O8 structure type be geometrically constrained by the RE3+ size, and would interpolating to intermediate lanthanides (Tb, Ho) predict a crossover point where the O8 stoichiometry becomes charge-balanced?

Tb2IO6 is an oxyhalide with both oxi methods agreeing on mixed valence, yet carries a charge residual of -4.0 -- the worst among oxyhalides in this batch. BVS shows I at 4.275 v.u. vs. expected 5+ (dev 0.145), and its family member TbIO4 (Cmcm, GII 0.385, charge 0.0) achieves charge neutrality. The stoichiometry Tb2IO6 requires 2*Tb(3+) + I(5+) + 6*O(2-) = +11 -12 = -1 per formula unit, not -4.0. Could the discrepancy between the expected -1.0 and observed -4.0 charge residual indicate that the mixed-valence assignment involves Tb4+ (rare but known in TbO2), which would create additional charge imbalance rather than resolving it?

NdSbO achieves charge neutrality with both oxi methods agreeing, zero Shannon violations, and a formation energy of -2.44 eV/atom, yet 100% of its 4 Pauling Rule 2 bonds are violated. All Nd sites show identical BVS of 2.48 v.u. (dev 0.173 from expected 3+), indicating uniform under-bonding. Its family member Nd(SbO3)3 (Cmcm, GII 0.384, charge 0.0) has a similarly moderate GII but zero Pauling violations. Could the complete Pauling failure in the simple NdSbO stoichiometry reflect the ZrSiS-type layered structure where Nd-O bonding is intrinsically different from corner-sharing polyhedra, making Pauling's rule inapplicable rather than violated?

Pr(CoO2)8 has the worst Pr BVS in this batch at 1.761 v.u. vs. expected 3+ (dev 0.413), combined with a charge residual of -5.0 and disagreeing oxi methods. Yet its family member Pr(CoO2)3 (C2/m, GII 0.305, charge 0.0) achieves both charge neutrality and good bonding. The ratio jump from CoO2 multiplicity of 3 to 8 corresponds to a dramatic increase in Co content, and GII worsens from 0.305 to 0.374. Could Pr(CoO2)8 be a misindexed superstructure of Pr(CoO2)3, where the apparent 8:1 Co:Pr ratio actually represents a modulated structure with Pr vacancies in every third layer?

LuCo2O5 has disagreeing oxi methods and a charge residual of -4.0, with all three worst BVS sites on Co at 2.43 v.u. vs. expected 3+ (dev 0.190). Its sole family member Lu5(CoO6)2 has null GII and charge values, meaning validation could not even run. Given that both Lu-Co-O compositions involve Co in ambiguous oxidation states and that Co2+/Co3+ redox is notoriously difficult for oxi state guessing algorithms due to similar ionic radii (0.745 vs. 0.610 A for high-spin octahedral), does the systematic failure to validate any Lu-Co-O compound suggest that this chemical system exposes a blind spot in both the BVS parameterization and the oxidation state assignment pipeline?

Ho7CrO12 adopts SG 148 (R-3) while experimental Ho-Cr oxides exclusively appear in SGs 62, 88, and 141 -- all non-trigonal. Its Cr site shows BVS of 2.135 vs. expected 3+ (28.8% underbonded), yet the family members Ho5Cr2O12 and Ho2Cr3O8 both crystallize in C2/m with similar GII values (0.381, 0.386). Could the trigonal R-3 structure represent a metastable polymorph where the large Ho3+:Cr3+ size ratio (7:1 stoichiometry) stabilizes a garnet-like framework that systematically underbonds the minority Cr site?

U(S8O)3 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with an extraordinary S:O ratio of 24:3, yet Pauling Rule 2 reports zero violations across 3 checked bonds with a warning flag. The oxi state assignment relies on a single method (oxi_state_guesses), and BVS shows U at 6.644 vs. expected 6+ (10.7% overbonded). Given the Pauling check warning indicating O2- assumption may not hold for 24 sulfur atoms, are the BVS parameters even valid for a structure where sulfur dominates the anion sublattice and likely participates in S-S bonding rather than acting as S2-?

Nd3ReO8 is computationally known and matches the experimental SG 63 (Cmcm, 50% probability), yet its Nd sites show severe underbonding at BVS 2.074 vs. expected 3+ (30.9% deviation) while Re is only 5.0% off at 6.652 vs. 7+. Its family member Nd(ReO4)3 in P6_3/m achieves a dramatically lower GII of 0.112 with perfect charge neutrality. Why does the Re7+ perrhenate framework in Nd(ReO4)3 accommodate Nd3+ so much better (GII 0.112 vs. 0.372) when the 3:1 Nd:Re ratio forces a denser Nd packing in Nd3ReO8?

Cs6(IrO3)5 shows a residual charge of -4.0 despite single-method oxi assignment, has a novel SG 155 (R32) when the only experimental Cs-Ir oxide adopts SG 12 (C2/m), and all five Ir sites show consistent ~19-20% overbonding (BVS 4.75-4.79 vs. expected 4+). Across the Cs-Ir-O family, four members have null GII/charge data and span wildly different stoichiometries. Is the -4 charge residual an artifact of forcing Ir4+ when the actual oxidation state should be a mix of Ir4+/Ir5+, which would also explain why BVS systematically reads ~4.8?

Ba3Pb2O7 is computationally known but all three worst-BVS sites are Ba at 1.313-1.423 vs. expected 2+ (28.8-34.3% underbonded), while the 43% most-probable experimental SG is 221 (Pm-3m, cubic perovskite-related) and GNoME predicts orthorhombic SG 63. Family member BaPb2O5 in Pnma achieves much better GII (0.245 vs. 0.371). Does the Ba-rich 3:2 stoichiometry create oversized cavities that systematically underbond the large Ba2+ cation, suggesting the structure might be dynamically unstable toward decomposition into BaPb2O5 + BaO?

La5(IrO6)2 presents a cascade of red flags: methods_disagree on oxidation states, mixed valence, -1.0 charge residual, and near-zero bandgap (0.0022 eV) suggesting metallic behavior atypical for a La3+ oxide. Both Ir sites are overbonded at 4.831 vs. expected 4+ (20.8%), while La is underbonded at 2.322 vs. 3+ (22.6%). The family shows La2IrO6 with excellent GII (0.202) and zero charge residual. Could the disagreement between oxi methods indicate that Ir is actually in a 4.5+ mixed-valent state, explaining both the charge imbalance and the metallic conductivity implied by the vanishing bandgap?

Ti10C8O has the largest charge imbalance in this batch at -8.0, methods_disagree on oxidation states, mixed valence, 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (2/2 bonds checked), and sits in triclinic SG 2 while experiments show only SG 64 (Cmca). The Ti-C-O family spans GII from 0.186 (Ti6C4O) to 0.572 (Ti8C4O) with most members also charge-imbalanced. Given that TiC is a well-known metallic carbide and the near-zero bandgap (0.009 eV) confirms metallic character, is this really a misclassified carbide with interstitial oxygen rather than an oxide, making all O2--based validators fundamentally inapplicable?

RbGa9O14 is a novel material with perfect charge neutrality, zero Shannon violations, and zero Pauling violations across 28 bonds -- yet all three worst BVS sites are Ga at 2.40-2.49 vs. expected 3+ (17-20% underbonded). Its only family member Rb4Ga2O5 has a much higher GII of 0.564. The 1:9 Rb:Ga ratio is unusual, suggesting a gallium-oxide framework with Rb filling channels. Could the systematic underbonding of Ga3+ indicate that some Ga sites are actually in tetrahedral coordination (where BVS parameters yield lower values) rather than the octahedral coordination assumed, similar to beta-gallia frameworks?

TmCo2O5 and HoCo2O5 (237605f953) share identical structural signatures: both orthorhombic SG 55 (Pbam), both mixed-valent with -4.0 charge residual, and both show Co underbonded at ~2.4 vs. expected 3+ (~20% deviation). TmCo2O5 is computationally known while HoCo2O5 is novel, yet their BVS scores are nearly identical (0.370 vs. 0.368). Given that Ln2Co2O5 brownmillerites are known to exhibit oxygen vacancy ordering, could the -4.0 charge residual indicate systematic miscounting of oxygen vacancies by the structure model, with actual stoichiometry closer to LnCo2O4?

Mn3Mo2O9 is novel with perfect charge neutrality and both methods agreeing on oxi states, yet Mn shows severe underbonding at BVS 1.404 vs. expected 2+ (29.8% deviation) alongside anomalous O underbonding at -1.456 vs. -2 (27.2%). Family member MnMo2O7 achieves GII of 0.221 with charge neutrality. The experimental SG distribution is spread across SGs 2, 12, and 13 (all monoclinic), with GNoME predicting SG 11 -- could the large Mn2+ underbonding and O underbonding together indicate that some O sites are actually bridging Mo-O-Mo with elongated bonds, creating a molybdate framework where Mn2+ sits in oversized interstices?

KIr5O13 is novel with perfect Tier 1 checks (charge neutral, zero Shannon and Pauling violations across 26 bonds) but shows all three worst BVS sites as Ir at 5.732 vs. expected 5+ (14.6% overbonded). Across the large K-Ir-O family (6 members), most have null GII data, but K2Ir7O18 shows alarming GII of 0.710 with -6.0 charge while K3IrO4 is well-behaved at GII 0.247. Does the Ir5+ oxidation state assignment hold for a 1:5:13 stoichiometry, or could Ir be in a 4+/5+ mixed state where the systematic 14.6% overbonding reflects an average between Ir4+ (BVS~4) and Ir5+ (BVS~5.7) sites?

PrTi2O5 is computationally known with methods_disagree on oxi states, mixed valence, -4.0 charge residual, and a near-zero bandgap of 0.0009 eV. All three worst BVS sites are Pr at 2.280 vs. expected 3+ (24.0% underbonded). Its family member Pr2Ti4O11 in C2/c has GII 0.349 and perfect charge neutrality. The -4.0 residual in a material with only three element types is extreme -- could Pr actually be in the 4+ state here (known for Pr but rare), which would resolve the charge balance but also invalidate the BVS parameters used for the Pr3+ calculation?

EuTi2O5 is novel with perfect charge neutrality and both methods agree on oxi states, yet it shows an unusually high Pauling Rule 2 violation of 0.80 (8 of 10 bonds) alongside Ti BVS of 3.496 vs. expected 4+ (12.6% underbonded). It has no family members for comparison. Given that Eu commonly adopts both 2+ and 3+ states, and the 80% Pauling violation suggests severe coordination geometry issues, could GNoME have predicted a structure where Eu2+ (not Eu3+) is the actual state, which would break charge neutrality as Eu2+Ti4+2O5 gives +10 vs. -10, while Eu3+ gives +11 vs. -10?

Lu7VO12 and its family members Lu3VO6 and Lu2V3O8 show remarkably consistent GII values (0.369, 0.367, 0.367) despite spanning V:Lu ratios from 1:7 to 3:2 and different space groups (R-3, R-3, C2). In all three, V is the most underbonded site (BVS 2.14-2.45 vs. expected 3+). Only LuV3O9 breaks the pattern with GII 0.299. Does the persistent ~0.37 GII across the Lu-V-O family suggest a fundamental incompatibility between V3+ ionic radius and the Lu3+-dominated oxide lattice that cannot be resolved by changing stoichiometry?

HoCo2O5 mirrors TmCo2O5 (535a1cd928) exactly: SG 55, mixed valence, -4.0 charge residual, Co BVS ~2.39 vs. expected 3+ (~20% underbonded). Both oxidation state methods disagree. The sole family member Ho5(CoO6)2 in C2/m has null GII/charge data. Given that both the Tm and Ho analogs independently produce the same validation fingerprint despite being predicted separately by GNoME, is this systematic pattern evidence that GNoME learned a consistent but charge-imbalanced LnCo2O5 structural motif from its training data, and could the missing GII for Ho5(CoO6)2 be computed to test if the 5:2 stoichiometry resolves the charge issue?

Nd2SeO6 is an oxychalcogenide with a Pauling warning flag, yet achieves charge neutrality and matches one experimental SG (15, C2/c at 20%). All three worst BVS sites are Se at 5.238 vs. expected 6+ (12.7% underbonded). Family member Nd2Se3O10 has charge residual -4.0 and GII 0.566, while Nd2Se4O11 is charge-neutral with GII 0.281. The family shows that increasing Se:Nd ratio improves GII (0.566 to 0.368 to 0.281). Is there a Se/O site-mixing effect where the Pauling warning correctly identifies that some nominally O2- sites are actually occupied by Se, and does the Se BVS underbonding reflect bond-length distortion from this mixing?

Cs6Pb2O5 is novel with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations, yet the three worst BVS sites are all O at -1.486 to -1.514 vs. expected -2 (24.3-25.7% underbonded). This is unusual -- typically cation sites dominate worst-BVS lists. Family member Cs2Pb4O7 also shows high GII (0.566). With a 6:2 Cs:Pb ratio in a triclinic cell, the structure is alkali-rich. Could the systematic oxygen underbonding indicate that Cs-O distances are too long to contribute adequate bond valence to oxygen, suggesting the large Cs+ ions create a lattice with anomalously expanded oxygen sites that may be prone to hydration or atmospheric instability?

Lu2V3O8 is novel with mixed valence, -2.0 charge residual, and three V sites underbonded at BVS 2.45-2.47 vs. expected 3+ (17.7-18.2%). Its family members Lu3VO6 (GII 0.367, charge 0.0) and Lu7VO12 (GII 0.369, charge 0.0) achieve charge neutrality with V3+. However, in a V3O8 unit the charge balance Ln2(3+)V3(x+)O8(2-) requires V at +10/3 = 3.33+, impossible for integer oxidation states. Does the -2.0 residual directly reflect this stoichiometric impossibility of achieving charge balance with integer V oxidation states, and should the validator flag such compositions as fundamentally requiring mixed V3+/V4+ valence?

Lu3VO6 is computationally known in SG 148 (R-3) with V showing the most extreme BVS deviation in the Lu-V-O family: 2.140 vs. expected 3+ (28.7% underbonded) at one site, alongside a second V site at 2.443 (18.6%). The O site also appears at BVS -1.656 (17.2% underbonded). Given the consistent ~0.37 GII across this family (Lu7VO12: 0.369, Lu2V3O8: 0.367, Lu3VO6: 0.367), and that DFT typically optimizes structures to local energy minima, could the V3+ underbonding plateau represent a real structural feature where V3+ prefers a larger coordination volume than the rigid Lu3+ sublattice permits in the R-3 framework?

Rb3Ta8O21 presents the most extreme charge residual (-14.0) among pure oxides in this batch, combined with 71.4% Pauling Rule 2 violations (30/42 bonds), single-method oxi assignment, and a novel hexagonal SG 193 (P6_3/mcm) unseen experimentally. Yet family members RbTa5O13 (GII 0.166) and Rb3Ta7O19 (GII 0.173) are well-behaved with charge neutrality. The Ta BVS of 4.766 vs. expected 4+ (19.1% overbonded) suggests Ta may actually be 5+, which for Rb+(3)Ta5+(8)O2-(21) gives +3+40-42 = +1, not -14. Is the -14 charge residual entirely an artifact of misassigning Ta as 4+ rather than the far more common 5+ state?

Ca4Sb6O13 is novel with perfect charge neutrality, zero Shannon and Pauling violations, but Sb shows systematic underbonding (BVS 2.19-2.38 vs. expected 3+, 20.6-26.9% deviation). The 40% most probable experimental SG is 227 (Fd-3m, pyrochlore-related). Family member Ca4Sb2O9 achieves GII 0.321 vs. this material's 0.367. With 6 Sb atoms per formula unit vs. only 2 in Ca4Sb2O9, could the Sb-rich stoichiometry force some Sb3+ into unfavorable coordination environments, and might Sb3+ lone-pair stereochemical activity (common in Sb2O3 polymorphs) be responsible for the monoclinic SG 6 distortion away from the expected cubic pyrochlore?

Mn6AgO12 shows the most extreme single-site BVS deviation in this batch: Ag at 0.340 vs. expected 1+ (66.0% underbonded), alongside -10.0 charge residual and methods_disagree on oxidation states. The family member Mn8AgO16 is equally troubled with -7.0 charge and GII 0.364. With an Ag BVS of only 0.34, the Ag site appears almost completely disconnected from the oxide framework. Could the structure actually contain Ag0 (metallic silver) rather than Ag+, which would explain the near-zero bond valence, and does the -10 charge residual partly arise from the validator incorrectly counting Ag as contributing +1 to the charge balance?

Ho3MoO7 is the only material in this batch with a non-zero Shannon radii violation (score 0.037), indicating at least one ion pair falls outside the 25% tolerance for known ionic radii combinations. It also shows Ho underbonded at BVS 2.213 vs. 3+ (26.2%) and Mo at 4.548 vs. 5+ (9.0%). With no family members for comparison and an experimental SG distribution spread across five different monoclinic groups (SGs 12, 14, 15), what specific ion-pair triggers the Shannon violation -- is it Ho3+-O2- at an unusual coordination number, or Mo5+-O2-, and could this violation correlate with the 14.3% Pauling Rule 2 violations (2/14 bonds)?

Pr(IrO3)3 is novel but matches the experimental SG 63 (Cmcm, 50% probability) -- the best space group match in this batch alongside Nd3ReO8. All three worst BVS sites are Ir at 5.718 vs. expected 5+ (14.4% overbonded), identical within precision. Yet all three Pr-Ir-O family members (Pr6IrO12, Pr5(IrO6)2, Pr3(IrO5)2) show -1.0 charge residuals. Given that Pr(IrO3)3 achieves charge neutrality with Pr3+Ir5+3O2-9 while every family member fails, does this suggest that the 1:3 Pr:Ir ratio uniquely satisfies the valence balance that larger Pr:Ir ratios cannot, making it the most synthesizable candidate in the Pr-Ir-O family?

Nd2TcO6 contains technetium, a radioactive element with no stable isotopes, making experimental validation essentially impossible. Its oxi states come from single-method assignment only, and the experimental SG distribution shows 100% at SG 227 (Fd-3m, pyrochlore) while GNoME predicts monoclinic SG 15 (C2/c). Family member Nd6Tc16O has an extraordinary GII of 1.621 -- the highest in this batch by far -- suggesting a metallic Tc-rich intermetallic misclassified as an oxide. With Nd BVS at 2.54 vs. 3+ (15.3% underbonded), is GNoME's monoclinic prediction a lower-symmetry distortion of the expected pyrochlore, or a fundamentally different structural solution driven by Tc's unusual d-electron configuration?

K6Mo2O9 is charge-neutral and passes Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 checks across all 18 bonds, yet Mo sites show BVS of 5.17 v.u. against an expected +6, a 13.9% underbonding deviation. In known molybdates, Mo(VI) in tetrahedral coordination typically achieves BVS within 5% of formal charge. Does the monoclinic C2/c structure (SG 15) force Mo into an unusual coordination geometry that systematically lengthens Mo-O bonds, or does the large K:Mo ratio of 3:1 create an expanded lattice where oxygen is pulled toward K, starving Mo of bond valence?

Across the La-Bi-O family, GII values track a clear trend with La:Bi ratio: La3Bi5O12 (La:Bi=0.6, GII=0.213) is structurally the most relaxed, while Bi-rich compositions like La(BiO2)7 (GII=0.777) and LaBi3O7 (GII=0.770) show severe strain, and several members (La6BiO12, La9(BiO)5, La8Bi3O8) cannot even be charge-balanced. Given that La3BiO7 itself has La BVS of 2.08 v.u. (30.8% underbonded from expected +3), does the La-Bi-O system have a narrow compositional stability window around La:Bi approximately 1:1, with deviations either way producing structures GNoME can predict but classical bonding rules reject?

K3OsO5 passes charge neutrality and Pauling Rule 2 across all 10 bonds, yet K sites show extreme BVS underbonding: two K sites at 0.386 v.u. (61.4% deviation from expected +1) and one at 0.841 v.u. (15.9% deviation). This pattern of severely underbonded alkali sites recurs across the K-Os-O family, where charge-neutral members like K4OsO6 (GII=0.225) and K3OsO4 (GII=0.302) perform much better. Is K3OsO5 sitting in a local energy minimum where the Os(VII) oxidation state forces a topology that cannot adequately coordinate K+, essentially trapping potassium in oversized cavities?

Tm2V3O8 carries a residual charge of -2.0 despite both oxidation state methods agreeing, and is flagged as mixed-valence with V in the +3 state showing BVS of 2.45-2.46 v.u. (18.2-18.3% underbonded). The family member TmV4O8 similarly fails charge neutrality (charge=-4.0). Given that vanadium commonly adopts +3/+4/+5 states, could the charge imbalance indicate that V is actually in a mixed +4/+5 state rather than the assigned +3, and the oxi-state guessers both converged on the wrong solution despite formally agreeing?

TlV4O8 has a residual charge of -3.0 despite both oxidation state methods agreeing, with mixed valence flagged and O sites showing BVS of -1.52 and -1.56 v.u. (22-24% underbonded from expected -2). Its sole family member TlV3O9 is charge-neutral with GII=0.527. Given that Tl can adopt either +1 or +3, could the charge imbalance in TlV4O8 signal that GNoME predicted a structure where Tl is actually Tl(III) rather than the assigned Tl(I), which would change the electron count by 2 and partially resolve the -3.0 residual?

Ba4Tc2O9 is a novel 60-atom structure with 55.6% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 36 bonds -- the highest violation fraction in this batch -- yet it passes charge neutrality and Shannon radii perfectly, and its BVS (GII=0.365) is within the dataset median range. The Ba-Tc-O family shows a GII gradient from Ba2TcO5 (0.285) to Ba(TcO4)2 (0.660), with Ba4Tc2O9 falling mid-range. Since oxidation states were assigned by only oxi_state_guesses (single_method confidence), could the extreme Pauling violations reflect incorrect Tc oxidation state assignment in this radioactive element, where Tc(IV) vs Tc(VII) would produce dramatically different expected coordination environments?

Mn8AgO16 exhibits cascading red flags: a residual charge of -7.0, oxi methods that both disagree, mixed valence, and Ag BVS of only 0.329 v.u. (67.1% deviation from expected +1). Its only family member Mn6AgO12 similarly fails with charge=-10.0. Despite this, Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 both pass perfectly across 16 bonds. How can two geometric validators report clean results while the electronic structure is so severely inconsistent -- does this expose a blind spot where CrystalNN-derived coordination geometry can appear locally reasonable even when the global charge balance is catastrophically wrong?

Eu6IrO12 is computationally known with a near-zero bandgap (0.0012 eV) and shows Ir BVS of 5.27 v.u. (12.2% underbonded from expected Ir(VI)), while all Eu sites are underbonded at 2.59 v.u. (13.7% below expected +3). The trigonal R-3 structure (SG 148) deviates from the expected SGs 63 and 227. Given that Eu is one of the few lanthanides that readily adopts a +2 state, could the systematic underbonding of Eu (2.59 vs expected 3.0) indicate partial Eu(II) character, which would also explain the near-metallic bandgap through Eu 4f-Ir 5d hybridization?

Pr3(IrO5)2 is computationally known but exhibits a -1.0 residual charge with both oxi methods disagreeing, and all three Pr sites are substantially underbonded (BVS 2.41-2.56 v.u. vs expected +3). The Pr-Ir-O family shows a consistent pattern: Pr6IrO12 (charge=-1.0), Pr5(IrO6)2 (charge=-1.0), yet Pr(IrO3)3 achieves charge neutrality with GII=0.366. Does the persistent -1.0 residual across multiple Pr-rich iridates suggest that the true ground state involves partial Ir(V)/Ir(IV) mixing rather than a single Ir oxidation state, and the compositions achieving neutrality simply happen to have stoichiometries compatible with integer Ir charges?

K3TcO5 passes every Tier 1 check perfectly -- zero charge residual, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling Rule 2 violations across 20 bonds -- yet K sites show extreme and identical BVS underbonding: three K sites at exactly 0.386 v.u. each (61.4% deviation). This 0.386 v.u. value for K appears in K3OsO5 as well (same SG 129, same deviation). Remarkably, family member K2TcO4 achieves a much lower GII of 0.282. Is the P4/nmm framework inherently hostile to K+ coordination in A3MO5 stoichiometries, creating a systematic structural trap that GNoME's energy landscape misses?

B6Pb2O11 is novel, passes charge neutrality, Shannon radii, and Pauling checks across all 44 bonds, and even partially matches the expected space group (SG 14, score=0.222 -- the highest SG score in this batch). Yet all Pb sites show BVS of only 0.90 v.u., a 55% deviation from expected Pb(II). Its family member B8PbO13 achieves GII=0.268 with charge neutrality. With 76 atoms in the unit cell and Pb nominally in the +2 state, could the severe Pb underbonding indicate that Pb is occupying a site designed for a larger cation, or that the 6s2 lone pair of Pb(II) is creating an asymmetric coordination environment that BVS parameters derived from symmetric Pb-O bonds cannot properly capture?

Gd3WO7 is a novel pure oxide where both oxi methods disagree yet the structure is charge-neutral, with Gd severely underbonded at BVS 2.16 v.u. (28.1% below expected +3) while W is mildly underbonded at 4.64 v.u. (7.3% below expected +5). The bandgap of 2.28 eV and high formation energy of -3.43 eV/atom suggest a stable insulator. Could the large Gd underbonding indicate that GNoME predicted a structure where the Gd-O distances correspond to 8+ coordinate Gd(III), but the orthorhombic SG 20 framework constrains Gd to a lower coordination number, creating a thermodynamically stable but bond-valence-strained configuration?

Tb5Mn2O12 carries a -1.0 residual charge with mixed valence flagged, a near-zero bandgap (0.0006 eV), and Mn sites showing BVS of 3.37 v.u. against expected Mn(IV) (+4), a 15.8% underbonding. Both oxi methods agree on the assignment, yet the charge does not balance. For a novel compound with Tb(III) and Mn(IV), the formula Tb5Mn2O12 requires 15+8=23 positive charges for 24 negative (12 O at -2), leaving exactly -1. Is this a stoichiometry that simply cannot exist with integer oxidation states, suggesting GNoME predicted a composition that requires fractional Mn valence (e.g., Mn3.5+) to be physically realizable?

Tb3MoO7 is the only material in this batch with a nonzero Shannon radii violation (score=0.071), alongside Pauling violations (14.3% of 14 bonds) and Tb underbonding at BVS 2.24 v.u. (25.5% below +3). Its family members Tb6MoO12 (GII=0.401) and Tb3MoO6 (GII=0.356) both achieve charge neutrality. Given that Tb3MoO7 requires Mo in the +5 state (BVS confirms 4.47 v.u.) while Tb6MoO12 would have Mo(VI) and Tb3MoO6 has Mo(III), does the Tb-Mo-O system exhibit a compositional dependence where odd Mo valences like +5 produce systematically worse structural metrics than even valences, reflecting the half-filled 4d1 instability?

K(SnO2)6 has a catastrophic charge imbalance of -10.0, the worst in this batch, with K BVS of only 0.348 v.u. (65.2% underbonded) and Sn showing BVS of 3.46 v.u. against expected Sn(III) (+3), suggesting Sn is actually closer to Sn(IV). If Sn is reassigned to +4, the formula K(+1)Sn6(+4)O12(-2) gives +1+24-24=+1, almost neutral. Yet oxi_state_guesses assigned Sn(III). Could this be a systematic failure of the oxidation state guesser for Sn, where the similar ionic radii of Sn(II) and Sn(IV) in octahedral coordination cause misassignment, and the true compound is a K-intercalated SnO2 rutile variant?

Ba3Ir2O9 is novel and charge-neutral with zero Shannon violations, but exhibits 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations across all 18 bonds -- every single anion coordination environment fails the electrostatic valence rule. The Ba-Ir-O family spans a wide GII range from Ba4Ir6O19 (0.238) to BaIr5O13 (0.722), with charge-neutral members clustering at lower GII. The trigonal SG 167 (R-3c) is a high-symmetry space group often seen in corundum derivatives. Could Ba3Ir2O9 adopt a face-sharing octahedral Ir2O9 dimer motif (as in hexagonal perovskites) that satisfies global charge balance but systematically violates Pauling's second rule because the shared faces create overbonded bridging oxygens?

K5(TcO3)2 has a residual charge of -2.0, with K sites showing BVS of 0.525-0.625 v.u. (37.5-47.5% underbonded), and oxidation states assigned by only oxi_state_guesses. Its family member K3TcO5 (computationally known, SG P4/nmm) achieves charge neutrality with GII=0.364, and K2TcO4 (GII=0.282) is the best-performing K-Tc-O member. The formula K5(TcO3)2 implies Tc(+3.5) for charge neutrality, which is non-integer. Since Tc commonly adopts +4 or +7, could the -2.0 residual indicate that the oxi guesser forced Tc into an incompatible integer state, and this stoichiometry fundamentally requires mixed-valent Tc to exist?

NaIr5O13 is a novel compound where all Ir sites show BVS of 5.79 v.u., which is 15.7% above the expected +5 (overbonded), an unusual pattern since most materials in this dataset show underbonding. Six Na-Ir-O family members (Na2(IrO3)3, Na4Ir2O9, Na3IrO6) have null GII values, suggesting BVS parameters could not be computed for those structures. The family spans exclusively novel predictions. Could the consistent Ir overbonding at 5.79 v.u. indicate that Ir is actually in the +4 state with compressed Ir-O bonds, and the Na-Ir-O system represents a compositional space where GNoME's neural network had minimal training data, leading to systematically contracted bond lengths?

UNO is an oxynitride (compound class: oxynitride) that passes all checks including charge neutrality and Pauling Rule 2 (0/4 violations), with N showing BVS of -3.50 v.u. (16.6% overbonded from expected -3). It is computationally known with a near-zero bandgap (0.0047 eV), and its family member U2N3O has a much higher GII of 0.650 with a -2.0 charge residual. Given that the Pauling check carries a warning flag for this non-oxide, and BVS parameters for U-N bonds are less well-calibrated than U-O bonds, how reliable are the validation scores for actinide oxynitrides where both the U 5f electron complexity and the mixed anion environment challenge the assumptions of every validator in the pipeline?

K4Os2O9 shares the K-Os-O family with K3OsO5 (c60379ac0d), and both are charge-neutral, yet K4Os2O9 adopts hexagonal P6_3/mmc (SG 194) while K3OsO5 is tetragonal P4/nmm (SG 129). K4Os2O9 has 33.3% Pauling violations across 18 bonds and K BVS of 0.575 v.u. (42.5% underbonded), while KOs5O13 in the same family achieves near-perfect GII of 0.011. Does the K-Os-O phase diagram bifurcate into a high-K regime (K:Os >= 2) where K is systematically underbonded due to oversized cavities, versus a low-K regime (K:Os < 1) like KOs5O13 where the dense Os-O framework provides adequate K coordination?

SmCo2O5 is novel with a -4.0 residual charge, oxi methods disagreeing, mixed valence, and all Co sites underbonded at BVS 2.41 v.u. (19.8% below expected Co(III)). Yet Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 pass perfectly across 20 bonds. The family shows a pattern where Sm-rich compositions (Sm5(CoO6)2) have null GII and the Co-rich member Sm(CoO2)8 has a -5.0 charge residual. If the oxi methods disagree on Co valence and the charge is -4.0, this suggests 4 excess electrons. Could the near-metallic bandgap (0.22 eV) indicate that SmCo2O5 is actually a metallic oxide with itinerant d-electrons on Co that cannot be captured by formal oxidation states, similar to LaCoO3 spin-state transitions?

Tl6W2O9 is novel and charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing, yet shows 33.3% Pauling violations across 18 bonds and oxygen BVS of -1.48 v.u. (26.1% underbonded). The family member Tl2W3O10 achieves a much lower GII of 0.178 with charge neutrality, while Tl(WO3)4 has a catastrophic charge of -9.0. The predicted SG 15 (C2/c) deviates from the only expected SG 164 (P-3m1). With Tl(I) as a stereochemically active lone-pair cation like Pb(II), could the monoclinic distortion from the expected trigonal symmetry be driven by Tl 6s2 lone pair ordering that creates the observed oxygen underbonding by pushing O away from Tl?

Mn2V4O13 is a novel 76-atom structure that passes charge neutrality, Shannon radii, and Pauling Rule 2 across all 50 bonds (the most bonds checked in this batch), with V sites showing uniform BVS of 4.41 v.u. (11.8% below expected V(V)). Its family member Mn3V3O11 has a -2.0 charge residual and higher GII of 0.465. The systematic 11.8% V underbonding across all V sites in a large unit cell with 4 formula units suggests a structural rather than compositional origin. Could Mn2V4O13 represent a new vanadate framework type where V-O polyhedra are slightly expanded to accommodate the relatively small Mn(II) cation in interstitial sites?

LaIO4 is classified as an oxyhalide, and the Pauling Rule 2 check carries a warning flag because the O2- assumption may not hold for all anions. I sites show BVS of 4.27 v.u. (14.7% below expected I(V)), while the 3.36 eV bandgap suggests a wide-gap insulator consistent with stable iodate chemistry. Three La-I-O family members are all novel, with La2I4O13 achieving charge neutrality (GII=0.378) while La2I2O9 and La6IO12 have null GII values. Given that iodates (IO3-) are well-known stable anion groups, should the validator pipeline treat I(V) in tetrahedral/pyramidal IO4 coordination differently from halide I(-1), and does the oxyhalide classification itself misrepresent what is chemically an iodate salt?

Rb3OsO5 is computationally known and charge-neutral, with Rb BVS uniformly at 0.581 v.u. (41.9% underbonded from expected +1) -- virtually identical to the K analog K3OsO5 where K shows 0.386 v.u. (61.4% underbonded). Despite Rb being a larger cation that should better fill cavities in the A3MO5 framework, its underbonding (41.9%) is only moderately improved over K (61.4%). The Rb-Os-O family shows a GII range from 0.352 (Rb4OsO4) to 0.460 (Rb(OsO3)3). Does the persistent alkali underbonding across both K3OsO5 and Rb3OsO5 indicate that the A3MO5 stoichiometry creates inherently oversized A-site cavities regardless of alkali size, representing a structural topology that DFT stabilizes but bond valence analysis flags as geometrically strained?

Tb3MoO6 (novel, trigonal R-3, SG 148) shows Mo with a BVS of 2.285 vs. expected 3+, a 23.8% deviation suggesting the Mo site is significantly underbonded. Its family member Tb6MoO12 in the same R-3 space group has a higher GII (0.401) and is computationally known, while Tb3MoO7 (novel, C222_1) has a lower GII (0.362). Could the 2:1 Tb:Mo stoichiometry in Tb3MoO6 create an oxygen-deficient coordination environment around Mo that the trigonal symmetry cannot accommodate as effectively as the orthorhombic Tb3MoO7, explaining why the Mo-O bond valence falls short by nearly a quarter?

Ti8CO12 is computationally known yet exhibits a charge neutrality residual of -4.0, both oxi methods disagree, and C is assigned BVS of -5.018 vs. expected -4 (25.5% deviation). Across the Ti-C-O family, charge imbalance is pervasive: Ti10C8O (charge -8.0), Ti3C2O (-1.0), and Ti8C4O (-2.0), while only Ti2CO and Ti6C4O achieve neutrality. Given that these are carbide-oxides where carbon likely occupies interstitial sites rather than forming CO3^2- units, why does the oxi state assignment framework systematically fail for this entire family, and does the near-zero bandgap (0.0001 eV) suggest metallic bonding that fundamentally violates the ionic model underpinning BVS?

Ho5Mn2O12 (computationally known, monoclinic C2/m) has Mn with BVS of 3.434 vs. expected 4+ (14.1% deviation) and a charge residual of -1.0, but oxi states were assigned by only one method (oxi_state_guesses). The near-zero bandgap (0.003 eV) hints at possible Mn^3+/Mn^4+ mixed valence, yet mixed_valence is flagged as 0. Could the single-method oxi assignment be incorrectly forcing all Mn to 4+ when the structure actually contains mixed Mn^3+/Mn^4+, which would simultaneously explain the systematic Mn underbonding (BVS 3.43) and resolve the -1.0 charge imbalance?

In the Pr-Se-O family, GII decreases monotonically with increasing Se:Pr ratio -- PrSeO (1.226), Pr2SeO5 (0.343), Pr2SeO6 (0.354), Pr2Se3O10 (0.566), Pr2Se5O13 (0.306), Pr2(SeO4)3 (0.100) -- with the fully formed selenate Pr2(SeO4)3 achieving a remarkably low GII of 0.100 and being the only computationally known member. Given that Pr2SeO6 (novel) shows all Pr sites uniformly underbonded at BVS 2.381 vs. expected 3+ (20.6% deviation), does this suggest that the Se^6+ tetrahedral coordination in the selenate structure is uniquely capable of satisfying Pr^3+ bonding requirements, and that intermediate Se:O ratios like Pr2SeO6 represent a structural no-man's-land?

Cr2TeO5 is an oxychalcogenide (computationally known, monoclinic P2_1/c) with a space group score of 0.5 -- the highest in this batch -- matching the 50% frequency of SG 14 in experimental Cr-Te-O data. All Cr sites show identical underbonding at BVS 2.512 vs. expected 3+ (16.3% deviation), and the Pauling check carries a warning flag for non-pure-oxide composition. Given that Te can adopt Te^4+ (lone-pair active) or Te^6+ coordination, and the warning flag indicates the O^2- assumption may not hold for the Te-O bonds, how much of the 16.3% Cr underbonding is a genuine structural distortion versus an artifact of applying oxide-calibrated BVS parameters to an oxychalcogenide?

YCo2O5 (computationally known, orthorhombic Pbam, SG 55) has a charge residual of -4.0 despite both oxi methods agreeing, and all Co sites are uniformly underbonded at BVS 2.465 vs. expected 3+ (17.8% deviation). The sole family member Y5(CoO6)2 (novel) has null GII and charge data, suggesting complete validator failure. Experimental YCoO3 perovskites show well-documented Co^3+ intermediate-to-high spin state transitions near 500K. Could the -4.0 charge residual indicate that GNoME's predicted structure actually requires Co in a mixed 2+/3+ state rather than uniform 3+, and does the SG 55 (Pbam) prediction -- absent from the 100% SG 62 experimental distribution -- represent a charge-ordering superstructure that would stabilize such mixed valence?

Tm6C2O3 (novel, monoclinic C2/m) shows oxygen BVS of -1.437 vs. expected -2 (28.1% deviation), the largest oxygen underbonding in this batch, alongside a charge residual of -2.0 and only single-method oxi assignment. Strikingly, the family shows a bifurcation: Tm2(CO3)3 achieves an exceptional GII of 0.021 with full charge neutrality, while carbon-rich phases Tm4C2O (GII 0.905, charge +2.0) and Tm2CO (GII 0.705) show severe strain. Does the extreme oxygen underbonding in Tm6C2O3 indicate that C is not forming carbonate groups but rather occupying carbide-like interstitial positions, making this structurally closer to the strained Tm4C2O subfamily than to the well-behaved Tm2(CO3)3?

NaMn6O12 (novel, monoclinic C2/m) exhibits the most extreme charge imbalance in this batch at -10.0, Na is catastrophically underbonded at BVS 0.422 vs. expected 1+ (57.8% deviation), and both oxi methods disagree. The structure resembles birnessite-type layered MnO2 with intercalated Na, where Mn exists in mixed 3+/4+ states. Its family member Na2Mn3O6 (novel) also fails charge neutrality at -3.0. Given that experimental birnessite Na_xMnO2 contains significant water and vacancies, could GNoME be predicting an idealized anhydrous framework that is physically unrealizable without interlayer water, explaining both the extreme Na underbonding and the massive charge deficit?

Ba2(ReO3)3 (computationally known, cubic I2_13, SG 197) shows Re at BVS 4.736 vs. expected 4+ (18.4% deviation, overbonded) and a charge residual of -4.0. The Re overbonding contrasts sharply with the family members Ba4Re2O11 (GII 0.379, charge neutral) and Ba3(ReO5)2 (GII 0.287, charge neutral), both of which successfully accommodate Re in higher oxidation states. Given that Re can access oxidation states from +4 to +7, could the charge deficit and Re overbonding indicate that the correct assignment is Re^5+ or Re^6+ rather than Re^4+, which would simultaneously resolve the charge imbalance and explain why the single-method oxi assignment failed?

Rb4OsO4 (computationally known, triclinic P-1) is charge-neutral with all checks passing at Tier 1, yet all Rb sites show uniform underbonding at BVS 0.640 vs. expected 1+ (36% deviation). Across the Rb-Os-O family, charge neutrality is achieved only by Rb4Os2O9 (GII 0.382) and Rb3OsO5 (GII 0.357), while Rb3(OsO4)2, Rb(OsO3)3, and Rb(OsO4)2 all carry charge deficits. Does the consistent Rb underbonding across all Rb-Os-O phases suggest that BVS reference parameters for Rb-O bonds systematically underestimate actual bond strengths in large alkali metal osmate frameworks, representing a calibration gap rather than genuine structural strain?

ErSO (novel, orthorhombic Cmce, SG 64) is the only material in this batch with a Pauling Rule 2 score of 1.0 (100% violation), meaning all 8 checked coordination polyhedra violate electrostatic valence balance. Yet it passes charge neutrality perfectly (0.0) and Shannon radii (0.0), with both oxi methods agreeing on Er^3+/S^2-/O^2-. Its sole family member Er(S8O)3 has an extreme GII of 1.173 and charge -3.0. For an oxychalcogenide with an S^2- anion, the Pauling check assumes O^2- for all anions -- could the complete Pauling failure be entirely an artifact of miscounting S^2- as an oxide, or does the 16.4% Er underbonding (BVS 2.509) indicate a genuinely strained structure?

Ca11(OsO6)4 (novel, tetragonal I4_1, SG 80) has 78 sites -- the largest unit cell in this batch -- with a charge residual of -4.0 and all Ca sites underbonded at BVS 1.495 vs. expected 2+ (25.2% deviation). The sole family member CaOsO4 (computationally known, Pbcn) has a much lower GII of 0.389 and achieves charge neutrality. The non-centrosymmetric SG 80 (I4_1) is a polar chiral space group, experimentally unprecedented for Ca-Os-O (100% SG 74 experimentally). Could GNoME be predicting a metastable high-pressure polymorph where the large unit cell (78 sites) accommodates ordering of Ca vacancies in an otherwise fluorite-derived OsO6 octahedral framework?

Mn16PbO32 (novel, monoclinic Pm, SG 6) has the most extreme charge imbalance among pure oxides in this batch at -14.0, despite both oxi methods agreeing. Pb shows catastrophic underbonding at BVS 1.155 vs. expected 2+ (42.2% deviation). The polar non-centrosymmetric SG 6 (Pm) is absent from all experimental Mn-Pb-O distributions (SG 62 at 25%, SG 13 at 17%). With 49 sites and mixed Mn valence, could the -14.0 charge residual indicate that Pb should be assigned 4+ rather than 2+ (yielding Mn16Pb^4+O32 with charge closer to neutral), and that the unusual SG 6 prediction reflects a charge-ordering pattern impossible in higher-symmetry structures?

Rb6S2O9 (novel, cubic Fm-3m, SG 225) is an oxychalcogenide that achieves charge neutrality with both oxi methods agreeing, yet shows O underbonded at BVS -1.259 vs. expected -2 (37% deviation) while S is slightly overbonded at BVS 6.523 vs. expected 6+ (8.7%). The high-symmetry cubic SG 225 is absent from experimental Rb-S-O distributions (SG 15 at 33%, SG 4/14 at 17%). With the family member Rb(S8O)3 showing an extreme GII of 1.447, could the Fm-3m symmetry force Rb into a highly symmetric coordination that is geometrically incompatible with optimal Rb-O bonding, making this a case where high symmetry paradoxically destabilizes the structure?

KNb7O9 (computationally known, tetragonal P4/mmm, SG 123) has the highest Pauling Rule 2 violation score in this batch at 0.556 (5 of 9 polyhedra violated), Nb shows BVS 2.919 vs. expected 2+ (46% overbonded), charge residual is -3.0, and both oxi methods disagree. Across the K-Nb-O family, charge neutrality failures are widespread: K3Nb16O23 (-11.0), KNb4O6 (-3.0). Yet KNb5O8 (novel) achieves charge neutrality with GII 0.242 and K5NbO5 (computationally known) is also neutral. Does the 46% Nb overbonding definitively indicate the assigned Nb^2+ is wrong and should be Nb^5+, which would transform the charge balance from -3.0 to +18 and suggest a fundamentally different electronic structure?

TaSb3O10 (novel, triclinic P1, SG 1) achieves perfect charge neutrality, zero Shannon and Pauling violations, and both oxi methods agree -- yet it crystallizes in the lowest possible symmetry (SG 1), while all experimental Ta-Sb-O phases appear in SG 52 (100%). Both Sb sites are slightly overbonded (BVS 5.576 and 5.557 vs. expected 5+), and Ta is also overbonded at 5.505. The family members in SG P2 show dramatically worse behavior: TaSb7O16 (GII 0.962, charge -6.0) and Ta3Sb5O16 (GII 0.571, charge -2.0). Could the P1 symmetry represent GNoME resolving subtle Sb^5+ lone-pair-induced distortions that higher symmetry space groups cannot capture, making this a genuinely stable novel polymorph?

Rb(SnO2)6 (novel, triclinic P-1, SG 2) has a charge residual of -10.0, Rb is dramatically underbonded at BVS 0.390 vs. expected 1+ (61% deviation -- the worst alkali underbonding in this batch), and both oxi methods disagree while flagging mixed valence. The sole family member Rb2Sn4O7 (computationally known, also P-1) achieves charge neutrality with GII 0.623. The Sn BVS of 3.445 vs. expected 3+ (14.8% overbonding) suggests Sn is likely closer to Sn^4+ than the assigned 3+. Could reclassifying all Sn as Sn^4+ resolve both the charge imbalance (6 Sn sites x +1 = +6 toward the -10 deficit) and explain the Rb rattling behavior in oversized cavities of a rutile-derived SnO2 framework?

Tm5Mn2O12 (novel, monoclinic C2/m, SG 12) mirrors Ho5Mn2O12 (also monoclinic C2/m, SG 12) in this batch with nearly identical validation profiles: both have charge residual -1.0, Mn BVS ~3.4-3.5 vs. expected 4+, Tm/Ho BVS ~2.5 vs. expected 3+, and single-method oxi assignment. Both rare-earth manganates share the same space group, same stoichiometry type (RE5Mn2O12), and same systematic underbonding pattern. Given the lanthanide contraction from Ho^3+ (1.015 A) to Tm^3+ (0.994 A), does the near-identical GII (0.350 vs. 0.355) and charge deficit suggest that this RE5Mn2O12 structure type has a fundamental charge balance problem independent of the specific rare earth, pointing to a systematic Mn^4+ assignment error?

LiNpO4 (computationally known, monoclinic P2_1/c, SG 14) achieves perfect charge neutrality with both Li sites showing identical underbonding at BVS 0.650 vs. expected 1+ (35% deviation). The Li-Np-O family shows a clear trend: increasing Li:Np ratio correlates with lower GII -- Li6NpO6 (0.152), Li3NpO5 (0.256), Li5NpO6 (0.304) -- while LiNpO4 has GII 0.350. Given that LiNpO4 is isostructural with monazite-type LiLnPO4 phosphates and all family members are charge-neutral, could the systematic Li underbonding indicate that the Li sites are oversized cavities designed for fast Li-ion conduction, making this neptunium compound a candidate for nuclear waste immobilization in a lithium-conducting matrix?

Sc3AlO6 (novel, trigonal R-3, SG 148) passes every Tier 1 check perfectly -- charge neutrality 0.0, Shannon 0.0, Pauling 0.0 -- with both oxi methods agreeing and a high bandgap of 4.35 eV indicating a wide-gap insulator. All three Sc sites show identical underbonding at BVS 2.514 vs. expected 3+ (16.2% deviation). Experimental Sc-Al-O phases appear exclusively in SG 62 (100%), making the trigonal R-3 prediction entirely novel. With formation energy -3.837 eV/atom (among the most negative in this batch), could Sc3AlO6 be a previously overlooked garnet-related phase where the R-3 symmetry accommodates an ordered Sc/Al distribution on octahedral and tetrahedral sites?

Rb3BiO4 (computationally known, monoclinic P2/c, SG 13) achieves charge neutrality and passes Shannon checks, yet Pauling Rule 2 violations reach 50% (4 of 8 polyhedra fail). Bi is slightly underbonded at BVS 4.533 vs. expected 5+ (9.3% deviation), while Rb shows 38.8% underbonding. The family member Rb4BiO4 (novel, P-1) has a charge deficit of -2.0 and GII of 0.562 -- significantly worse. Given that Bi^5+ is a strong oxidizer and the 50% Pauling violation suggests half the polyhedra have incorrect electrostatic valence distribution, could the monoclinic P2/c structure be attempting to accommodate Bi^5+ in an environment better suited to the more common Bi^3+, with the Pauling failures marking the specific polyhedra where bond valence is redistributed away from the Bi coordination sphere?

TlSb5O13 (novel, orthorhombic Ama2, SG 40) is charge-neutral with zero Shannon and Pauling violations across all 26 checked polyhedra, and both oxi methods agree -- a remarkably clean validation profile for a novel material. All Sb sites are uniformly slightly overbonded at BVS 5.583 vs. expected 5+ (11.7% deviation). The Tl-Sb-O family shows an interesting pattern: Tl2Sb4O7 (novel) has exceptionally low GII of 0.195, while Tl(SbO3)3 and Tl3SbO7 (both novel) show GII 0.658 and 0.633. Could the Sb-rich compositions (TlSb5O13, Tl2Sb4O7) achieve structural stability through edge-sharing SbO6 octahedral networks that dilute the effect of the stereochemically active Tl^+ lone pair, explaining why all Tl-Sb-O phases are novel?

Pr2Ti4O11 (computationally known, monoclinic C2/c, SG 15) shows a Pauling Rule 2 violation of 27.3% (6 of 22 polyhedra), the only significant Pauling failure among charge-neutral pure oxides in this batch. All Ti sites are uniformly underbonded at BVS 3.451 vs. expected 4+ (13.7% deviation). The sole family member PrTi2O5 (computationally known, Pbam) also has a notable charge deficit of -4.0. Given that the Pr2Ti4O11 stoichiometry implies a mix of TiO6 octahedra and TiO5 trigonal bipyramids (required to achieve the 11:4 O:Ti ratio), could the 27.3% Pauling failures specifically localize to the trigonal bipyramidal Ti sites where the non-octahedral coordination inherently violates Pauling's electrostatic valence principle?

Lu6MoO12 (novel, trigonal R-3, SG 148) is charge-neutral with zero Shannon and Pauling violations, but Mo is underbonded at BVS 5.080 vs. expected 6+ (15.3% deviation) and O sites show BVS -1.596 vs. expected -2 (20.2% deviation). Its family member Lu3MoO6 (novel, also R-3) has a lower GII of 0.345 with identical charge neutrality. Comparing to Tb3MoO6 (also in this batch, same R-3 SG, novel): Tb3MoO6 assigns Mo as 3+ with severe underbonding, while Lu6MoO12 assigns Mo as 6+. Given the lanthanide contraction (Lu^3+ = 0.861 A vs. Tb^3+ = 0.923 A), does the smaller Lu^3+ force Mo into a higher oxidation state to maintain the same fluorite-derived R-3 framework, creating a Mo oxidation state gradient across the RE6MoO12 series?

Sr(CoO2)8 (computationally known, triclinic P-1, SG 2) has a charge residual of -6.0, Sr is severely underbonded at BVS 1.127 vs. expected 2+ (43.7% deviation), and both oxi methods disagree with mixed valence flagged. The Sr-Co-O family reveals a systematic pattern: charge deficit scales with Co:Sr ratio -- Sr(CoO2)2 (0.0), Sr(CoO2)3 (-2.0), Sr(CoO2)4 (-4.0), Sr(CoO2)6 (-8.0), Sr(CoO2)8 (-6.0), Sr8(CoO3)7 (-10.0). Yet GII does not track charge: Sr(CoO2)3 has GII 0.289 despite -2.0 charge, while Sr6Co5O16 has GII 0.640 at neutrality. Does this decoupling between charge balance and structural strain indicate that the Sr-Co-O system fundamentally requires a fractional Co oxidation state model that integer-based oxi assignment cannot capture?

Ba4IrO7 is computationally known yet adopts space group P2_1 (SG 4), which appears in none of the experimental space groups for this chemistry (C2/m at 25%, P2_1/c at 12%, C2/c at 12%). Across the Ba-Ir-O family, GII values rise sharply with increasing Ir content -- Ba2IrO5 at 0.28, Ba3Ir2O9 at 0.36, Ba4Ir6O19 at 0.24, then Ba2Ir7O18 jumps to 0.59 with a -4.0 charge imbalance. Given that Ba4IrO7 shows Ir BVS of 5.32 against an expected +6 (11.3% deviation), does the low Ir:Ba ratio in this compound create an unusually underbonded Ir environment that destabilizes the structure toward this unconventional low-symmetry space group?

La3WO7 is flagged as novel with mixed valence and methods_disagree oxidation state confidence, yet it passes charge neutrality perfectly (total charge 0.0) and Shannon radii checks. The W sites show BVS of 4.36 against an expected +5 (12.9% deviation), suggesting the tungsten is systematically underbonded. Given that both oxidation state methods disagree on this compound and the predicted space group Cmcm (SG 63) does not match any of the experimentally observed space groups (P-1 at 25%, C2/c at 25%, P2_12_12_1 at 25%), could the oxi state ambiguity indicate that W actually adopts +6 rather than +5, which would simultaneously resolve the BVS underbonding but break charge neutrality?

Sm2NO is classified as an oxynitride with a charge neutrality residual of -2.0 and methods_disagree oxidation state confidence. The O sites show BVS of -1.50 against expected -2 (25.2% deviation), indicating severe oxygen underbonding. With only 2 bonds checked for Pauling Rule 2 (all passing) and a very small unit cell of 8 sites, does the oxynitride classification combined with the -2.0 charge imbalance suggest that the assigned oxidation states (likely Sm3+, N3-, O2-) are fundamentally incorrect, and that Sm may actually be in a +2 state as is common in reduced samarium nitrides?

SmSO is a novel oxychalcogenide with perfect charge neutrality and Shannon radii, but 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (4/4 bonds checked) and a Pauling warning flag. Its sole family member Sm(S8O)3 shows dramatically worse structural quality with GII of 1.077 and charge imbalance of -4.0. Given that SmSO adopts space group Cmce (SG 64) rather than any experimentally observed space groups (P2_1/c, I-42d, P-3m1), and all Sm sites show identical 16.1% BVS deviation (BVS 2.52 vs expected 3.0), could the universal Pauling violation indicate that the O2- assumption is invalid for this oxychalcogenide and that mixed S2-/O2- anion ordering creates coordination environments fundamentally incompatible with Pauling's electrostatic valence rule?

K(WO3)2 shows a striking internal contradiction: both oxidation state methods agree on the assignment, yet the compound fails charge neutrality with a -2.0 residual and exhibits mixed valence. The K site is catastrophically underbonded with BVS of 0.44 against expected +1 (56.5% deviation), while the W sites are slightly overbonded at 5.80 vs expected +5 (16.0% deviation). Its family member K6W2O9 achieves charge neutrality with GII 0.34 in a different K:W ratio. Does the extreme K underbonding (56.5% deviation, the worst in this batch) indicate that K occupies an oversized cavity in this tungsten bronze-type structure, and could partial K-site occupancy resolve both the charge imbalance and the anomalous BVS?

K4(CoO2)3 belongs to a K-Co-O family of 5 members spanning a wide compositional range, where a systematic pattern emerges: compounds with charge neutrality (K12Co2O9 and K4CoO4) have higher GII values (0.67-0.70) while charge-imbalanced compounds (K(CoO2)6 at -10.0, K(CoO2)3 at -4.0, K(CoO2)8 at -7.0) have lower GII values (0.27-0.31). K4(CoO2)3 itself has -2.0 charge residual with GII ~0.35 and all O sites underbonded at BVS -1.59 (20.5% deviation). Does this inverse correlation between charge neutrality and structural strain across the K-Co-O family indicate that GNoME's energy minimization trades off formal charge balance for local bond-length optimization?

Na3Ga5O9 is computationally known with excellent Tier 1 validation -- perfect charge neutrality, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across all 18 bonds checked -- yet its Ga sites show 21.7% BVS deviation (BVS 2.35 vs expected +3), suggesting significant underbonding. Its family member Na7Ga3O8 shows a similar pattern with GII 0.39 and charge neutrality maintained. Given the wide bandgap of 2.62 eV and the monoclinic C2/c (SG 15) structure matching one of the experimental space groups (P2_1/c at 20%), could the systematic Ga underbonding indicate that some Ga sites adopt tetrahedral rather than octahedral coordination, which would be chemically reasonable for Ga3+ but would shift the expected BVS parameters?

DySO is a novel oxychalcogenide that is structurally near-identical to SmSO (batch mate 4f97ccb89a): same space group Cmce (SG 64), same compound class, same 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation rate (4/4 checked), and nearly identical BVS deviations (Dy: 2.52 vs exp 3.0 at 16.0% deviation; Sm: 2.52 vs exp 3.0 at 16.1%). Both have sole family members with the same R3m structure type and extremely high GII (Dy(S8O)3 at 1.164 vs Sm(S8O)3 at 1.077). Given that these lanthanide oxychalcogenides show such remarkably parallel behavior despite different lanthanide radii, does this suggest GNoME learned a single structural template for LnSO compounds, and could the universal Pauling failure be a systematic artifact of applying O2--calibrated BVS parameters to mixed-anion environments?

K5Cr2O7 is novel with mixed valence, 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (14/14 bonds), and a -2.0 charge residual, yet it achieves a non-zero space group score of 0.077 -- the only material in this batch with any space group match. Its Cr sites show BVS of 3.37 against expected +4 (15.7% deviation). Across the K-Cr-O family, all other members maintain charge neutrality but with higher GII values (K7CrO6: 0.42, K6Cr2O7: 0.54, K5CrO5: 0.53, K3Cr4O8: 0.46). Why does K5Cr2O7 show universally worse Pauling violations than its charge-neutral family members, and could the mixed valence assignment (Cr3+/Cr4+) be masking a uniform Cr6+ dichromate-like configuration that would radically change the expected local geometry?

K7MnO6 is a novel pure oxide with 56 sites (the largest unit cell in this batch), charge neutrality, and only single-method oxidation state confidence. All Mn sites show identical BVS deviation of 12.9% (BVS 4.36 vs expected +5), while 66.7% of Pauling Rule 2 bonds are violated (16/24). The sole family member K2Mn5O10 has a dramatically different K:Mn ratio with GII 0.39 and charge imbalance of -3.0. Given the extremely alkali-rich stoichiometry (K:Mn = 7:1) and orthorhombic SG 60 (Pbcn) structure, could K7MnO6 represent a hyperalkali manganate where isolated [MnO6] octahedra are surrounded by an excess K matrix, and does the Pauling violation pattern indicate that the O atoms are overbonded by K contributions that the electrostatic valence rule does not properly account for?

Cs3AsO3 is a novel pure oxide with perfect Tier 1 scores (charge neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across 12 bonds) and a wide bandgap of 2.86 eV, yet all As sites show consistent ~19.5% BVS deviation (BVS 2.42 vs expected +3). Its family member Cs5As3O10 has excellent GII of 0.20 with charge neutrality. Given that As3+ is a lone-pair active cation and the monoclinic P2_1/c structure (SG 14) matches one of the experimentally observed space groups at 25%, could the systematic As underbonding reflect the stereochemically active lone pair creating an asymmetric coordination environment where standard BVS parameters (calibrated on symmetric coordination) systematically underestimate the true bond valence?

Nb9SO25 is computationally known but shows the most extreme charge neutrality failure in this batch at -8.0 residual charge, despite both oxidation state methods agreeing on the assignment. It is an oxychalcogenide with mixed valence, and the S site shows BVS of 6.63 against expected +6 (10.5% overbonding), while Nb sites show BVS of 4.66 vs expected +4 (16.4% overbonding). With 52% Pauling violation rate (13/25 bonds) and near-zero bandgap (0.001 eV), this compound simultaneously fails charge neutrality and shows metallic character. Is the massive -8.0 charge imbalance evidence that the assigned mixed Nb4+/Nb5+ state is incorrect, and could the near-zero bandgap indicate delocalized electrons that make formal oxidation states meaningless for this compound?

Y2IrO6 is novel with charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across 24 bonds, but experimentally Y2IrO6 adopts the pyrochlore structure in Fd-3m (SG 227, 100% of experimental observations), while GNoME predicts orthorhombic P2_12_12_1 (SG 19) -- a dramatic symmetry reduction from cubic to orthorhombic. All Y sites are systematically underbonded at ~20.5% deviation (BVS 2.38-2.39 vs expected +3), and the oxidation state was determined by only a single method. Given that pyrochlore Y2Ir2O7 is a well-known topological semimetal, does GNoME's prediction of a low-symmetry Y2IrO6 polymorph represent a metastable phase, or has the network confused the Ir4+ pyrochlore (Y2Ir2O7) with a hypothetical Ir5+ structure?

Lu3MoO6 is novel with perfect Tier 1 checks, a wide bandgap of 2.78 eV, and trigonal R-3 symmetry (SG 148). The Mo site shows the largest BVS deviation at 19.0% (BVS 2.43 vs expected +3), while Lu sites deviate by 14.0% (BVS 2.58 vs expected +3). Its family member Lu6MoO12 has the same R-3 space group with GII 0.35 and perfect charge neutrality, and is exactly double the formula unit (Lu3MoO6 x 2). Given that these two compounds share the same space group and represent a 1:1 compositional scaling, could Lu6MoO12 actually be the same phase as Lu3MoO6 with a doubled unit cell, rather than a distinct compound, and does GNoME's prediction of both reflect a systematic tendency to generate supercell variants as nominally distinct materials?

Eu3Al4O9 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds, yet the Eu sites show the most extreme BVS deviation in this batch at 36.2% (BVS 1.28 vs expected +2). This is far worse than the dataset median GII of ~0.43 v.u. With a near-zero bandgap of 0.001 eV, the compound appears metallic. Given that Eu commonly adopts both +2 and +3 oxidation states and the assigned state is Eu2+, could the extreme 36.2% underbonding instead indicate that Eu is actually in the +3 state in this structure, which would break charge neutrality (Eu3+: 3*3 + 4*3 - 9*2 = 3 excess) but dramatically improve the BVS match?

ErCo2O5 and DyCo2O5 (batch mate 6e9b301357) are both computationally known, both adopt SG 55 (Pbam), both have methods_disagree oxidation state confidence, both show mixed valence, identical -4.0 charge residual, and nearly identical Co BVS deviations (Er: 2.53/3.0 at 15.7%; Dy: 2.50/3.0 at 16.6%). Both have a single family member with formula Ln5(CoO6)2 in C2/m with null GII. The experimental SG is Pnma (SG 62) at 100% for both. Does this parallel behavior across two isostructural RCo2O5 compounds indicate a systematic issue in how GNoME models rare-earth cobaltites, and does the universal Co underbonding combined with methods_disagree status suggest that Co may be in a mixed Co2+/Co3+ state rather than uniform Co3+?

Gd2OF4 is a computationally known oxyhalide with perfect charge neutrality, zero Shannon violations, and zero Pauling violations (though only 2 bonds were checked with a warning flag). The Gd sites show uniform 18.0% BVS deviation (BVS 2.46 vs expected +3). Experimentally, this composition exclusively adopts the R-3m structure (SG 166, 100% of observations), but GNoME predicts monoclinic C2/c (SG 15). With a very high bandgap of 3.50 eV typical of fluoride-dominated compounds, could the predicted monoclinic polymorph represent a high-pressure phase of Gd2OF4, given that monoclinic distortions from rhombohedral symmetry are commonly observed under compression in rare-earth oxyfluorides?

Pr2SeO5 is a novel oxychalcogenide showing the only non-zero Shannon radii score in this batch (0.086), alongside 30% Pauling violations (6/20 bonds) and a Pauling warning flag. Across its 5-member Pr-Se-O family, GII values span a remarkable range: Pr2(SeO4)3 at 0.10 (charge neutral, computationally known), Pr2As4O9-analog Pr2Se5O13 at 0.31, Pr2SeO6 at 0.35, Pr2Se3O10 at 0.57, and PrSeO at 1.23 (charge neutral). This pattern shows GII degrading as the Se:O ratio deviates from selenate-like stoichiometry. Does the Shannon violation (the only one in 25 materials) indicate that the ionic radius model breaks down specifically at the Pr-Se interface, and should oxychalcogenide validators apply distinct radius tables for chalcogenide vs oxide sublattices?

Li5UO5 is novel with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations, yet its Li sites show catastrophic underbonding: BVS values of 0.56, 0.57, and 0.58 against expected +1, representing 42-44% deviation -- among the worst in this batch. This extreme Li underbonding in a structure with only 11 sites suggests the Li atoms occupy cavities far too large for their ionic radius. Its family member LiU8O18 has a dramatically different Li:U ratio with much better GII of 0.19 but a -3.0 charge imbalance. Could the extreme Li underbonding indicate that this Li5UO5 structure has significant Li-ion mobility (analogous to LISICON-type conductors), and would the formation energy of -2.73 eV/atom support thermodynamic stability for a potential solid-state electrolyte application?

Gd11Ta3O24 is novel in the lowest-symmetry space group P1 (SG 1) with 38 sites, no symmetry operations, and a very negative formation energy of -3.82 eV/atom. One oxygen site shows extreme underbonding with BVS of -1.36 vs expected -2.0 (32.3% deviation), while the Ta sites show 12.9-14.8% deviation. The sole family member Gd6TaO12 in R-3 has null GII, preventing direct comparison. Given that P1 is exceptionally rare for ternary oxides and the Gd:Ta ratio of 11:3 is unusually non-stoichiometric, is this compound actually a computationally relaxed defect structure or superstructure of the simpler Gd6TaO12 phase, and does the 32.3% oxygen underbonding at a specific site indicate a structural vacancy that GNoME has filled with an oxygen atom?

Ba4Bi2O9 is novel with charge neutrality and hexagonal P6_3/m symmetry (SG 176), a space group not among any of the experimentally observed ones (P2_1/c at 33%, C2/m at 17%, R-3 at 17%). Two Ba sites show extreme underbonding at 43.8% deviation (BVS 1.12 vs expected +2), the worst Ba underbonding in this batch. In the Ba-Bi-O family, Ba2Bi2O7 achieves excellent GII of 0.20 with charge neutrality, while Ba3Bi4O and Ba5Bi3O have null GII (likely failed validation entirely due to unusual O-poor stoichiometry).
