Does the coexistence of severely underbonded Ba (43.8% deviation) with charge neutrality suggest that the hexagonal structure creates anomalously large Ba cages, and could this Ba4Bi2O9 represent a hexagonal perovskite derivative where the face-sharing octahedral columns inherently produce underbonded A-site cations?

Rb3ReO5 is novel with perfect charge neutrality, zero Shannon and Pauling violations (20/20 bonds pass), yet all three worst-deviating sites are oxygen at 22.8% underbonding (BVS -1.55 vs expected -2.0). Experimentally, Rb3ReO5-type compounds adopt tetragonal I-41/a (SG 88, 100% of observations), but GNoME predicts orthorhombic Cmcm (SG 63). Its family member Rb3ReO4 is computationally known with GII 0.34 in I-42m. Given that the step from ReO4 (tetrahedral perrhenate) to ReO5 (square pyramidal) adds one oxygen and changes Re from +7 to +7 (maintained), could the uniform oxygen underbonding pattern indicate that the fifth oxygen is weakly bound in an apical position, suggesting Rb3ReO5 might be better described as Rb3[ReO4]-O with a loosely associated interstitial oxide?

KV6O12 has the most extreme charge neutrality failure (-10.0 residual) of any pure oxide in this batch, despite both oxidation state methods agreeing on the assignment, zero Pauling violations (24/24 pass), and zero Shannon violations. The compound has mixed valence and the worst-deviating sites are all oxygen with 23-24% underbonding (BVS -1.52 to -1.54 vs expected -2.0). Its family member KV3O5 achieves charge neutrality but with a much higher GII of 0.53. How can a compound with -10.0 charge residual simultaneously pass all Pauling and Shannon checks perfectly, and does this suggest that the V oxidation state mixture is incorrectly assigned -- perhaps V should be in a lower average oxidation state that would reduce the total negative charge while also explaining the systematic oxygen underbonding?

DyCo2O5 is computationally known and isostructural with ErCo2O5 (same SG 55, same -4.0 charge residual, same methods_disagree status), yet shows slightly lower Co BVS deviation (16.6% vs 15.7%) and marginally lower formation energy (-2.09 vs -2.10 eV/atom). Both experimental databases indicate 100% occurrence in Pnma (SG 62) for RCo2O5 compositions, but GNoME predicts Pbam (SG 55) for both. Given that Pbam is a subgroup of Pnma with broken mirror symmetry, could GNoME be predicting a genuine symmetry-lowering phase transition in the RCo2O5 family, potentially related to charge ordering on the Co sublattice that experimentally occurs at low temperatures in these double perovskite cobaltites?

Pr4As3O4 is novel with mixed valence, a +1.0 charge residual (unusually positive, unlike most imbalances in this batch which are negative), and 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation across only 4 bonds checked. All Pr sites are underbonded (BVS 2.37-2.62 vs expected +3), with deviations ranging from 12.6% to 20.9%. The experimental space group for this composition is I-41/a (SG 88, 100%), but GNoME predicts Amm2 (SG 38). Its family member Pr2As4O9 is computationally known with excellent GII of 0.17 and perfect charge neutrality. Given that Pr4As3O4 has an unusually low O:As ratio compared to the arsenate Pr2As4O9, and a positive charge excess of +1.0, could this composition actually represent a pnictide-oxide hybrid (with As3- rather than As3+/As5+) where the oxidation state assignment is fundamentally wrong, producing a material more akin to a rare-earth arsenide oxide than an arsenate?

U2AsO2 is classified as a pure oxide yet contains arsenic assigned As3- (BVS -3.153 vs expected -3), and both oxidation state methods disagree, yielding a residual charge of -1.0. Given that uranium shows a BVS of 3.521 against an expected +3 (17.4% overbonded), could the true oxidation state assignment involve U4+/As3- rather than U3+/As3-, and does the space group mismatch (predicted SG 164 trigonal vs 100% experimental SG 142 tetragonal) suggest this structure was forced into the wrong symmetry during GNoME optimization?

Novel Co6AgO12 exhibits a catastrophic charge neutrality failure of -10.0, the largest residual in this batch, yet passes Shannon radii and Pauling checks across all 24 coordination environments. The Ag sites show BVS of only 0.493 against expected +1 (49.3% underbonded), suggesting silver may be severely undercoordinated or misassigned. With only single-method oxidation state assignment (oxi_state_guesses), could the correct formulation involve Co in mixed valence (Co2+/Co3+) rather than uniform oxidation, which would reconcile the massive charge imbalance?

Tm7VO12 is charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing, yet vanadium shows a BVS of only 2.334 against expected +3 (22.2% underbonded), suggesting the V site geometry is unusually expanded. Across the Tm-V-O family, GII values increase systematically as the Tm:V ratio decreases (Tm7VO12: 0.338, Tm2VO5: 0.385, Tm2V3O8: 0.366, TmV4O8: 0.416), and the V-rich members also fail charge neutrality. Does this pattern indicate that thulium's large ionic radius stabilizes vanadate structures preferentially at high Tm:V ratios, with the trigonal R-3 framework being the most geometrically accommodating?

Ho7VO12 is isostructural (SG 148, R-3, trigonal) and isoformula to Tm7VO12, with nearly identical GII scores (0.338 vs 0.338) and the same vanadium underbonding pattern (BVS 2.28 vs expected +3, 24% deviation). Across the Ho-V-O family, the charge-neutral members HoV3O9 (GII 0.304) and Ho2VO5 (GII 0.390) bracket Ho7VO12 in structural strain. Given that Ho3+ (1.015 A) is slightly larger than Tm3+ (0.994 A), why does the lanthanide contraction produce essentially no measurable difference in GII for this 7:1:12 stoichiometry, and does this suggest the R-3 cage geometry is insensitive to A-site radius within the heavy lanthanide series?

CeSeO5, classified as an oxychalcogenide, is charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing on Ce4+/Se4+, yet shows a Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 0.20 (2 of 10 bonds violated, with warning flag). The BVS reveals Ce overbonded at 4.703 vs expected +4 (17.6% deviation) and oxygen overbonded at -2.531 vs expected -2 (26.5% deviation). Since the BVS parameters for Ce-Se and Se-O bonds in mixed-anion systems are less well-calibrated than pure oxide references, how much of this apparent overbonding is a genuine structural strain versus a systematic artifact of applying oxide-derived BVS parameters to an oxychalcogenide?

La(IrO3)3 achieves a rare space group match (SG 63 Cmcm, matching 33% of experimental precedent) and is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds, yet all three symmetry-equivalent Ir sites show identical BVS of 5.695 against expected +5 (13.9% overbonded). Within the La-Ir-O family, La2IrO6 has the lowest GII (0.202) while La(IrO3)3 sits at 0.337 and La5(IrO6)2 at 0.371. Does the progressive increase in GII with higher Ir:La ratio suggest that iridium's preference for regular octahedral coordination becomes increasingly frustrated as the La3+ spacer ions are diluted?

Oxyhalide Dy3IO8 shows a striking split in BVS quality: iodine is well-bonded (BVS 6.686 vs expected +7, only 4.5% deviation) while both Dy sites are severely underbonded at 2.032 vs expected +3 (32.3% deviation). Combined with a Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 0.25 (4 of 16 bonds) and only single-method oxi assignment, this pattern suggests the Dy coordination polyhedra may be systematically expanded. Its family member DyIO4 (computationally known, GII 0.390) has a more conventional stoichiometry -- could the Dy3IO8 composition represent an unlikely oxygen-excess variant that GNoME generated by interpolating between DyIO4 and Dy2O3 endpoints?

Ba7W4O19 is a novel charge-neutral tungstate with a wide bandgap of 3.126 eV and near-zero Pauling violations (1 of 19 bonds, 5.3%), yet two Ba sites show BVS of only 1.426 against expected +2 (28.7% underbonded) while W is modestly underbonded at 5.444 vs +6 (9.3%). The sole family member Ba4WO7 (GII 0.418, also novel) has an even higher Ba:W ratio. Does the systematic Ba underbonding across both stoichiometries indicate that GNoME is generating barium tungstate structures with excessively large Ba-O cavities, and could this be tested by comparing predicted Ba-O distances against the known Ba2WO5 and BaWO4 reference structures?

Ca5U5O18 stands out as the most internally contradictory material in the Ca-U-O family: it has mixed valence, methods-disagree oxi confidence, residual charge of -1.0, and the highest GII (0.336) among its relatives. Strikingly, the U-rich family members CaU8O18 (GII 0.150), CaU9O20 (GII 0.160), and CaU4O10 (GII 0.142) all achieve much lower GII despite also failing charge neutrality at -2.0. The Ca sites in Ca5U5O18 are severely underbonded (BVS 1.299 vs expected +2, 35.1% deviation) while U is overbonded (5.877 vs +5, 17.5%). Does the 1:1 Ca:U ratio create a size-mismatch crisis where neither cation can be properly coordinated simultaneously, explaining why nature favors U-dominated stoichiometries in this system?

Computationally known La6IrO12 uses only bv_analyzer for oxidation state assignment (single_method confidence), yielding Ir6+ -- an unusually high but known state for iridium. Its BVS shows Ir underbonded at 5.201 vs expected +6 (13.3% deviation) and oxygen underbonded at -1.565 vs -2 (21.7%). Notably, its family member La(IrO3)3 achieves a lower GII (0.337 vs 0.336, effectively identical) but with Ir5+ assignment from both-agree confidence. Could La6IrO12 and La(IrO3)3 actually represent the same structural motif with ambiguous Ir oxidation state, and would comparing their Ir-O bond lengths resolve whether Ir5+ or Ir6+ is the correct assignment?

K6W2O9 is a novel potassium tungstate with bandgap 2.882 eV and perfect Tier 1 scores (charge-neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds), yet W shows BVS of 5.381 against expected +6 (10.3% underbonded) and oxygen -1.553 vs -2 (22.4% underbonded). Its family member K(WO3)2 fails charge neutrality at -2.0. Given that the K6W2O9 stoichiometry implies isolated WO4 or WO5 units rather than corner-sharing WO6 octahedra, does the systematic W underbonding indicate that GNoME predicted tungsten in lower-than-octahedral coordination, which would be unusual for W6+ and could be verified by examining the predicted W coordination number?

Ho5V2O12 is the only Ho-V-O family member with mixed valence and methods-disagree oxi confidence, producing a residual charge of -1.0. Vanadium is assigned V4+ here (BVS 3.401 vs expected +4, 15% underbonded) rather than V3+ as in the other family members Ho7VO12 (BVS 2.28/exp +3) and HoV3O9. Yet the family shows a clear trend: GII increases from HoV3O9 (0.304) to Ho5V2O12 (0.336) to Ho2VO5 (0.390) as the Ho:V ratio increases from 1:3 to 5:2 to 2:1. Is the ambiguous vanadium oxidation state in Ho5V2O12 a signature of a phase boundary between V3+ and V5+ stability fields in the Ho-V-O system?

Computationally known Cs(CoO2)4 has a massive charge residual of -3.0 with methods-disagree confidence and mixed valence, yet the Cs-Co-O family reveals an extraordinary pattern: GII values span from 0.290 (Cs(CoO2)2) to 0.734 (Cs4CoO4), and 6 of 8 family members are novel. The Cs-rich compositions (Cs4Co2O5: GII 0.706, Cs4CoO4: 0.734, Cs3CoO3: 0.680) show dramatically worse structural strain than Co-rich ones. Does this systematic GII degradation with increasing Cs:Co ratio indicate that GNoME's neural network extrapolated cesium cobaltate structures beyond the stability boundary where Cs+ can be geometrically accommodated?

Na3IO5 is classified as an oxyhalide and achieves charge neutrality with I7+ (periodate), yet the BVS for all three symmetry-equivalent I sites shows 6.107 vs expected +7 (12.8% underbonded). With only single-method oxi assignment and the Pauling warning flag active despite zero violations in 15 bonds, this material sits at the boundary of the oxyhalide classification. Given that iodine in the +7 state forms IO4 tetrahedra or IO6 octahedra in known periodates like NaIO4 and Na3H2IO6, does the predicted trigonal SG 152 structure accommodate IO5 square pyramidal coordination, which would be geometrically unprecedented for I7+?

Gd2Sb4O13 is charge-neutral with both-agree oxi confidence, yet its Sb5+ sites show systematic overbonding (BVS 5.738 and 5.675 vs expected +5, 13.5-14.8% deviation) and a minor Pauling violation (2 of 26 bonds). Across the Gd-Sb-O family, GII varies dramatically: Gd11(SbO8)3 achieves 0.261 while GdSb5O13 reaches 0.932 and Gd3Sb9O26 hits 0.840, both with severe charge failures (-6.0 and -7.0). The Sb-rich compositions appear structurally untenable. Does this suggest an upper bound on the Sb:Gd ratio (~2:1) beyond which the antimonate framework cannot maintain geometric integrity, making Gd2Sb4O13 the most Sb-rich viable composition?

Sr4Bi2O9 achieves a partial space group match (SG 14, 25% of experimental precedent) and is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations across 36 bonds, yet all three worst-BVS sites are Sr with identical deviations of 33.9% (BVS 1.322 vs expected +2). With 60 sites in the unit cell making it one of the largest structures in this batch, the uniform Sr underbonding across multiple crystallographically distinct sites suggests a systematic problem. Does the combination of a large unit cell (60 sites) and uniformly underbonded Sr indicate that GNoME expanded the lattice parameters beyond physical equilibrium, perhaps to accommodate the large Bi3+ lone pair?

Sm2Ti4O11 is the only material in this batch with a non-zero Shannon radii violation fraction (0.05), meaning 1 in 20 site radii fall outside the 25% tolerance. It also shows elevated Pauling violations (6 of 22 bonds, 27.3%) and all four Ti sites are uniformly underbonded at 3.497 vs expected +4 (12.6% deviation). Known Sm2Ti2O7 pyrochlores adopt SG 227 (Fd-3m), which accounts for 33% of the experimental precedent here, yet GNoME predicts monoclinic C2/c (SG 15). Could the Shannon radii violation signal that the predicted structure forces Ti4+ into a coordination environment too large for its ionic radius, and would the pyrochlore structure (SG 227) eliminate both the Shannon and Pauling violations?

Gd2Zr7O16 fails charge neutrality at -5.0 with methods-disagree oxi confidence, yet achieves zero Pauling violations across 16 bonds and zero Shannon violations. The Gd sites are underbonded (BVS 2.480 vs +3, 17.3% deviation) and oxygen is underbonded (-1.550 vs -2, 22.5%). Known Gd2Zr2O7 pyrochlores adopt cubic SG 227 (100% of experimental precedent), but this composition has a much higher Zr:Gd ratio (3.5:1 vs 1:1). Its family member Gd4Zr3O12 (computationally known, GII 0.416) inverts the ratio. Does this suggest GNoME is exploring a Zr-rich extension of the pyrochlore stability field, and is the -5.0 charge residual evidence that Zr4+/Gd3+ cannot achieve balanced stoichiometry at this extreme ratio?

Oxychalcogenide TmSO achieves charge neutrality and both-agree oxi confidence, yet shows the maximum possible Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 1.0 (all 4 checked bonds violated), the worst in this entire batch. This means every anion coordination environment violates electrostatic valence balance. Despite this, the BVS is moderate (Tm underbonded at 2.537 vs +3, 15.4% deviation). Its family member Tm(S8O)3 has an extreme GII of 1.162. Given that S2- and O2- have different charges but similar BVS parameters, does the complete Pauling failure indicate that the mixed-anion ordering in TmSO is fundamentally incompatible with Pauling's rules, or is the validator incorrectly assuming all anions are O2-?

Computationally known Rb3ReO4 is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations, yet Rb shows extreme underbonding: BVS 0.531 and 0.590 against expected +1 (41-47% deviation), the most severe alkali underbonding in this batch. The predicted tetragonal SG 121 (I-42m) conflicts with 100% experimental precedent for SG 88 (I4_1/a). Its family member Rb3ReO5 (novel, GII 0.340) adds one oxygen but maintains similar GII. Could the severe Rb underbonding indicate that GNoME predicted Rb-O distances that are systematically too long, and would re-optimizing this structure in the experimentally observed SG 88 framework significantly improve the Rb coordination environment?

La(CoO2)8 has the highest Co:La ratio (8:1) in its family and shows cascading failures: charge residual -5.0, methods-disagree oxi confidence, mixed valence, and La underbonded at 1.995 vs expected +3 (33.5% deviation). Its computationally known family member La(CoO2)3 achieves GII 0.246 with zero charge residual, suggesting the 3:1 Co:La ratio is the stability sweet spot. The 8:1 ratio implies La3+ must stabilize eight CoO2 layers, yet its BVS of 1.995 is closer to La2+ than La3+. Does this extreme stoichiometry represent a GNoME extrapolation artifact where the neural network extended a stable La-Co-O motif beyond the geometric limit of lanthanum's coordination capacity?

Pr3PO7 has 66 sites (the largest unit cell in this batch) and shows a rare non-zero Shannon violation (0.88%) alongside a 28.6% Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction (12 of 42 bonds). All three worst-BVS sites are phosphorus, overbonded at 5.964-6.032 vs expected +5 (19.3-20.6% deviation). Since P5+ exclusively forms PO4 tetrahedra in known phosphates with BVS close to 5.0, a systematic 20% overbonding across all P sites suggests either compressed P-O bonds or excess coordination. With 67% experimental precedent for SG 14 (P2_1/c) yet prediction of SG 8 (Cm), could the wrong symmetry assignment have distorted the PO4 tetrahedra, artificially inflating the P BVS values?

Mn4Sb2O9 is charge-neutral with both-agree oxi confidence and zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds, yet Mn shows severe underbonding: BVS 1.397 vs expected +2 (30.1-30.2% deviation across three sites). This ~30% Mn underbonding is consistent across all symmetry-equivalent Mn sites, suggesting a systematic rather than local effect. The experimental space group precedent is spread across SG 135, 150, and 152 (20% each), but GNoME predicts SG 165 (P-3c1). Could the predicted trigonal structure create Mn-O octahedra that are systematically too large, and would the Mn2+ ions be better accommodated in the SG 150 or 152 structures that are experimentally observed for Mn antimonates?

Computationally known Ho(SbO3)3 achieves charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations with both-agree confidence, while its novel family member HoSb5O13 catastrophically fails with GII 0.949 and charge residual -6.0. The Sb5+ overbonding pattern (BVS 5.744 vs +5, 14.9%) is nearly identical to that seen in Gd2Sb4O13 (5.738, 14.8%), suggesting a systematic Sb5+ overbonding signature across rare-earth antimonates. Does this shared ~15% Sb5+ overbonding across Ho and Gd antimonates reflect an intrinsic limitation of BVS reference parameters for Sb-O bonds in rare-earth hosts, or does it indicate genuine compression of SbO6 octahedra by the surrounding lanthanide framework?

Y2(S2O7)3 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with 58 sites, and despite charge neutrality and both-agree confidence, all three worst-BVS sites are sulfur overbonded at 6.71-6.75 vs expected +6 (11.8-12.5%). The Pauling warning flag is active with 14.3% violation fraction (6 of 42 bonds). Its family members YSO (GII 0.477) and Y(S8O)3 (GII 1.241, charge -3.0) show dramatically different structural quality. Given that S2O7 (pyrosulfate) groups have well-characterized S-O bond lengths in known compounds, is the 12% S overbonding evidence that GNoME compressed the S-O bonds relative to experimental pyrosulfate references, or does the triclinic P-1 structure simply lack the symmetry constraints to maintain ideal SO4 tetrahedra?

Dy2OF4 is computationally known but GNoME predicts it in SG 15 (C2/c, monoclinic) while 100% of experimentally observed Dy-O-F compounds adopt SG 166 (R-3m, trigonal): given that the BVS shows all Dy sites uniformly underbonded at 2.477 v.u. vs. expected 3+ (17.4% deviation), could the monoclinic distortion be an artifact of the DFT relaxation trapping the structure in a local minimum rather than converging to the higher-symmetry rhombohedral ground state?

U4Se3O4 carries a massive charge imbalance of -4.0 despite both oxidation state methods agreeing, and its family members show a consistent pattern: U3Se2O3 (novel, charge -4.0) fails identically while U2SeO2 (computationally known, charge 0.0) passes -- does this systematic charge failure across U-Se-O stoichiometries with Se:U ratios below 1.0 indicate that the standard U3+/U4+ oxidation state assignment cannot accommodate the mixed-valence character (flagged as mixed_valence=1) in Se-rich uranium oxychalcogenides?

K3AsO3 is charge-neutral and passes Shannon radii and Pauling checks perfectly, yet every As site shows BVS of 2.414 v.u. against an expected 3+ (19.5% deviation) and the oxygen sites are also systematically underbonded at -1.636 v.u. vs. -2: could this uniform undervaluation across both cation and anion sublattices indicate that GNoME's predicted structure has unit cell dimensions that are systematically too large, inflating all bond lengths by a consistent ~8-10%?

RbV6O12 is novel with an extreme charge imbalance of -10.0 and sits in SG 1 (P1, triclinic), yet its Rb-V-O family members Rb5VO5 and RbV3O5 are both charge-neutral with moderate GII values (0.569 and 0.540 respectively): given that all oxygen sites in RbV6O12 are underbonded (~-1.54 v.u. vs. expected -2), does the V6O12 stoichiometry require a V oxidation state mixture (e.g., V3+/V4+) that neither oxidation state method can resolve despite both agreeing, making the -10.0 charge residual an artifact of forcing a single V oxidation state?

Co8BiO16 is a novel prediction where both oxidation state methods disagree yet the structure passes Shannon radii and all 16 Pauling checks perfectly -- meanwhile, the Bi site is severely underbonded at BVS 2.044 v.u. vs. expected 3+ (31.9% deviation) and the charge imbalance is -5.0: with 8 Co atoms in a mixed-valence environment and a triclinic SG 1 cell, could the oxi method disagreement stem from Co2+/Co3+ ambiguity, and does the extreme Bi underbonding suggest the predicted Bi coordination polyhedron is physically unrealistic?

The Nb-O-F oxyhalide family shows a striking charge-balance gradient: Nb4O5F7 (charge -1.0, GII 0.124), Nb4O7F5 (charge -3.0, GII 0.256), and Nb16O37F3 (charge -13.0, GII 0.330) -- as the F:O ratio decreases from 1.4 to 0.08, charge imbalance worsens dramatically from -1 to -13 while GII nearly triples, and Pauling violations spike to 78.4% (29/37 sites): is GNoME systematically unable to correctly place fluorine in oxygen-dominated niobium frameworks, generating structures where F substitution sites are chemically implausible?

Nd2Zr7O16 is computationally known but predicted in trigonal SG 148 (R-3) while 100% of experimental Nd-Zr-O compounds adopt SG 227 (Fd-3m, pyrochlore): given that the charge imbalance is -5.0, both oxi methods disagree, and the family member Nd4Zr3O12 (novel, charge 0.0, GII 0.482) is charge-neutral, could Nd2Zr7O16 represent a Zr-rich defect pyrochlore where the Nd:Zr ratio of 2:7 exceeds the stability limit for the fluorite-derived superstructure, forcing the lower-symmetry trigonal distortion?

Eu2CO5 is a novel prediction that is charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing (Eu3+, C4+), passes all Shannon and Pauling checks, yet has a near-zero bandgap of 0.0012 eV and all three Eu sites show identical underbonding at BVS 2.522 v.u. (15.9% deviation from 3+): given that Eu2+ is well-known for stabilizing in reduced environments, could the near-metallic bandgap indicate that this structure actually favors Eu2+ rather than the assigned Eu3+, which would break charge neutrality and suggest the DFT electronic structure is inconsistent with the assumed ionic model?

Zn3(BiO4)2 passes charge neutrality and all 16 Pauling checks perfectly, but the three Zn sites are severely underbonded at BVS ~1.41 v.u. vs. expected 2+ (29.3% deviation) -- its family member ZnBi3O8 could not even be evaluated for BVS or charge (both null): does the extreme Zn underbonding indicate that GNoME has placed Zn2+ in coordination environments with systematically elongated Zn-O bonds, and could the Zn-Bi-O chemical space be poorly represented in the GNoME training data given that even the simpler family member failed basic validation?

Fe3I4O is a novel oxyhalide predicted in cubic SG 198 (P2_13) while experimental Fe-I-O compounds exclusively adopt SG 173 (P6_3, hexagonal), and it shows 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations (4/4 anion sites checked) combined with extreme I underbonding at BVS -0.574 v.u. vs. expected -1 (42.6% deviation): with only a single oxygen atom in the formula unit and four iodine atoms, does this structure represent a case where GNoME has incorrectly predicted an iodide-dominated compound as an oxide-containing phase, producing coordination environments where iodine cannot achieve proper valence saturation?

Dy4Hf3O12 is a novel prediction that is charge-neutral with high oxi confidence (both_agree), passes Shannon and all 24 Pauling checks, and has a wide bandgap of 4.44 eV suggesting genuine insulating character -- however, all Hf sites are underbonded at BVS ~3.28 v.u. vs. expected 4+ (18.1% deviation) while experimental Dy-Hf-O exclusively adopts the pyrochlore SG 227: could this triclinic (SG 2) structure represent a metastable polymorph of the Dy2Hf2O7 pyrochlore with a distorted fluorite framework where the Hf underbonding reflects genuine structural strain that might be experimentally accessible through high-pressure synthesis?

Ba5(IrO5)2 shows severe Ba underbonding at BVS 1.098 v.u. vs. expected 2+ (45.1% deviation), the worst in this batch, yet is charge-neutral and passes Shannon checks -- remarkably, its extensive Ba-Ir-O family of 7 members spans a wide GII range from 0.238 (Ba4Ir6O19) to 0.722 (BaIr5O13), with charge failures appearing only in Ir-rich compositions (Ba2Ir7O18 at -4.0, BaIr5O13 at -8.0): does this pattern reveal that classical BVS parameters for Ir4+/Ir5+ in high-coordination Ba environments are poorly calibrated, or is GNoME systematically overexpanding Ba-O bond lengths in Ir-containing structures?

Ag2AsO4 is novel with only single-method oxi state assignment (oxi_state_guesses) and carries a charge imbalance of -2.0 -- notably, both family members Ag5(AsO5)2 (GII 0.741, charge 0.0) and Ag3As2O7 (GII 0.295, charge -2.0) also show either high structural strain or charge failure: given that all oxygen sites are uniformly underbonded at BVS -1.63 v.u. (18.5% deviation), could the systematic -2.0 charge residual across Ag-As-O compositions indicate that the assumed Ag1+ state is incorrect and Ag2+ should be considered, potentially resolving both the charge imbalance and the oxygen underbonding simultaneously?

Ba6Bi2O11 is novel, charge-neutral, and passes all Pauling checks (0/22 violations) -- an unusually clean validation profile -- yet all Ba sites are underbonded at BVS ~1.36 v.u. (31.5-31.9% deviation from 2+), and its family reveals an intriguing pattern: Ba2Bi2O7 (GII 0.201) is well-bonded while Ba3Bi4O and Ba5Bi3O both have null GII/charge data, suggesting extreme compositions that validators cannot even process: does the Ba6Bi2O11 stoichiometry with its 3:1 Ba:Bi ratio represent a genuinely novel structural motif where Ba occupies unusually large cavities, or does the systematic 30%+ Ba underbonding indicate a fundamentally unrealistic coordination environment?

Nd2(S2O7)3 is a novel oxychalcogenide with 58 sites, charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing on S6+ -- the S sites show BVS values of 6.72 and 6.69 v.u. (11.5-12.0% overbonding relative to expected 6+), while its family member Nd(S8O)3 has an extreme GII of 1.113 and charge of -4.0: given that the S2O7 pyrosulfate unit typically has very specific S-O-S bridging geometry, could the slight S overbonding indicate that GNoME has predicted compressed S-O bonds within the pyrosulfate tetrahedra, and does the dramatic structural failure of Nd(S8O)3 suggest GNoME struggles with sulfur in non-standard oxidation environments?

Bi28Se2O47 is an exceptionally large novel structure (77 sites, SG 1) where the two Se sites show wildly different BVS values -- 3.758 v.u. (24.8% below expected 5+) and 5.863 v.u. (17.3% above expected 5+) -- suggesting two chemically distinct Se environments despite the same formal oxidation state: combined with oxi assignment from a single method only, 17% Pauling violations (8/47 sites), and the fact that family member Bi2(SeO4)3 achieves a near-perfect GII of 0.041 while this compound scores 0.326, does the Se BVS divergence indicate that one Se site may actually be Se4+ (selenite) rather than Se6+ (selenate), creating a mixed-anion compound the validators cannot properly classify?

Nb2Bi4O11 is the only material in this batch with a non-zero space group score (0.333, matching SG 2 which appears in 33% of experimental Nb-Bi-O compounds), is charge-neutral, passes all 22 Pauling checks, and shows moderate Nb underbonding at BVS ~4.45 v.u. vs. expected 5+ (10.6-10.9% deviation): its family member Nb3Bi7O18 (novel, GII 0.319, charge 0.0) also validates well, while Nb(BiO2)7 (computationally known, GII 0.591, charge -2.0) performs worse -- could this suggest that Nb-Bi-O compositions near the 1:2 Nb:Bi ratio represent a thermodynamically favorable structural basin that GNoME has correctly identified?

Nd(OsO3)3 is novel with only single-method oxi state assignment yet achieves charge neutrality and passes all 18 Pauling checks with 0 violations -- however, its family members Nd3Os2O9 (GII 0.598, charge -2.0) and Nd3OsO8 (GII 0.577, charge 0.0) both show substantially higher structural strain: given that the Nd BVS of 2.675 v.u. (10.8% below expected 3+) is relatively modest, does the superior structural quality of the 1:3 Nd:Os stoichiometry compared to the 3:2 and 3:1 ratios suggest that high Os content stabilizes the structure by providing a more rigid octahedral framework, and should the single-method oxi assignment be considered reliable given all other validators pass?

Tb5(FeO6)2 is computationally known with mixed valence and methods_disagree oxi confidence, producing a charge imbalance of -3.0, yet it passes all 12 Pauling checks and Shannon radii perfectly -- the oxygen sites show the worst underbonding in this structure at BVS -1.487 v.u. (25.6% below expected -2): its family reveals that Tb2Fe2O7 (pyrochlore SG Fd-3m, GII 0.677, charge 0.0) has much higher strain than Tb7FeO12 (GII 0.395, charge 0.0), suggesting that Fe-rich Tb-Fe-O compositions are structurally problematic -- does the 5:2 Tb:Fe ratio create an unusual Fe coordination that the mixed-valence Fe2+/Fe3+ ambiguity cannot properly describe?

Sr3Al4O9 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality, Shannon radii, and Pauling checks (0/18 violations), yet all three Sr sites show substantial underbonding at BVS ~1.32 v.u. (33.7-33.9% below expected 2+) while having a wide bandgap of 3.89 eV typical of genuine aluminate insulators: given that the Sr-Al-O system is well-studied experimentally (SrAl2O4 phosphors), could the extreme Sr underbonding indicate that GNoME has predicted an expanded framework aluminate where Sr2+ occupies unusually large cages, potentially making this structure a candidate for ionic conductivity if the open channels accommodate Sr2+ migration?

U4Pb3O13 is computationally known and charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing, yet all three Pb sites show severe underbonding at BVS 1.235 v.u. vs. expected 2+ (38.2% deviation) -- this is the second-worst BVS deviation in this batch: given that Pb2+ is a well-known lone-pair cation where asymmetric coordination environments can produce anomalous BVS results, and the family member UPb2O5 (novel, GII 0.404, charge 0.0) also shows moderate strain, could the extreme Pb underbonding indicate that GNoME has predicted an incorrect Pb coordination geometry that fails to account for the stereochemically active 6s2 lone pair directing the Pb-O bond distribution?

Y2UO6 is computationally known with an unusually clean validation profile -- charge-neutral, both oxi methods agree, 0/12 Pauling violations, and modest U6+ BVS of 5.465 v.u. (8.9% deviation) -- and has an extensive family of 6 novel Y-U-O compounds all showing remarkably consistent GII values between 0.217 and 0.230 but with uniform -1.0 charge imbalance: does this striking GII convergence across YU3O8, YU5O12, YU7O16, YU8O18, and YU9O20 suggest that GNoME has learned a robust U-O bonding template that produces geometrically reasonable structures even when the Y:U ratio is suboptimal for charge balance, and could these represent a family of reducible uranium oxide host structures?

NiS2O7 (nickel pyrosulfate) is computationally known with a non-zero space group score of 0.143 (matching SG 2 at 14% of experimental compounds) and shows S sites overbonded at BVS 6.58-6.65 v.u. vs. expected 6+ (9.7-10.8% excess), while its family member Ni(S8O)3 has an extreme GII of 1.011 and charge of -4.0: given that pyrosulfate S2O7^2- units have well-characterized S-O bond lengths in the literature, does the consistent S overbonding across both NiS2O7 and the batch-mate Nd2(S2O7)3 (S BVS 6.69-6.72) indicate a systematic bias in BVS R0 parameters for S6+ in the pyrosulfate geometry, rather than a structural error in GNoME's predictions?

Co(PtO3)2 is a novel prediction with single-method oxi assignment that achieves charge neutrality and passes all 12 Pauling checks, but shows Co overbonded at BVS 2.324 v.u. vs. expected 2+ (16.2% excess): experimental Co-Pt-O compounds favor SG 166 (R-3m, 67%) while GNoME predicts SG 136 (P4_2/mnm, tetragonal rutile-type) -- could this symmetry mismatch indicate that GNoME has placed Co2+ in a compressed octahedral site typical of the rutile structure that is energetically unfavorable compared to the layered R-3m arrangement, and might the overbonded Co actually be better described as Co3+ in a low-spin state?

The Rb-Ti-O family exhibits a dramatic and systematic charge balance catastrophe: Rb3Ti8O17 (charge -7.0), Rb3Ti14O28 (charge -22.0), and RbTi6O12 (charge -10.0) all show large negative residuals, with the only charge-balanced member being RbTi8O13 (charge -1.0, computationally known) -- combined with methods_disagree oxi confidence and Ti BVS values of ~3.64 v.u. against expected Ti3+ (21.2% overbonding), does this pattern reveal that GNoME consistently predicts Ti-rich alkali titanate bronzes assuming Ti3+ when the actual structures require mixed Ti3+/Ti4+ occupancy, and is the -7.0 residual in Rb3Ti8O17 quantitatively consistent with 7 of the 8 Ti sites needing to be Ti4+?

Mn2BiO6 carries a residual charge of -4.0 despite passing Shannon radii and Pauling checks with zero violations across 24 bonds, and its family member Mn(BiO3)2 in P321 achieves charge neutrality with a GII of 0.581 — does the charge imbalance in this SG 162 polymorph indicate that the oxi_state_guesses method (single_method confidence) is assigning Mn and Bi oxidation states incompatible with the trigonal coordination environment, and could mixed Mn2+/Mn3+ or Bi3+/Bi5+ resolve the -4.0 residual?

EuV3O9 is a novel charge-neutral europium vanadate with both oxi methods agreeing, yet all three worst BVS deviations occur on vanadium sites (BVS 4.48-4.49 vs expected V5+, ~10% underbonded) — given that its family member Eu2VO5 fails charge neutrality at -4.0 with a higher GII of 0.454, could the 3:1 V:Eu ratio in this monoclinic SG 9 structure represent a more stable V-rich stoichiometry in the Eu-V-O system, where vanadium's slight underbonding is compensated by the formation energy of -2.57 eV/atom being among the lowest in this family?

Bi2Sb4O13 is computationally known and charge-neutral, yet across its 8 Bi-Sb-O family members, GII values range dramatically from 0.400 (Bi(SbO3)3, charge-neutral) to 0.904 (Bi7SbO16, charge -6.0), and only this compound and Bi(SbO3)3 achieve charge neutrality — with Sb5+ sites consistently overbonded at BVS 5.64-5.66, does the Bi:Sb ratio systematically control structural strain in this family, where Bi-rich compositions (Bi7SbO16, GII 0.904) produce far worse lattice mismatch than Sb-rich ones (Bi(SbO3)3, GII 0.400)?

Na(CoO2)6 shows a massive charge residual of -10.0 while maintaining zero Shannon radii and Pauling violations across 24 bonds, and its worst BVS deviations all fall on oxygen (BVS -1.52 vs expected -2, 24% underbonded) — the family member Na2Co3O7 achieves charge neutrality with GII 0.529, suggesting the extreme Na-deficiency in the 1:6 Na:CoO2 ratio forces an unrealistic Co oxidation state assignment; could this tetragonal SG 87 structure actually contain mixed Co3+/Co4+ rather than the single-method guess?

Rb(CoO2)20 has the largest charge residual (-19.0) in this batch yet achieves a remarkably low GII of 0.323, and its extensive Rb-Co-O family reveals a striking inverse correlation: compositions with higher alkali content (Rb4CoO3, Rb3CoO3) achieve charge neutrality but have much higher GII (0.647-0.701), while CoO2-rich compositions (Rb3(CoO2)16, GII 0.263; Rb(CoO2)8, GII 0.287) have lower strain but extreme charge failures — does this pattern suggest GNoME is predicting metastable layered cobaltate structures analogous to NaxCoO2 battery cathodes, where the single_method oxi assignment cannot capture the fractional Co oxidation states inherent to these intercalation compounds?

Mn16TlO32 has an enormous charge residual of -15.0 with single_method oxi confidence, while its oxygen BVS values (-1.58 vs expected -2, ~21% underbonded) suggest the Mn-O bond network is systematically stretched — given that experimentally known Mn-Tl-O compounds adopt SG 227 (Fd-3m, 100% of experimental hits) rather than GNoME's predicted SG 83 (P4/m), and the family member Mn6TlO12 also shows extreme charge failure (-10.0), could the tetragonal structure be an artifact of GNoME forcing a symmetry incompatible with the Mn4+/Tl3+ charge balance required for this composition?

Ti3NO3 is a novel oxynitride in cubic SG 221 (Pm-3m, perovskite-type) that achieves perfect charge neutrality with both oxi methods agreeing, but BVS reveals nitrogen is significantly overbonded (BVS -3.77 vs expected -3, 25.6% excess) while oxygen is underbonded (BVS -1.79, 10.4% deficit) — with only 7 sites and a very favorable formation energy of -2.915 eV/atom, does this suggest GNoME has discovered a stable perovskite-derivative oxynitride where N3- occupies a compressed anion site, and could the anion-site size mismatch between N3- (1.46 A) and O2- (1.40 A) in the cubic framework explain the opposing BVS deviations?

Rb2(CoO2)5 is flagged as mixed_valence with methods_disagree oxi confidence, and its charge residual of -3.0 contrasts sharply with the family member Rb(CoO2)20 (charge -19.0, GII 0.323) and Rb4CoO3 (charge 0.0, GII 0.647) — across the 8-member Rb-Co-O family, only Rb4CoO3 and Rb3CoO3 achieve charge neutrality but both have GII above 0.64, while this compound sits at the boundary with the lowest GII among charge-failing members (0.322); does the oxidation state disagreement at this specific Rb:Co ratio mark a phase boundary in the Rb-Co-O system where Co transitions between distinct valence regimes?

La5(MoO6)2 is novel with a near-zero charge residual (-1.0) and its worst BVS deviation falls on La (BVS 2.28 vs expected 3+, 24% underbonded), while its family member La2Mo5O18 in Pbcn achieves exact charge neutrality with an exceptionally low GII of 0.108 — given the very favorable formation energy of -3.318 eV/atom (deepest in this batch) and the dramatic GII improvement in the Mo-rich stoichiometry (0.108 vs 0.321), could the La5(MoO6)2 composition represent a thermodynamically accessible but structurally strained intermediate in the La-Mo-O phase diagram, where La3+ is systematically under-coordinated in the monoclinic SG 12 framework?

Na2Np2O7 is computationally known and charge-neutral with a space group score of 0.333 (SG 12 matches 33% of experimental hits), yet it shows a complete Pauling Rule 2 violation (score 1.0, all 14 bonds checked fail electrostatic valence balance) alongside a moderate GII of 0.321 — the worst BVS deviations fall entirely on Na+ sites (BVS 0.63-0.69 vs expected 1, 31-37% underbonded), suggesting sodium is drastically under-coordinated; does this tier-conflict pattern (charge-neutral but total Pauling failure with severely underbonded Na) indicate that the predicted structure places Na in cavities too large for its ionic radius in this neptunium pyrophosphate-type framework?

Ca4Sb2O9 is novel and passes every Tier 1 check — charge neutrality, Shannon radii, zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds — with both oxi methods agreeing on Ca2+/Sb5+, and achieves a GII of 0.321 with Sb uniformly underbonded at BVS 4.44 (11.2% below Sb5+); given its family member Ca4Sb6O13 achieves similar quality (GII 0.367, charge-neutral) in a different stoichiometry, could this trigonal SG 165 (P-3c1) structure represent a genuinely synthesizable new calcium antimonate, where the consistent Sb underbonding across the family reflects Sb5+ preferring asymmetric lone-pair-free coordination in these Ca-dominated frameworks?

Li4Pt5O12 is novel and charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations across 24 bonds, but its worst BVS deviations reveal severely underbonded Li+ (BVS 0.63-0.66 vs expected 1, 34-37% deficit) — strikingly, the Li-Pt-O family shows a clear GII trend: Li-rich compositions (Li6PtO6, GII 0.138; Li4PtO5, GII 0.171; LiPt3O8, GII 0.149) achieve much lower strain than Pt-rich ones (Li(Pt3O4)4, GII 0.414; Li3(Pt3O4)4, GII 0.527), and this compound at Li:Pt = 4:5 sits at the crossover; does the Li underbonding indicate that the monoclinic SG 15 structure cannot accommodate Li+ in the interstitial sites of the Pt-O framework as effectively as the simpler stoichiometries?

Ce2(SO4)3 is classified as an oxychalcogenide despite being a well-known cerium sulfate with S6+ (not S2-), and its BVS shows S overbonded at 6.55-6.77 (9-13% above expected S6+) — the Pauling Rule 2 check carries a warning flag for non-pure-oxide applicability, yet all 24 bonds pass; given that the family member Ce(S8O)3 shows an extreme GII of 1.46 suggesting a fundamentally different sulfur bonding environment, does the compound class misclassification as 'oxychalcogenide' systematically affect validator applicability for sulfate-containing compounds where S is in its highest oxidation state and behaves as a cation, not a chalcogenide anion?

La3OsO8 is a novel lanthanum osmate with a space group score of 0.333 (SG 63, Cmcm, matches 33% of experimental data) and passes all Tier 1 checks, but La shows BVS of 2.31 (23.1% underbonded from La3+) at two equivalent sites while a third La site is near-ideal at 2.89 — compared to its family members where Pr3Os2O9 (GII 0.599) and Pr3OsO8 (GII 0.579) in the same structural family show significantly higher strain, does the orthorhombic Cmcm framework uniquely accommodate the La3+-Os combination with lower distortion, and could the two distinct La environments (one well-bonded, one strained) indicate an incipient ordering motif?

Sm2Sb4O13 is novel and structurally analogous to the computationally known Bi2Sb4O13 (same SG 11, same formula pattern, nearly identical GII of 0.320 vs 0.324), both showing Sb5+ overbonded at BVS 5.64-5.71 — yet the sole Sm-Sb-O family member SmSb11O26 has a dramatically higher GII of 1.018 and charge failure of -5.0; does the Ln2Sb4O13 stoichiometry (where Ln = Bi, Sm) represent a stability island in the lanthanide-antimonate phase space, and does the GII collapse from 1.018 to 0.320 when moving from 1:11 to 2:4 Ln:Sb ratio reveal a critical composition threshold for structural viability?

Tb3Ti4O12 has mixed_valence with methods_disagree oxi confidence, a large charge residual of -12.0, and 16.7% Pauling violations across 48 bonds — yet its space group score of 0.50 (SG 62, Pnma, matching 50% of experimental data) is the highest in this batch, suggesting GNoME got the symmetry right even if the electronic structure is problematic; with Tb showing BVS of 2.38 (20.7% below Tb3+) at all three worst sites and 76 sites in the unit cell, does the oxidation state disagreement indicate that Tb might adopt a mixed Tb3+/Tb4+ state or Ti a mixed Ti3+/Ti4+ state in this large orthorhombic cell, which neither oxi method can resolve?

Er2OF4 is a novel oxyhalide with an exceptionally large bandgap of 6.33 eV, perfect charge neutrality with both oxi methods agreeing, and a low GII of 0.320 — the Er3+ sites show uniform underbonding at BVS 2.50 (16.8% below expected), and the Pauling check warns about non-pure-oxide applicability with only 2 bonds checked; given the very favorable formation energy of -4.410 eV/atom (the most negative in this entire batch) and the wide-bandgap insulating character, could this monoclinic SG 15 structure represent a promising scintillator or optical material candidate, where the Er3+ underbonding creates suitable crystal-field environments for 4f luminescence?

Nb3Bi7O18 is novel with perfect charge neutrality and both oxi methods agreeing, but BVS reveals two distinct distortion mechanisms: Bi3+ is significantly underbonded (BVS 2.32-2.36, 21-23% deficit suggesting lone-pair-driven asymmetry) while Nb5+ is moderately underbonded (BVS 4.44, 11.2% deficit) — with family members showing that Nb2Bi4O11 (GII 0.326, charge-neutral) achieves similar quality to this compound while Nb(BiO2)7 (GII 0.591, charge -2.0) is significantly worse, does the Nb:Bi ratio near 1:2 represent an optimal composition for accommodating both Bi3+ lone-pair stereochemistry and Nb5+ octahedral coordination in this triclinic P1 framework?

Bi3MoO7 is novel and charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing, but shows 28.6% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 14 bonds — the highest Pauling violation rate among charge-neutral compounds in this batch — while both Mo (BVS 4.35-4.37 vs Mo5+, 13% underbonded) and Bi (BVS 2.54 vs Bi3+, 15% underbonded) are simultaneously underbonded; given that the family member Bi2Mo4O15 achieves near-ideal bonding (GII 0.167, charge-neutral) in a Mo-rich stoichiometry, does the 3:1 Bi:Mo ratio in this triclinic structure create electrostatic frustration from the high Bi3+ lone-pair density that disrupts Pauling's second rule at nearly one-third of coordination polyhedra?

K6UO6 is a novel potassium uranate that passes all Tier 1 checks with charge neutrality, zero Shannon and Pauling violations, and a moderate GII of 0.319 — uranium shows BVS 5.49 vs expected U6+ (8.5% underbonded) while oxygen is underbonded at BVS -1.66 (16.8% deficit); the family member K3UO4 is computationally known with a lower GII of 0.314, suggesting the K:U = 6:1 ratio is near the stability optimum for this system; could this trigonal SG 148 (R-3) structure represent a high-alkali-content uranate phase relevant to nuclear waste immobilization, where the extensive K+ coordination shell effectively encapsulates the UO6 octahedra?

Cs(SnO2)6 shows a charge residual of -10.0 with methods_disagree oxi confidence and mixed_valence flag, yet achieves zero Shannon radii and Pauling violations across 24 bonds — the worst BVS deviations fall on Sn at BVS 3.43-3.44 vs expected Sn3+, showing 14-15% overbonding; given that Sn commonly exists as Sn2+ or Sn4+ but rarely Sn3+, and the bandgap is near-zero (0.066 eV suggesting metallic/semimetallic character), could the oxi method disagreement reflect the fundamental difficulty of assigning integer oxidation states to a material where Sn occupies a fractional average valence between Sn2+ and Sn4+ in this layered Cs-intercalated tin oxide structure?

La5U2O12 is computationally known with mixed_valence and both methods agreeing, but the two U sites show dramatically different BVS values (4.70 vs 3.46 against expected U4+, representing +17.6% overbonding and -13.4% underbonding respectively) — across the extensive 6-member La-U-O family, all compositions show remarkably consistent GII values (0.217-0.265) and persistent small charge residuals (-1.0 to -3.0), but none achieve exact charge neutrality; does this systematic near-miss pattern across multiple stoichiometries and space groups indicate a fundamental limitation in the BVS parameterization for actinide-lanthanide mixed oxides, where U4+/U5+ redox flexibility is not captured by fixed reference parameters?

Rb3AsO3 is computationally known and charge-neutral in cubic SG 198 (P2_13), yet its Rb+ sites are the most severely underbonded in this entire batch at BVS 0.564 (43.6% below expected Rb+), far worse than typical alkali underbonding — while experimentally this composition appears exclusively in SG 57 (Pbcm, orthorhombic), the family member Rb5As3O10 achieves dramatically better bonding with GII 0.190; does the extreme Rb underbonding at 43.6% indicate that the cubic P2_13 framework creates Rb cavities far too large for the ion, and that this GNoME prediction may represent a mechanically unstable phase that would spontaneously distort toward the experimentally observed orthorhombic symmetry?

Pr(OsO3)3 is a novel praseodymium osmate with charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds, while Pr3+ shows only moderate underbonding (BVS 2.68, 10.6% deficit) — notably, all three Pr-Os-O family members (Pr3Os2O9, Pr2OsO5, Pr3OsO8) have significantly higher GII values (0.526-0.599) than this compound (0.318), and the Os-rich 1:3 stoichiometry uniquely achieves this low strain; given the single_method oxi confidence assigning Os6+, does the OsO3 polyhedral framework provide a more rigid and self-consistent bonding network than the Os-poor compositions, suggesting that osmium-rich stoichiometries are structurally preferred in the Ln-Os-O system?

LiIr3O8 is computationally known and passes all Tier 1 checks with both oxi methods agreeing on Li+/Ir5+, achieving a moderate GII of 0.318 with Ir5+ uniformly overbonded at BVS 5.48-5.56 (9.5-11.3% excess) — the family member LiIr5O12 shows dramatically worse performance (GII 0.728, charge -3.0), while Li5IrO6 has null GII, suggesting the Li:Ir = 1:3 ratio in monoclinic SG 14 (P2_1/c) is near the optimal composition for balancing Li+ intercalation and IrO6 octahedral stability; could this structure be relevant to iridium-based battery cathode or electrocatalyst design, where the moderate Ir overbonding indicates compressed IrO6 octahedra favorable for oxygen evolution catalysis?

EuBiO4 in P2_1/c (SG 14) passes all Tier 1 checks perfectly yet its Eu sites show systematic BVS underbonding at 2.385 v.u. vs expected 3+ (dev 0.205). The Eu-Bi-O family reveals a pattern: the computationally known Eu3BiO7 (Cmcm) has GII 0.511, while the novel Eu(BiO2)7 in P1 has GII 0.824 and a -4.0 charge imbalance. Could Eu's proximity to the Eu2+/Eu3+ redox boundary mean GNoME is predicting a structure where Eu is partially reduced, and that the BVS underbonding reflects genuine mixed-valence character rather than geometric strain?

Co3Mo2O9 is novel with both oxi methods agreeing, yet its BVS reveals Co sites at 1.473-1.492 v.u. against expected 2+ (dev 0.254-0.263), and oxygen sites underbonded at -1.52 v.u. vs expected -2 (dev 0.24). The 11.1% Pauling Rule 2 violation across 18 bonds and triclinic P-1 symmetry are consistent with genuine geometric frustration. Given that Co2+ in octahedral coordination is Jahn-Teller inactive but highly sensitive to coordination geometry, does this systematic underbonding of both cation and anion sublattices indicate that GNoME is predicting a metastable polymorph with expanded bond lengths?

Sr(CoO2)2 is computationally known in Pmmn (SG 59) and passes every Tier 1 check, but its Co sites uniformly show BVS of 2.567 v.u. vs expected 3+ (dev 0.144). Strikingly, the Sr-Co-O family spans 7 compositions with GII ranging from 0.289 (SrCo2O6, charge -2) to 0.640 (Sr6Co5O16, charge neutral). Only Sr(CoO2)2 and Sr6Co5O16 achieve charge neutrality. Does the monotonic increase in GII with Co-enrichment across this family suggest a thermodynamic stability window specific to the 1:2 Sr:Co ratio, where the cobaltate layered structure optimizes both electrostatic balance and bond strain?

Ba6Nb5O18 presents a cascade of red flags: both oxi methods disagree, mixed valence is flagged, charge neutrality fails at -4.0, and 100% of 18 Pauling Rule 2 bonds are violated (score 1.0) -- the maximum possible. Yet Shannon radii pass perfectly and BVS is moderate at GII 0.316 with Ba underbonded at 1.429 v.u. (dev 0.286) while Nb is slightly overbonded at 4.447 v.u. (dev 0.112). The family shows all members also carry charge imbalances (-2 to -4). Is the complete Pauling Rule 2 failure evidence that the assigned Nb oxidation states are incorrect, or does the trigonal R-3m structure genuinely accommodate extreme electrostatic bond strength deviations?

Pr2CO5 is novel in Cmcm (SG 63, just one number off from the 100% experimental SG 62) with a large bandgap of 3.91 eV and strong formation energy of -3.17 eV/atom. It passes charge neutrality and Shannon radii perfectly, but 40% of its 10 Pauling Rule 2 bonds are violated. Its family member Pr2(CO3)3 in P6_3/m achieves a remarkably low GII of 0.107 with perfect charge neutrality. Given that Pr2CO5 can be rewritten as a carbonate-deficient composition relative to Pr2(CO3)3, could the high Pauling violation rate indicate that the C-O bonding environment in this prediction deviates from the expected trigonal planar carbonate geometry?

Y(SbO3)3 is computationally known with perfect Tier 1 scores (charge neutral, Shannon pass, zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds), but Sb sites are overbonded at 5.738 v.u. vs expected 5+ (dev 0.148) and one O site is overbonded at -2.395 v.u. (dev 0.198). Its family member YSb5O13 in P2_1/m has dramatically worse GII of 0.951 and a -6.0 charge failure. Given that Sb5+ is a lone-pair-inactive cation with well-defined octahedral preferences, does the consistent Sb overbonding across the Y-Sb-O system reflect a systematic bias in the BVS reference parameters for Sb-O bonds, or is GNoME compressing Sb-O distances beyond equilibrium?

RbMn14O28 has 86 sites -- one of the largest unit cells in the dataset -- and presents an extreme charge imbalance of -26.0 with methods_disagree oxi confidence and mixed valence. Yet it passes Shannon radii and has zero Pauling Rule 2 violations across 50 checked bonds, while oxygen sites are systematically underbonded at -1.584 to -1.588 v.u. (dev ~0.208). The Rb-Mn-O family shows that even the computationally known RbMn8O16 (hollandite-type) carries a -7.0 charge imbalance. Is the massive -26 charge residual an artifact of forcing Mn into a single oxidation state when this Mn-rich tunnel structure likely requires Mn3+/Mn4+ mixed valence to achieve neutrality?

Ba2OsO5 is novel in Pnma (SG 62), matching one of its three experimental space groups (33% match), with charge neutrality passing perfectly despite only single_method oxi confidence. The Ba-Os-O family is remarkably rich (8 members) with GII spanning from an exceptional 0.045 (Ba2(OsO3)3, I23) to 0.745 (Ba3OsO7). The charge-neutral members Ba4Os6O19 (GII 0.113) and Ba3(OsO5)2 (GII 0.244) bracket Ba2OsO5 in Ba:Os ratio. Does the parabolic GII-vs-composition trend in this family suggest that Os6+ accommodates a specific optimal coordination environment, and that Ba2OsO5 sits near but not at the structural optimum?

LiOs3O8 is computationally known in P2_1/c (SG 14) with only single_method oxi confidence, and its Li sites show the most severe underbonding in this batch: BVS 0.686 v.u. vs expected 1+ (dev 0.314). The Li-Os-O family is extensive (7 members) and reveals a clear trend: as the Li:Os ratio increases from 1:5 to 6:1, GII decreases from 0.307 to 0.142 (Li6OsO6), suggesting Li-rich compositions better satisfy bond valence requirements. Why does Li show such extreme underbonding in Os-rich structures -- is it because Li occupies oversized cavities in the osmium oxide framework, and could this indicate Li-ion mobility relevant to battery applications?

K(CoO2)3 is novel with mixed valence and methods_disagree oxi confidence, failing charge neutrality at -4.0, yet passing Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 perfectly (0/12 violations). All three worst BVS sites are oxygen at -1.568 to -1.569 v.u. (dev 0.216), showing extreme systematic O underbonding. The K-Co-O family shows an intriguing pattern: K-rich members (K12Co2O9, K4CoO4) achieve charge neutrality but have high GII (0.669-0.699), while Co-rich members (K(CoO2)6, K(CoO2)8) have lower GII (0.275-0.290) but massive charge failures (-7 to -10). Is there no stable stoichiometry in the K-Co-O system that simultaneously satisfies both charge neutrality and low geometric strain?

PrSbO is computationally known with a minimal 6-site unit cell and both oxi methods agreeing, yet it shows a complete Pauling Rule 2 failure: 100% of its 2 checked bonds are violated (score 1.0). With only 2 bonds checked out of a 6-site structure, the coordination environment appears unusually sparse. The Pr BVS of 2.556 v.u. (dev 0.148 from expected 3+) and O at -1.755 v.u. (dev 0.122) suggest moderate but not extreme underbonding. Given that PrSbO has the Sb3- pnictide assignment rather than Sb5+ oxide, could the complete Pauling failure indicate that CrystalNN is misidentifying the bonding topology in this anti-fluorite-type structure?

K3UO4 is computationally known with perfect Tier 1 checks (charge neutral, Shannon pass, zero Pauling violations across 8 bonds), but K sites show severe underbonding at 0.584 v.u. vs expected 1+ (dev 0.416) -- the second-highest cation deviation in this batch. Meanwhile U at 4.584 v.u. vs expected 5+ (dev 0.083) is nearly ideal. The K-U-O family shows that the novel KU3O9 has GII 0.498 with charge failure, while K6UO6 achieves neutrality with GII 0.319. Does the extreme K underbonding in K3UO4 reflect the well-known tendency of large alkali cations to rattle in oversized oxide cavities, and could this predict high K-ion conductivity in this phase?

Ti8NO12 is classified as an oxynitride -- one of the ~18% non-pure-oxide materials -- and presents a trifecta of concerns: methods_disagree oxi confidence, mixed valence, and a -3.0 charge failure. The nitrogen site shows dramatic overbonding at -3.923 v.u. vs expected -3 (dev 0.308), while Ti sites are overbonded at 3.576 v.u. vs expected 3+ (dev 0.192). The Pauling validator flagged a compound class warning. Given that BVS reference parameters are calibrated primarily for oxide systems, does the N overbonding at 0.308 deviation represent a genuine structural anomaly, or is it an artifact of applying O2--calibrated BVS parameters to a nitrogen coordination environment?

Cs4Os2O9 is novel in P6_3/mmc (SG 194), with charge neutrality passing but 66.7% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 18 bonds. All three worst BVS sites are Cs at 0.582 v.u. vs expected 1+ (dev 0.418) -- the most extreme alkali underbonding in this batch. The Cs-Os-O family spans 6 compositions, with the P6/mmm members Cs(OsO3)3 (GII 0.078) and Cs5(OsO3)18 (GII 0.046) achieving remarkably low strain despite charge failures. Does the hexagonal symmetry preference and extreme Cs underbonding suggest that Cs is serving primarily as a space-filling template rather than a bonding participant, analogous to Cs in hexagonal tungsten bronzes?

Ta4Sn3O13 is computationally known in R3m (SG 160) with both oxi methods agreeing, passing charge neutrality and Shannon radii, but showing 23.1% Pauling violations across 13 bonds. All three worst BVS sites are Sn at 1.385 v.u. vs expected 2+ (dev 0.307), indicating severe and uniform Sn2+ underbonding. Sn2+ is a stereochemically active lone-pair cation whose asymmetric coordination often causes BVS anomalies. Is the 30.7% BVS deviation for Sn2+ within the expected range for lone-pair distorted environments, or does it suggest that GNoME has placed Sn in sites that are too large for this cation?

BaPa4O11 is novel in P6_322 (SG 182) with only single_method oxi confidence, yet passes charge neutrality, Shannon radii, and Pauling Rule 2 perfectly across 22 bonds -- an unusually clean validation profile for a novel actinide compound. Its formation energy of -4.058 eV/atom is among the most negative in this batch, suggesting strong thermodynamic driving force. The sole family member Ba6PaO8 (Fm-3m) has a dramatically higher GII of 0.745. Given that protactinium chemistry is among the least explored of the actinides, could BaPa4O11's excellent validation scores combined with deep formation energy make it a high-priority candidate for experimental synthesis verification?

Sn2As2O9 is computationally known with perfect oxi confidence (both_agree), charge neutral, Shannon pass, and only 11.1% Pauling violations -- yet all three worst BVS sites are As at 5.57-5.576 v.u. vs expected 5+ (dev 0.114-0.115), showing consistent moderate overbonding. Its family member Sn5(AsO4)6 in R-3 has a much higher GII of 0.621 and -3.0 charge failure. Given that both Y(SbO3)3 and NbSb3O10 in this batch also show group-15 pnictogen overbonding (Sb at dev 0.148 and 0.112 respectively), is there a systematic positive bias in BVS reference parameters for heavy pnictogens in high oxidation states?

Sr(CoO2)6 is novel in C2/m (SG 12) with mixed valence flagged and a massive -8.0 charge failure, despite both oxi methods agreeing. Sr shows severe underbonding at 1.353 v.u. (dev 0.324) and O at -1.497 v.u. (dev 0.252). Critically, this material shares its family with the computationally known Sr(CoO2)2 (GII 0.316, charge neutral) in this same batch. Across the Sr-Co-O family, GII ranges from 0.289 to 0.640, but the charge-neutral members cluster at moderate GII (0.316-0.640) while charge-failing members span 0.289-0.525. Does the combination of agreed-upon oxi states yet -8.0 charge failure indicate that the assigned Co3+ is incorrect and Co should be in a lower average oxidation state in this Co-rich layered structure?

Cs3OsO5 is computationally known in Cmcm (SG 63) with single_method oxi confidence, achieving charge neutrality but with 40% Pauling Rule 2 violations and Cs underbonded at 0.658 v.u. (dev 0.342). It shares its Cs-Os-O family with Cs4Os2O9 (also in this batch), and both show extreme Cs underbonding. Yet the family includes Cs(OsO3)3 and Cs5(OsO3)18 with extraordinarily low GII values of 0.078 and 0.046 in P6/mmm symmetry. Does the dramatic GII improvement in the hexagonal OsO3-rich compositions indicate that Os in octahedral OsO6 coordination achieves near-ideal bond valence, and that the structural strain in Cs3OsO5 arises specifically from forcing Os into tetrahedral-like OsO5 coordination?

RbTi6O12 is novel in P-1 (SG 2) with methods_disagree oxi confidence, mixed valence, and a severe -10.0 charge failure. All three worst BVS sites are Ti, but overbonded at 3.439-3.472 v.u. vs expected 3+ (dev 0.146-0.157) -- this is unusual because the charge failure suggests electrons are missing, yet Ti appears overbonded rather than underbonded. The Rb-Ti-O family shows all members carry large charge failures (-1 to -22). Given that Ti commonly adopts both 3+ and 4+ oxidation states, could the simultaneous overbonding and charge failure indicate that some Ti sites should be assigned as Ti4+ rather than uniformly Ti3+, which would simultaneously resolve the charge imbalance and reduce the BVS deviation?

Sm(OsO3)3 is computationally known in P2_1/m (SG 11) with single_method oxi confidence but a remarkably clean validation profile: charge neutral, Shannon pass, zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds, and moderate BVS with Sm at 2.691 v.u. vs expected 3+ (dev 0.103). The Sm-Os-O family members Sm2OsO5 (GII 0.436) and Sm3Os2O9 (GII 0.498) both have higher GII values. Given that the OsO3-stoichiometry appears repeatedly across this batch's Os-containing materials (Cs(OsO3)3 at GII 0.078, Li3(OsO3)4 at GII 0.081) with consistently excellent GII scores, does the OsO3 building unit represent a particularly well-optimized structural motif for Os6+ coordination in oxide frameworks?

Na(Pt3O4)4 is novel in Fm-3m (SG 202) with a -7.0 charge failure and single_method oxi confidence, yet passes Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 perfectly. Only one site appears in the BVS worst list: Na at 1.309 v.u. vs expected 1+ (dev 0.309), meaning Na is significantly overbonded -- the opposite of the systematic alkali underbonding seen in K3UO4 and Cs4Os2O9 in this batch. The Na-Pt-O family is extensive (8 members) with most charge-neutral members showing low GII (0.102-0.171), but Na(Pt3O4)4's extreme Pt-rich stoichiometry is unique. Does Na overbonding in a Pt-rich cubic framework suggest the Na site is compressed by the rigid PtO4 network, potentially trapping Na ions rather than enabling mobility?

Bi2Pb2O7 is computationally known in P-1 (SG 2) with both oxi methods agreeing, but it is the only material in this batch with a non-zero Shannon radii violation score (0.0385), indicating 3.85% of ion pairs fall outside expected radii bounds. Bi sites show underbonding at 2.338-2.483 v.u. vs expected 3+ (dev 0.172-0.221). Both Bi3+ and Pb4+ are lone-pair cations whose stereochemical activity creates asymmetric coordination environments. Given that the experimental SG for this composition is I23 (SG 197, cubic) while GNoME predicts P-1 (triclinic), does the symmetry reduction from cubic to triclinic reflect GNoME capturing lone-pair-driven distortions that conventional structure prediction might symmetrize away?

NbSb3O10 is novel in P1 (SG 1) -- the lowest possible symmetry -- with only 14 sites, a 2.62 eV bandgap, and perfect Tier 1 checks: charge neutral, Shannon pass, zero Pauling violations across 10 bonds. The BVS shows Sb sites consistently overbonded at 5.403-5.560 v.u. vs expected 5+ (dev 0.081-0.112), matching the systematic group-15 overbonding trend observed for Y(SbO3)3 and Sn2As2O9 in this batch. With no family members and P1 symmetry, could this material represent a genuinely new structural prototype where the Nb5+-Sb5+ cation combination, with similar ionic radii but different d-electron configurations, stabilizes a low-symmetry framework inaccessible to either cation alone?

LiOs5O12 is computationally known in Cmmm (SG 65) with a -3.0 charge failure and single_method oxi confidence. Its sole BVS worst site is Li at 0.686 v.u. (dev 0.307), nearly identical to the 0.686 v.u. seen in its family sibling LiOs3O8 (also in this batch). The Li-Os-O family shows a striking monotonic GII trend: Li6OsO6 (0.142) < Li4OsO6 (0.150) < Li4OsO5 (0.177) < Li2OsO4 (0.204) < LiOs3O8 (0.314), with GII increasing as the Li:Os ratio decreases. Is the identical Li BVS of 0.686 across two different structures (P2_1/c and Cmmm) evidence that Li systematically occupies a specific cavity size in osmium oxide frameworks regardless of the overall crystal symmetry?

Fe3(SeO3)4 is an oxychalcogenide with mixed valence iron and a charge residual of -4.0, yet all Fe sites show BVS of 2.497 against an expected 2+, yielding identical 0.248 deviations -- why does the GNoME structure assign uniformly equivalent Fe environments instead of differentiating Fe2+/Fe3+ sites as mixed-valence selenites typically require, and does this structural homogeneity explain the charge imbalance?

Sr5Pu5O19 adopts triclinic P1 (SG 1) despite 100% of experimental Sr-Pu oxides crystallizing in rhombohedral R-3m (SG 166), and its charge residual of -3.0 with systematically underbonded Sr sites (BVS 1.615-1.728 vs. expected 2.0) contrasts sharply with the family member Sr5Pu5O18 (P-1, GII 0.395, charge -1.0) that differs by exactly one oxygen -- could the extra oxygen in the O19 stoichiometry be a DFT artifact producing an overstuffed unit cell that forces the symmetry collapse from rhombohedral to triclinic?

DyV3O9 passes all Tier 1 checks (charge neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across 18 bonds) yet every V5+ site is systematically underbonded at BVS ~4.47-4.49 (10.2-10.6% deviation) -- given that isostructural HoV3O9 (GII 0.304) and GdV3O9 (GII 0.302) in this batch show nearly identical V underbonding patterns, does the RE3+V5+3O9 family in SG 9 (Cc) represent a genuinely stable structural motif where vanadium consistently adopts elongated VO4 tetrahedra, or is GNoME systematically reproducing the same bonding error across all lanthanide analogues?

Pr2Se5O13 is one of the few materials matching its expected space group (P2_1/c, SG 14, 50% experimental prevalence, score 0.5) and shows 16% Pauling violations across 50 bonds with Se sites uniformly underbonded at BVS 3.399 (15% deviation from Se4+) -- compared to family member Pr2(SeO4)3 which is computationally known with an excellent GII of 0.10, does the higher Se:O ratio in Se5O13 force selenium into distorted coordination environments that explain the systematic BVS deficit, and could the Se4+ assignment itself be wrong given the oxychalcogenide classification?

MnS2O7 is computationally known and charge-neutral with S6+ showing BVS of 6.55-6.59 (only 9.2-9.9% overbonded), yet it carries an oxychalcogenide warning despite sulfur clearly being in the sulfate-like S6+ state rather than a reduced chalcogenide -- should the compound class algorithm distinguish sulfates (S6+, fully oxidized) from true oxychalcogenides (S2-) since the warning inappropriately flags a material whose validators are actually well-calibrated for the O2- assumption?

Co3Br4O adopts cubic SG 198 (P2_13) while 100% of experimental Co-Br-O compounds crystallize in orthorhombic SG 61 (Pbca), and all three symmetry-equivalent oxygen sites show identical severe underbonding at BVS -1.471 (26.5% deviation from O2-) -- with only 4 Pauling bonds checked and a single-oxygen stoichiometry placing O in an unusual tetrahedral Co3O cluster geometry, does this cubic structure represent a physically implausible oxygen coordination that GNoME's graph neural network has no experimental precedent to validate?

Pr(CoO2)3 passes every Tier 1 check perfectly (charge neutral, zero Shannon and Pauling violations across all 12 bonds) with Pr3+ underbonded at BVS 2.573 (14.2% dev) and Co3+ at 2.642 (11.9% dev), yet the computationally known family member Pr(CoO2)8 in P1 carries a charge of -5.0 -- does the CoO2 layered delafossite-type motif become charge-balanced only at the 1:3 Pr:Co ratio, and would experimental synthesis of this monoclinic C2/m phase confirm GNoME's prediction of a new praseodymium cobaltate polymorph?

CsMn8O16 shows the largest charge residual in this batch (-7.0) with oxi methods disagreeing, mixed valence Mn, and Cs overbonded at BVS 1.403 (40.3% above Cs+), while its family member CsMn3O6 also fails charge neutrality at -8.0 -- given that the hollandite structure alpha-MnO2 is well-known to accommodate tunnel cations like K+ and Rb+, is GNoME predicting a Cs-stuffed hollandite variant where the methods_disagree confidence reflects genuine ambiguity in Mn3+/Mn4+ mixed valence ratios rather than a structural error?

HfV5O14 has mixed valence vanadium with both methods agreeing on oxi states, yet carries a charge residual of -4.0 and shows V4+ sites overbonded at BVS 4.60 (15% deviation) alongside V4+ sites underbonded at BVS 3.503 (12.4% deviation) -- with the expected space group being Pa-3 (SG 205, 100%) versus the predicted monoclinic SG 10, does the dramatic symmetry reduction from cubic to monoclinic reflect GNoME struggling to accommodate the V4+/V5+ charge ordering that Hf-V oxides require?

Li5NpO6 is charge-neutral with zero Shannon and Pauling violations, but all three worst-deviating sites are Li+ severely underbonded at BVS 0.683-0.698 (30.2-31.7% deviation), far exceeding the ICSD baseline GII of 0.2 v.u. -- the family shows a clear trend where Li6NpO6 (GII 0.152) and Li3NpO5 (GII 0.256) are structurally sound, suggesting Li5NpO6 occupies an unstable intermediate stoichiometry where lithium sites are too large for the available coordination, making this a candidate for decomposition into Li6NpO6 + Li3NpO5 phases?

HoV3O9 shows V5+ underbonding at BVS 4.474-4.480 (10.4-10.5% deviation) virtually identical to DyV3O9 (4.472-4.490) and GdV3O9 (4.477-4.480) in this same batch, all in SG 9 (Cc) with 26 sites and formation energies within 0.02 eV/atom (-2.70 to -2.73) -- does this remarkably consistent V underbonding across the lanthanide series indicate that GNoME has learned a single template structure and applied it uniformly, and would the monotonic lanthanide contraction (Gd > Dy > Ho) predict systematically decreasing GII values as observed (0.302 > 0.306 > 0.304)?

VSe3O8 matches its most common experimental space group (P2_1/c, SG 14, 57% prevalence) giving a space group score of 0.57, the highest in this batch, yet shows 25% Pauling rule 2 violations across 32 bonds with all Se4+ sites identically underbonded at BVS 3.515 (12.1% dev) -- since the oxychalcogenide warning flags potential issues with the O2- assumption, could the Pauling violations specifically arise from Se-O bonds being evaluated with pure-oxide BVS parameters when selenite Se4+-O bonding has systematically different bond-valence parameters?

Re6Pb4O19 is charge-neutral and passes Shannon radii checks, but all four Pb2+ sites are identically and severely underbonded at BVS 1.341 (32.9% deviation), the most extreme Pb underbonding in this batch -- with experimental Re-Pb oxides split between trigonal SG 157 and SG 166 (50/50) while GNoME predicts cubic I23 (SG 197), does the high symmetry cubic structure force Pb into oversized cavities that cannot provide adequate bonding, and is this the signature of a lone-pair-active Pb2+ ion being placed in a centrosymmetric site that suppresses its stereochemical activity?

Pr2S4O15 is computationally known, charge-neutral, and shows S6+ slightly overbonded at BVS 6.57-6.69 (9.6-11.4% dev), yet its sole family member Pr(S8O)3 has a catastrophic GII of 1.426 and charge of -2.0 -- given that both carry oxychalcogenide warnings despite sulfur being in the fully oxidized S6+ sulfate state, does the compound class detection need a refinement to check actual oxidation states rather than just elemental composition, since sulfate-containing compounds should be validated identically to pure oxides?

K3OsO4 is computationally known with charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations, but K+ sites are severely underbonded (BVS 0.663, 33.7% dev) -- remarkably, the K-Os-O family spans 7 members with GII ranging from 0.011 (KOs5O13) to 0.596 (K(OsO3)6), where the K-poor phases are structurally superior, suggesting that high alkali content creates oversized cavities around K+ that degrade structural quality -- does this systematic trend indicate that Os-rich stoichiometries provide the rigid [OsO6] octahedral framework needed to constrain alkali coordination?

Ba7Nb6O21 is the only material in this batch with a perfect 1.0 Pauling rule 2 violation score (all 21 bonds violate electrostatic valence balance), combined with a charge residual of -4.0 and oxi methods disagreeing on the mixed-valence Nb -- with family members Ba6Nb7O21 (GII 0.22) and Ba4Nb5O15 (GII 0.191) showing much better structural quality at different Ba:Nb ratios, does the 7:6 stoichiometry represent an impossible composition where no assignment of Nb4+/Nb5+ can simultaneously satisfy charge neutrality and local electrostatic balance?

GdV3O9 completes a trio with DyV3O9 and HoV3O9 in this batch, all sharing SG 9 (Cc), 26 sites, zero Pauling violations, and V5+ BVS values of 4.477-4.480, yet GdV3O9 has the lowest GII (0.302) consistent with Gd3+ being the largest of the three RE ions (Gd > Dy > Ho) and potentially providing the best size match for the vanadate cage -- does this suggest a minimum-strain RE3+ radius exists for this structure type, and would La or Nd analogues show even lower GII values?

Cs3Os2O9 carries a charge residual of -2.0 with 77.8% Pauling violations (14 of 18 bonds) and all Cs+ sites severely underbonded at BVS 0.629-0.637 (36.3-37.1% dev), yet family members Cs3OsO5 (GII 0.31, charge 0.0) and Cs(OsO3)3 (GII 0.078, charge -4.0) show that Cs-Os oxides can achieve good structural quality -- with only single_method oxi confidence, could the Os oxidation state assignment be incorrect (Os7+ assumed when Os6+ fits), and would correcting it resolve both the charge imbalance and the Pauling violations simultaneously?

Ho2OF4 is an oxyhalide with a remarkably high formation energy magnitude (-4.404 eV/atom, most negative in this batch) and wide bandgap (6.35 eV), passing all Tier 1 checks with Ho3+ uniformly underbonded at BVS 2.527 (15.8% dev) -- given that the expected structure is rhombohedral R-3m (SG 166, 100%) while GNoME predicts monoclinic C2/c (SG 15), and Tb2OF4 in this same batch shows an almost identical pattern (BVS 2.530, same SG 15, formation energy -4.392), are these isostructural RE2OF4 oxyhalides a systematic GNoME prediction of a monoclinic polymorph that might be a metastable distortion of the known rhombohedral phase?

Tb6TaO12 has a charge residual of -1.0 with only single_method oxi confidence, and Ta5+ shows BVS of 4.498 (10.0% dev) while oxygen sites are underbonded at BVS -1.653 (17.3% dev) -- the predicted trigonal R-3 (SG 148) differs from both experimental options (SG 13 and SG 15, each 50%), and with a near-zero bandgap of 0.003 eV suggesting metallic behavior unusual for a Tb-Ta oxide, could the oxi_state_guesses method be assigning incorrect Tb3+ when Tb4+ mixed valence would better explain the charge residual and the anomalous electronic structure?

RbMn8O16 is computationally known with a charge residual of -7.0 and systematically underbonded oxygen (BVS -1.608 to -1.609, ~19.6% dev), mirroring CsMn8O16 in this batch which shows the same -7.0 charge residual and similar O underbonding -- given that both adopt the hollandite tunnel structure (AMn8O16) and the family includes RbMn14O28 with charge -26.0, does the persistent -7.0 residual across both Rb and Cs variants indicate that the oxi_state_guesses method systematically fails to capture the Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio of 1:7 needed for charge balance in hollandite-type materials?

Eu3WO7 shows methods_disagree oxi confidence with mixed valence, a charge residual of -4.0, and 42.9% Pauling violations (6 of 14 bonds), yet W6+ is well-bonded at BVS 5.661 (only 5.7% dev) -- both family members Eu5W3O14 (GII 0.586) and Eu2W2O7 (GII 0.642) show poor structural quality, suggesting the entire Eu-W-O family struggles with bonding -- could the mixed valence flag indicate Eu2+/Eu3+ ambiguity, and if Eu is partially divalent, would the charge residual and Pauling violations resolve since Eu2+ has a dramatically different ionic radius than Eu3+?

PrWO4 matches its expected space group P2_1/c (SG 14, 50% prevalence, score 0.5) and is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations across 16 bonds, but Pr3+ is uniformly underbonded at BVS 2.548 (15.1% dev) with a Shannon violation of 0.037 -- compared to Pr3WO7 (GII 0.460) and Pr2W2O7 (GII 0.425) in the family, the 1:1 PrWO4 stoichiometry achieves the best GII (0.300), suggesting this is the optimal Pr:W ratio for structural stability -- would this scheelite/wolframite-type phase be a strong synthesis candidate given its combined space group match, charge balance, and relatively low GII?
