(deviation 0.304) -- both have charge residuals of -1.0 and single-method oxi assignments; given that substituting the smaller K+ for Rb+ should reduce the A-site cavity and compress the surrounding oxygen framework, does this ~3% increase in oxygen overbonding upon K substitution quantitatively match the Shannon radius difference between K+ and Rb+ in this coordination, or does it suggest a disproportionately large structural response to A-site cation size?

EuTa4O11 is a novel hexagonal compound in the rare SG 182 (P6322) with a formation energy of -3.43 eV/atom -- one of the most negative in this batch -- and all four Ta sites show identical BVS of 4.636 v.u. against expected 5+ (deviation 0.073), indicating very uniform but slightly underbonded tantalum -- its novel family member Eu3Ta4O14 in R-3m has an impressively low GII of 0.165; given that no experimental space group percentages exceed 14% (distributed across SGs 13, 15, and 62), does the prediction of the unusual hexagonal P6322 symmetry represent a genuinely novel structure type for rare-earth tantalates, and does the low 7.3% Ta BVS deviation combined with strong formation energy suggest this could be a synthesizable candidate?

U7CdO16 is a novel mixed-valence compound where Cd shows a striking BVS of only 1.269 v.u. against expected 2+ (deviation 0.365), the largest cation underbonding deviation in this batch -- the charge residual of -2.0 and the absence of any family members isolate this composition in the U-Cd-O phase space; given that Cd2+ strongly prefers tetrahedral coordination while the tetragonal P4/mmm structure (SG 123) implies high-symmetry sites that may force Cd into an unfavorable octahedral or square-planar environment, does the extreme Cd underbonding indicate a fundamental mismatch between Cd's coordination preferences and the crystal structure GNoME has predicted, potentially making this one of the less plausible novel predictions in the dataset?

The Na-Os-O family shows a striking inverse correlation between Na:Os ratio and GII: Na(OsO4)2 achieves a near-perfect GII of 0.011, Na4OsO5 sits at 0.093, and Na4OsO6 rises to 0.24 -- yet Na4OsO6 is the one GNoME places in the high-symmetry R-3c (SG 167) while the experimentally known space groups for this composition type cluster around SG 12, 62, and 152. Could the trigonal structure be forcing Na into undersaturated coordination (BVS 0.731 vs expected 1.0, deviation 27%) because the high-symmetry framework cannot provide enough Na-O contacts, and would a lower-symmetry polymorph in one of the experimentally observed space groups reduce the Na underbonding?

Sr2Ir3O8 is computationally known with both oxi-state methods agreeing on Ir4+, yet among its Sr-Ir-O family members, GII values span a factor of nearly 5x -- from Sr2Ir2O7 at 0.157 (charge-neutral, computationally known) to SrIr5O13 at 0.747 (charge residual -8.0). Given that Sr2Ir3O8 shows systematic Sr underbonding (BVS 1.658 vs expected 2.0, deviation 17.1%) while the Ir sites are slightly overbonded (BVS 4.42 vs expected 4.0), does this pattern suggest that the monoclinic C2/m framework is accommodating a mismatch between ideal Sr2+ and Ir4+ coordination environments, and would the pyrochlore-related Sr2Ir2O7 structure (GII 0.157) represent a more natural equilibrium for this family?

Ba4Ir6O19 adopts the unusual cubic I23 (SG 197), which partially matches the experimental distribution at 12.5%, while the most common experimental space groups for this chemistry are monoclinic (SG 12, 14, 15). Despite this symmetry mismatch, all six Ir sites show identical BVS overbonding at 5.42 vs expected 5.0 (deviation 8.4%), suggesting high site-symmetry consistency. Its family member BaIr5O13 has a much worse GII of 0.722 and a -8.0 charge residual, while Ba2IrO5 at GII 0.28 and Ba4IrO7 at GII 0.349 are both charge-neutral. Is there a critical Ir:Ba ratio threshold beyond which the iridium-rich compositions become electronically unstable, and does the near-zero bandgap (0.004 eV) of Ba4Ir6O19 indicate metallic character that could stabilize an otherwise strained lattice through itinerant electron screening?

Ba2SeO5 is flagged as an oxychalcogenide with a Pauling Rule 2 warning, showing 20% violation fraction across 10 checked polyhedra -- elevated relative to the dataset mean of 17% for pure oxides. Its only family member BaSe2O7 has a significantly lower GII of 0.111 vs 0.236 for Ba2SeO5, despite both being novel and charge-neutral. Given that Ba shows BVS of 1.699 vs expected 2.0 (15% underbonded) and the oxygen sites are overbonded at -2.319 vs -2.0, could the Se coordination environment be creating an asymmetric bonding landscape where Se-O bonds are overly strong at the expense of Ba-O contacts, and does the higher Se:Ba ratio in BaSe2O7 resolve this by providing more covalent Se-O framework for Ba to nest within?

Ca4Bi2O9 is novel, charge-neutral, and passes Shannon radii and Pauling Rule 2 checks perfectly (0/18 violations), yet every Ca site is substantially underbonded at BVS 1.529 vs expected 2.0 (23.6% deviation). Strikingly, its family members Ca(BiO2)7 and Ca3Bi5O14 both show GII values above 0.8 and neither is charge-neutral (residuals -5.0 and -2.0 respectively). Is the Ca underbonding in this trigonal R-3c structure (SG 165) a sign that Ca2+ is too small for the coordination cavity created by the Bi3+ sublattice, and given that no Ca-Bi-O compound in this family achieves both charge neutrality and low GII simultaneously, does this suggest a fundamental size-mismatch problem across the entire Ca-Bi oxide composition space?

KNpO4 is computationally known but GNoME predicts SG P21 (SG 4) while 100% of experimental entries for this chemistry type adopt P21/c (SG 14), a simple centrosymmetric supergroup. The K sites show BVS of 0.766 vs expected 1.0 (23.4% underbonded), a recurring pattern for large alkali cations in tight frameworks. Within the K-Np-O family, GII decreases monotonically with increasing K:Np ratio -- K2Np2O7 at 0.106, K6NpO6 at 0.188, K3NpO4 at 0.252 -- except KNpO4 breaks this trend at 0.234. Does the absence of the inversion center in GNoME's P21 prediction indicate a polar distortion driven by the Np5+ lone pair or second-order Jahn-Teller effect, and could this be experimentally testable via SHG measurements?

Gd6OsO12 is computationally known with a GII of 0.233 in R-3 (SG 148), yet the only experimentally observed space groups for this composition family are orthorhombic (Pna21 at 50%, Cmcm at 50%). All three worst-deviation Gd sites show identical BVS of 2.673 vs expected 3.0 (10.9% underbonded), suggesting a uniform coordination deficit rather than site-specific strain. Its family member Gd2OsO5 has a nearly doubled GII of 0.428 and Gd5(OsO6)2 shows 0.424 with a -1.0 charge residual. Given the extremely low bandgap (0.004 eV) and the rare Os oxidation state chemistry involved, could the Gd underbonding reflect a partially reduced Os species where the actual Os oxidation state is lower than the assigned value, redistributing electron density and artificially inflating the Gd BVS deviation?

Li7Co11O24 presents an alarming confluence of red flags: both oxi-state methods disagree, it has mixed valence, a charge residual of -8.0, and yet Shannon radii pass cleanly (score 0.0). The worst BVS deviations fall on oxygen sites (BVS -1.662 vs expected -2.0, deviation 16.9%), suggesting systematic oxygen underbonding consistent with the massive charge imbalance. Both family members -- Li13Co17O40 (charge -16.0) and Li13(CoO2)28 (charge -15.0) -- show similarly enormous charge residuals. Given that LiCoO2 is the foundational lithium-ion battery cathode material, could this entire Li-Co-O family represent GNoME's attempt to model partially delithiated cathode compositions where Co3+/Co4+ mixed valence is physically real but cannot be captured by integer oxidation state assignments?

La5U5O19 is computationally known but shows a -3.0 charge residual with disagreeing oxi-state methods and mixed valence, while the worst BVS deviation falls on an oxygen site at -1.554 (22.3% underbonded from expected -2.0). Remarkably, across its entire 6-member La-U-O family, every single composition carries a negative charge residual (-1.0 to -2.0), and none achieves charge neutrality. The GII values cluster tightly between 0.217 and 0.319, suggesting structurally plausible but electronically problematic compounds. Is the systematic negative charge residual across the La-U-O family evidence that uranium adopts fractional oxidation states between U4+ and U5+ in these structures, and could neutron diffraction reveal oxygen vacancy ordering that would restore charge balance?

LaU5O12 appears as a family member of La5U5O19 (GII 0.233, charge -3.0) and shares the same La-U-O system, yet LaU5O12 itself has a -1.0 charge residual with mixed valence despite both oxi methods agreeing. The U sites show BVS of 3.62 vs expected 4.0 (9.5% underbonded) while La is slightly overbonded at 3.302 vs 3.0 (10.1%). Across the family, LaU8O18 (GII 0.222), LaU5O12 (GII 0.233), and LaU9O20 (GII 0.232) all cluster near GII ~0.23 despite spanning U:La ratios from 5:1 to 9:1. Does this GII convergence suggest that the uranium oxide sublattice acts as a self-regulating framework where additional U atoms maintain constant structural quality regardless of La dilution?

Ba(CoO2)6 is novel with a severe -8.0 charge residual and disagreeing oxi-state methods, yet achieves perfect Pauling Rule 2 compliance (0/24 violations) and zero Shannon radii violations. The oxygen sites show systematic underbonding (BVS -1.573 vs expected -2.0, deviation 21.4%), and its sole family member Ba(CoO2)8 is computationally known but also carries a -6.0 charge residual. Given the large unit cell (38 sites) and the CoO2 layered motif reminiscent of NaxCoO2 thermoelectric materials, could these compositions represent non-stoichiometric intercalation compounds where the actual Ba occupancy is fractional, and would the true composition be closer to Ba0.5CoO2 -- a misfit layered structure rather than the integer formula GNoME reports?

LaU9O20 is novel with mixed valence and a -1.0 charge residual, showing La overbonded at BVS 3.41 vs expected 3.0 (13.7% deviation) while U is underbonded at 3.643 vs 4.0 (8.9%). This material is a member of the extensive La-U-O family where GII values range from 0.217 (La2U11O26) to 0.319 (La5U2O12), and every composition carries a negative charge residual. The predicted triclinic P-1 structure (SG 2) contrasts with the 100% experimental preference for R-3 (SG 148). Given that the U-rich end members (LaU9O20 at GII 0.232) consistently outperform the La-rich ones (La5U2O12 at GII 0.319), does uranium's ability to adopt flexible coordination geometries with f-orbital participation provide superior structural adaptability compared to the rigid La3+ coordination sphere?

MgU9O20 has the most dramatic single-site BVS deviation in this batch: Mg shows BVS 1.114 vs expected 2.0 (44.3% underbonded), yet the overall GII of 0.232 remains moderate because the uranium and most oxygen sites compensate. Its family member MgU3O10 has a much higher GII of 0.399 but achieves charge neutrality, while MgU9O20 carries a -2.0 charge residual. Given that Mg2+ (ionic radius 0.72 A in octahedral coordination) is dramatically smaller than the La3+ (1.03 A) and Y3+ (0.90 A) that occupy the equivalent site in the isostructural LaU9O20 and YU9O20, is the 44% Mg underbonding evidence that Mg2+ is simply too small for the cavity this fluorite-derived structure provides, and could this predict a pressure-induced phase transition where the cavity contracts to better match Mg coordination requirements?

Tb2Te5O13 is an oxychalcogenide with a high Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 30.8% across 26 checked polyhedra (flagged with a compound class warning), yet it is perfectly charge-neutral with both oxi methods agreeing. All three worst BVS deviations fall on Te sites overbonded at ~4.45-4.47 vs expected 4.0 (10.7-11.8% deviation). With no family members in the dataset, this material stands isolated -- unlike the extensive La-U-O or Y-U-O networks. Given that Te4+ has a stereochemically active lone pair that typically creates asymmetric coordination environments, could the elevated Pauling violations reflect the BVS parameterization's failure to account for lone-pair-driven bond asymmetry rather than genuine structural instability?

YU9O20 is novel with a -1.0 charge residual, mixed valence, and disagreeing oxi methods, yet its Y site shows the worst BVS deviation at 2.463 vs expected 3.0 (17.9% underbonded) -- notably more severe than the La analog LaU9O20 where La shows only 13.7% deviation. Across its 6-member Y-U-O family, all five uranium-rich compositions (YU3O8 through YU9O20) carry a consistent -1.0 charge residual, while the sole charge-neutral member Y2UO6 (GII 0.325) is the only computationally known entry. Does the ubiquitous -1.0 charge deficit across novel Y-U-O compositions suggest GNoME is systematically predicting structures with one excess electron per formula unit, and could these actually be n-type electronic conductors where the extra electron occupies a U 5f conduction band?

Ir4Pb3O13 is novel, charge-neutral, and shows remarkably uniform BVS across all Ir sites (5.371 vs expected 5.0, 7.4% deviation), suggesting a well-ordered iridium sublattice. However, its sole family member Ir4Pb3O14 has one additional oxygen, a -2.0 charge residual, and a substantially worse GII of 0.387 vs 0.230. Both adopt trigonal structures (R3m and R-3m respectively), but Ir4Pb3O13 in SG 160 is non-centrosymmetric while the experimental preference is for cubic Fd-3m (SG 227). Could the single-oxygen difference between these two compositions represent an oxygen vacancy ordering transition, where Ir4Pb3O13 is the vacancy-ordered superstructure of Ir4Pb3O14, and does the loss of centrosymmetry in the vacancy-ordered phase predict piezoelectric or ferroelectric behavior?

InB3O5 passes every Tier 1 check perfectly -- charge-neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across 20 polyhedra -- yet the In sites show an extraordinary BVS of 0.405 vs expected 1.0 (59.5% underbonded), one of the most extreme single-site deviations in the dataset. The wide bandgap of 3.25 eV is consistent with a boron oxide framework. With no family members to compare, InB3O5 stands alone. Is the severe In underbonding an artifact of assigning In1+ (which is extremely rare and unstable) rather than the far more common In3+, and would reassigning indium to In3+ with a compensating borate framework rearrangement (e.g., InBO3 + B2O2) yield a chemically more plausible description of this structure?

Rb4Si3O8 is novel, charge-neutral, and has zero Shannon violations, yet shows a striking 50% Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction (16 of 32 polyhedra fail), the highest in this entire batch. The Rb sites are severely underbonded at BVS 0.535 vs expected 1.0 (46.5% deviation), consistent with the well-known tendency of large alkali cations to rattle in oversized cavities. With 60 atoms in the triclinic unit cell (P-1, SG 2), this is one of the largest structures in the batch. Given that the experimental space group distribution favors P21/c (33%) and Amm2 (22%), could the triclinic distortion represent GNoME's attempt to lower symmetry enough to shorten some Rb-O distances, and would a high-temperature phase transition to the more symmetric Amm2 structure be expected as thermal energy overcomes the weak Rb-O bonding preferences?

SrU4O11 is computationally known in hexagonal P6322 (SG 182), a strikingly high-symmetry choice given that the experimental distribution heavily favors monoclinic P21/c (29%) and lower-symmetry space groups. The Sr sites are dramatically underbonded at BVS 1.180 vs expected 2.0 (41% deviation), while the U sites are nearly ideal at 4.827 vs 5.0 (3.5% deviation). All three family members (Sr2U11O26, SrU8O18, SrU9O20) have lower GII values (0.164-0.189) than SrU4O11's 0.229, despite all carrying charge residuals of -2.0 to -4.0. Does the hexagonal structure impose coordination geometries that are ideal for U5+ but terrible for Sr2+, and would replacing Sr with the larger Ba (as in the isoelectronic BaU4O11) substantially reduce the A-site underbonding?

V4Cl7O is an oxyhalide with a remarkable 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction, though only 1 polyhedron was checkable -- suggesting the single oxide ion in this chlorine-dominated structure has a highly anomalous coordination environment. The O site shows BVS -1.555 vs expected -2.0 (22.2% underbonded), while V is at 1.68 vs expected 2.0 (16% underbonded) and Cl at -0.801 vs expected -1.0 (19.9% underbonded). With mixed valence, a -1.0 charge residual, and only 12 sites in a trigonal R3m structure, this is a minimal, highly constrained system. Given that the compound is essentially a vanadium chloride with a single interstitial oxygen, could the oxygen be acting as a structure-directing template that nucleates the trigonal symmetry rather than participating in conventional bonding, analogous to oxygen-centered clusters in Zintl phases?

EuAl4O7 is novel, charge-neutral, passes Pauling Rule 2 perfectly (0/14 violations), yet the Eu sites show dramatic underbonding at BVS 1.277 vs expected 2.0 (36.1% deviation), while Al is nearly ideal at 3.141 vs 3.0. The sole family member Eu3Al4O9 is computationally known with a higher GII of 0.344 but the same charge neutrality. Given that Eu commonly adopts both Eu2+ and Eu3+ oxidation states, could the severe Eu underbonding at the Eu2+ site actually indicate that Eu3+ is the correct assignment (where BVS 1.277 would represent a 57% deviation from 3.0, even worse), or does it suggest a genuine Eu2+ compound where the monoclinic C2/c framework provides coordination cavities that are too large -- and would this make EuAl4O7 a candidate for pressure-tunable Eu2+/Eu3+ valence switching with accompanying red-to-blue phosphor color change?

MgU8O18 is the lighter sibling of MgU9O20, both novel with -2.0 charge residuals and mixed valence, both in triclinic P-1 (SG 2). Mg underbonding is nearly identical: BVS 1.140 vs 1.114 (43% vs 44.3% deviation from expected 2.0), and both share identical oxygen BVS values of -1.713. The GII values are also remarkably close at 0.228 (MgU8O18) vs 0.232 (MgU9O20), with the only structural difference being one fewer UO2 unit. Given the experimental preference for SG 74 (Imma, 100%), could these two triclinic structures represent low-temperature ground states of a high-symmetry Imma parent phase that distorts to accommodate the undersized Mg2+, and would they merge into a single Imma phase above some critical temperature?

Y2(TeO3)3 is an oxychalcogenide with an 84-atom unit cell -- the largest in this batch -- and shows a Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 32% across 50 checked polyhedra (flagged with compound class warning), yet achieves perfect charge neutrality and zero Shannon violations. All three worst BVS deviations fall on Te sites showing ~12-13% overbonding (BVS 4.48-4.52 vs expected 4.0). Its space group score of 0.25 is among the highest in this batch, with the predicted P-1 matching the 25% experimental P-1 representation. Given that Tb2Te5O13 in the same batch shows similar Te overbonding but a lower Pauling violation rate (30.8%), does the higher Te:cation ratio in Y2(TeO3)3 vs Tb2Te5O13 force more Te-O-Te bridging that naturally violates Pauling's electrostatic rule, and could this predict a decomposition pathway to Y2O3 + 3TeO2 under thermal stress?

SmTa3O9 is computationally known, perfectly charge-neutral, with zero Pauling violations across 18 polyhedra and zero Shannon violations, yet the Sm site shows significant underbonding at BVS 2.408 vs expected 3.0 (19.7% deviation). With a wide bandgap of 3.26 eV and a monoclinic P21/m structure (SG 11) that differs from the experimental preferences of P2/c (33%), C2/c (33%), and Cmcm (33%), this is a well-validated insulator with only A-site strain. Given that SmTa3O9 shares the RTa3O9 stoichiometry common to rare-earth tantalates known for photocatalytic water splitting, and considering the near-ideal Ta bonding implied by its absence from the worst-deviation list, could the 19.7% Sm underbonding indicate that the predicted structure has the Sm in a cavity sized for a larger rare earth (e.g., La3+ at 1.03 A vs Sm3+ at 0.96 A), suggesting a substitution-tolerant framework worth exploring for bandgap tuning?

YU8O18 shares the same Y-U-O family as YU9O20 and shows nearly identical validation signatures: Y underbonded at BVS 2.471 vs 3.0 (17.6%), U underbonded at 3.744-3.747 vs 4.0 (6.3-6.4%), both in triclinic P-1 with -1.0 charge residual. However, YU8O18 has a slightly lower GII of 0.227 vs YU9O20's 0.230, and the oxi assignment drops to single_method confidence. Across the full Y-U-O family, YU3O8 in cubic Pm-3m achieves the lowest GII of 0.217 despite the same -1.0 charge residual. Does the progressive GII decrease from YU9O20 (0.230) to YU8O18 (0.227) to YU3O8 (0.217) with decreasing U:Y ratio suggest that these fluorite-derivative structures become progressively better optimized as U content decreases, and is there a crossover point where the Y-rich composition Y2UO6 (GII 0.325, charge-neutral) sacrifices structural quality to achieve electronic balance?

Sm2Te5O13 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with Te4+ sites showing consistent BVS overvaluation (4.47 v.u. vs expected 4.0, deviation ~11.8%), yet charge neutrality is perfect and Shannon radii pass cleanly -- does the systematic Te overbonding reflect genuine structural compression of TeO polyhedra in the triclinic P-1 cell, or does it indicate that the BVS reference parameters for Te4+-O bonds are poorly calibrated for tellurite-rich environments where Te has a stereochemically active lone pair?

The entire Y-U-O family predicted by GNoME (YU5O12, YU7O16, YU3O8, YU8O18, YU9O20) shares a remarkably persistent charge neutrality residual of exactly -1.0 and nearly identical GII values (0.217-0.230), while the sole computationally known member Y2UO6 achieves perfect neutrality (charge 0.0) but higher GII (0.325) -- does this pattern suggest GNoME has learned a specific metastable U-rich structural motif that systematically requires one excess electron per formula unit, perhaps indicating metallic or mixed-valence U4+/U5+ character that classical oxidation state assignment cannot capture?

DyTcO5 passes all Tier 1 checks (charge neutral, Shannon radii valid, zero Pauling violations in 20 bonds) yet its family member Dy6Tc16O has a catastrophic GII of 1.638 v.u. -- given that technetium compounds are almost never experimentally synthesized due to Tc's radioactivity, and oxi states were assigned by a single method only, how reliable is the Dy3+/Tc7+ assignment for this monoclinic P2_1/c structure, and could the moderate Dy underbonding (BVS 2.77 vs expected 3.0) signal an incorrect coordination environment?

Tm2CO5 is computationally known and shares its Cmcm structure with novel Ho2CO5 (both sg 63, 16 sites, identical Pauling violation fraction 0.40), yet the family member Tm2(CO3)3 achieves a near-perfect GII of only 0.021 v.u. -- given that Tm2CO5 has a GII of 0.226 and a 10.2% Tm underbonding deviation, does the large bandgap of 4.52 eV and the contrast with the pristine carbonate structure suggest that Tm2CO5 represents a metastable decarboxylation intermediate rather than a thermodynamically stable phase?

Ho2CO5 is isostructural with Tm2CO5 (both Cmcm, sg 63, 16 sites) and shows nearly identical validation signatures -- Pauling violation 0.40, GII ~0.226, lanthanide underbonding ~10% -- yet Ho2CO5 is novel while Tm2CO5 is computationally known, and the Ho family member Ho2(CO3)3 has a remarkably low GII of 0.048; does this lanthanide-independent structural replication suggest GNoME has found a genuine Ln2CO5 structure type, and if so, why has it not been predicted for other similarly-sized rare earths like Er or Dy?

K4OsO6 adopts trigonal R-3c (sg 167) but experimental K-Os-O phases span three different space groups (P-1, I4_1/a, Fd-3m), and the K sites show a striking bimodal BVS distribution -- some overbonded at 1.231 v.u. and others underbonded at 0.778 v.u. relative to expected K+ -- could this 45.3% spread across K sites indicate that the predicted structure has K in two fundamentally different coordination environments, and does the family trend of worsening GII with increasing K:Os ratio (KOs5O13 at 0.011 vs K4Os2O9 at 0.359) suggest a solubility limit for K in osmium oxide frameworks?

NiMo2O7 shows a dramatic 24.3% Ni underbonding (BVS 1.515 vs expected 2.0 for Ni2+) across all Ni sites, the largest divalent cation deviation in this batch, while Mo6+ is well-bonded at 5.718 v.u. -- given that Ni2+ in molybdate frameworks is known to adopt both octahedral and unusual 5-coordinate geometries, does this systematic underbonding in the 40-atom monoclinic P2_1/c cell indicate that CrystalNN is assigning too high a coordination number to Ni, or could it reflect a genuinely underbonded Ni site that would make this material a candidate for ion-exchange or catalytic activity?

U3Se2O3 is an oxychalcogenide with mixed valence, a large charge neutrality residual of -4.0, and a Pauling warning, yet its family member U2SeO2 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality and lower GII (0.222 vs 0.224) -- strikingly, the family member U4Se3O4 also carries a -4.0 charge residual, suggesting this is a systematic failure of oxidation state assignment in U-Se-O systems rather than a structural deficiency; could the U3+/U4+ mixed valence combined with Se2- create a charge-transfer pathway that makes formal integer oxidation states fundamentally inappropriate?

Na7Ti10O20 has the rare 'methods_disagree' oxi confidence flag, a -3.0 charge residual, mixed valence, and oxygen sites showing 16-17% underbonding (BVS -1.667 vs expected -2.0), yet passes Shannon radii and Pauling checks perfectly -- with 37 sites in monoclinic P2/m (sg 10) and an unusual Na:Ti ratio that doesn't match any known sodium titanate stoichiometry, could this represent a novel sodium-intercalated titanium bronze where the charge imbalance reflects delocalized electrons in a Ti 3d conduction band rather than a structural error?

Gd2Te5O13 is an oxychalcogenide isostructural analog of Sm2Te5O13 in this batch (both triclinic P-1, 40 sites, both with Te4+ overbonding around 11.7% and identical Pauling violation fractions of 0.3077 in 26 bonds) -- the family member Gd2(TeO3)3 in Pnma has a much lower GII of 0.149, suggesting the tellurite connectivity reorganizes favorably in an orthorhombic setting; does the systematic replication of this Ln2Te5O13 structure type across the lanthanide series indicate a robust structural prediction, or is GNoME simply interpolating between known rare-earth tellurite frameworks?

LaU8O18 belongs to a six-member La-U-O family where every compound carries a charge residual of -1.0 to -3.0 and methods disagree on oxidation states, yet GII values cluster tightly between 0.217 and 0.319 -- the sole computationally known member La5U2O12 has the worst GII (0.319) while novel LaU9O20 scores better (0.232); does this inverse correlation between prior computational knowledge and BVS quality suggest that GNoME's neural network has learned to optimize local bonding environments more effectively than earlier computational approaches for U-rich compositions?

YU7O16 adopts tetragonal P4/mmm (sg 123) while experimental Y-U-O phases exclusively use R-3 (sg 148), and the Y site shows a 15.2% BVS deficit (2.543 vs expected 3.0) -- this is the largest Y underbonding in the Y-U-O family, which otherwise shows consistent GII values of 0.217-0.230; given that every family member except Y2UO6 carries a -1.0 charge residual and is novel, could the Y underbonding specifically in this highest-symmetry member indicate that the tetragonal cell imposes geometric constraints on the Y-O polyhedron that are relaxed in the lower-symmetry triclinic analogs?

U2SeO2 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality and a compact 5-atom trigonal P-3m1 (sg 164) cell, yet its Se2- site shows the largest BVS deviation in the structure at 19.7% overbonding (BVS -2.394 vs expected -2.0) -- since the family members U3Se2O3 and U4Se3O4 both carry -4.0 charge residuals despite containing the same U-Se-O building blocks, does the Se overbonding in U2SeO2 indicate covalent U-Se interactions that make the ionic BVS model inappropriate, and is this why charge balance fails catastrophically when more Se enters the structure?

MnMo2O7 and NiMo2O7 in this batch share the same AMo2O7 stoichiometry and nearly identical GII scores (~0.221-0.224), yet Mn2+ shows 21.8% underbonding while Ni2+ shows 24.3% -- the consistent divalent cation underbonding across both transition metals suggests the Mo2O7 framework imposes a cavity size that is systematically too large for the A-site cation; does the 25% match with experimental space group P-1 (sg 2) for MnMo2O7 vs zero match for NiMo2O7 indicate that the Mn analog is closer to a physically realizable structure?

Sr4As2O9 has 60 atoms in monoclinic P2_1 (sg 4) with charge neutrality and zero Shannon violations, yet its worst BVS sites show oxygen underbonding at -1.550 v.u. (22.5% deficit) alongside Sr underbonding at 1.553 v.u. (22.4% deficit) -- this symmetric underbonding of both cation and anion sublattices is unusual and may indicate a globally expanded lattice; given the low formation energy of -2.77 eV/atom, could this structure represent a metastable high-pressure phase that has been relaxed to ambient conditions in the DFT calculation?

Ba6Nb7O21 is computationally known yet shows 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (all 21 checked bonds fail), a -2.0 charge residual, and single-method oxi assignment -- this is the worst Pauling score in this batch despite the material being previously known; given that the Ba-Nb-O family consistently shows charge residuals of -2.0 to -4.0 and the lowest-GII family member Ba4Nb5O15 (0.191) also carries a -2.0 residual, does this systematic pattern indicate that Nb adopts a fractional effective oxidation state (between +4 and +5) in these barium niobate frameworks that integer-valence models fundamentally cannot represent?

Sr2Pt2O7 is novel with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations, but two of four Sr sites are underbonded at 1.703 v.u. (14.8% deficit) while the other two are slightly overbonded at 2.092 v.u. -- this bimodal Sr behavior contrasts sharply with the family trend where all other Sr-Pt-O compositions show dramatically worse GII values (0.524-0.704); does the anomalously good GII of 0.220 for Sr2Pt2O7 in orthorhombic Imma (sg 74) suggest this is the most structurally viable Sr-Pt-O stoichiometry, and could the bimodal Sr environment indicate a layered structure with alternating close-packed and open Sr layers?

Gd2(SeO3)3 is computationally known with both-agree oxi confidence and perfect charge neutrality, yet all three Se4+ sites show ~10% BVS deficit (3.605-3.649 vs expected 4.0) -- the family spans from pristine Gd2(SeO4)3 (GII 0.131, Se6+) to strained Gd2Se5O13 (GII 0.290), suggesting that increasing Se:O ratio destabilizes the structure; given the 3.01 eV bandgap indicating insulating character, does the systematic Se4+ underbonding reflect genuine lone-pair-driven asymmetric coordination that shortens some Se-O bonds while elongating others?

Lu2UO6 has the highest formation energy magnitude in this batch (-3.96 eV/atom), perfect charge neutrality, zero Pauling violations, and a moderate GII of 0.219 -- its seven-member Lu-U-O family shows a remarkable bifurcation where stoichiometries with charge residuals of -1.0 cluster tightly at GII 0.20-0.22 while LuU5O16 (charge -4.0) jumps to 0.617; does this threshold behavior suggest that the Lu-U-O system can tolerate exactly one excess electron per formula unit through mixed U valence, but collapses structurally when higher reduction levels are attempted?

Pt4Pb4O13 is computationally known yet carries a -2.0 charge residual and has Pb2+ sites uniformly underbonded at 1.756 v.u. (12.2% deficit) in cubic F-43m (sg 216) -- remarkably, its family members Pt4Pb3O14 and PtPb3O7 have extreme GII values of 1.02 and 0.985 respectively, five times worse than this compound's 0.219; does the dramatically better structural quality of the 4:4 Pt:Pb stoichiometry suggest that equal Pt and Pb proportions enable a special ordering arrangement on the cubic sublattice, and could the -2.0 charge residual indicate Pt in a non-standard +3 oxidation state rather than the assumed +4?

NdIO5 is a novel oxyhalide with I7+ (BVS 6.576, 6.1% deficit) in monoclinic P2_1/c, and its family members Nd6IO12 and Nd2IO6 have null GII and charge values indicating complete failure of oxidation state assignment -- this suggests the I-O bonding in these compositions is sufficiently unusual that standard methods cannot determine valence; given the moderate bandgap of 1.85 eV and the fact that periodate (IO4-) and orthoperiodate (IO6 5-) are the only well-characterized I7+ oxyanions, does the NdIO5 stoichiometry imply an unusual edge- or face-sharing periodate network that might enable novel oxidative chemistry?

SmTcO5 and DyTcO5 in this batch are isostructural (both monoclinic P2_1/c, sg 14, 28 sites) with nearly identical GII values (0.219 vs 0.226) and both show ~7% lanthanide underbonding, yet the Sm compound has a larger bandgap (1.45 vs 1.38 eV) despite Sm3+ having a larger ionic radius than Dy3+ -- given that their family structures Sm2TcO6 and Dy2TcO6 both adopt C2/c with similar GII (~0.29), does this lanthanide-insensitive structural consistency suggest that the TcO5 framework geometry is entirely dictated by Tc7+ coordination preferences, making the rare earth merely a spectator cation?

Bi6Se2O15 is a novel oxychalcogenide with 46 atoms in orthorhombic Ccc2 (sg 37), perfect charge neutrality, and zero Pauling violations across 30 bonds, yet its oxygen sites show 16.9% underbonding (BVS -1.663) -- the family member Bi2(SeO4)3 achieves a near-perfect GII of only 0.041 with Se6+, while this Se4+ compound has GII of 0.218; does the contrast suggest that Se4+ lone pairs in Bi6Se2O15 create asymmetric coordination environments that force some oxygens into underbonded positions, and could these underbonded oxygens serve as reactive sites for oxidation or hydration?

La2U11O26 is the most U-rich member of the La-U-O family with methods disagreeing on oxidation states, a -2.0 charge residual, and mixed valence, yet its GII of 0.217 is among the best in the family -- given that the closely related LaU8O18 and LaU9O20 also show excellent GII values (0.222 and 0.232) despite their own charge residuals, does the consistent structural quality across U-rich compositions suggest that uranium's flexible coordination chemistry (accommodating 6- to 9-fold environments) acts as a structural buffer, and could the methods_disagree flag specifically indicate U5+ intermediate valence that neither BV analyzer nor oxi_state_guesses handles correctly?

K6S2O9 adopts cubic Fm-3m (sg 225) with perfect charge neutrality and both methods agreeing on S6+, yet its worst oxygen site shows an extreme 28.4% underbonding (BVS -1.432 vs expected -2.0) -- this is the largest single-site oxygen deficit in the entire batch, despite the high-symmetry cubic structure; given that the family member K(S8O)3 has a catastrophic GII of 1.591 and -5.0 charge residual, does the oxygen underbonding in K6S2O9 indicate that the sulfate SO4 tetrahedra are unusually isolated within an oversized potassium cage, and could this extreme O underbonding make these oxygen sites highly basic or susceptible to protonation?

YU3O8 adopts cubic Pm-3m (SG 221) while experimental Y-U oxides exclusively crystallize in rhombohedral R-3 (SG 148) -- across 5 family members (YU7O16, YU5O12, YU8O18, YU5O16, YU9O20) all show persistent charge imbalance of -1.0, yet the computationally known Y2UO6 (C2/c) achieves neutrality: does the U-rich stoichiometry in these yttrium uranates force a fractional U oxidation state that the oxi_state_guesses method cannot resolve, explaining the systematic -1.0 residual charge?

CdSe2O7 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with Se6+ and Cd2+, yet Cd shows BVS values of only 1.45-1.47 v.u. (27% underbonded relative to the expected +2), while Se sites are nearly ideal at 5.81 v.u. vs expected 6 -- given that the family member Cd2SeO5 has a much higher GII of 0.468 compared to this compound's 0.216, does the Se-rich stoichiometry provide a more favorable coordination environment for Cd despite the triclinic distortion?

LuU8O18 in triclinic P-1 shows Lu systematically underbonded at BVS 2.451 v.u. (18.3% deviation from expected +3), mirroring the pattern across the entire Lu-U-O family where Lu is consistently underbonded -- remarkably, the family spans 7 compositions from LuUO4 to LuU9O20 with GII values tightly clustered at 0.201-0.248 except LuU5O16 which jumps to 0.617: is the anomalous strain in LuU5O16 connected to its charge imbalance of -4.0 versus the -1.0 seen in most other Lu-U-O phases?

UIO2 is a computationally known oxyhalide where iodide shows a striking 36.6% BVS underbonding (BVS -0.634 vs expected -1), while the Pauling rule 2 violation rate reaches 50% -- its family member U(IO)2 in P4/mmm achieves a lower GII of 0.198 with charge neutrality, suggesting that the iodate arrangement may be more stable than the iodide arrangement: could the large I- ion be too loosely held in the orthorhombic Pnma lattice, making this computationally known phase metastable?

La2TeO5 is an oxychalcogenide where Te4+ shows BVS of 4.473 v.u. (11.8% overbonded relative to expected +4), and 30% of Pauling rule 2 bonds are violated across 20 checked polyhedra -- given that the compound adopts SG 39 (Abm2) while experimental La-Te-O phases split across three very different space groups (15, 19, 139), does the lone pair activity of Te4+ drive the structural instability implied by this space group mismatch?

La3Bi5O12 passes all Tier 1 checks perfectly (charge neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across 24 polyhedra) with a modest GII of 0.213 -- yet the broader La-Bi-O family reveals dramatic instability: Bi-rich members LaBi3O7 (GII 0.770), La(BiO2)7 (GII 0.777), and LaBi7O16 (GII 0.709) all show severe strain and large charge imbalances, while La-rich La3BiO7 has GII of only 0.366: is La3Bi5O12 sitting at a compositional sweet spot where the La3+/Bi3+ ratio optimally satisfies the cubic I-43m framework?

TmNb3O6 adopts hexagonal P6322 (SG 182) while experimental Tm-Nb-O compounds are exclusively monoclinic C2/c (SG 15) -- both Tm and Nb are systematically underbonded (Tm BVS 2.53 vs expected 3, Nb BVS 2.769 vs expected 3), yielding 15.7% and 7.7% deviations respectively: does the unusual hexagonal symmetry force coordination geometries that cannot fully satisfy the bond valence requirements of the smaller late-lanthanide Tm3+ ion?

Tb6SbO12 in trigonal R-3 (SG 148) has a charge residual of -1.0 with only single-method oxi assignment, while its Sb site achieves a near-ideal BVS of 4.65 v.u. for Sb5+ -- strikingly, the Tb-Sb-O family shows a pattern of escalating structural distress: Tb(SbO3)3 has GII 0.428, TbSb5O13 reaches 0.942, and Tb3Sb9O26 hits 0.861 with a -7.0 charge imbalance, suggesting that Sb-rich compositions in this system are fundamentally charge-incompatible: is Tb6SbO12 the only thermodynamically viable Tb:Sb ratio?

LuU9O20 is the most U-rich member of the extensive Lu-U-O family and uniquely exhibits mixed valence with disagreeing oxi state methods -- its Lu BVS of 2.447 (18.4% underbonded) is the most extreme underbonding of Lu across all family members, and the U sites show BVS values of 3.746-3.747 vs expected +4 (6.3% deviation): does the U9 stoichiometry necessarily require U4+/U5+ mixing that neither oxi assignment method can consistently resolve, and could this mixed valence actually stabilize the triclinic P-1 structure?

Er2(TeO3)3 is one of the rare materials achieving a non-zero space group match score (0.50), with its triclinic P-1 (SG 2) matching one of the experimentally observed space groups -- yet despite this structural plausibility, the Pauling rule 2 violation rate is 32% across 50 checked polyhedra with an oxychalcogenide warning, and Te4+ sites show 11.7-13.2% overbonding: given the large 84-atom unit cell, could the complex Te4+ lone-pair ordering drive the high Pauling violation rate while still permitting an overall stable framework?

HoIO5 achieves a perfect space group match score of 1.0 (P21/c, SG 14) -- the only material in this batch to do so -- with zero Pauling violations across 20 polyhedra and charge neutrality, yet I7+ shows a BVS of 6.533 (6.7% underbonded): given that the family member HoIO4 with lower iodine-to-oxygen ratio has a significantly higher GII of 0.397, does the IO5 stoichiometry provide optimal oxygen coordination for the heptavalent iodate, making this novel prediction particularly promising for experimental synthesis?

Zn(PtO3)2 passes every Tier 1 check (charge neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations) with Zn showing only 10.6% BVS underbonding (1.789 vs expected 2) -- as a novel tetragonal P42/mnm (SG 136) prediction with no family members in the dataset, this isolated Zn-Pt oxide has no compositional relatives to benchmark against: given that Pt4+ in octahedral oxygen coordination is well-established in minerals like cooperite, is the absence of any known Zn-Pt-O ternary phase surprising or expected from a crystal-chemical perspective?

UI4O in tetragonal I4/m (SG 87) shows a fascinating anion bonding signature: oxygen is 13.2% overbonded (BVS -2.264 vs expected -2) while iodide is 14.9% underbonded (BVS -0.851 vs expected -1), suggesting the single oxide ion is over-coordinated while the four iodides are under-coordinated -- its family member UIO2 has essentially the same GII (0.216 vs 0.211) but with the inverse I:O ratio: does the U6+ cation preferentially satisfy its bond valence through oxide rather than iodide coordination, creating an inherent bonding asymmetry in uranium oxyiodides?

UClO2 is a computationally known oxyhalide where Cl- shows 34.1% BVS underbonding (BVS -0.659 vs expected -1), closely paralleling the 36.6% underbonding of I- in the related UIO2 -- both U oxyhalides show 50% Pauling rule 2 violation rates, and the family members UCl4O (GII 0.195) and UCl3O (GII 0.175) achieve better structural metrics: is there a systematic trend in uranium oxyhalides where increasing the halide-to-oxide ratio paradoxically improves structural stability by reducing competition for U-O bonding?

Dy3Ta17O47 has an exceptionally large unit cell (67 sites) with a Ta:Dy ratio of 5.67:1, and Dy3+ shows the most severe BVS underbonding in the structure at 2.274 v.u. (24.2% deviation) -- the sole family member Dy6TaO12 (R-3) has the inverse cation ratio and could not even compute GII: does the extreme Ta-enrichment in this monoclinic P2/m structure force Dy3+ into oversized cavities within the tantalate framework, explaining why only 4.3% of the 47 oxygen polyhedra violate Pauling rule 2 despite the large lanthanide strain?

KTa5O8 in tetragonal P4/m (SG 83) has a Ta site with BVS 2.297 v.u. (23.4% below the expected +3 from oxi_state_guesses), while the sole family member KTa10O18 has a GII of 0.526 with a massive charge residual of -10.0 -- if Ta is actually in +5 rather than the assigned +3 state, the charge neutrality score of 0.0 would be incompatible: is the single-method oxi assignment misidentifying Ta's oxidation state, and could this material actually contain reduced Ta3+ in an unusual low-valent tantalum oxide?

NaU5O12 is computationally known with mixed valence and a charge residual of -3.0, yet its family member NaU8O18 achieves a remarkably low GII of only 0.126 (also with -3.0 charge) -- the family spans from Na-rich Na5UO5 (GII 0.297, neutral) to U-rich NaU8O18, with Na3U4O12 (GII 0.198) as an intermediate: given that both NaU5O12 and NaU8O18 share the same -3.0 charge imbalance, does this persistent residual indicate that U4+/U5+ mixed valence is a fundamental feature of Na-U-O chemistry rather than an assignment error?

LuUO4 is the simplest member of the extensive Lu-U-O family (6 sites, tetragonal P4/mmm) and achieves charge neutrality with both methods agreeing on oxi states -- across the 7-member family, GII values cluster tightly (0.201-0.248) except for LuU5O16 at 0.617, and all U-rich compositions carry persistent -1.0 charge residuals: does LuUO4's combination of minimal formula unit, charge balance, and moderate GII of 0.205 make it the most synthetically accessible entry point into the Lu-U-O phase space?

Li2OsO4 achieves a partial space group match (score 0.333) with its C2/c (SG 15) appearing among experimental possibilities -- all Li sites show identical 20.4% BVS underbonding (0.796 vs expected 1), while the Li-Os-O family reveals a remarkable trend: GII decreases systematically with increasing Li:Os ratio from LiOs3O8 (0.314) through Li2OsO4 (0.204) to Li6OsO6 (0.142): is lithium underbonding an intrinsic feature of the Li-Os-O system that improves as the structure provides more oxide neighbors per Li, suggesting Li6OsO6 may be the most stable stoichiometry?

U5O12F is a novel oxyhalide with an infinite bandgap prediction and 25% Pauling rule 2 violations across 24 polyhedra, where all five U5+ sites show nearly identical BVS values of 5.357 v.u. (7.1% overbonded) -- its family members U3O7F (GII 0.166) and UO2F (GII 0.138) both achieve charge neutrality and lower GII values with lower U:F ratios: does the high U5O12F stoichiometry represent a fluorine-deficient limit where the single F- cannot adequately compensate the structural strain of five uranium polyhedra?

La4As3O4 is a computationally known mixed-valence compound with 100% Pauling rule 2 violation across all 4 checked polyhedra and a +1.0 charge residual -- As shows BVS of -0.802 vs expected -1 (arsenide, As3-), yet the family member La2As4O9 has GII of only 0.137 with perfect charge neutrality using arsenate (As5+): is the coexistence of arsenide (As3-) and oxide (O2-) anions in La4As3O4 fundamentally problematic from a Pauling perspective, explaining the complete violation of electrostatic rule 2?

Cs5As3O10 achieves a partial space group match (score 0.25) and charge neutrality, but its Cs+ sites are dramatically underbonded at BVS 0.530 v.u. (47% deviation from expected +1), and 60% of Pauling rule 2 bonds are violated across 20 polyhedra -- with the family member Cs3AsO3 also showing substantial strain (GII 0.345): given that Cs+ is the largest common alkali cation, is the arsenate framework in this monoclinic C2/c structure simply too open to provide adequate coordination, and does this represent a fundamental size-mismatch limit for Cs-arsenate chemistry?

La2IrO6 in orthorhombic P212121 (SG 19) passes all Tier 1 checks perfectly with Ir6+ showing BVS of 5.635 (6.1% underbonded) -- across the La-Ir-O family, La6IrO12 (R-3, GII 0.336) and La(IrO3)3 (Cmcm, GII 0.337) have nearly identical strain despite very different La:Ir ratios, while La5(IrO6)2 has GII 0.371 with a -1.0 charge residual: does the Ir6+ ion's d3 electronic configuration stabilize the octahedral IrO6 unit so strongly that the family's structural quality depends more on how La3+ fills the interstitial space than on the Ir coordination itself?

LuU3O8 is computationally known in cubic Pm-3m (SG 221) while experimental precedent demands rhombohedral R-3 (SG 148) -- this exact same SG mismatch appears in the isostructural YU3O8 (also Pm-3m predicted, R-3 expected), and both share a -1.0 charge residual with single-method oxi assignment: given that LuU3O8 has the highest formation energy magnitude in its family (-3.868 eV/atom) and the tightest GII (0.202), is GNoME consistently predicting the wrong symmetry for this RE-U3O8 structure type, or could there be a genuine cubic polymorph at high pressure?

Lu3U2O10 is computationally known in monoclinic C2/m (SG 12) with all Lu sites underbonded (BVS 2.66-2.71 vs expected 3) and a -1.0 charge residual -- it has the lowest GII in the entire Lu-U-O family at 0.201 and the highest formation energy magnitude (-3.963 eV/atom): given that 4 of the 7 family members are computationally known while 3 are novel, and the novel members (LuUO4, Lu2UO6) achieve charge neutrality while the computationally known ones do not, is the charge imbalance in Lu3U2O10 an artifact of the oxi_state_guesses method failing to capture U4+/U5+ mixing in U-rich compositions?

Re3SbO12 is predicted in hexagonal SG 176, yet known Re-Sb-O compounds crystallize exclusively in monoclinic (SG 15) or triclinic (SG 2) settings -- what structural driving force could stabilize a hexagonal framework given that the Sb sites show BVS of only 2.23 v.u. versus the expected 3+, a 25.6% underbonding that suggests the Sb coordination polyhedra are anomalously expanded?

Cs2Se5O16 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with a 32% Pauling Rule 2 violation rate across 50 bonds, yet all Se sites show consistent BVS of 5.62 v.u. against expected 6+ (only 6.3% deviation) -- does the Pauling violation pattern arise specifically from Se-O bonds where the assumption of pure O2- breaks down, and could the Se atoms be playing a dual anion/cation role in this Se-rich (5 Se per formula unit) structure?

The Ba-Bi-O family presents a striking trend: Ba2Bi2O7 (GII 0.20), Ba4Bi2O9 (GII 0.34), and Ba6Bi2O11 (GII 0.33) are all novel and charge-neutral, but as the Ba:Bi ratio increases beyond 2:2, the GII worsens -- is the 2:2 stoichiometry an optimal balance point where Ba2+ and Bi5+ coordination requirements are simultaneously satisfied, and could this explain why Ba3Bi4O and Ba5Bi3O fail to even produce valid oxidation state assignments?

PbSe2O7 is notable for being an oxychalcogenide that actually matches its most common experimental space group (SG 14, P2_1/c, 57% prevalence), yet its family member Pb2Se3O8 shows dramatically worse bonding: GII of 0.74 v.u. and a residual charge of -2.0 -- does the 1:2 Pb:Se ratio in PbSe2O7 represent a compositional sweet spot that avoids the charge imbalance problems that emerge when additional Pb and Se are introduced?

Na3U4O12 fails charge neutrality with a residual of -1.0 and uses only single-method oxidation state assignment, yet its U sites show remarkably consistent BVS of 5.34 v.u. against expected U5+ -- within the Na-U-O family, the computationally known NaU5O12 and Na5UO5 also carry charge residuals of -3.0 and 0.0 respectively, suggesting that does U5+ even represent the correct oxidation state, or could mixed U4+/U5+ valence resolve both the charge imbalance and the cubic SG 204 symmetry?

U(IO)2 is an oxyhalide with 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations across all 4 checked bonds (the maximum possible score), yet its BVS is quite reasonable at GII 0.20 v.u. -- its family member UIO2 in Pnma is computationally known with similar GII of 0.22, suggesting the U-I-O bonding topology is fundamentally incompatible with Pauling's electrostatic valence rule: is the highly covalent nature of U-I bonds making the ionic Pauling framework inapplicable here?

Er3Ta17O47 has an unusually large unit cell (67 sites) with a massive Ta:Er ratio of 17:3, yet achieves a low GII of 0.20 v.u. and only 4.3% Pauling violations -- however, all three Er sites are severely underbonded (BVS 2.26-2.34 v.u. vs expected 3+, deviations of 22-25%), while Ta sites presumably compensate: does this systematic Er underbonding indicate that the Er3+ ions occupy oversized cavities in the Ta-O framework, and could this predict mechanical instability or cation mobility?

In(BiO3)2 adopts tetragonal SG 136 despite experimental In-Bi-O compounds favoring orthorhombic settings (SG 33 and 62), and while all validators pass cleanly (charge neutral, zero Shannon violations, zero Pauling violations across 12 bonds), its family member InBi3O7 has a dramatically worse GII of 0.86 v.u. and a -4.0 charge residual -- what makes the 1:2 In:Bi stoichiometry so much more structurally viable than 1:3, given that both contain Bi in the same 5+ oxidation state?

UCl4O sits within a U-Cl-O family where the computationally known members UClO2 (GII 0.21) and UCl3O (GII 0.18) both have lower GII values in lower Cl:U ratios -- UCl4O itself shows oxygen overbonding at BVS -2.36 (18.1% deviation) while Cl is nearly perfect at BVS -0.99: does the crowding of four Cl- around U6+ force the single O2- into an over-compressed coordination environment, and is there a maximum Cl:U ratio beyond which U-oxychlorides become geometrically untenable?

Tl2Sb4O7 is the only member of the Tl-Sb-O family in triclinic SG 2 with a non-zero Shannon radii violation (0.049), unique among the 25 materials in this batch -- across the family, GII worsens progressively: Tl2Sb4O7 (0.19), TlSb5O13 (0.35), Tl3SbO7 (0.63), Tl(SbO3)3 (0.66): does the anomalous ionic radius mismatch in this compound reflect the well-known difficulty of accommodating Tl+ lone-pair stereochemistry in structures that simultaneously must host Sb3+ lone pairs?

Y2As4O9 is computationally known but GNoME predicts it in triclinic SG 2 rather than the tetragonal SG 141 (I4_1/amd) seen in 100% of experimental Y-As-O structures -- with all Y sites underbonded at BVS 2.61-2.66 (11-13% deviation from expected Y3+), could this triclinic polymorph represent a metastable high-pressure phase where the Y coordination environment is systematically expanded compared to the known tetragonal form?

GdHO and TbHO (also in this batch) are both rare-earth oxyhydrides in cubic SG 216 (F-43m) with strikingly parallel validation profiles: Gd shows H- at BVS -1.16 (16% overbonded) and O2- at -1.73 (13.4% underbonded), while Tb shows H- at -1.17 (17.4% overbonded) and O2- at -1.75 (12.7% underbonded) -- does this systematic H- overbonding pattern across the lanthanide series indicate that the BVS reference parameters for hydride in fluorite-type structures need recalibration, or is it evidence of genuine anion site disorder?

Mg4Bi2O9 achieves perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across all 18 bonds in trigonal SG 165, yet every Mg site is substantially underbonded at BVS 1.68 v.u. (16.1% below expected 2+) -- given that the known Mg-Bi-O system experimentally prefers tetragonal SG 136 (100% prevalence), could this trigonal structure represent a lattice expansion where the Mg-O bonds are systematically stretched, and would this predict anomalously low bulk modulus or thermal expansion coefficients?

Ba4Nb5O15 presents a triple red flag: methods disagree on oxidation states, it is flagged as mixed-valence, and charge neutrality fails at -2.0 residual, with an extreme 80% Pauling Rule 2 violation rate across 15 bonds -- across the Ba-Nb-O family, Ba6Nb7O21 (computationally known, GII 0.22) also has a -2.0 charge residual: is the persistent charge deficit in this family evidence that Nb adopts a non-standard oxidation state (perhaps Nb4+ alongside Nb5+) that neither assignment method captures correctly?

Rb5As3O10 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling/Shannon violations, yet all Rb sites show severe underbonding at BVS 0.59 v.u. (41% below expected 1+), the largest alkali metal BVS deficit in this batch -- its family member Rb3AsO3 (also computationally known) achieves GII 0.32 with a simpler stoichiometry: does the 5:3 Rb:As ratio create an excess of large cavities that leave Rb+ ions rattling in oversized coordination environments, potentially making this a candidate for fast-ion conduction?

SrU9O20 combines mixed valence uranium with a charge residual of -2.0 and a very low bandgap of 0.0009 eV (essentially metallic), yet its BVS is reasonable at GII 0.19 -- across the Sr-U-O family, GII actually decreases as U content increases: SrU4O11 (0.23), SrU9O20 (0.19), SrU8O18 (0.16), Sr2U11O26 (0.17): does this trend indicate that U-rich compositions allow more flexible U-O polyhedral tilting that improves local bonding, and could the near-zero bandgap arise from U 5f band overlap in these U-dense frameworks?

LiU8O18 has the worst single-site BVS deviation in this batch: Li shows BVS of only 0.39 v.u. against expected 1+, a 61.2% deficit, alongside a -3.0 charge residual and single-method oxidation state assignment -- given that the only family member Li5UO5 (novel, GII 0.34) has the inverse Li:U ratio, is the extreme Li underbonding evidence that Li+ occupies an interstitial-like site in the U-O framework rather than a true crystallographic position, potentially enabling lithium-ion mobility?

K6NpO6 is computationally known in trigonal SG 148 but experimental K-Np-O compounds exclusively adopt monoclinic SG 14 -- across the K-Np-O family, the GII improves dramatically from K6NpO6 (0.19) to K3NpO4 (0.25) to K2Np2O7 (0.11) as the K:Np ratio decreases: does the trend toward better bonding with more Np suggest that the high-K compositions force K+ into unfavorable coordination (BVS 0.81, 18.8% deficit), and is K2Np2O7 with its exceptional GII of 0.11 the thermodynamic ground state of this system?

K2Bi4O7 has the largest unit cell in this batch at 104 sites and is the only material with a non-zero space group compatibility score (0.17, matching SG 15 at 17% prevalence), yet its K sites are severely underbonded at BVS 0.66 (34.4% deficit) -- with 36% Pauling violations across 50 bonds, does the 104-atom cell arise from a superstructure that accommodates Bi3+ lone-pair-driven distortions at the cost of creating oversized K+ cavities, and would a smaller cell with fewer Bi lone pairs improve the K bonding?

Ti6C4O is a remarkable oxycarbide (computationally known) where carbon exists as C4- with BVS -4.24 (only 6% deviation), but the sole O site triggers 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation -- across 5 Ti-C-O family members, all show significant charge residuals (-1 to -8) and elevated GII (0.36-0.57) except Ti6C4O itself (GII 0.19, charge 0.0): what makes this specific Ti:C:O ratio of 6:4:1 uniquely stable, and does the dominance of carbide character over oxide character explain why it passes checks that other Ti-C-O compositions fail?

MoO2F is a computationally known oxyfluoride where Mo shows BVS of 4.65 v.u. against expected 5+ (7% underbonded) and F shows BVS of -0.75 (24.7% underbonded) -- given that the predicted SG 4 (P2_1) differs from the 100% experimental preference for SG 14 (P2_1/c), could GNoME be predicting a non-centrosymmetric polymorph where the Mo-F bond elongation breaks inversion symmetry, potentially conferring useful nonlinear optical or piezoelectric properties?

Na2Ir2O7 has 6 novel Na-Ir-O family members but none with computable GII except Na6IrO6 (0.28) and Na5Ir3O8 (0.44, charge -2.0) -- in Na2Ir2O7 itself, Ir6+ is slightly overbonded at BVS 6.36 while Na+ is severely underbonded at 0.69 (30.7% deficit): given the pyrochlore-like A2B2O7 stoichiometry and the extremely low bandgap of 0.0018 eV, could this be a candidate Weyl semimetal where the Na underbonding reflects large A-site cavities characteristic of frustrated pyrochlore geometry?

TbHO mirrors GdHO in cubic SG 216 with nearly identical BVS patterns (H- overbonded at -1.17, O2- underbonded at -1.75, Tb3+ nearly perfect at 2.92), but TbHO has a notably higher bandgap of 3.61 eV versus GdHO's 2.54 eV -- given the lanthanide contraction from Gd to Tb is only ~0.02 Angstroms, what electronic mechanism produces this 1.07 eV bandgap jump, and does the half-filled 4f7 configuration of Gd3+ versus Tb3+'s 4f8 create fundamentally different f-d transition energies in this fluorite-type oxyhydride?

Nd2Mo5O18 has an unusually large unit cell (100 sites) in orthorhombic SG 60 with a high Mo:Nd ratio of 5:2, yet achieves excellent validation scores: only 6% Pauling violations across 50 bonds and GII of 0.18 -- however, all Nd sites are uniformly underbonded at BVS 2.63 (12.4% deficit), while the only family member Nd6MoO12 (computationally known, inverse Mo:Nd ratio) has a much worse GII of 0.50: does this suggest Mo-rich compositions form more geometrically favorable polyhedral networks, with Nd acting as a space-filler in the Mo-O framework?

Tl2W3O10 has the worst single-element BVS in the Tl-containing compounds of this batch: all Tl sites at BVS 0.61 (38.6% underbonded from expected 1+), combined with 26% Pauling violations across 50 bonds -- its family member Tl(WO3)4 carries an extraordinary -9.0 charge residual suggesting catastrophic oxidation state misassignment, while Tl6W2O9 (charge neutral, GII 0.36) performs better: is there a fundamental incompatibility between the Tl+ lone pair and the W6+O4 tetrahedral framework in W-rich compositions, and does this explain why no experimental Tl-W-O phases adopt these high-W stoichiometries?

Across the Li-Os-O family, GII values decrease monotonically with increasing Li:Os ratio -- Li3(OsO3)4 at 0.081, Li7(OsO3)8 at 0.092, Li6OsO6 at 0.142, Li4OsO6 at 0.150, Li2OsO4 at 0.204, and LiOs3O8 at 0.314 -- yet Li4OsO5 sits at GII 0.177 with Li BVS values of only 0.786-0.808 v.u. (21% underbonded). Does the triclinic P-1 structure create Li coordination cavities that are systematically oversized, and could this underbonding indicate Li-ion mobility relevant to solid-state electrolyte applications?

Bi3IrO7 is computationally known yet adopts triclinic P-1 (SG 2) while 100% of experimental Bi-Ir oxides crystallize in the cubic pyrochlore structure Fd-3m (SG 227) -- a dramatic symmetry mismatch. Given that Bi BVS values are 2.547 v.u. versus the expected 3+ (15.1% underbonded), does GNoME's DFT relaxation systematically distort the pyrochlore A-site to accommodate Bi3+'s lone pair, producing a triclinic ground state that might represent a low-temperature phase inaccessible to conventional synthesis?

Ba7Os4O19 is a novel prediction with a remarkably low GII of 0.177 and zero Pauling violations across all 19 bonds checked, yet within the Ba-Os-O family, charge neutrality failures are widespread: Ba2(OsO4)3 at -2.0, Ba2(OsO3)3 at -4.0, BaOs5O13 at -8.0, and Ba2Os7O18 at -4.0. Given that Ba7Os4O19 achieves perfect charge balance while the one Ba site shows BVS of 2.427 v.u. (21% overbonded), is this specific Ba:Os ratio of 7:4 a stability sweet spot that avoids the Os oxidation state ambiguity plaguing the rest of the family?

Eu2(SeO3)3 is flagged as an oxychalcogenide yet achieves a Pauling violation score of 0.0 across all 18 bonds despite the warning that the O2- assumption may not hold for Se-containing compounds. However, all three Eu sites show identical BVS of 2.66 v.u. (11.3% underbonded from Eu3+). Given that the Eu-Se-O family members show uniformly high GII values -- Eu3SeO7 at 0.626, EuSeO at 0.530, Eu2(SeO4)3 at 0.428 -- does the selenite (SeO3)2- structural unit provide unusually favorable Eu3+ coordination compared to other Se-O stoichiometries, and is the hexagonal P6_3/m structure stabilizing this motif?

NiSe2O7 shows a striking split in bond valence accuracy: Se6+ sites are nearly perfectly bonded at BVS 5.827 v.u. (2.9% deviation), while both Ni2+ sites are severely underbonded at 1.56-1.589 v.u. (20-22% deviation). With this oxychalcogenide classified as novel and both oxi methods agreeing on the assignments, does the 20% Ni underbonding suggest that the DFT-relaxed structure places Ni in coordination environments with Ni-O distances that are systematically too long, potentially indicating a Jahn-Teller-like distortion not captured by the BVS parameterization?

UCl3O is an oxyhalide with zero Pauling violations across its 4 checked bonds but shows systematic O overbonding -- all O sites have BVS of -2.337 v.u. (16.9% overbonded). Within the U-Cl-O family, GII values are remarkably consistent: UCl3O at 0.175, UCl4O at 0.195, and UClO2 at 0.211. Does this progressive GII increase from Cl-rich to O-rich compositions reflect a fundamental competition between U-Cl and U-O bond lengths, where higher chlorine content actually relieves strain on the oxygen sublattice?

Cs2Ge4O9 is a novel prediction where both Cs+ sites are dramatically underbonded -- BVS of 0.613-0.651 v.u. representing 35-39% deviation from the expected +1 -- the largest alkali underbonding in this batch. The family shows an interesting split: Cs6Ge10O23 (computationally known) has moderate GII of 0.261, while the novel Cs2Ge4O7 has GII 0.675. Given that Cs2Ge4O9 sits between these stoichiometries, does the extreme Cs underbonding indicate that this triclinic structure contains oversized Cs cavities, possibly making it a candidate for Cs-ion conduction or suggesting the structure would prefer a larger cation like Fr or Ba?

Pr2As4O9 is computationally known with a wide bandgap of 3.402 eV and excellent validation metrics -- zero charge residual, zero Shannon violations, and only 11.1% Pauling violations -- yet shows an intriguing BVS pattern: Pr3+ sites at 2.667 v.u. (11.1% underbonded) while one O site registers -1.683 v.u. (15.9% underbonded). The sole family member Pr4As3O4 has a +1.0 charge residual. Does the asymmetric underbonding of both cation and anion sublattices in Pr2As4O9 suggest that this arsenate structure sits in a shallow energy minimum, and could its wide bandgap make it a candidate for UV-transparent optical materials?

Rb3Ta7O19 is a novel 58-site structure with Rb+ sites showing BVS of only 0.671 v.u. (32.9% underbonded) -- the second-largest alkali underbonding in this batch. Its family member RbTa5O13 (computationally known) has a much lower GII of 0.166, while Rb3Ta8O21 shows catastrophic charge failure at -14.0 and GII of 0.367. Given the pattern that higher Rb:Ta ratios correlate with worse structural metrics, does the 3:7 ratio in Rb3Ta7O19 represent the maximum Rb content that Ta-O frameworks can accommodate while maintaining structural integrity, and does the persistent Rb underbonding indicate channel-like Rb sites?

RbSb3O5 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across all 20 bonds, yet its worst BVS deviations are exclusively on oxygen -- three O sites at -1.626 v.u. (18.7% underbonded). The family member RbSb5O13 shows a significantly higher GII of 0.406. Does the consistent oxygen underbonding in RbSb3O5 suggest that the Sb3+ lone pair effect creates asymmetric coordination environments where some O sites receive insufficient bond valence, and could this undercoordination explain why GNoME predicts it in monoclinic P2_1/c rather than the higher-symmetry structures seen experimentally?

Li4Pb5O12 exhibits the most extreme alkali underbonding in this batch: two Li+ sites at BVS 0.555 v.u. (44.5% deviation from expected +1), while Pb4+ is nearly ideal at 4.186 v.u. (4.6% deviation). Remarkably, both family members -- Li(PbO2)4 and Li(PbO2)6 -- have null GII and charge data, suggesting the pipeline could not assign oxidation states. Does the severe Li underbonding indicate that the trigonal P-3 structure contains Li sites in cavities far too large for Li+, potentially making this material a fast Li-ion conductor, or does it instead suggest that the DFT-relaxed structure is metastable?

Ti5OF14 is a computationally known mixed-valence oxyhalide with a charge neutrality residual of -1.0 and a Pauling violation score of 1.0 (the only bond checked violated), yet its GII of 0.172 is remarkably low. All three worst BVS deviations are on Ti3+ sites at 2.636-2.687 v.u. (10-12% underbonded). The family shows a pattern of charge failures: Ti2OF5 at -3.0 and Ti4(OF3)3 at -3.0. Does the combination of mixed valence (Ti3+/Ti4+), systematic Ti underbonding, and universal charge neutrality failures across the Ti-O-F family indicate that the assumed oxidation state partitioning is incorrect, and could a Ti3.x+ average valence better describe these fluoride-rich titanium oxyhalides?

CaU3O8 adopts the high-symmetry cubic Pm-3m (SG 221) structure -- rare in this dataset -- yet has a charge residual of -2.0 and only single-method oxi confidence. Strikingly, charge neutrality failures pervade the entire Ca-U-O family: CaU5O12 at -2.0, Ca5U5O18 at -1.0, Ca5U5O19 at -3.0, Ca5U3O12 at -2.0, CaU9O20 at -2.0, and CaU4O10 at -2.0. Given that U can adopt +4, +5, or +6 oxidation states and every family member fails charge balance, does this systematic pattern indicate that the oxi state guesser consistently mis-assigns the U4+/U5+/U6+ partitioning in calcium uranates, rather than reflecting genuine structural instability?

Na2PtO4 is a novel hexagonal P-62m prediction with Na+ sites showing BVS of 0.719-0.871 v.u. (13-28% underbonded) and an unusually high Pauling violation score of 0.25. The Na-Pt-O family is strikingly prolific -- 8 members spanning Na:Pt ratios from 1:3 to 6:1 -- with GII values that decrease at higher Na content: Na6PtO6 at 0.062, Na4PtO5 at 0.102, Na2Pt3O8 at 0.118. Does this inverse correlation between Na content and structural strain suggest that Pt4+ prefers higher-coordination oxygen environments that naturally form when more Na+ is present, and does Na2PtO4's intermediate position on this trend predict moderate synthesizability?

Li4PtO5 is a novel triclinic prediction with Li BVS values of 0.795-0.818 v.u. (18-21% underbonded), mirroring the Li underbonding seen in the isostructural Li4OsO5 (BVS 0.786-0.808). Across the Li-Pt-O family, charge-neutral members show a clear GII hierarchy: Li6PtO6 at 0.138, LiPt3O8 at 0.149, Li4Pt5O12 at 0.321 -- while Pt-rich compositions with known structures (Li(Pt3O4)4, Li3(Pt3O4)4) show severe charge failures and GII above 0.4. Does the consistent ~20% Li underbonding across both Li4PtO5 and Li4OsO5 point to a structural archetype where tetrahedral Li sites are universally oversized in A4MO5 compounds?

Eu(B3O5)2 is a novel 68-site monoclinic structure -- one of the largest unit cells in this batch -- with zero Pauling violations across all 40 bonds and perfect charge neutrality. However, the Eu BVS reveals an unexpected result: all three Eu sites show BVS of 2.539 v.u. versus an expected +2, meaning Eu is 27% overbonded rather than underbonded. This suggests Eu2+ in an unusually compressed coordination environment. Given that europium borates are known phosphor hosts, does this overbonding indicate that the B3O5 borate framework imposes a cage-like constraint on Eu2+ that could enhance its 4f-5d emission properties?

Bi2Mo4O15 stands out with the highest space group validation score in this batch (0.385) -- its predicted monoclinic P2_1/c matches the 38% frequency of SG 14 in experimental Bi-Mo oxides -- and also shows a non-zero Shannon radii violation of 0.032. With all Mo6+ sites showing identical BVS of 5.686 v.u. (5.2% underbonded) and the lone family member Bi3MoO7 having GII of 0.319, does the unusually good space group agreement suggest that GNoME has reproduced a known structural motif for bismuth molybdates, and does the slight Shannon violation hint at a borderline ionic radius mismatch between Bi3+ and Mo6+ in shared polyhedral layers?

Sr2U11O26 combines three red flags: a charge residual of -4.0, methods_disagree oxi confidence, and mixed valence -- yet achieves a surprisingly low GII of 0.167. Its family member SrU4O11 (computationally known, GII 0.229) is charge-neutral, while SrU8O18 and SrU9O20 share the -2.0 charge residual pattern. With Sr BVS at 2.231 v.u. (11.5% overbonded) and U at 3.769 v.u. in a 39-site triclinic cell, does the disagreement between oxi methods reflect genuine U4+/U5+ mixed valence in this uranium-rich phase, and could the low GII despite charge failure indicate that BVS is insensitive to the specific U oxidation state partitioning?

U3O7F is a computationally known oxyhalide where the fluorine site shows BVS of -0.781 v.u. (21.9% underbonded from expected -1), suggesting F occupies a site that is too spacious. Its Pauling violation score of 0.286 with only 7 bonds checked carries a warning flag. The U-O-F family shows consistent charge neutrality: U3O7F, UO2F, and U5O12F all at 0.0 residual, with GII values of 0.166, 0.138, and 0.204 respectively. Does the systematic F underbonding across the orthorhombic Cmmm structure suggest that this U5+ oxyfluoride has F in a site designed for O2-, and could partial O/F disorder lower the energy?

RbTa5O13 appears as both a standalone entry (computationally known, orthorhombic Ama2, GII 0.166) and as a family member of Rb3Ta7O19 (novel, triclinic P-1, GII 0.173). These two structures have nearly identical GII yet fundamentally different symmetries and Rb:Ta ratios (1:5 vs 3:7). With RbTa5O13 showing Ta BVS of 4.694 v.u. (6.1% underbonded) and zero Pauling violations across 26 bonds, while Rb3Ta8O21 shows catastrophic charge failure at -14.0, does the Rb-Ta-O system exhibit a sharp compositional cliff where adding even small amounts of Rb beyond the 1:5 ratio destabilizes the tantalate framework?

Eu3Ta4O14 is a novel trigonal R-3m prediction with three simultaneous warning signs: a charge residual of -2.0, methods_disagree oxi confidence, and mixed valence -- yet both Eu and Ta pass Shannon radii checks. The family member EuTa4O11 (novel, GII 0.240) is charge-neutral, while Eu6TaO12 (computationally known) has null GII. With all three worst BVS deviations on O at -1.782 v.u. (10.9% underbonded), does the oxygen underbonding combined with oxi method disagreement suggest that the true Eu valence is intermediate between 2+ and 3+, and could this mixed-valent europium tantalate exhibit interesting magnetic or optical properties from the coexistence of 4f6 and 4f7 configurations?

SrU8O18 is a novel mixed-valence uranium oxide with a charge residual of -2.0, yet its GII of 0.164 is lower than the charge-neutral family member SrU4O11 (GII 0.229). Sr shows BVS of 2.288 v.u. (14.4% overbonded) while U sites are at 3.770 v.u. (5.7% underbonded from U4+). The family member Sr2U11O26 also appears in this batch with an even worse charge residual of -4.0 but similar GII of 0.167. Does the pattern of better GII at higher U:Sr ratios (8:1 beats 4:1) suggest that uranium-rich compositions provide more structural flexibility to accommodate the large Sr2+ cation, and is the systematic charge failure an artifact of incorrect U4+/U5+ partitioning rather than true instability?

Sr(OsO3)3 is computationally known with a charge residual of -2.0 and single-method oxi confidence, yet achieves zero Pauling violations across all 18 bonds. The Sr-Os-O family exhibits a dramatic GII range: SrOsO5 at 0.299, Sr4Os6O19 at 0.404, Sr5(OsO6)2 at 0.498, Sr3(OsO5)2 at 0.435, Sr2(OsO3)3 at 0.564, and SrOs5O13 at 0.696 -- with GII increasing as Os content grows. Given that Sr(OsO3)3 itself has GII of only 0.163, far below any family member, does this compound represent an anomalously stable island in the Sr-Os-O compositional space, and does the -2.0 charge failure reflect difficulty assigning Os oxidation states rather than structural implausibility?

Bi3(Pt2O7)2 is a novel trigonal R-3m prediction with a charge residual of -3.0, yet all three Bi sites show BVS of 3.199 v.u. -- nearly perfect for Bi3+ at only 6.6% deviation. The family member Bi2PtO6 (computationally known) has an extremely high GII of 0.839, while Bi3PtO7 (novel) sits at 0.266. With Bi3(Pt2O7)2 at GII 0.163, the Bi-rich compositions appear progressively more strained: does the Bi3:Pt4 ratio optimize a fluorite-related superstructure where Bi3+'s stereochemically active lone pair is better accommodated in the trigonal symmetry, and does the -3.0 charge residual indicate that some Pt must adopt a +5 state not captured by the oxi guesser?

Fe2Te3O8 is a novel oxychalcogenide with the highest Pauling violation score in this batch (0.50 -- half of all 16 bonds checked are violated) yet carries a warning that the O2- assumption may not hold. Te4+ shows BVS of 4.40 v.u. (10% overbonded) while Fe2+ is at 1.77 v.u. (11.5% underbonded), creating a push-pull pattern. With a wide bandgap of 2.727 eV and charge neutrality of 0.0 despite the oxychalcogenide classification, does the extreme Pauling violation rate reflect the genuine structural chemistry of tellurite units (TeO3 pyramids with lone pairs) rather than instability, since Pauling's electrostatic rule was formulated for fully ionic oxides and may systematically overcall violations in lone-pair-containing chalcogenide structures?

In(ReO4)3 in SG 176 (hexagonal) shows In3+ systematically underbonded at BVS 2.391 vs expected 3 (20.3% deviation) while Re7+ is nearly ideal at 7.103 -- given that the computationally known polymorph crystallizes in SG 148 (rhombohedral, 100% of experimental analogues), could the hexagonal P6_3/m setting be introducing a coordination geometry for In that is too spacious, and would a distortion toward the R-3 setting relieve the In underbonding?

Novel U(SbO2)6 achieves remarkably low GII (0.162) with U6+ at BVS 6.592 (9.9% over) and Sb3+ at 2.849 (5.0% under), yet the only U-Sb-O family member U2SbO2 has a completely different stoichiometry, a charge imbalance of -1.0, and is computationally known -- does the trigonal SG 148 structure of U(SbO2)6 represent a genuinely new topology for actinide antimonites, or could it be an artifact of GNoME extrapolating from the sparse U-Sb-O training data?

CoSe2O7 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with 14.3% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 14 bonds and Co2+ underbonded at BVS 1.701 (15% deviation) -- its family member Co2SeO6 in Cmce shows a much higher GII of 0.707, suggesting Co-Se-O bonding is generally strained. Given that experimental CoSe compounds preferentially adopt SG 62 (33%) or 14 (17%) rather than the predicted SG 4, is the monoclinic P2_1 setting forcing an unfavorable Co coordination that drives both the Pauling violations and the Co underbonding?

UBr3O is one of four U-Br-O family members spanning stoichiometries from UBr3O to U2Br8O, and it uniquely matches its experimental SG (P2_1/c, SG 14 at 50% probability, space group score 0.5) -- across the family, GII values are remarkably consistent (0.156-0.161) except for U(BrO)2 at 0.375. Why does shifting from Br-rich U2Br8O (GII 0.156) to O-rich U(BrO)2 (GII 0.375) more than double the structural strain, when both are charge-neutral and computationally known?

UBr4O adopts tetragonal I4/m (SG 87) but experimental analogues split 50/50 between SG 14 and SG 63 -- notably, oxygen is the most strained site with BVS -2.358 (17.9% overbonded), which is considerably worse than family member UBr3O where O shows 14.4% deviation. Does the Br-heavy stoichiometry in UBr4O create an oxygen site that is over-coordinated by uranium, and could this explain why no tetragonal polymorph appears in the experimental space group distribution?

Ti(SeO4)2 is a novel oxychalcogenide predicted in trigonal SG 147 while 100% of experimental analogues crystallize in monoclinic SG 14 -- its family reveals a striking GII gradient: TiSeO5 at 0.102 (SG P1), Ti(SeO4)2 at 0.161 (SG P-3), and TiSe2O7 at 0.505 (SG P-1). Does increasing the Se:Ti ratio progressively destabilize the structure because Se6+ tetrahedral selenate groups become geometrically incompatible at higher concentrations, and is the SG 147 prediction an attempt by GNoME to accommodate this strain through higher symmetry?
