Ac3RuO7 achieves charge neutrality and passes Shannon radii checks, but shows a GII of 2.27 v.u. with both Ru sites identically underbonded at BVS 2.73 vs. expected +5 (45.5% deviation) -- its Ac-Ru family members Ac5(RuO6)2 (GII 1.39) and Ac4Ru6O19 (GII 1.02) show lower but still elevated GII values, suggesting that actinium's very large ionic radius (1.12 A for Ac3+ in 6-fold coordination) may create oxide frameworks where Ru-O distances are systematically elongated; is this the largest A-site cation paired with Ru in the GNoME dataset, and does the GII improve predictably as the Ac:Ru ratio decreases?

Os(RuO3)2 adopts the rutile-derived P4_2/mnm structure (SG 136) with charge neutrality and perfect Pauling scores (0/12 violations), yet all three Ru sites show nearly identical BVS values of 2.79-2.79 v.u. against expected +5, yielding GII 2.21 -- this tetragonal structure is shared with the much better-performing Ru2PtO6 (same SG 136, GII 1.97) and V2PtO6 (GII 1.66); does the systematic improvement in GII when replacing Os with Pt or V suggest that the P4_2/mnm framework specifically penalizes 5d transition metals with strong spin-orbit coupling?

OsRu3O8 achieves charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations (0/8 checked) in C2/m (SG 12), with all three Ru sites consistently underbonded at BVS 2.84-2.90 vs. expected +5 -- at GII 2.14, this is the best-performing member of the Os-Ru family yet still ~10x the ICSD baseline; given that Ru3O8-type stoichiometries are not known experimentally for any platinum group metal combination, could this entire compositional space represent a systematic artifact where GNoME's training data from binary RuO2 and OsO2 structures is being erroneously extrapolated to ternary compositions that violate fundamental bonding constraints?

ReTcO4 achieves charge neutrality with zero Shannon and Pauling violations, and its GII of 2.05 v.u. is moderate -- but its Re-Tc family tells a remarkable story: seven other compositions spanning Re7TcO28 (GII 0.13), ReTcO7 (GII 0.04), Re(TcO4)3 (GII 0.07), and Re(TcO4)7 (GII 0.05) all achieve GII below 0.21 and charge neutrality; why does the simplest 1:1 stoichiometry ReTcO4 show 50x worse bonding than the closely related ReTcO7, and does the orthorhombic P2_12_12_1 structure of ReTcO4 force Re7+ and Tc7+ into incompatible coordination polyhedra that the higher-oxygen stoichiometries avoid?

Tc3RuO12 in R-3c (SG 167) has 24 Pauling-checked anion neighbors with zero violations, yet both Ru sites show identical BVS of 2.95 vs. expected +5 (41% deviation) and the compound carries a -2.0 residual charge -- comparing to its family, the lower-oxygen Tc3RuO8 (P1, GII 2.28) and intermediate Tc2RuO8 (P-3m1, GII 1.89) show a non-monotonic relationship between oxygen content and structural quality; does the high-symmetry R-3c framework constrain Tc-O-Ru bond angles in ways that prevent optimal Ru coordination despite providing more oxide ligands?

Ru2PtO6 in P4_2/mnm (SG 136) achieves charge neutrality with zero Shannon and Pauling violations (0/12 checked), and all three Ru sites show identical BVS of 3.03 vs. expected +5 (39% deviation) at GII 1.97 v.u. -- its sole family member Ru5PtO12 (Cmmm, GII 0.91, charge -2.0) shows dramatically better bonding with a higher Ru:Pt ratio; does this suggest that the tetragonal rutile-type framework systematically compresses Pt4+ sites at the expense of Ru-O bond lengths, and would a composition closer to Ru3PtO8 potentially optimize both sublattices?

Np2UO6 is computationally known (Immm, SG 71) with perfect charge neutrality, Shannon, and Pauling scores, yet uranium shows BVS of 4.04 vs. expected +6 (33% deviation) giving GII 1.96 v.u. -- within its Np-U family, the novel compositions NpUO5 (GII 0.28), NpU5O12 (GII 0.24), and Np3U7O20 (GII 0.20) all achieve dramatically better bonding in monoclinic C2/m or C2/c structures; does the orthorhombic Immm framework impose coordination constraints on U6+ that the lower-symmetry monoclinic structures relax, and does the trend of decreasing GII with increasing U:Np ratio suggest uranium-rich compositions better accommodate the actinide bonding requirements?

Np4UO10 in tetragonal I4/m (SG 87) carries a -2.0 residual charge and shows U at BVS 4.07 vs. expected +6 (32% deviation), yielding GII 1.93 -- remarkably, across its Np-U family, there is a near-perfect inverse correlation between charge residual magnitude and GII: Np3U7O20 (charge -3.0, GII 0.20), NpU5O12 (charge -1.0, GII 0.24), NpUO5 (charge 0.0, GII 0.28), Np2UO6 (charge 0.0, GII 1.96), Np4UO10 (charge -2.0, GII 1.93) -- the Np-rich stoichiometries break this trend; does this indicate that the oxi_state_guesses method systematically misassigns neptunium's oxidation state in Np-rich compositions, perhaps confusing Np4+ with Np5+?

Tc2RuO8 in trigonal P-3m1 (SG 164) shows 25% Pauling Rule 2 violations (2/8 anion neighbors) alongside Ru at BVS 3.11 vs. expected +5 (38% deviation) and GII 1.89 v.u. -- this is the best-performing member of the Tc-Ru family, yet it is the only one with non-zero Pauling violations; is there a trade-off where the P-3m1 structure partially satisfies Ru bonding requirements at the cost of Pauling electrostatic rule violations around specific oxygen sites, effectively redistributing strain from bond-length mismatch to electrostatic imbalance?

PIO4 is classified as an oxyhalide but its BVS analysis reveals P sites at 6.50 and 6.49 vs. expected +3, while I shows BVS 2.18 vs. expected +5 -- with both oxidation state methods disagreeing, could the correct assignment actually be P5+ (matching the BVS of ~6.5 which is closer to P5+ tetrahedral coordination) and I- or I3+ rather than the guessed P3+/I5+ combination, and does the charge-neutral result with the current assignment mask a fundamentally incorrect oxidation state picture that the BVS is actually detecting?

V2PtO6 adopts the same P4_2/mnm rutile-type structure (SG 136) as Ru2PtO6, but achieves significantly better bonding with GII 1.66 vs. 1.97, with all three V sites showing identical BVS of 3.34 vs. expected +5 (33% deviation) -- this 16% improvement in GII when substituting Ru for V in the same framework, despite V5+ and Ru5+ having similar ionic radii (0.54 vs. 0.565 A in 6-fold coordination), suggests a subtle electronic rather than geometric origin; could V's preference for off-center displacement in VO6 octahedra (second-order Jahn-Teller effect) actually be partially accommodated by the tetragonal distortion of the rutile framework?

Tl(TcO4)2 in trigonal R3 (SG 146) carries a -3.0 residual charge and shows remarkably divergent BVS across its three Tl sites: one severely underbonded at 0.85 (72% deviation from expected +3), one overbonded at 4.74 (58% deviation), and one moderate at 2.29 (24% deviation) -- this extreme site-to-site variation in a supposedly single-valence Tl3+ compound suggests the structure may actually require mixed Tl+/Tl3+ occupation; could the underbonded site (BVS 0.85) be Tl+ while the overbonded site (BVS 4.74) reflects forced coordination geometry, and would a mixed-valence assignment resolve the -3.0 charge residual?

Y6Tc16O in cubic Im-3m (SG 229) achieves charge neutrality but shows a bizarre bonding picture: all three Y sites have BVS of only 0.24 vs. expected +3 (92% underbonded) and 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations (1/1 checked), yet Shannon radii pass -- with 16 Tc atoms to just 1 oxygen in a 23-site unit cell, is this effectively a Tc-rich intermetallic with a trace oxygen impurity rather than a true oxide, and does the near-zero Y BVS indicate that Y atoms are coordinated almost exclusively by Tc rather than O, making oxide-based validators fundamentally inapplicable?

Ho6Tc16O shows nearly identical behavior to its Y6Tc16O analog -- same SG 229, same 92% Y/Ho underbonding (BVS 0.25 vs. expected +3), same 100% Pauling violation rate -- but is classified as novel rather than computationally known; given that Y3+ and Ho3+ have virtually identical ionic radii (0.90 vs. 0.901 A in 6-fold coordination) and the computationally known Y6Tc16O differs by only 0.005 in GII (1.64 vs. 1.64), does this represent a trivial lanthanide substitution that GNoME counted as a 'novel' prediction, and does the family data (Ho5(TcO6)2 at GII 0.36, Ho(TcO4)3 at GII 0.36) suggest that Ho-Tc compounds with normal oxide stoichiometries are far more plausible?

Tb6Tc16O is the third member of the RE6Tc16O series (alongside Y and Ho analogs) in SG 229, with Tb at BVS 0.26 vs. expected +3 (91% underbonded) and GII 1.63 -- its family members TbTcO5 (GII 0.15) and Tb2TcO6 (GII 0.25) achieve order-of-magnitude better bonding with conventional oxide stoichiometries; given that GNoME predicts this entire RE6Tc16O isostructural series as stable, yet BVS analysis shows the rare earth sites are essentially non-bonded to oxygen in all three cases, is the GNN misinterpreting metallic Tc-Tc bonding networks (common in Tc metal) as oxide-compatible frameworks, and should these be reclassified as intermetallic compounds with incidental oxygen?

Gd6Tc16O has a severely underbonded Gd site (BVS 0.29 v.u. vs expected 3+, deviation 90%), yet all four Gd-Tc-O family members (Gd(TcO4)3, Gd3TcO7, Gd2TcO5, Gd2TcO6) achieve GII values of 0.27-0.38 v.u. with charge neutrality -- does the extreme Tc:O ratio of 16:1 in this cubic Im-3m structure imply a metallic Tc sublattice where the single oxygen is essentially interstitial, making the BVS framework inapplicable because the bonding is predominantly Tc-Tc rather than ionic?

Rb(PdO2)3 is flagged as mixed-valence with a +2.0 charge imbalance and Pd sites reaching only BVS 1.49-1.69 against an expected +4, while four of its five Rb-Pd-O family members also fail charge neutrality (Rb6(PdO3)5 at -14.0, Rb4(PdO2)3 at -2.0) -- is GNoME systematically struggling with palladium oxidation state assignment across the entire Rb-Pd-O compositional space, and could this reflect Pd's well-known tendency to adopt square-planar Pd2+ coordination that confuses the BV analyzer into assigning Pd4+?

Pu3NiO12 shows Ni with BVS of 1.46 against an expected +3 (deviation 51%), a Pauling Rule 2 violation fraction of 0.33, and a formation energy of -2.45 eV/atom suggesting thermodynamic stability -- given that its sole family member PuNiO4 also shows elevated GII (0.678 v.u.), could the persistent underbonding of Ni indicate that these Pu-Ni-O phases require Ni in an unusual +2 state rather than +3, which would in turn break charge neutrality for Pu3NiO12?

Pr5Si3O is classified as a pure oxide yet carries a massive +4.0 charge residual, has Si assigned negative BVS (-2.14 vs expected -4, deviation 47%), mixed valence, and adopts hexagonal P6_3/mcm (sg 193) -- a space group with zero overlap with the experimentally known sg 14 and 76 for this composition class -- is this actually a Zintl-type intermetallic silicide with incidental oxygen rather than a true oxide, making all ionic validators fundamentally inapplicable?

Se4I2O11, classified as an oxychalcogenide with methods-disagree oxi confidence, shows iodine BVS of +1.87 against an expected -1 (deviation 2.87 v.u.) while simultaneously passing charge neutrality -- does this enormous sign reversal in iodine's effective valence suggest that the BV analyzer assigned I5+ (as in IO3- iodate) while the guesses method assigned I-, and could the 40% Shannon radii violation fraction confirm that whichever assignment was used produces geometrically impossible coordination environments?

Ag7BrO8 is one of the rare computationally known oxyhalides in the dataset yet shows a -4.0 charge residual, 100% Pauling Rule 2 violation (8/8 checked), and Br with BVS -0.16 against an expected +5 -- this dramatic mismatch (deviation 103%) combined with methods-disagree oxi confidence suggests the structure may actually require Br- rather than Br5+; if Br is bromide, how does the charge balance accommodate seven silver atoms, and does the Fm-3m cubic symmetry point toward a fluorite-derived anion-excess structure?

TcHgO4, computationally known in P2_1/c, shows all Hg sites dramatically underbonded (BVS 0.55 vs expected 2+, deviation 73%) despite achieving perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations -- its family member TcHg2O5 has an even worse GII of 1.089 v.u.; given mercury's strong preference for linear 2-coordinate geometry, is the DFT-relaxed structure placing Hg in higher-coordination polyhedra that are geometrically correct for DFT but incompatible with the BVS parameterization that assumes standard Hg-O bond lengths?

Pa5Fe3O16 has a -3.0 charge residual despite being a pure oxide, with two Fe sites severely underbonded (BVS 1.36 vs expected 3+, deviation ~55%) while the third Fe site reaches BVS 2.17 -- this within-structure variance of 0.8 v.u. across chemically identical Fe3+ sites in P2 (sg 3) is striking; does the low-symmetry space group permit such dramatically inequivalent iron environments, or does this suggest the structure should actually contain both Fe2+ and Fe3+ in a mixed-valence arrangement that the oxi_state_guesses method failed to capture?

VTc2O9 shows a -2.0 charge imbalance with V underbonded at BVS 3.58 vs expected 5+ (deviation 28%), and its family member V(TcO4)2 has a catastrophic GII of 2.74 v.u. with -3.0 charge residual -- across both stoichiometries in this V-Tc-O family, neither achieves charge neutrality; is the fundamental issue that Tc7+ (pertechnetate) plus V5+ cannot balance any reasonable oxygen content, suggesting these compositions require Tc in a reduced state (Tc4+ or Tc5+) that the oxi_state_guesses method does not consider?

U(TcO5)2 achieves perfect charge neutrality and zero Shannon violations but shows 60% Pauling Rule 2 violations (6/10 checked) and uranium overbonded at BVS 7.41 vs expected 6+ (deviation 24%) -- given the bandgap of 2.08 eV indicating insulating character, could the uranium overbonding reflect genuine U-O bond compression in this triclinic P-1 structure, and does the high Pauling violation rate suggest the TcO5 polyhedra share edges or faces in a way that is electrostatically unfavorable but stabilized by the high formal charges?

Eu5Np3O14 in trigonal R-3m has a modest -1.0 charge residual but severely underbonded Eu (BVS 1.25 vs expected 3+, deviation 58%), while its family spans a remarkable GII range from 0.025 (EuNpO4, nearly perfect) to 0.609 (Eu6NpO12) -- does the dramatically better validation of EuNpO4 (GII 0.025 in P4/mmm, charge-neutral) compared to this Eu-rich phase suggest that the Eu5Np3 stoichiometry forces europium into coordination environments that are simply too large for Eu3+, and would Eu2+ be a more realistic assignment for the underbonded sites?

Ac5(RuO6)2 shows Ru underbonded at BVS 2.61 vs expected 4+ (deviation 35%) with a -1.0 charge residual, while both Ac-Ru-O family members show severe distress: Ac3RuO7 with GII 2.273 and Ac4Ru6O19 with GII 1.02 and -2.0 charge -- given that actinium is exclusively trivalent and has the largest ionic radius of any trication (1.12 A), is the persistent structural strain across this family driven by the extreme size mismatch between Ac3+ and the relatively small RuO6 octahedra?

Rb2Pd3O7 stands out in the Rb-Pd-O family as the only member with both_agree oxi confidence and perfect charge neutrality, yet its Pd sites are still underbonded at BVS 1.71-1.73 vs expected 4+ (deviation 57%) -- comparing it to Rb(PdO2)3 in the same family which has single_method confidence and +2.0 charge imbalance, does the consensus oxi assignment actually make the BVS situation worse by locking in Pd4+ when the local geometry clearly supports only ~Pd2+ coordination?

Eu4Pa3O12 achieves perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations with both_agree-level Shannon compliance, yet all three Eu sites show BVS of 1.61-1.65 against expected 3+ (deviation 45-46%) -- this uniform underbonding pattern across crystallographically distinct Eu sites suggests a systematic offset rather than local distortion; could the BVS R0 parameters for Eu3+-O2- bonds be poorly calibrated for protactinium-containing host lattices where Pa5+ pulls electron density away from the shared oxygen ligands?

Sb(PdO3)2 in tetragonal P4_2/mnm (sg 136) is charge-neutral with zero Pauling and Shannon violations, yet all Pd sites show BVS of only 1.54 against expected 4+ (deviation 62%) -- this near-identical underbonding across all three Pd sites and the near-zero bandgap (0.021 eV) raise the question: is this actually a metallic or semimetallic phase where the Pd 4d electrons are delocalized rather than participating in localized Pd-O bonds, making the BVS ionic model systematically overestimate the expected valence?

Ni2Pd3O8 in trigonal R-3m achieves both_agree oxi confidence, perfect charge neutrality, and zero Pauling/Shannon violations -- yet Pd is consistently underbonded at BVS 1.84 vs expected 4+ (deviation 54%); given that this material shares the same Pd underbonding pattern as Rb2Pd3O7, Cs2Pd3O7, Sb(PdO3)2, and Cu3PdO6 in this batch, is there a systematic error in the Pd4+-O2- BVS R0 parameter that consistently underestimates Pd valence across diverse chemical environments?

Cs2Pd3O7 is structurally analogous to Rb2Pd3O7 (both P-1 triclinic, both A2Pd3O7, both charge-neutral with both_agree oxi confidence) yet shows slightly lower Pd BVS (1.70-1.71 vs 1.71-1.73) -- does the larger Cs+ ion (1.67 A vs Rb+ 1.52 A) create marginally longer Pd-O bonds through lattice expansion, and does the Cs-Pd-O family's Cs6(PdO3)5 member with -14.0 charge residual suggest that Cs-rich compositions in this system are fundamentally unphysical?

Cu2HgO4, computationally known with methods-disagree oxi confidence, shows Cu underbonded at BVS 1.18 vs expected 3+ (deviation 61%) uniformly across all three Cu sites -- given that Cu3+ is extremely rare in oxide chemistry (found mainly in superconducting cuprates under high-oxygen pressure), is the oxi assignment of Cu3+ the root problem, and would reassignment to Cu2+ with Hg in a higher oxidation state or oxygen non-stoichiometry produce more physically reasonable BVS values?

Pu5UO11 in triclinic P1 (sg 1, the lowest possible symmetry) has -1.0 charge residual and U underbonded at BVS 4.67 vs expected 6+ (deviation 22%), yet its family member PuU3O8 in Pm-3m achieves near-perfect GII of 0.057 despite also carrying -1.0 charge -- does the dramatically better structural validation of the cubic U-rich phase suggest that high uranium content stabilizes the fluorite-type framework, while the Pu-rich Pu5UO11 forces uranium into an undercoordinated environment incompatible with U6+?

P2I2O9, an oxyhalide with charge neutrality and a 2.54 eV bandgap, shows I sites with BVS 2.04 vs expected 5+ (deviation 59%) and P with BVS 6.47 vs expected 4+ (deviation 62%) -- these deviations are in opposite directions (I under, P over), and both PIO family members show elevated GII (0.664 for PIO5, 1.84 for PIO4); does the phosphorus overbonding indicate P-O bonds shorter than the BVS parameterization expects, possibly because phosphate tetrahedra in iodate-containing structures experience compression from the bulky IO3- lone pairs?

Ac5Bi3O14 shows three Bi sites with wildly different BVS values (2.51, 5.15, 5.10 against expected 4+), a -1.0 charge residual, and adopts P1 (sg 1) -- the lowest symmetry possible; its family member Ac3BiO7 achieves near-perfect GII of 0.066 with charge neutrality, while Ac2Bi4O9 (computationally known, GII 0.538) validates moderately; does the enormous Bi BVS variance (2.51 to 5.15) in the P1 structure suggest two distinct Bi oxidation states (Bi3+ and Bi5+) coexisting, which the single Bi4+ assignment cannot capture?

Cr2TcO8 has a -2.0 charge residual with Cr sites showing a striking BVS split: two sites at 2.52-2.60 and one at 5.00, all against expected 4+ -- this pattern strongly suggests the structure contains both Cr3+ and Cr6+ rather than uniform Cr4+; given that Cr4+ is rare while Cr3+ and Cr6+ are common stable states, and the family member Cr(TcO4)2 also shows -1.0 charge residual, does the oxi_state_guesses method's inability to assign mixed Cr valence systematically corrupt the validation across the entire Cr-Tc-O system?

Cu3PdO6 shows mixed valence, methods-disagree oxi confidence, -2.0 charge residual, and Pd underbonded at BVS 1.85 vs expected 4+ -- yet its two family members Cu3PdO4 and CuPd3O4 both achieve perfect charge neutrality despite GII values above 0.95; given the near-zero bandgap (0.003 eV) suggesting metallic behavior, is this structure better described as a conducting oxide where formal oxidation states break down, and does the Cu-Pd site disorder implied by the Cu3PdO4/CuPd3O4 compositional inversion hint at a solid solution rather than an ordered compound?

Np3TlO12 achieves perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling/Shannon violations, yet Tl shows BVS 4.22 against expected 3+ (overbonded by 41%) -- this is unusual because most materials in this batch show underbonding; given that Tl can exist as both Tl+ and Tl3+, and the sole family member Np3Tl3O10 has -8.0 charge residual with GII 1.073, could the Tl overbonding indicate that the structure actually accommodates Tl3+ with shorter-than-expected Tl-O bonds driven by the compact NpO6 framework, while the Tl-rich Np3Tl3O10 composition is simply unphysical?

Fe(TcO4)2 shows a -3.0 charge residual with Fe underbonded at BVS 1.71-1.93 vs expected 3+ (deviation 36-43%), yet its sole family member Fe(TcO4)3 is computationally known with a respectable GII of 0.493 and perfect charge neutrality -- the key difference is the Fe:Tc ratio (1:2 vs 1:3), suggesting Fe3+ with Tc7+ pertechnetate works stoichiometrically at 1:3 but not at 1:2; does this imply Fe(TcO4)2 requires Fe2+ to approach charge balance, and if so, why did the oxi_state_guesses method not consider it?

Eu2Pd2O7 adopts the Fd-3m pyrochlore structure (SG 227) with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across 14 bonds, yet every Pd site shows a BVS of only 1.73 v.u. against an expected +4, yielding a GII of 1.20 -- the highest in the Ln2Pd2O7 series in this batch. Given that Eu is the largest lanthanide represented here, could the expanded A-site be stretching the Pd-O distances beyond what the pyrochlore B-site can accommodate, and does the existence of the alternative Eu2PdO6 phase (P321, GII 0.26) suggest that GNoME's DFT landscape actually favors a lower-Pd-content stoichiometry for europium?

Sm2Pd2O7 is computationally known and shares the identical Fd-3m pyrochlore structure (SG 227, 22 sites) with the novel Ln2Pd2O7 entries, displaying a Pd BVS of 1.74 v.u. versus expected +4 and a GII of 1.18. Since this compound already exists in computational databases while its heavier-lanthanide analogs (Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Lu) are flagged as novel, does the samarium compound serve as a DFT-validated anchor confirming that the systematic Pd under-bonding (~0.57 v.u. deviation) is intrinsic to the pyrochlore topology rather than a sign of structural instability?

Sc(S8O)3 is an oxychalcogenide with a charge neutrality residual of -4.0, 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations (3/3 bonds checked), and oxygen BVS of only -0.64 v.u. against expected -2, all determined by a single oxi-state method. Given that its predicted SG 160 (R3m) contradicts the sole experimentally known space group for this composition type (SG 194, P6_3/mmc), could the extreme sulfur-to-oxygen ratio of 8:1 mean that the oxygen is essentially isolated in a sulfur cage, making the O^2- assumption completely inapplicable and rendering all oxide-calibrated BVS parameters meaningless for this compound?

EuTcO4 is a novel tetragonal (I4_1/amd, SG 141) technetium oxide with a remarkably low formation energy of -2.55 eV/atom and perfect charge neutrality, yet its Eu sites show BVS values of only 1.85 v.u. against expected +3 (GII 1.15). Across its Eu-Tc-O family, GII varies dramatically: Eu6TcO12 (computationally known, GII 0.38) versus Eu(TcO4)2 (novel, GII 0.82) and Eu3TcO7 (novel, GII 0.68). Does the progressive increase in Tc:Eu ratio systematically worsen structural strain, and could EuTcO4 represent a metastable intermediate composition that GNoME predicts precisely because DFT underestimates the difficulty of achieving Tc^7+ coordination in a europium oxide matrix?

Pr2Pt7O18 is a novel triclinic (P-1) compound with an unusually high Pt:Pr ratio of 3.5, a charge neutrality residual of -2.0, and Shannon radii violations at 6.25% of sites -- one of the few non-zero Shannon scores in this batch. Across its Pr-Pt-O family, the charge imbalance persists: Pr5(PtO6)2 has charge -1.0 and Pr4Pt6O19 has charge -2.0, while only Pr2Pt2O7 (Fd-3m, GII 0.33) achieves neutrality. Is the recurring negative charge residual across multiple Pr-Pt-O stoichiometries evidence that oxi-state guessing systematically fails for Pt-rich rare-earth oxides, possibly because Pt is being assigned +4 when the actual bonding environment supports a mixture of +2 and +4?

Tb2Pd2O7 is one of six novel Ln2Pd2O7 pyrochlores in this batch (all SG 227, 22 sites), and it stands out with a bandgap of 0.94 eV -- squarely in the semiconductor range -- compared to the near-zero bandgaps of Eu2Pd2O7 (0.001 eV) and Sm2Pd2O7 (null). Across the series from Eu to Lu, the Pd BVS increases monotonically (1.73 to 1.90), tracking the lanthanide contraction as smaller Ln^3+ ions compress the B-site. Does the onset of a significant bandgap at Tb mark a metal-to-semiconductor transition driven by the contraction, and could this series provide a tunable platform for thermoelectric applications?

CaPa4O11 is a novel hexagonal (P6_3/22, SG 182) protactinium oxide with perfect charge neutrality, zero Shannon and Pauling violations across 22 bonds, but Ca BVS of only 0.86 v.u. against expected +2 (deviation 0.57). Its Ca-Pa-O family spans five compositions -- all novel -- with GII ranging from 0.11 (CaPa3O8) to 0.47 (Ca4Pa2O9), and two entries lacking BVS data entirely. Given that protactinium chemistry is experimentally almost inaccessible due to radioactivity, does the wide spread of GII values across the family suggest that GNoME is exploring a genuinely uncharted Pa^5+ coordination landscape, and could the low-GII CaPa3O8 (0.11) be the most synthetically plausible candidate in the entire family?

Dy2Pd2O7 displays a bandgap of 1.00 eV and Pd BVS of 1.83 v.u. (GII 1.13) in the Fd-3m pyrochlore structure, continuing the monotonic trend across the Ln2Pd2O7 series where heavier lanthanides yield progressively better Pd bonding. With Dy sitting between Tb (BVS 1.80, bandgap 0.94) and Ho (BVS 1.84, bandgap 1.05), can the near-linear relationship between ionic radius and both BVS and bandgap be used to predict that a hypothetical Gd2Pd2O7 (absent from this dataset) would have a BVS near 1.77 and bandgap near 0.85 eV, and if so, does this regularity validate or challenge GNoME's interpolation capabilities?

Er2Pd2O7 has the second-highest bandgap (1.08 eV) among the Ln2Pd2O7 pyrochlores in this batch and its family includes Er(Pd3O4)2 in the Pm-3 structure -- a Pd-rich variant that could not be evaluated by BVS. Across the Ln2Pd2O7 series, only the Eu, Er, Ho, and Lu analogs spawn Ln(Pd3O4)2 family members, all in Pm-3, while Tm uniquely generates Tm(PdO2)2 in I4_1/a with GII 1.10. Does the consistent appearance of the Pm-3 Pd-rich phase suggest a universal tendency for these pyrochlores to decompose toward a Pd3O4 sublattice, and why does the Tm system alone prefer a different structural solution?

Hg(AuO2)2 is computationally known with perfect Tier 1 scores (charge neutral, zero Shannon and Pauling violations) but a GII of 1.13 driven entirely by Hg under-bonding: BVS 0.87 v.u. versus expected +2 (deviation 0.56). Given that Hg^2+ is notoriously linear-coordinating and BVS parameters are calibrated to more typical coordination environments, could the high GII reflect a genuine preference for 2-coordinate Hg that the DFT structure has relaxed into a higher-coordination geometry, and does the tetragonal I4_1/a (SG 88) framework impose coordination constraints incompatible with mercury's stereochemical preferences?

Tm2Pd2O7 is computationally known with a bandgap of 1.13 eV and Pd BVS of 1.86 v.u. (GII 1.12), and its family includes a novel Tm(PdO2)2 phase (I4_1/a) with GII 1.10 -- nearly identical strain. Remarkably, the separate entry for Tm(PdO2)2 in this batch (9b25b138df) assigns Pd as +3 via bv_analyzer rather than +4, producing a completely different BVS picture (Pd BVS 1.26 vs expected +3). Does the existence of two Tm-Pd-O phases with similar GII but fundamentally different assumed Pd oxidation states (+4 pyrochlore vs +3 scheelite-type) indicate a genuine Pd^3+/Pd^4+ redox flexibility, or does it expose a systematic ambiguity in oxi-state assignment for palladium oxides?

Ho2Pd2O7 continues the Ln2Pd2O7 pyrochlore trend with Pd BVS 1.84 v.u. (GII 1.12) and bandgap 1.05 eV, and its family member Ho(Pd3O4)2 (Pm-3) lacks BVS data -- matching the pattern seen for Er(Pd3O4)2 and Lu(Pd3O4)2. Given that six Ln2Pd2O7 pyrochlores in this batch span from Eu (GII 1.20) to Lu (GII 1.11) with a total GII variation of only 0.09 v.u. over the entire lanthanide contraction, does this remarkably narrow spread suggest that the pyrochlore framework is exceptionally tolerant of A-site size changes, or that the Pd under-bonding problem dominates so completely that A-site effects are masked?

IrPdO4 is a novel orthorhombic (Cmmm, SG 65) compound where the BVS reveals a striking asymmetry: Ir shows a BVS of 5.29 v.u. against expected +4 (over-bonded by 1.29), while Pd shows 1.68 v.u. against expected +4 (under-bonded by 2.32). This opposite-sign deviation within the same structure is unusual -- the Ir-O bonds are too short while the Pd-O bonds are too long. Given that the related Ir2PdO6 (P4_2/mnm) achieves a GII of only 0.14, does the 1:1 Ir:Pd ratio in IrPdO4 force both cations into geometrically incompatible sites, and would the 2:1 ratio better accommodate their radically different bonding preferences?

Lu2Pd2O7 has the highest bandgap (1.22 eV) and lowest GII (1.11) among the Ln2Pd2O7 pyrochlores, with Pd BVS reaching 1.90 v.u. -- the closest to the expected +4 in the entire series. Its family member Lu(Pd3O4)2 (Pm-3) is computationally known but lacks BVS data. As the smallest lanthanide in the series, Lu maximally compresses the pyrochlore framework; does the monotonic improvement in Pd bonding from Eu (1.73) to Lu (1.90) suggest that an even smaller A-site cation (e.g., Sc^3+ or Y^3+) could push Pd BVS past 2.0 v.u. and potentially stabilize the structure, or does the pyrochlore topology impose a geometric ceiling on Pd-O bond optimization?

Tm(PdO2)2 is assigned Pd^3+ by bv_analyzer (single-method confidence), yielding Pd BVS of 1.26 v.u. versus expected +3 (deviation 0.58) and a GII of 1.10, while its pyrochlore family member Tm2Pd2O7 (GII 1.12, Pd^4+) is computationally known. The tetragonal I4_1/a (SG 88) structure type matches that of Hg(AuO2)2 and Pr(AgO2)2 in this batch -- all scheelite-derived phases with different B-site metals. Is Pd^3+ in an 8-coordinate scheelite-type site chemically reasonable given that Pd^3+ is exceptionally rare in oxide chemistry, or should this be reinterpreted as a mixed-valent Pd^2+/Pd^4+ compound where the average BVS of 1.26 masks a disproportionation?

In(S8O)3 is an oxychalcogenide isostructural with Sc(S8O)3 and Ga(S8O)3 -- all three adopt SG 160 (R3m), all show charge neutrality residuals of -4.0, all have 100% Pauling violations (3/3), and all show severely under-bonded oxygen (BVS -0.64 to -0.82 vs expected -2). However, the predicted SG 160 differs from both experimental space groups known for this composition type (SG 14 and SG 148 split 50/50 for In, SG 194 for Sc). Given that GII decreases from Sc (1.18) through In (1.10) to Ga (1.05) as cation size varies non-monotonically, is the M^3+ cation radius the dominant factor, or does the 24:3 sulfur-to-oxygen ratio make cation identity nearly irrelevant to the oxygen bonding environment?

TcHg2O5 is novel with charge neutrality and zero Shannon violations, but Hg BVS values of 0.52 v.u. against expected +2 represent one of the most extreme under-bonding deviations in this batch (74% deficit). Its family member TcHgO4 (P2_1/c) is computationally known but has an even higher GII of 1.46. Given that both Tc-Hg-O compositions show severe Hg under-bonding, and that Hg^2+ strongly prefers linear 2-coordinate environments while Tc^7+ demands tetrahedral oxygen coordination, could the fundamental incompatibility between these coordination preferences explain why no Tc-Hg oxide has ever been experimentally synthesized?

Cu3PdO4 is a novel orthorhombic (Cmmm, SG 65) compound sharing the same space group as IrPdO4, with three symmetry-inequivalent Cu sites showing BVS values of 0.77, 0.86, and 0.87 v.u. against expected +2 -- all severely under-bonded. Its family includes CuPd3O4 (Cmmm, GII 0.95, charge neutral) with inverted Cu:Pd stoichiometry and Cu3PdO6 (P2/m, GII 1.23, charge -2.0). Does the fact that swapping the Cu:Pd ratio from 3:1 to 1:3 improves the GII from 1.09 to 0.95 suggest that Pd is a better structural host cation than Cu in this framework, and could Cu's Jahn-Teller distortion be the source of the systematic under-bonding in the Cu-rich variant?

Pr(AgO2)2 is computationally known but its oxi-state methods disagree (both_disagree confidence), making it the only material in this batch with methods_disagree status. Despite this, it achieves charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations across 8 bonds. The BVS reveals Pr at 2.27 v.u. versus expected +4 (deviation 0.43) and Ag at 1.03 v.u. versus expected +2 (deviation 0.48). If the oxi-state assignment is wrong and Pr is actually +3 rather than +4, the BVS deviation for Pr would drop from 0.43 to only 0.24 -- dramatically improving agreement. Does the methods_disagree flag here serve as a genuine early warning that the assumed Pr^4+ is incorrect, and should this compound be reinterpreted as Pr^3+ with Ag^3+ to maintain charge balance?

Np3Tl3O10 is a novel triclinic compound with 64 sites and a charge neutrality residual of -8.0 -- the largest magnitude in this batch. The BVS exposes the likely culprit: Tl sites show BVS of 3.94 v.u. against an assigned +1, an extraordinary 2.94 v.u. over-bonding that strongly suggests Tl should be +3 rather than +1. If Tl were reassigned from +1 to +3, the charge balance would shift by +6 (3 Tl atoms x 2 charge units), reducing the residual from -8.0 to -2.0. Could the remaining -2.0 deficit then implicate Np being +4 rather than +5, and does this cascade of corrections suggest the oxi_state_guesses method is fundamentally unreliable for compounds containing both actinides and thallium?

Cu(TcO4)2 is a novel trigonal (R3, SG 146) technetium pertechnetate with perfect charge neutrality, zero violations across all Tier 1 checks and 24 Pauling bonds, yet Cu BVS values of 0.89-1.00 v.u. versus expected +2 indicate roughly half the expected bonding. Its family member Cu3(TcO4)4 (P1, GII 0.15) achieves a dramatically lower GII despite having a charge residual of -1.0. Does the seven-fold reduction in GII from 1.06 to 0.15 when moving from the 1:2 to 3:4 Cu:TcO4 ratio suggest that the larger unit cell provides sufficient flexibility for Cu^2+ to find its preferred coordination geometry, and could the P1 symmetry of the family member be enabling distortions that the R3 symmetry of Cu(TcO4)2 forbids?

Cr3PtO8 is a novel orthorhombic (Cmmm, SG 65) compound with all Cr sites showing BVS of 2.87-3.07 v.u. against expected +4 -- a remarkably consistent ~25% under-bonding. Its family member Cr2PtO6 (P4_2/mnm) achieves a GII of only 0.077, one of the lowest in this entire batch, while the alternative Cr(PtO3)2 stoichiometry gives GII 0.27. Given that the Cr:Pt ratio of 3:1 in Cr3PtO8 (GII 1.06) performs 14x worse than the 2:1 ratio in Cr2PtO6 (GII 0.08), is there a critical Cr concentration above which the structure cannot provide enough oxygen neighbors to satisfy Cr^4+ coordination demands?

Ac5Cu5O13 is computationally known with a charge neutrality residual of -1.0 and Cu BVS values of 0.90-0.95 v.u. against expected +2 (about 50% under-bonded). Actinium is one of the rarest elements in the periodic table, and its +3 state with the largest ionic radius among trivalent cations creates enormous coordination polyhedra. Given that the 5:5:13 stoichiometry does not satisfy simple charge balance for Ac^3+/Cu^2+/O^2- (expected: +15+10-26 = -1, matching the observed residual), does the persistent -1.0 charge deficit indicate that one Cu must be Cu^+ rather than Cu^2+ to achieve neutrality, and would this mixed-valence Cu^+/Cu^2+ scenario be consistent with the near-zero bandgap of 0.003 eV?

Cu7O8F is a novel cubic (Fm-3m, SG 225) oxyhalide with a charge neutrality residual of -3.0 and Cu BVS of only 0.80 v.u. against expected +2, while oxygen shows BVS of -0.88 versus expected -2 -- both severely under-bonded. The -3.0 charge residual for Cu7^2+O8^2-F^- gives +14-16-1 = -3, which is exactly the observed value. Could the charge imbalance be resolved by assuming three of the seven Cu atoms are Cu^+ rather than Cu^2+ (giving +11-16-1 = -6, worse) or alternatively that some oxygen is O^- rather than O^2- (radical oxygen), and does the cubic Fm-3m symmetry with its high site multiplicity create an averaging artifact that masks a more complex local bonding environment?

Ga(S8O)3 completes the M(S8O)3 trio (M = Sc, In, Ga) with the lowest GII of 1.05, yet shares the same pathologies: charge residual -4.0, 100% Pauling violations, oxygen BVS of -0.82 v.u. versus expected -2, and a predicted SG 160 that contradicts experimental space groups (SG 148 and 166 at 50% each for Ga). Since all three M(S8O)3 compounds show virtually identical failure patterns despite spanning three different cation sizes (Sc^3+ 0.75 A, Ga^3+ 0.62 A, In^3+ 0.80 A), does this confirm that the validation failures are entirely driven by the sulfur-dominated anion framework rather than cation chemistry, making these compounds fundamentally outside the domain of oxide-calibrated BVS parameters?

Zn(Cu3O4)2 adopts the cubic Fm-3m structure (SG 225) yet shows a charge residual of -2.0 and a GII of 1.05 v.u. with every oxygen site severely under-bonded (BVS -0.90 vs. expected -2.0, deviation 0.55). Both oxidation state methods disagree, suggesting the assumed Cu and Zn oxidation states may be incorrect -- could this structure actually stabilize through a mixed-valence Cu+/Cu2+ scenario that would simultaneously resolve the charge imbalance and bring oxygen BVS closer to the expected values?

La(S8O)3 is an oxychalcogenide with a massive charge residual of -4.0 and 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations across all 3 checked coordinations, yet its family member La2S4O15 achieves perfect charge neutrality and a low GII of 0.30 v.u. -- does the trigonal R3m structure (SG 160) of La(S8O)3, which is completely novel relative to experimental La-S-O space groups (14, 15, 57), represent an inherently unstable polymorph, or is the failure driven by the O2- assumption being inapplicable in a sulfur-dominated anion sublattice?

In Ru4Pb3O13, a computationally known orthorhombic phase, the Ru sites show BVS values of ~2.98-3.03 v.u. against an expected +5, yielding deviations of ~0.40 -- this ~40% under-bonding of Ru is strikingly consistent across all Ru sites. Given that Ru commonly adopts +4 in oxide perovskites (like SrRuO3), could GNoME's DFT relaxation have actually converged on a Ru4+ geometry while the oxidation state guesser assigned Ru5+, and would reassigning Ru to +4 improve or worsen the BVS match?

Tb(AgO2)2 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality and zero Pauling violations, yet BVS reveals Tb at 2.42 v.u. (expected +4, deviation 0.39) and Ag at 1.04 v.u. (expected +2, deviation 0.48) -- both cations are bonded at roughly half their expected valence. Is GNoME predicting an anomalously expanded unit cell for this tetragonal I41/a structure that systematically lengthens all cation-oxygen bonds, or does the assignment of Tb4+ (rather than the more common Tb3+) represent the root cause of the apparent under-bonding?

Cd(Ag3O4)2 shares the exact same cubic Fm-3m structure (SG 225, 15 sites) as the large RE(Ag3O4)2 family in this batch, but with Cd2+ replacing the rare earth -- it has the weakest formation energy of the group (-0.58 eV/atom vs. ~-1.05 for the RE members) and methods disagree on oxidation states. Does the substitution of a d10 Cd2+ ion for a trivalent rare earth fundamentally destabilize this spinel-like framework, and is the lower thermodynamic stability reflected in its charge residual of -2.0 (worse than the -1.0 seen in the RE analogs)?

Pa4PbO11 is a novel hexagonal phase (SG 182) with an exceptionally deep formation energy of -3.79 eV/atom, perfect charge neutrality, zero Pauling violations across 22 checked coordinations, and a wide bandgap of 3.06 eV -- yet Pb shows a BVS of only 0.98 v.u. against an expected +2, a deviation of 0.51. How can a material pass every Tier 1 check so convincingly while its Pb sites appear bonded at less than half their nominal valence -- is the hexagonal structure placing Pb in an unusually under-coordinated site, or might Pa's 5f electron chemistry create an unusual bonding environment?

Ac4Ru6O19 (cubic SG 197) shows a charge residual of -2.0 and Ru BVS of 2.98 v.u. against expected +4, while its Ac-Ru-O family members show dramatically escalating GII values: Ac5(RuO6)2 at 1.39 v.u. and Ac3RuO7 at 2.27 v.u. -- all three are novel predictions. Given that actinium chemistry is extremely poorly characterized experimentally, is GNoME exploring a compositional space where the Ac3+ ionic radius (~1.12 A) is simply too large to form stable Ru-O polyhedral frameworks, as evidenced by the systematic GII degradation with increasing Ac:Ru ratio?

Tc3IrO12 combines two of the rarest elements in oxide chemistry -- technetium and iridium -- in a trigonal R-3c structure (SG 167) with a notable bandgap of 1.31 eV and charge residual of -4.0. The Ir BVS of 5.02 v.u. against expected +4 indicates overbonding (deviation 0.25), suggesting Ir may actually be closer to Ir5+ in this environment. Given that Tc-Ir-O compounds have essentially no experimental precedent, is this prediction exploring a genuinely viable region of phase space where both metals adopt high oxidation states, or is the -4.0 charge residual evidence that the assumed oxidation states are fundamentally wrong?

Ag7O8F is a novel oxyhalide in cubic Fm-3m (SG 225) with Ag BVS of only 0.82 v.u. against expected +2 (deviation 0.59) -- the most severe Ag under-bonding in this entire batch. Its Ag-O-F family member Ag2O2F5 could not even be evaluated by BVS. Given that the known compound Ag7O8NO3 features mixed Ag+/Ag3+ and is one of the few verified silver(III) compounds, could this fluoride analog stabilize a similar charge-disproportionated state, and would reassigning some Ag sites to +1 and others to +3 dramatically improve the BVS agreement?

Cu(RuO3)2 in tetragonal P42/mnm (SG 136) achieves perfect charge neutrality with both methods agreeing on oxidation states, yet every Ru site shows BVS of 3.41 v.u. against expected +5 (deviation 0.32). Its family member CuRu5O12 has a charge residual of -3.0 but a lower GII of 0.65 v.u. -- does the higher Ru content in CuRu5O12 allow Ru-O-Ru edge-sharing that better satisfies Ru bonding requirements, suggesting that the 1:2 Cu:Ru ratio in Cu(RuO3)2 forces Ru into geometrically unfavorable isolated octahedra?

Y(Ag3O4)2 is one of six RE(Ag3O4)2 compounds in this batch all crystallizing in cubic Fm-3m (SG 225) with 15 sites, yet Y3+ (ionic radius 0.90 A) is not a lanthanide -- it sits between Ho3+ (0.90 A) and Dy3+ (0.91 A) in size. The Ag BVS values track this size trend: Y gives 0.963, Ho gives 0.964, and Dy gives 0.953. Does the near-identical Ag bonding environment across the Y/Ho/Dy triad confirm that this spinel-type Ag3O4 framework is remarkably tolerant of A-site cation substitution, and if so, what is the critical ionic radius below which the structure destabilizes?

Tm(Ag3O4)2 has the smallest rare earth in the RE(Ag3O4)2 series (Tm3+ = 0.88 A) and shows the lowest Ag BVS of the group at 0.951 v.u., consistent with the lanthanide contraction progressively compressing the Ag-O sublattice. Both oxidation state methods disagree, and the charge residual is -1.0. Across the full series (Sm, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Y), the Ag BVS spans only 0.949-0.964 -- is this remarkably narrow 1.6% BVS variation evidence that the Ag3O4 framework is structurally rigid and essentially decoupled from the rare earth site, or is the uniformity an artifact of the Fm-3m symmetry constraints in GNoME's relaxation?

CeCu7O12 in cubic Im-3 (SG 204) shows a catastrophic charge residual of -6.0 with mixed valence, 100% Pauling Rule 2 violations, and oxygen BVS of -0.92 (expected -2.0) -- yet it has an isomorphous partner ThCu7O12 with nearly identical failures. Given that Ce can be Ce3+ or Ce4+ while Th is locked at Th4+, the fact that both show identical charge residuals of -6.0 suggests the problem lies entirely with the Cu-O sublattice. Could this Im-3 structure actually require a Cu+/Cu2+ mixed-valence scheme rather than the uniform oxidation state assumed by the guessers?

ThCu7O12 mirrors CeCu7O12 almost exactly -- same cubic Im-3 structure (SG 204), same 20 sites, same -6.0 charge residual, same 100% Pauling violations, same O BVS (~-0.92) -- but with a slightly deeper formation energy (-1.39 vs. -1.32 eV/atom). Since Th4+ is one of the most electropositive tetravalent cations (ionic radius 0.94 A), and the Cu7O12 framework apparently cannot achieve charge balance with either Ce or Th, is GNoME predicting a fundamentally unstable structural prototype, or does the Cu7O12 cage require a divalent A-site cation (like Ba2+) that neither Ce nor Th can provide?

Er(Ag3O4)2 sits in the middle of the RE(Ag3O4)2 series with Er3+ (0.89 A) and shows Ag BVS of 0.962 -- virtually identical to Ho (0.964) despite a 0.01 A difference in RE ionic radius. All six members of this series are novel GNoME predictions with no experimental precedent. Given that AgO (Ag+Ag3+O2) is known to exist, could this entire RE(Ag3O4)2 family represent a systematic GNoME artifact where the network learned the Fm-3m spinel template and populated it with chemically implausible Ag2+ across 15 RE-Ag-O compositions?

Dy(Ag3O4)2 has the second-largest RE in the series (Dy3+ = 0.91 A) yet shows the second-lowest Ag BVS at 0.953, breaking the expected monotonic trend where larger A-site cations should expand the framework and increase Ag-O bond valence. The methods disagree on oxidation states and the charge residual is -1.0. Is the Dy anomaly evidence of a local structural distortion within the Fm-3m framework -- perhaps Dy3+ being slightly too large for ideal cubic symmetry in this particular Ag3O4 cage -- or is the deviation within the noise of the BVS parameterization for Ag?

Tb4(PbO4)3 is computationally known yet shows Pb BVS values of 3.67-4.27 v.u. against expected +2, with the worst deviation reaching 1.13 -- this is massive overbonding suggesting Pb is actually in the +4 state rather than +2. The family member Tb2PbO2 in I4/mmm has a GII of 1.17 v.u. with neutral charge, also suggesting systematic Pb oxidation state misassignment. Would reassigning Pb from +2 to +4 in Tb4(PbO4)3 simultaneously resolve the BVS overbonding and the -2.0 charge residual, converting the formula unit to a charge-balanced Tb3+4Pb4+3O12?

Sm(Ag3O4)2 has the largest rare earth in the RE(Ag3O4)2 series (Sm3+ = 0.96 A) and the lowest Ag BVS at 0.949, which is paradoxical -- larger A-site cations typically expand the unit cell and should increase, not decrease, Ag-O bond valence. With formation energy of -1.03 eV/atom (the weakest in the RE series), is the Sm compound approaching the upper ionic radius limit of the Fm-3m structure's stability field, where the Ag3O4 framework begins to stretch beyond viable Ag-O bonding distances?

Ag5AuO8 in triclinic P-1 has three Ag-Au-O family members with remarkably low GII values (0.04-0.13 v.u.), yet Ag5AuO8 itself shows oxygen BVS of -0.83 (expected -2.0) and a charge residual of -1.0. The family compounds Ag3Au3O8 (GII 0.09) and Ag2AuO4 (GII 0.04) both also carry charge residuals of -1.0 to -2.0. Given that Au commonly exhibits +1/+3 mixed valence in oxides (as in Cs2Au2O3), could the entire Ag-Au-O family require a Au+/Au3+ disproportionation model rather than uniform Au oxidation states to achieve both charge balance and reasonable BVS?

Pr4Pt6O19 in cubic I23 (SG 197) shows all Pr sites with BVS of 1.97 v.u. against expected +3 (deviation 0.34), while its pyrochlore-related family member Pr2Pt2O7 in Fd-3m has a much better GII of 0.33. The GII escalates sharply with Pt enrichment: Pr5(PtO6)2 at 0.55 and Pr2Pt7O18 at 1.14 v.u. Does increasing the Pt:Pr ratio systematically compress the Pr-O coordination environment below the optimal bond length for Pr3+, and does the pyrochlore Pr2Pt2O7 represent the thermodynamic ground state that GNoME's other Pr-Pt-O compositions are metastable variants of?

LuSb5O13 is computationally known but shows mixed valence, a charge residual of -6.0, and Sb BVS of 5.98-6.05 v.u. against expected +4 -- the Sb is overbonded by ~50%, strongly suggesting Sb5+ rather than Sb4+. The family shows a striking contrast: Lu2SbO2 (GII 0.21) and Lu11(SbO8)3 (GII 0.20) both achieve charge neutrality, while LuSb5O13 with its high Sb content fails catastrophically. Is the Sb-rich composition forcing antimony into an octahedral coordination environment natural for Sb5+ but incompatible with the assigned Sb4+/Sb2+ mixed valence scheme?

Ho(Ag3O4)2 shows Ag BVS of 0.964 -- the highest in the entire RE(Ag3O4)2 series, suggesting Ho3+ (0.90 A) provides the optimal A-site cation size for maximizing Ag-O bond valence in this Fm-3m framework. Yet even this best-case scenario has Ag bonded at less than half its expected +2 valence. Across all six RE members, no material achieves charge neutrality (all at -1.0). Is the systematic ~52% Ag under-bonding across the entire family definitive evidence that Ag2+ is the wrong oxidation state assignment, and that these structures actually contain Ag+ in a metallic or charge-transfer framework?

Ac4PdO7 is computationally known with perfect charge neutrality but a Pauling violation rate of 43% (3 of 7 coordinations fail) and Pd BVS of 1.03 v.u. against expected +2 (deviation 0.49). Its family member AcPd3O4 in Pm-3n could not even be evaluated by BVS. Given that Pd2+ strongly prefers square-planar coordination in oxides while the monoclinic C2/m structure likely offers distorted octahedral sites, is the ~50% Pd under-bonding evidence that GNoME placed Pd in a coordination geometry incompatible with its d8 electronic configuration?

Mn(RuO3)2 shares the exact same tetragonal P42/mnm structure (SG 136) as Cu(RuO3)2 in this batch, with both methods agreeing on oxidation states and perfect charge neutrality in both compounds. However, Ru BVS in Mn(RuO3)2 is 3.18-3.19 v.u. (deviation 0.36) versus 3.41 in Cu(RuO3)2 (deviation 0.32) -- the Mn variant shows worse Ru under-bonding despite having a slightly deeper formation energy (-1.58 vs. -1.30 eV/atom). Does the smaller Mn2+ ion (0.83 A vs. Cu2+ 0.73 A) paradoxically expand the Ru-O framework, or is the Jahn-Teller activity of Cu2+ creating local distortions that better satisfy Ru bonding?

Pu7UO24 achieves perfect charge neutrality with zero Pauling violations across all 24 checked coordinations, and U shows a BVS of 6.96 v.u. (expected +6, deviation only 0.16) -- one of the best BVS matches in this batch. Its Pu-U-O family spans three compositions with GII values ranging from an excellent 0.057 (PuU3O8) to a poor 1.33 (Pu5UO11), all carrying -1.0 charge residuals. Given that Pu7UO24 outperforms its family members on every metric, does the 7:1 Pu:U ratio represent a thermodynamic sweet spot where Pu3+ and U6+ achieve optimal charge compensation, and could this composition guide experimental synthesis of novel actinide oxide phases?

Pa7Mn3O20 carries a residual charge of -6.0 and all three Mn sites show BVS values near 1.0 v.u. against an expected +2, giving deviations around 0.5 -- could the oxi_state_guesses assignment be underestimating Mn oxidation (e.g., Mn3+ or Mn4+ rather than Mn2+), and would reassigning Mn to a higher state simultaneously resolve the charge imbalance and the systematically halved BVS across all Mn sites?

The Ca-Cd-O family spans seven compositions from CaCd4O5 to CaCd15O16, all charge-neutral, yet GII values rise monotonically with Cd content (0.582 for Ca15CdO16, 0.894 for CaCd4O5, 0.952 for CaCd15O16) -- does this trend indicate that the CdO-rich end of this solid-solution-like series is approaching a lattice strain limit beyond which the rocksalt-derived framework cannot accommodate the larger Cd2+ population?

CuPd3O4 is charge-neutral with no Pauling violations, yet Cu shows a BVS of only 0.78 v.u. against an expected +2 (deviation 0.61), and the family member Cu3PdO4 has an even higher GII of 1.089 -- is Cu systematically underbonded across the Cu-Pd-O system because the Pd2+ sublattice dominates the oxygen coordination geometry, effectively starving Cu of bond valence?

In Ac(BiO2)7, two Bi sites show BVS values of 5.4 and 5.3 v.u. against an expected +3, indicating severe overbonding, while a third Bi sits at 2.4 v.u. -- given the -4.0 charge residual and the family member Ac3BiO7 having a near-perfect GII of 0.066, could the structure actually contain Bi5+ (as in bismuthates) rather than Bi3+, which would explain both the high BVS and the charge imbalance?

KPa9O20 is computationally known yet carries a -3.0 charge residual and K shows a BVS of 1.95 v.u. against expected +1 -- this near-doubling suggests K may be in an unusually high-coordination environment that inflates its apparent bond valence; does the triclinic P-1 structure force K into a cage-like site with excessive oxygen neighbors, and does the family member K3PaO4 (charge-neutral, GII 0.292) represent a more chemically reasonable K-Pa-O stoichiometry?

Pa3MnO8 in cubic Pm-3m (SG 221) is a high-symmetry novel prediction with a -2.0 charge residual, and its only family member Pa7Mn3O20 shows an even worse charge of -6.0 and comparable GII of 0.958 -- given that both Pa-Mn-O compositions fail charge neutrality, is the single-method oxi_state_guesses systematically misassigning Pa (perhaps choosing Pa4+ when Pa5+ is needed), and could this explain why no Pa-Mn-O compounds appear in experimental databases?

CaCd9O10 is novel, perfectly charge-neutral, passes all Tier 1 checks, yet its GII of 0.942 is notably high -- across the six-member Ca-Cd-O family, the two Ca-rich compositions (Ca15CdO16 and Ca9CdO10) have dramatically lower GII values (~0.58) than the four Cd-rich ones (~0.89-0.95); does this bifurcation reflect a genuine structural transition from CaO-type to CdO-type frameworks at some critical Ca:Cd ratio?

Ge2(SO4)3 is classified as an oxychalcogenide with S assigned as S5+ (BVS 6.59 v.u. vs. expected 5), but in a true sulfate S should be S6+ -- given the -2.0 charge residual, the 50% Pauling Rule 2 violation rate across 24 bonds, and Ge showing BVS of only 1.29 vs. expected +4, could the oxi_state_guesses be systematically wrong for both cations, and would reassigning S6+ and Ge4+ simultaneously fix the charge balance and reduce the anomalously large Ge underbonding?

Hg2Pt3O8 is computationally known and charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations, yet both Hg sites show BVS of 1.06 v.u. against expected +2, yielding ~47% underbonding -- given that Hg2+ is notoriously linear in its coordination (as in HgO), does the trigonal R-3m structure force Hg into a higher-coordination environment that distributes its bond valence too thinly, and would a lower-symmetry polymorph better accommodate Hg's coordination preference?

PaMoO5 is charge-neutral and novel, yet all three Mo sites show identical BVS of 4.68 v.u. against expected Mo6+ -- the family member PaMoO4 has a catastrophic GII of 2.591, while the computationally known Pa2Mo2O11 has a healthy GII of 0.226; does the Mo coordination geometry in PaMoO5 represent an intermediate distortion between these extremes, and is the systematic 22% Mo underbonding a signature of Pa5+ competing with Mo6+ for the same oxygen coordination shell?

AcSb5O12 has Sb assigned as Sb4+ (BVS 3.07 vs. expected 4), but Sb4+ is extremely rare -- Sb typically adopts +3 or +5 oxidation states; given the -1.0 charge residual, the 50% Pauling violation rate, and that none of the five Ac-Sb-O family members have computable GII values, could the entire family's oxi state assignments be fundamentally flawed, with the true chemistry requiring a mixed Sb3+/Sb5+ disproportionation?

CaCd7O8 is novel and charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations, but every Cd site shows BVS near 1.0 v.u. against expected +2 -- this ~50% underbonding is identical across the entire Ca-Cd-O family (CaCd4O5, CaCd6O7, CaCd9O10, CaCd15O16), regardless of Ca:Cd ratio or space group; is this a systematic artifact of the BVS reference parameters for Cd-O bonds in DFT-relaxed structures being calibrated against a bond length regime that differs from ICSD experimental structures?

SrCd6O7 is computationally known and isostructural (R-3, SG 148) with CaCd6O7, both charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations, yet SrCd6O7 shows Cd BVS of 0.98 v.u. while CaCd6O7 shows 1.02 v.u. -- does the larger Sr2+ ion (1.26 A vs. Ca2+ 1.12 A) expand the lattice just enough to lengthen Cd-O bonds and push Cd further into underbonding territory, and is this the reason GNoME finds no Ba analogue in this structure type?

Gd10Si6O has only a single oxygen atom among 17 sites, mixed valence, and Si assigned as Si4- (BVS -2.54 vs. expected -4) -- this is essentially an intermetallic silicide with trace oxygen; given the -6.0 charge residual, 100% Pauling violation rate, and that the predicted trigonal SG 162 matches neither of the experimentally known space groups (P21/c at 67%, P-1 at 33%), is GNoME stabilizing this structure through metallic bonding that classical ionic validators are fundamentally unable to assess?

La4Pd6O19 is computationally known yet has a massive +13.0 charge residual and mixed valence with Pd assigned as Pd4+ (BVS 1.99 v.u., deviation 0.50) -- the predicted cubic I23 structure (SG 197) matches none of the experimentally known space groups (C2/m, Pnma, P42/m), and the family spans from La2Pd2O7 (GII 1.234) down to La(Pd3O4)2 (GII 0.797); could the bv_analyzer be forcing Pd into +4 when a Pd2+/Pd4+ mixed state or even Pd3+ would better explain the extreme charge excess?

CaCd6O7 is the computationally known anchor of the six-member Ca-Cd-O family, with all Tier 1 checks passing cleanly, yet its GII of 0.914 is far above the ICSD baseline of ~0.2 v.u. -- if the computationally known reference itself shows this level of bond strain, does this suggest that the entire Ca-Cd-O compositional space is metastable, or is the ~0.49 v.u. Cd deviation simply a systematic offset in DFT-relaxed Cd-O bond lengths relative to experimental values?

Ac15SmO24 passes charge neutrality perfectly (score 0.0) and all Pauling checks across 24 bonds, with Sm showing a BVS of 2.09 v.u. against expected +3 (30% underbonding) -- given that Ac3+ and Sm3+ are chemically similar lanthanide/actinide ions with comparable ionic radii, does the 15:1 Ac:Sm ratio suggest this is essentially an actinium oxide with dilute Sm doping, and would the Sm site be under compressive or tensile strain in the Ac-dominated lattice?

Ru5PtO12 is novel with a -2.0 charge residual, and all Ru sites show BVS values of 2.89-2.97 v.u. against expected Ru4+ -- the family member Ru2PtO6 has a dramatically worse GII of 1.969; given that Ru commonly adopts +3, +4, and +6 oxidation states, could the BVS values near 3.0 indicate that Ru3+ rather than Ru4+ is the actual oxidation state, which would shift the charge residual and potentially explain why no Ru-Pt-O compounds are experimentally known?

Sc3PO has P assigned as P1- with a BVS of -2.80 v.u. (deviation 1.80), the largest single-site deviation in this batch -- the 100% Pauling violation rate and SG 63 matching none of the three known experimental space groups (Cc, I41/amd, I-43d) suggest this compound may be a Zintl-type phosphide rather than an oxide; is the single oxygen atom in the formula essentially interstitial in what is fundamentally a Sc-P intermetallic?

La2Pt7O18 is novel with a -2.0 charge residual, and its family member La5(PtO6)2 has a much lower GII of 0.365 compared to La4Pt6O19's 0.782 -- the La BVS of 2.10 v.u. (30% underbonded vs. expected +3) mirrors the pattern in Ac15SmO24 for large trivalent cations; does the Pt-rich stoichiometry force La into oversized cavities, and could the La:Pt ratio of 2:7 be beyond the stability limit for maintaining adequate La-O bond valence?

Sr2Pa2O7 is computationally known, charge-neutral, and passes all Tier 1 checks, yet within its eight-member Sr-Pa-O family, GII values span from 0.140 (SrPa9O20) to 0.863 (SrPa4O11) -- notably, the Pa-rich compositions consistently show lower GII than the Sr-rich ones (Sr5Pa3O12 at 0.689 vs. SrPa8O18 at 0.161); does the Pa5+ ion's ability to sustain high coordination numbers give Pa-rich compositions a structural advantage in achieving bond valence satisfaction?

Tl(Ag3O4)2 in cubic Fm-3m (SG 225) has a -1.0 charge residual with Ag showing BVS of 1.0 v.u. against expected +2 (50% underbonded) -- Tl is known for its Tl+/Tl3+ ambivalence, and if Tl3+ were assigned instead of Tl+, the charge balance would shift by +2; could the single-method oxi_state_guesses be choosing the wrong Tl oxidation state, and would Tl3+ assignment simultaneously fix both the charge residual and alter the expected Ag oxidation state to improve BVS agreement?

CaCd4O5 is the simplest stoichiometry in the Ca-Cd-O family and computationally known in I4/m (SG 87), yet its GII of 0.894 is the lowest among the Cd-rich members -- across the series, the formation energy becomes less negative with increasing Cd content (-1.77 for CaCd4O5 vs. -1.49 for CaCd15O16); does this thermodynamic trend, combined with the rising GII, suggest that CaCd4O5 represents the true ground-state composition of this family while the Cd-richer variants are progressively more metastable?

Nd4Ag2O9 is novel with 60 sites in the unit cell and Ag assigned as Ag3+ (BVS 1.26 v.u., deviation 0.58), but Ag3+ is exceedingly rare outside of AgF4- and KAgF4 -- given that all six equivalent Ag sites show identical BVS of 1.26 and the sole family member Nd6Ag11O24 has a -8.0 charge residual, is GNoME predicting a class of Ag3+ oxides that would be chemically unprecedented, or does the Ag valence suggest a mixed Ag+/Ag3+ disproportionation that the validators cannot resolve?

Cs(PdO2)4 has a -7.0 charge residual, mixed valence, 100% Pauling violation rate, and oxygen BVS values of -0.84 and -0.93 v.u. against expected -2 -- across the five-member Cs-Pd-O family, charge residuals range from 0.0 to -14.0 and multiple members lack computable GII; given that the computationally known Cs(PdO2)6 also has no GII data, is the entire Cs-Pd-O chemical space plagued by fundamental oxi state assignment failures for Pd in alkali-metal environments?

Ac3NbO7 is charge neutral and passes Shannon radii, yet Nb shows a BVS of 4.12 against an expected +5, a 17.6% underbonding deviation — does this suggest the orthorhombic (Cmcm) structure places Nb in an unusually spacious coordination polyhedron, and could the actual Nb environment favor a lower effective oxidation state closer to +4 in this actinium-rich lattice?

Lu3Bi5O14 carries a -4.0 residual charge and its Bi sites show extreme overbonding (BVS 5.71 vs expected +3, deviation 0.90), a pattern shared across the entire Lu-Bi-O family where Lu(BiO2)7, LuBi3O7, and Lu2Bi2O7 all show charges of -4.0 or GII values above 0.77 — does this systematic failure to achieve charge neutrality in bismuth-rich compositions indicate that GNoME consistently misassigns Bi as +3 when it should be +5 in these structures, and would reclassifying Bi as Bi5+ resolve both the charge and BVS anomalies?

Rb6(RhO3)5 is a novel mixed-valence compound where all Rh sites show BVS values near 2.67 despite an expected +4 (33% underbonding), and every member of the Rb-Rh-O family fails charge neutrality with residuals ranging from -3.0 to +14.0 — given that the Rh-richer composition Rb2Rh4O11 is the only family member showing a positive charge residual (+14.0) and the lowest GII (0.52), is there a critical Rb:Rh ratio where the mixed-valence Rh3+/Rh4+ balance can actually achieve electrostatic stability?

Nd6Ag11O24 is a novel material where oxidation state methods disagree (methods_disagree confidence) and Ag sites show BVS values near 0.98 against an expected +2 (51% underbonding), while its lone family member Nd4Ag2O9 achieves perfect charge neutrality with a GII of 0.894 — does the dramatically different Ag stoichiometry (11 vs 2 Ag per formula unit) create an impossible demand for high-oxidation-state Ag that the crystal structure simply cannot satisfy, suggesting GNoME generated an electrochemically implausible composition?

Tm3Bi5O14 is computationally known yet shows Bi BVS values of 5.69 and 5.64 (expected +3, deviations ~0.89), nearly identical to the pattern in its family member TmBi3O7 (Bi BVS 5.64, deviation 0.88) — given that the Tm-Bi-O family spans GII values from 0.699 (TmBi7O16) to 0.867 (Tm3Bi5O14), is the systematic Bi overbonding an artifact of using Bi3+ BVS parameters when these structures actually accommodate Bi5+, and does the lower GII of TmBi7O16 indicate it is the most structurally relaxed composition in this family?

SrPa4O11 is charge neutral with zero Pauling violations across 22 bonds, yet Sr shows BVS of only 1.14 vs expected +2 (43% underbonding) — intriguingly, the Sr-Pa-O family shows GII improving monotonically as the Pa:Sr ratio increases, from 0.898 (Sr2Pa2O7) down to 0.140 (SrPa9O20), suggesting that diluting Sr in a Pa-dominated lattice reduces structural strain — does the hexagonal (P6322) framework of SrPa4O11 provide an oversized cavity for Sr that would be better filled by a larger alkaline earth like Ba?

Hg2Pd2O7 adopts the Fd-3m pyrochlore structure (SG 227) but shows catastrophic failures: a charge residual of -12.0, 100% Pauling rule 2 violations across all 14 bonds, and oxygen BVS of only -0.93 (expected -2, 54% underbonding) — with a near-zero bandgap (0.0002 eV) and mixed valence, could this novel prediction be an example of GNoME placing Hg and Pd into a pyrochlore topology that is geometrically forced but electrostatically impossible, given that neither Hg2+ nor Pd2+ are known to form stable pyrochlores?

Cs6(RhO3)5 is computationally known and isostructural with Rb6(RhO3)5 (both R32, SG 155), yet their Rh BVS values are nearly identical (2.65 vs 2.66, both expected +4) — across the entire Cs-Rh-O family, every composition fails charge neutrality with residuals from -4.0 to -16.0, and GII values cluster between 0.57 and 0.76 — does the substitution of Cs for Rb provide no relief to the systematic Rh underbonding, and does this suggest the Rh oxidation state assignment of +4 is fundamentally wrong for this structure type?

Ag5Ir3O14 is novel with disagreeing oxidation state methods and shows oxygen sites with BVS of only -0.72 (expected -2.0, 64% deviation) alongside Ag BVS of 0.74 vs expected +2 — its family member Ag2Ir2O7 adopts the pyrochlore structure (Fd-3m) with perfect charge neutrality but GII of 0.737, while AgIr5O13 achieves charge neutrality with a much lower GII of 0.373 — does increasing the Ir:Ag ratio systematically improve structural quality, and at the Ag5Ir3 stoichiometry has GNoME pushed beyond the compositional stability boundary for silver iridates?

Np9CdO20 is a novel neptunium-cadmium oxide where Cd shows BVS of 1.14 vs expected +2 (43% underbonding), and its family member NpCd2O5 achieves perfect charge neutrality (GII 0.801) while NpCdO4 (computationally known) is also charge neutral with GII 0.717 — given the extreme Np:Cd ratio of 9:1, does the structure essentially become a Np oxide lattice with isolated, poorly-coordinated Cd sites, and would the nearly metallic bandgap (0.0009 eV) reflect f-electron delocalization characteristic of neptunium-dominated phases?

TbHgO has only 6 sites and is charge neutral, but Tb shows BVS of 2.10 against an expected +1 (a rare Tb+ assignment from bv_analyzer), while Hg has a near-zero BVS of 0.01 vs expected +1 — with 100% Pauling rule 2 violations and Tb deviating by 109.6%, is this a case where the oxidation state guesser fundamentally misassigned Tb (typically +3) as +1, and would reassigning Tb3+/Hg2+/O2- with the stoichiometry TbHgO require a completely different structural model?

Rb4(PdO2)3 is novel with both oxidation state methods agreeing, yet oxygen sites show BVS near -0.90 (expected -2.0, ~55% deviation), and its Rb-Pd-O family shows alarmingly high GII values — Rb(PdO2)3 at 1.559 and Rb2Pd3O7 at 1.375 are among the worst in the entire dataset — does the pattern of extreme lattice strain across all Rb-Pd-O compositions suggest that Pd in square-planar coordination is fundamentally incompatible with the Rb+ ionic radius, making this entire predicted family thermodynamically inaccessible?

Rb6(PdO3)5 shows a charge residual of -14.0 (the most extreme in its family) with 100% Pauling violations across all 15 bonds and oxygen BVS of -0.89 (expected -2.0), while sharing a family with Rb4(PdO2)3 (GII 0.854) and Rb(PdO2)3 (GII 1.559) — given that this compound is isostructural (R32) with Cs6(PdO3)5, and the Cs analogue also shows extreme charge failure, is the A6(MO3)5 structure type with R32 symmetry fundamentally incompatible with Pd, or does the mixed-valence Pd assignment systematically overcount the negative charge?

Np3CrO12 is novel, charge neutral, passes all Pauling rules across 12 bonds, and has zero Shannon violations, yet Cr shows BVS of 2.15 vs expected +3 (28.4% underbonding) — given that Cr3+ is one of the most well-characterized ions in crystal chemistry with robust BVS parameters, does the 28% underbonding indicate that the triclinic (P-1) structure places Cr in an expanded octahedral site more typical of a Np-dominated framework, where the large Np4+ ions dictate the lattice constants at the expense of optimal Cr-O distances?

CeNp9O20 is novel with a near-zero bandgap (0.0001 eV) and Ce showing BVS of 3.85 vs expected +3 (28.4% overbonding), while its family member Ce4Np7O20 is the only one achieving charge neutrality (GII 0.597) — given that Ce is famously redox-flexible between Ce3+ and Ce4+, does the Ce overbonding in CeNp9O20 indicate the structure is driving Ce toward the +4 state, and would the Ce3+/Ce4+ ambiguity explain the small but nonzero charge residual of -1.0?

Tl3Bi5O14 is novel in P1 with Bi sites showing BVS of 5.55 and 5.43 (expected +3, deviations 0.85 and 0.81) alongside Tl BVS of 3.93 (expected +3, 30.9% overbonded) — this extreme Bi overbonding mirrors the pattern seen in Lu3Bi5O14 (Bi BVS 5.71) and Tm3Bi5O14 (Bi BVS 5.69), all sharing the same A3Bi5O14 stoichiometry — is the A3Bi5O14 structure type inherently unstable because it forces Bi into a coordination environment whose bond lengths match Bi5+ rather than the assigned Bi3+?

LuBi3O7 is novel with a -4.0 charge residual, and two of its three symmetry-distinct Bi sites show extreme overbonding (BVS 5.62 and 5.57, expected +3) while the third is mildly underbonded (BVS 2.48, expected +3) — within the Lu-Bi-O family, the computationally known Lu2Bi2O7 achieves charge neutrality with the lowest GII (0.772) — does the split Bi environment in LuBi3O7 suggest a disproportionation into Bi3+ and Bi5+ sites, and if so, would treating it as Lu(Bi3+)(Bi5+)2O7 resolve the charge imbalance?

TmBi3O7 is computationally known with the same charge residual (-4.0) and Bi BVS pattern as its isostructural analogue LuBi3O7 — two Bi sites at 5.64 and 5.57 (overbonded) and one at 2.49 (underbonded) — given that Tm3+ (0.880 A) and Lu3+ (0.861 A) have nearly identical Shannon radii and both compounds crystallize in P-1 with 22 sites, does the persistence of this Bi site splitting across the lanthanide series confirm that the ABi3O7 structure type inherently creates distinct Bi3+ and Bi5+ crystallographic positions?

La4Ag2O9 is novel and charge neutral with both oxidation state methods agreeing (Ag3+), yet all Ag sites show BVS of only 1.24 vs expected +3 (58.7% underbonding) — with 60 sites in the orthorhombic cell (Pbcn) and zero Pauling violations across all 36 checked bonds, this is a case where electrostatic sum rules are perfectly satisfied but local bond valence around Ag is catastrophically wrong — is Ag3+ genuinely achievable in a lanthanum oxide matrix, or does the 59% BVS deviation indicate that Ag should be +1 in this structure?

TcPdO4 is novel, charge neutral, and passes all Shannon and Pauling checks, but Pd shows BVS of 1.16 vs expected +2 (42% underbonding) — given that Tc is radioactive and rarely studied in oxide chemistry, is this one of GNoME's most experimentally untestable predictions, and does the systematic Pd underbonding suggest that the monoclinic (C2/c) structure provides oversized Pd coordination sites optimized for the Tc sublattice geometry rather than Pd-O bonding?

Tl3(Ir2O7)2 is novel in R-3m (SG 166) with mixed valence and all Ir sites showing BVS near 5.57 vs expected +4 (39.3% overbonding) — with both oxidation state methods agreeing yet a -3.0 charge residual persisting, does the uniform Ir overbonding indicate that Ir is actually closer to +5 in this structure, and would the trigonal symmetry of R-3m with its face-sharing IrO6 octahedra create short Ir-O distances that artificially inflate BVS values?

CdIr5O13 is novel with methods_disagree confidence, a charge residual of -8.0, and all Ir sites uniformly overbonded at BVS 5.74 vs expected +4 (43.6% deviation) — this Ir overbonding pattern is strikingly consistent with Tl3(Ir2O7)2 (Ir BVS 5.57) and Cr3IrO8 (Ir BVS 5.82), all showing Ir BVS clustered around 5.5-5.8 regardless of the counter-cation — does this systematic pattern indicate that Ir4+ BVS parameters are poorly calibrated for DFT-relaxed structures, or that GNoME consistently predicts Ir-O bonds that are too short?

Pa7Cd3O20 is novel with all Cd sites underbonded (BVS 1.14 vs expected +2, deviation 0.43), mirroring the Cd underbonding in Np9CdO20 (BVS 1.14, deviation 0.43) with nearly identical deviation despite very different stoichiometries — does this suggest that actinide-dominated oxide lattices (whether Np or Pa) consistently produce Cd coordination environments that are too large for optimal Cd-O bonding, and is the zero Pauling violation rate across 20 bonds simply reflecting that the oxygen sublattice is dictated by the actinide framework rather than Cd requirements?

Cr3IrO8 is novel and charge neutral with zero Pauling violations across 8 bonds, but shows a striking dual-cation BVS anomaly: Ir at 5.82 vs expected +4 (45.6% overbonding) and Cr at 2.73 vs expected +4 (31.8% underbonding) — with methods disagreeing on oxidation states and mixed valence flagged, could the actual electronic structure involve Cr3+ and Ir5+ rather than the assigned Cr4+/Ir4+ states, and would that reassignment simultaneously resolve both the Ir overbonding and Cr underbonding while maintaining charge neutrality?

Cs6(PdO3)5 is novel and isostructural with Rb6(PdO3)5 (both R32, SG 155) with a massive charge residual of -14.0 and 100% Pauling violations across all 15 bonds, yet its Cs-Pd-O family member Cs2Pd3O7 achieves charge neutrality with a GII of 1.362 — given that the Cs analogue shows oxygen BVS of -0.91 (essentially half the expected -2.0), is the A6(PdO3)5 structure type placing oxygen in such undercoordinated sites that the bonding model breaks down entirely, and does the extremely high GII across the entire Cs-Pd-O family (0.887-1.362) suggest Pd oxides with large alkali cations are a systematically unreliable region of GNoME's prediction space?

Mg3Pa7O20 shows a charge residual of -6.0 and all three Mg sites have BVS values near 1.16-1.23 vs. the expected +2, yielding deviations of ~0.39-0.42 v.u. -- could the GNoME-predicted structure be placing Mg in oversized cavities more suited to a larger divalent cation, and would reassigning Pa to a mixed +4/+5 state resolve both the charge imbalance and the systematic Mg underbonding?

Eu(TcO4)2 carries a charge residual of -1.0 and Eu appears underbonded (BVS 2.18 vs. expected +3, deviation 0.27), yet the Eu-Tc-O family shows a striking trend: the Eu-rich end member Eu6TcO12 is computationally known with a low GII of 0.38, while increasing Tc content drives GII upward (EuTcO4 at 1.15, Eu3TcO7 at 0.68) -- does this suggest a thermodynamic stability window favoring Eu-rich compositions, and is the Eu(TcO4)2 stoichiometry beyond that window?

Tm(BiO2)7 has two Bi sites with BVS values of 5.61 and 5.46 (expected +3, deviations 0.87 and 0.82), strongly suggesting those Bi atoms are actually Bi5+ rather than Bi3+ -- strikingly, the isostructural Lu(BiO2)7 shows nearly identical Bi overbonding (5.54, 5.41), and across the Tm-Bi-O family every composition with Bi-rich stoichiometry shows charge residuals of -1 to -4: is GNoME systematically predicting Bi3+/Bi5+ mixed-valence bismuthates while the oxidation state guesser assigns only Bi3+?

Sr3(RuO5)2 has a massive charge residual of +16.0 and all Ru sites show BVS of 3.93 vs. expected +6 (deviation 0.35), yet across the Sr-Ru-O family only Sr7Ru4O19 achieves charge neutrality (GII 1.08) -- with four novel Sr-Ru-O compositions all showing charge imbalances from -8 to +16, is GNoME exploring a Ruddlesden-Popper-like homologous series where the oxidation state assignment is failing because Ru actually occupies mixed +4/+5 states rather than the assumed +6?

CeNp2O6 achieves near-perfect Shannon radii and Pauling scores with only a minor charge residual of -1.0, and Ce shows BVS of 3.81 (slightly overbonded for Ce3+, deviation 0.27) -- given that Ce is well known for Ce3+/Ce4+ redox flexibility, could this structure actually accommodate Ce4+ (which would resolve the -1 charge residual), and does the family member Ce4Np7O20 with perfect charge neutrality and GII of 0.60 represent the thermodynamically preferred Ce4+ composition?

RbNp3O9 shows dramatically underbonded Rb with BVS of only 0.189 vs. expected +1 (deviation 0.81), yet its family member Rb2Np2O7 has a remarkably low GII of 0.167 with perfect charge neutrality -- why does the Rb-Np-O system show such a sharp divergence between the well-bonded 1:1 Rb:Np compositions (GII 0.17-0.37) and the Np-rich end members (GII 0.80-0.81), and does the extreme Rb underbonding indicate that Rb is rattling in a cavity designed for a larger alkali metal?
