Fe(BrO3)3 is charge-neutral with both methods agreeing on oxidation states, yet all three Br sites show BVS of 3.62 vs. expected Br5+ (deviation 0.28) -- intriguingly, the Fe-Br-O family contains only Br-poor phases (Fe3Br4O, Fe7Br12O) with low GII values (0.31, 0.41), suggesting these iron oxyhalides prefer reduced Br environments: is the bromate (BrO3-) coordination geometry in this hexagonal P63 structure genuinely stable, or is GNoME predicting a metastable polymorph of an inherently unstable high-oxidation-state bromine compound?

Lu(BiO2)7 is computationally known yet shows the same pathological Bi overbonding as its Tm analogue (BVS 5.54, 5.41 for Bi expected at +3), and across six Lu-Bi-O family members the charge-neutral ones (Lu2Bi2O7 with GII 0.77) all have lower Bi content -- does the RE(BiO2)7 structure type (RE = Tm, Lu) systematically stabilize Bi5+ sites, and should these compounds be reclassified as mixed-valence Bi3+/Bi5+ phases rather than treated as Bi3+ oxides?

Ga(BrO3)3 is isostructural with Fe(BrO3)3 (both hexagonal P63, 26 sites, charge-neutral, both_agree on oxi states) yet shows slightly more Br underbonding (BVS 3.60 vs 3.62) and a much wider bandgap (3.75 eV vs 2.43 eV) -- given that Ga3+ is a d10 closed-shell cation while Fe3+ is d5, does the electronic structure difference explain why GNoME predicts Fe(BrO3)3 as a narrow-gap semiconductor while its Ga analogue is a wide-gap insulator, and are either of these bromate structures likely synthesizable?

NpCd2O5 is charge-neutral and passes Shannon radii checks, but all three Cd sites show identical BVS of 1.20 vs. expected +2 (deviation 0.40), suggesting systematic Cd underbonding -- the family member NpCdO4 is computationally known with a lower GII of 0.72, so does the additional Cd in the 1:2 stoichiometry create coordination environments too large for Cd2+, and would substituting a larger divalent cation like Ca2+ or Sr2+ improve the bonding geometry?

RbNp6O18 shows Rb with BVS of only 0.199 vs. expected +1 (deviation 0.80), nearly identical to the Rb underbonding in RbNp3O9 (BVS 0.189) -- yet in the same Rb-Np-O family, Rb2Np2O7 achieves GII of 0.167 and RbNpO4 achieves 0.373, both charge-neutral: is there a critical Np:Rb ratio beyond which Rb cannot be properly coordinated, and does this threshold (~3:1) represent a fundamental limit on how dilute Rb can be in neptunium oxide frameworks?

Sr2Ru2O9 shows a charge residual of +14.0 with mixed valence Ru, and 55.6% Pauling Rule 2 violations across 18 checked polyhedra -- it shares a family with Sr3(RuO5)2 which has an even larger charge residual of +16.0, yet Sr7Ru4O19 achieves charge neutrality with GII 1.08: across this entire Sr-Ru-O family of five all-novel compositions, is GNoME exploring a genuine homologous series, and does the consistent Ru underbonding (BVS ~3.9-4.3 vs. expected +6) indicate that Ru4+ rather than Ru6+ is the actual oxidation state?

Ac3YO6 is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations and zero Shannon violations, yet Y shows BVS of 2.07 and 2.36 against expected +3 (deviations 0.31 and 0.22) -- given that Ac3+ is one of the largest trivalent cations (ionic radius ~1.12 A) and this trigonal R-3 structure has no family members for comparison, could this novel compound represent a genuine double oxide where the size mismatch between the very large Ac3+ and smaller Y3+ creates underbonded Y sites, similar to known A2BO6 double perovskite structures?

Ru2Br8O is an oxyhalide where both methods agree on oxidation states and charge neutrality is achieved, yet Br shows a negative BVS of -0.507 vs. expected -1 (deviation 0.49) while Ru shows BVS of 3.32 vs. expected +5 (deviation 0.34) -- with only 1 oxygen among 8 bromines and a very low formation energy of -0.81 eV/atom, is this structure better described as a bromide with an interstitial oxygen rather than a true oxyhalide, and does the unusual Br underbonding suggest the Br-Ru bonds are abnormally long?

Pu3CrO12 is charge-neutral with zero Pauling violations across all 12 checked polyhedra, yet Cr shows BVS of 2.20 vs. expected +3 (deviation 0.27) -- its family member PuCr2O6 achieves a much lower GII of 0.39 also with charge neutrality: does the 3:1 Pu:Cr ratio in Pu3CrO12 force Cr into an atypically expanded coordination environment compared to the 1:2 ratio in PuCr2O6, and could Cr actually be in the +6 state (as chromate CrO4^2-) rather than +3, which would dramatically change the charge balance?

PaP3O10 is charge-neutral with a 2.13 eV bandgap, but two symmetry-equivalent O sites show BVS of -2.79 vs. expected -2.0 (deviation 0.40), indicating overbonded bridging oxygens -- the computationally known family member PaPO5 has a simpler 1:1 Pa:P ratio: does the condensed phosphate (P3O10) polyanion in this structure create strained P-O-P bridging geometries similar to known tripolyphosphates, and is the overbonding localized at those bridging oxygens?

Cr(TcO4)2 has a charge residual of -1.0 and Cr shows BVS of 2.21 vs. expected +3 (deviation 0.26), while its only family member Cr2TcO8 has a much worse GII of 1.24 and also carries a -2.0 charge residual -- given that both Cr-Tc-O compositions fail charge neutrality and both show Cr underbonding, is GNoME struggling to find a viable Cr-Tc-O phase, possibly because the Tc7+ pertechnetate ion is too strongly oxidizing to coexist with Cr3+?

Sn(Pd3O4)2 is charge-neutral with both methods agreeing, passes all Pauling and Shannon checks, and sits in the highly symmetric Fm-3m space group -- yet Sn shows BVS of 2.73 vs. expected +4 (deviation 0.32) and all Pd sites show BVS of 1.24 vs. expected +2 (deviation 0.38): with both cation types systematically underbonded, is this cubic structure an expanded framework where bond lengths are uniformly stretched, and does the comparison with isostructural Eu(Pd3O4)2 (which shows even worse Pd underbonding at 1.18) suggest a fundamental instability of the Pd3O4 substructure?

Eu(Pd3O4)2 has a charge residual of -2.0 and all six Pd sites show identical BVS of 1.18 vs. expected +2 (deviation 0.41), nearly 10% worse than in isostructural Sn(Pd3O4)2 -- the Eu-Pd-O family member Eu2Pd2O7 in the pyrochlore Fd-3m structure has GII of 1.20 while Eu2PdO6 achieves GII 0.26 but with charge +6.0: is the Pd2+ ion fundamentally difficult to stabilize in these oxide frameworks, and could Eu2+ (rather than Eu3+) better explain the -2.0 charge residual?

Ta2Pb6O13 is computationally known yet shows two Pb sites with BVS of 4.26 vs. expected +2 (deviation 1.13) -- a deviation exceeding 1 v.u. is among the most extreme in this audit -- while another Pb site has BVS of only 1.28: does this bimodal Pb bonding indicate a Pb2+/Pb4+ mixed-valence compound (similar to Pb3O4), and would reassigning those high-BVS sites to Pb4+ resolve the -4.0 charge residual while explaining the 53.8% Pauling Rule 2 violation rate?

La4Pt6O19 has a charge residual of -2.0 and all La sites show identical BVS of 2.19 vs. expected +3 (deviation 0.27), while its Pt-rich family member La2Pt7O18 has a higher GII of 0.91 -- both La-Pt-O compositions show charge residuals of -2 to -1: given that Pt commonly adopts both +2 and +4 states, could a Pt2+/Pt4+ mixed-valence assignment (rather than uniform Pt4+) simultaneously resolve the charge residual and the La underbonding in this cubic I23 structure?

Ni2IO6 is an oxyhalide with I showing BVS of 6.49 vs. expected I5+ (deviation 0.30), suggesting the iodine may actually be I7+ (periodate) rather than I5+ (iodate) -- combined with Ni underbonding (BVS 1.84 vs. expected +3, deviation 0.39) and a charge residual of -2.0, could reassigning I from +5 to +7 simultaneously fix the charge balance and explain the I overbonding, effectively making this Ni2(IO6) with periodate anions in a rutile-derived tetragonal structure?

Np3Ta8O24 has a charge residual of -7.0 and 33.3% Pauling Rule 2 violations, yet all Ta sites show BVS of 4.95 vs. expected +4 (deviation 0.24) suggesting Ta is actually closer to +5 -- if Ta is reassigned from +4 to +5, the 8 Ta atoms contribute +40 instead of +32, and with Np at variable valence, could a Np4+/Np5+ mixed assignment achieve neutrality while explaining why the family member NpTa7O19 (with GII 0.17) is so well-bonded?

Ac2Zr2O7 adopts the classic pyrochlore structure (Fd-3m, SG 227) with charge neutrality, zero Pauling violations, and zero Shannon violations -- all Zr sites show identical BVS of 3.22 vs. expected +4 (deviation 0.19), which is actually within the typical DFT-vs-ICSD calibration offset: given this strong classical chemistry validation, does this Ac3+-Zr4+ pyrochlore represent one of the most plausible novel GNoME predictions in this audit, and could it be a candidate radiation-tolerant waste form material given that both Ac and Zr are relevant to nuclear applications?

Er2Rh2O7 also adopts the pyrochlore structure (Fd-3m, SG 227) with charge neutrality and zero Pauling/Shannon violations, yet Rh shows BVS of 2.62 vs. expected +4 (deviation 0.35) -- this is notably worse than the Zr underbonding in the isostructural Ac2Zr2O7 pyrochlore (deviation 0.19): does the larger discrepancy for Rh4+ reflect a genuine preference for Rh3+ in this coordination environment, and is the computationally known Er-rich family member Er7RhO12 (GII 0.42) evidence that the Er-Rh-O system thermodynamically favors lower Rh content?
